content:
Posted: April 23
												I've tried really hard to beat this game but I just cannot do it, as the biggest problem with this game is how actively it plays against you. I am very a much of fan of these tough-as-nails perma-death ironman games, XCOM is even my favorite game series, but this game just does not handle that formula properly. One of the first things you'll see the game tell you is that you have to "make the best of a bad situation", but that's a complete joke. Every now and then you'll come up against a challenging fight and sure you can salvage a tough fight but when the game starts throwing the dice against your favor you just can't win. Most of my squad wipes have come from purely random crits decimating my team without me being able to do anything to fight back.Honestly, this wouldn't really be a problem if the game actually provided you with the the ability to come back from squad wipes. Sure, early on a few deaths here and there don't impact you that much, but if you have your four best heroes equipped with your best trinkets and get a squad wipe you will lose all of those trinkets and essentially have to start from scratch, making all future missions harder without the bonuses provided by those trinkets. When you're a decent way into the game you can get completely crippled by squad wipes rather than just set back like in other perma-death games. The combat is pretty solid and will keep you entertained for a while, but once you've assembled a good army and know which squads synergize best it just becomes a rather bland repetitive experience of cycling through attacks that only ever gets spiced up if your squad randomly gets surprised which causes them to shuffle positions. It's really unfortunate that so many of the enemies are just identical and far too easy to exploit weaknesses on, which is then made extremely frustrating when your entire strategy falls apart due to the aforementioned random dice rolls that ruin everything.This game is just so beautiful though, the art is fantastic and sets a devilishly good tone for the grim and daunting environments you are put in. The narrator adds some much appreciated flair to the events you'll come across and the many Lovecraft-esque monsters will make you just as stressed and terrified as your heroes fighting them. If I could recommend the game for this alone I absolutely would, but there are just too many debilitating pitfalls all over the game that simply ruin the whole experience.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Simply put, the games stress mechanic works great, and is an amazing example of gameplay story integration. As a reality ensues version of a dungeon crawler, it succeeds amazingly. Alot of minor things may not be explained at first, and some things that work you may not even try because of thinking about what you can do, because you think of it as a game and dont try something you would do irl (see using bandages as handwraps for investigating a kniferack). The heros are varied and never seem to be just carbon copies of eachother, and the position based strategy like combat is fun and interesting. But be careful that the stress doesnt get to even you, rushing your judgement and making mistakes as a consequence of stress, again, that stress based mechanic is well implemented, an amazingly interesting theme, and adds alot to the gameplay. Though some might find the RNG a bit too powerful.The game leaves an impression when you just look at it that it will be overcomplicated but really its not, its the same effect as FTL, a cursory glance at the variety of features gives an illusion of overcomplication. Certain moves work in certain positions, and you remember them reasonably well, and some are more suited for the front or back of your lineup due to being a tanking melee or a healer/ranged for instance. The stress makes you go insane at first and eventually a heart attack, but camping, jesters, critical hits, disarming traps and sometimes kills heal it, with a bit of skill its not that bad. They can get negative traits to debuff them that cost a bit of money to remove, and you take them to buildings to upgrade armor and moves and relieve stress. Even the trinkets I found to be relatively intuitive, upsides and downsides use them to buff or compensate, try not to leave to big a weakness, at the very least stuff like the blight stones and archers rings are easily understood.The game doesnt ever tell you what you feel, despite what some may think, it tells you what they feel, and they can get stressed, go mad and have heart attacks. Stress can feel like more of a danger than the health, as its alot harder to cure. Death functions a bit differently, if someone loses all their health they go onto "Death's Door", where they theoretically could live forever, but every hit could strike them down, basically its a 67% chance that they dont die forever every time, and bleeding and blight count as hits every time they activate. Do you keep risking the fight? Do you abandon the mission to save them lest they die forever. I'm about to explain why you should care about just another Vestal or Crusader, but heres how camping works first, you get 12 "Time" Everyone has 3 camping skills at once, each requires time, they can grant buffs, stress heal, and heals, you use firewood granted on longer missions to camp, you can be ambushed while you camp every once in awhile with lower light, messing up your lineup, etc. Now, onto individuality.The game is also very good about letting you have time to care even with minimal individual traits. Theres 7 different possible camping and combat moves which you can unlock and upgrade for customization. You can switch them from a few palette swaps, change their names. Upgrade weapons armor, equip trinkets. Despite being just another Vestal the positive and negative quirks grant a bit of functional not just aesthetic individuality. Sheer force of time lets you humanize and invest in them. You give a♥♥♥♥♥♥if they die. Though its not only possible but profitable to get a ton of new guys for free, throw them in a mission with barely any supplies, let them go insane and die, grab a ton of money and things like Busts, Crests, Portraits and Deeds (what you use to upgrade the town) and fire them neglecting to cure their diseases and psychological damage, as thats not free. You monster.One thing I neglected to mention is the light, you use torches to keep the lights higher, as lights high, you have a higher chance of scouting around and knowing whats around you on the map ahead of time, suprising enemies, and everyone friend or foe gets less crits. But you get less treasure and cause less crits. Lower light gets more treasure, your less likely to scout and more likely to be suprised, and theres more treasure. By the way, Crits you deal stress heal, Crits that hurt you cause stress.For some the darker tone reaches Narm Charm levels, personally I disagree, but its a subjective thing. The game switches between saying the world is♥♥♥♥♥♥ or the world is♥♥♥♥♥♥but not beyond redeeming. Alot of your party isnt exactly noble. Bounty Hunters, Grave Robbers, Occultists, Crusaders, Highwaymen. Some only seek payment, they arent all in it for the heroism. People die and stay dead, the art styles appealing and gloomy, the whole stress mechanic and reality ensues theme isnt exactly idealistic. The animations isnt that present, when you attack it switches their images, centers them in the middle of the screen enlarged, and tilts the camera. Some might call that simpler style a problem, but personally it could easily be considered a stylistic choice and they make it work VERY well. the art style is definitely pleasent to look at, and its definitely easy to run because of it. So *I* consider it a positive, but dont expect to many extravagent animations, but frankly making something like that a dealbreaker especially when the game isnt even ugly is a ♥♥♥♥ing stupid desicion.Ultimately it has interesting mechanics, intergrates gameplay and story masterfully, has an interesting theme, tons of replayability, and its just really fun to play and really easy to get invested in. For those of you concerned about whether or not to get it yet cause its in early access, waiting till full release I can understand, wanting the whole experience all at once yknow, but if you dont care, its definitely interesting, well put together and fun, even in early access. Its worth buying as it is NOW, is what im saying. I recommend it. Also the musics well done. As the light gets darker the music gets more intense or chaotic, you can hear more unnerving ambience in the background. The tracks strings can really capture the stress of your situation. It composition covering the seriousness of every encounter. The music of your Estate is soft and sad, but not hopeless. The lighter keys making you feel at least like you have a chance.

number of helpful: 101 of 187 people (54%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Welp, I will start by saying I've been on the fence about this game for a while. Truthfully, unlike a lot of people I didn't start this game when it was considered its golden days, I started after corpses and heart attacks were allowed to be disabled, which I did from the get go and never looked back. That being said, I really enjoyed this game, and I still do to some extent. But every recent patch has just made the game more and more unbearable, with enemy crit chance being so damn high, prot being frickin ridiculous, and enemies in general having too much dodge. I could live with enemies in champion level dungeons having 40+ base dodge if my characters could get that much. When they do, it's with trinkets and it rarely seems to help. Enemies also have perfect skills, which pretty much make move skills only good for them. If your arbalest or healer, or plague doctor gets pulled to rank 1, well, unless you work fast they will die fast. What happens if I pull one of their ranged rank 4 units? He starts using close range moves, that, while weaker, still allow him to do something all while those who were moved back use moves pushing them forward/don't give a single crap about the rules and continue using their moves from back rows. I understand they don't want move to be op, but if my leper gets to rank 4 what does he do? Slowly walk his way up? Champion level dungeons right now are the biggest chore, with enemies having so much life/dodge/prot it takes forever to kill things. Oh, and disregard the tooltip telling you to use blight on high prot enemies, 9/10 times good classes can just do a melee swing and apply a bleed totalling to way more than the blight. The only time I would recommend blight is against the formless flesh in champion. Class balance; I haven't gotten to try the abomination out yet, but when I saw my cousin using him in apprentice dungeons he seemed really good. Whether or not that will last into champion who knows. But unfortunately, for class balance in general, it's not that good. In normal dungeon crawling scenarios, I'd argue it's ok. Any class can manage on normal runs. Hell, until champion, I'd even argue most classes can do most bosses. But unfortunately, even with that being said, there will always be classes better. My top pick would easily be Hellion, as this class has enough hp and dodge to function as a tank while easily outdamaging any other class in the game and even being able to hit further ranks of enemies, which is very important on bosses in champion level dungeons. Lepers, crusaders, a load of classes just won't cut it in champion. Also, most bosses cheat in champion dungeons too - the swine god still managed to do damage to my party when his damage was debuffed to -160%. So, in conclusion, I think this game had potential. It was fun, and to some extent now it's still fun. It's a lot more unique than the cookie cutter crafting games on steam early access, but unfortunately, these devs disregarded fun at one point and tried to make it as gimmicky and "hars" as possible. Take it from me, I've spent a lot of time in this game, maxed every estate building, and beaten almost every boss. Don't waste the time or money people - pass.Tl;dr - Unfair, unfun, RNG, stupid patches that only make it worse.

number of helpful: 41 of 73 people (56%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm currently writing this in a fit of salty rage over how cheatted Darkest Dungeon has made me feel, so you can consider this completely biased. However I just don't really give a single ♥♥♥♥ right now.Yes, yes Darkest Dungeon is a hard game. You can expect RNG to ruin a run, that your heroes are expendable, and that you know all of this to be true right when you buy the game. This does not change the fact that when all your hours of progess results in a monumental loss that makes your entire campaign trashed thats when I draw the line. Let me explain the absolute trainwreck that was my latest campaign.See this was actually my second campaign after my short introductory one that I fully conceded failed on my behalf. So I set off on the next one and I'm doing fantastic, it's going great. However a simingly mundane roadblock comes right out of nowhere putting my entire strategy in jepordy. Party members LV3 or above can't enter any dungeons below their level, even against bosses. *WHAT*?! So since the game doesn't tell me this absolutely massive detail my entire strategy is in upheaval. Well, I say to myself thats really big, but I can push past this. I've got plenty of time to build my forces, getting high LV 2s (but not too high) for bosses and a LV 3 team for veteran runs.While doing this I ran into an astonishingly bad development choice surronding ambush mechanics on medium/ long dungeons. When camping you have the option to eat, heal, and stress heal which is a life saver. The kicker is that you have a chance of being ambushed after camping where the game arbitrary takes away all your torch light, even though camping firewood gives you 100 light while surprsing nearly every party member. For those uninitiated when you have low torch light enemies do faaaaaar more damage, you gain stress at a much higher rate, and when you are surprised enemies get a whole free turn to attack. So after camping and getting everyone to full HP on two seperate occasions I lost a total of 1-2 party memebers to low level mobs since they all decide to gang bang the healer or what have you. Oh and don't even think about using a torch because when ambushed you can't use torches, DUH, obviously!But despite all that I had done it, 6-9 party members all at LV 3 a complete truimph. Persevering despite the horrific odds that's what Darkest Dungeon is all about!Oh I just failed both of my 2 raids to LV 3 dungeons along with my priceless trinckets... Well, it would have been nice if I could've leveled them up before entering the meat grinder, but ehehe that's not how this game wants you to play. In my latest failure ending just about 30 minutes ago I suffered 3 crits in a row, rabies, 2 occultist heals resulting in 0 HP with characters on death's door, and 3 misses since the veteran enemies have higher dodge + HP, accumulating in a complete wipe. You know I was ready to give this a complete and undivided recommendation. I loved it even while I hated it, and with so many games holding your hand to an obessesive degree Darkest Dungeon was truly refreshing. Plus its a game that handles its Lovecraftian atmosphere and world perfectly with gameplay reflecting that. However there is just so many times you can handle what feels like the game blatently cheating you over on factors you have no control over. So while this review might be unrecommended there is certainly a ton of value to be had, just be warry of the Darkest RNG.

								This game is painfully unrewarding. I have spent hours learning how to play it from walkthroughs and forums.... content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have to say that this game is one of my favorites. 9.3/10You will face hard♥♥♥♥♥enemies, you will fail probably even more than win, you will get frustrated because you let your higher level, well-equiped and fully upgraded hero die. But in the end, when you complete a dungeon alive a smile will pop in you face.The game is all about grinding. The more dungeons you complete, the more gold you have to spend in upgrades and trinkets (equipments for your heroes). Each dungeon has a reward, and there are three kinds of dungeons: you have a short dungeon - it has fewer rooms - and its easier to complete, you also have medium dungeons - it has an considerable amount of rooms - and you get a campfire, with you can set a camp and rest/buff you heroes mid-quest, and last but no least you have long dungeons - it has a lot of rooms - you will have to go through a huge amount of rooms in order to complete those kind of dungeons. You also have to set a strategy before going into an adventure. In certain areas of the game, monster will be more resistent as certain kind of DoT (damage over time) than others. Keep it in mind when you`re think in bring a Plague Doctor to the Weald, or remember to have a Crusader in you party when you`re going to the cursed Ruins. You will also have to manage resources before going to an adventure. You can buy torches, food, antivenom, bandages etc. Everything to raise the chances of your crew to return alive to the town. I`d say that is still possible to complete a dungeon without bringing anything, but you`ll have to retreat 99% of the time.Well, if world isn`t perfect, why should this game be?After about 100 hours I`ve reached the max level with every class in the game, killed all the bosses, collected all the ancestral items and my town was fully upgraded. Well, there was anything more to do. You still have dungeons to complete, but as I said the fun part is the grinding, and when you finish grinding you don`t have much to do. You definitely can still have fun, challenging yourself to do a dark run (without torches) and so on, but that`s up to you.I`d highly recommend this game for everyone who enjoy play RPG, turn-based like games. This game is totally worth the $15 you have to pay.

content:
Posted: April 17
												The Darkest Dungeon is an intially fresh RPG with a rich gothic aesthetic, but it slowly turns into a deeply unenjoyable soul-crushing experience. Calling the Darkest Dungeon a "strategy" game or "difficult" is deceptive. Both these terms imply navigating and problem solving within some matrix of information you are given, and rather in the Darkest Dungeon pretty much all valuable information you need is only given to you after post-hoc trial-and-error. This might be fine given the games self-described morbidity, but unfortunately each "mistake" creates such a setback that the real pain doesn't come from a character that you lost, but from the thought of how many hours you were just set back. The most succint way I can describe the Darkest Dungeon is to picure a game of chess where you perpetually only know 3/4ths of the rules, random spaces on the board are booby trapped, and your prospects of either winning (or losing) appear to approach infinity. While I certainly enjoyed the first 20+ hours of the game (and hence technically I got my money's worth) the next 20 were so egregious that like matter meeting anti-matter, anything nice I would have to say about this game was cancelled out by the real horror that lies inside the Darkest Dungeon: its game design.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Simple adventurer management paired with rough roguelike dungeon crawling wrapped in amazing atmosphere sums up as Darkest Dungeon!It is a fascinating, even hypnotic game to play. From UI to gameplay everything transfers swiftly, yet without breaking the immersion or atmosphere. The story is simple and goes well with the gameplay. Enviromental design, art style, narrator voice and the choice of words paint an awesome, yet grim, Warhammer Fantasy-style feeling in the canvas of your mind. Several times, I have found myself sitting in front of my screen playing "one more dungeon" and doing "little more management".In it's core Darkest Dungeon is a hardcore gaming experience that needs time and dedication to learn and master. More I learn, more I realize the outcome is in my hands. There is surprisingly little weight on RNG when compared on many other roguelikes. At times things have felt unfair but later the realization of mistakes has stroke me. For a singleplayer game, such as Darkest Dungeon, the feelings of victory and defeat are strong and enjoyable. They remind me of Dark Souls, Faster Than Light and This War of Mine.PS. I recommend renaming or adding nicknames to  your subjects whenever you feel like so. It creates a nice bond between You and your lackeys. However, I must warn that the feeling of loss is unavoidable and brings up all kinds of emotions. ;-)

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												My opinion on this game is that it is good- to a point. That point being the Veteran level dungeons. The early game is fun, interesting, challenging and good, but by even the mid-game the problems start to show. First off, your heros become locked away once they are high enough level to go to the next dungeon tier - in others words, you finally got that hero up to max level without one of the many crippling debilitations screwing them over (or paying money to fix them when you can) NOPE! Cant use them now, go to the next elvel of dungeon where they are back to being weak in comparision to the monsters. Second off, as with everyone else, I have to complain about the RNG. Forget cuthulu, you need to be building your shrines to RNGesus for you to really get anywhere, as basically everything in this game passes by him at LEAST once, if not more. Not that this is a problem in the earlier levels - the game doesn't expect you to be using any of the advanced tactics (which rely on RNG more heavily than just hitting the enemies), so if RNG betrays you a few times while using them, it's not a big deal, you aren't punished (you only aren't rewarded). Any of the later missions though - the game NEEDS you to be using the RNG reliant advanced tactics. This means that, even if you play the more intricate sytle perfectly, should RNG ever betray you, you're suddenly utterly obliterated becuase you apparently didn't know how to use the advanced tactics correctly - never mind if you're in a bad position and have to not spend turns doing things like shuffling openents in order to heal (becuase RNG screwed you over last time). The game is interesting and fun, and RNG is an important part of it, too, just like many other games. The problem lies in combat that does just involve RNG - it RELIES on RNG, and one failure means that the dungeon run is scrapped, do not continue, hope you didn't get too much stress/diseases/negative-quirks, better luck (litterally) next time, chap. The game can be either one of two things - forgiving of RNG screwing you over, or not letting RNG screw you over completely. Unfortunately, the game si currently a third thing - BAD, unfun, and punishing in the bad way (especially becuase it will punish you for RNG rather than your actions). Overall, I think that beucase of the games good comcept, ideas, and character, it makes for a good 7-10 hours or so in the quite great early game before you hit the veteran RNG-wall. I think it's a great 10 hours, though, so I recond buying the game but only if you're willing to spend it on only 8-10 hours of pretty good content. If you're looking for a longer life out of you game, look elsewhere. The game is basically a fun evening, but one you leave with a bad taste in your mouth.

number of helpful: 33 of 58 people (57%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon promised a lot of things that you often see associated with the "Rogue-like" tag; "Challenging", "difficult", "dark", "rewarding of skill", and the usual malarky. It even seemed like it might deliver on these. Playing through its Early Access was usually enjoyable, even when bugs interfered. Still, there was always this nagging feeling that the developers could not quite get the balance of player power versus the game's environment down. There were many times where the game simply decided that you could not win, no matter how well equipped and pre-planned you went in; enemies would land critical strings constantly and dodge far more than they should even after being debuffed, or the foes would relentlessly target one specific unit even when the targeting system is meant to be randomized (aside from certain rare encounters). This feeling grew as release version after release version added more to the enemy's side but did nothing to bring up the player's tools to match. No amount of skill or planning can save you against terrible luck, especially when the abilities available to you just can not measure up to the enemies'.What I'm trying to say is, the game fell prey to the most common pitfall of the tag: the Random Number God trumps anything you might do, as the developers confused biased dice systems and overpowered enemies with genuine challenge. The early game will let you pass if you use tactics, but the mid and late game are all about praying that the dice land in your favor.On top of luck being the deciding factor in combat and exploration, the game constantly stacks even the menus against you. Healing higher leveled heroes of stress, illnesses, or mental ailments becomes increasingly expensive just because they are a higher level than the scrubs fresh off the stagecoach; it's an arbitrary punishment for progressing with them! You may get stuck in a cycle of needing to do low level missions to pay for stress relief or illness removal on your higher level characters just so that you can play the missions that actually advance the story. Alternatively, you could just straight up dismiss characters that you already invested money in so that you can hire a fresh batch of heroes off the stagecoach to try again from the start.Imbalanced gameplay aside, the game does present a very nice... errr, grim atmosphere. The gloomy graphics, subdued sounds, and sudden spikes of noise when something dramatic happens are great at setting the mood. Character animations are rather limited (for example, you get the same animation whether a character dodges or gets hit by something), but they do get the idea of the move or action across. The narrator, your character's ancestor who kicked off the plot, is usually entertaining with his comments, but they do become stale after you've heard every comment many times.On a final note, major bugs are still seemingly common with the game, as it only recently left Early Access at the time of this review. My patience for it was finally ruined after my saves became corrupted. Such issues may be resolved in time, but until then you're risking all progress if you play in its current state.TLDR: It's luck-based, and still buggy. Wait to see if it gets fixed and rebalanced before you buy.

number of helpful: 33 of 58 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9
												Darkest Dungeon is a beautifully polished game filled with eldritch horrors alongside campy humor. Each of the bucketful of character classes plays differently, and finding combinations of types that work together is a joy. The art and animation is a clever use of low-budget (other "indie" gamemakers take note); it fits the game theme beautifully. The whole game is dark and difficult and weird.Unfortunately, as others have mentioned, you are at the mercy of a RNG. The game itself has a disclaimer when you first start; it warns you that the game is never going to be easy, and will always be about managing terrible situations. Fine.The trouble is, though, that the game is a mix of "perfect" strategy (each character class has best-in-slot items and abilities and positions and partners) and utter hands-off randomness. There's nothing you can do to respond to a situation; the dungeons are random, the combats are random, and the rolls are random. So even if you have a plan for addressing a certain type of situation, there's literally nothing you can do to react to a problem when it comes up. The perfect strategy is also frustrating - there's no point in trying a first-slot Vestal, for example. There's a use and pairing for each class. You'll need to get all of them, but it still won't matter.Overall, this is a great start, but needed to go back to the drawing board on mechanics.I will be downvoted for this review.

No matter what your numbers are, no matter how much planning went into your team, you are just going to lose because the game decides you need to lose your good squad. The game has some good ideas, it's just too bad the developers got lazy and took the easy way out by forcing your squad to get killed off artificially instead of having actual realistic game mechanics. There are instances in many games that involve good and bad luck and then there are games like Darkest Dungeon where the outcomes are predetermined. Predetermined outcomes are lazy and unenjoyable for the player. I won't play this game again and I wouldn't recoomend that anyone buy it either unless you enjoy frustration and being manipulated. Posted: January 21, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a party based dungeon crawler experience with a twist in its core setting: Stress.Not every game puts on such an important topic in to a game as a core mechanic, and Darkest Dungeon shows it is an interesting mechanic that gets along with the whole game very well. The sad part is this game is not for everyone, especially for people who cannot take randomness or prone to making mistakes. Every action you do is permanent, and overcoming the RNG is the major part in Darkest Dungeon. Though these elements really do make the game way harder, it is very satisfying to see yourself overcome the Darkest Dungeon. Artwork is unique and fits the game perfectly. The soundtrack is intense and makes you think twice before pulling a trigger. As far as I know, there is only one voice actor, and he does his job so well. Every comment he makes, in battle or in town, gives you goosebumps.Darkest Dungeon may not be for everyone, but if you have a little bit of courage to make the best of the worst situations, you should buy this game.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game when I first bought it, but a recent patch having introduced a frankly inconvenient and unfun mechanic (corpses) in a game that's already dangerously RNG and frustration prone makes me have to change my review. If you hate yourself or play nothing but difficult and frustrating games that function off high risk low reward, you'll still love this game, but if you're a casual gamer or generally don't enjoy RNG-driven difficulty spikes then avoid this for now.This IS a fun game, but it could really use a difficulty toggle that doesn't penalize your gains so much that playing on easy actually makes you suck more in the long run, since you gain less loot and gold, for only a small decrease in difficulty.The game would greatly benefit from letting you play on easy for the first few dungeons you run and clear, and then gradually ramping up the reward curve for playing on hard so as to incite you to get comfortable and increase difficulty at your own pace. But also, it would benefit from easy being easier. As it is right now it really is just a self-imposed penalty on gains for only a tiny decrease in difficulty, and RNG can still totally screw you over anyway.TL;DR: Easy mode not easy enough, imposes huge penalty for almost no gain, especially combined with RNG. Latest patches have been pandering to the vocal minority asking for a harder more tedious game, alienating casual players. Game desperately in need of a game mode to separate players.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is one of the few early access indie titles that I didn't hesitate to purchase after doing some research and it does not dissapoint.  Although it is still early access, Darkest Dungeon is well into development, has plenty of content, and is more then worth the asking price of $20.As for the gameplay itself, it is just as described:  A roguelike turn-based dungeon crawler rpg.  There is a good amount of depth and strategy involved, both in and out of battles.  Choosing how to spend your money and resources on upgrades and provisions, deciding which of your heroes to bring and which of their abilities to equip,  and choosing how to act during battles and other random events, etc...The art style is absolutely gorgeous, in a gritty, atmospheric kind of way.  The art and music come together perfectly to set a dark undertone.Oh, by the way, this game is hard.  You will always be struggling in one way or another while exploring a dungeon, and very rarely does a situation play out as planned, forcing you to change tactics and make decisions one turn at a time.  Although difficult and random (as expected from a roguelike) Darkest Dungeon never feels unfair.Overall this game is super dank and earns 8/10 bomb nuggets.  The final product will likely be a 9 or 10.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Do you like a difficult and unforgiven game? How about:-Getting your heroes killed by RNG and loosing hours of progress building up your characters.-Grinding endlessly on low level dungeons to upgrade your town and your high level characters?-Spending all of your money on keeping the characters sane and slowly spending any extra gold (if any) to upgrade your heroes.-Trying and experimenting just to die and loose a lot of progress-Getting faced with a Difficulty wall in some point of the game.it's so grindy that It just feel that the Devs wanted to put a ingame store for you to buy and spend in order to advance in a  normal rate. On the plus side, learning the dungeons and building a party with the right skill is toughfull and makes things interesting. And the battle are strategic and engaging. I like Darkest Dungeon but it needs to be more forgiving or to the least remove the grind a bit and have the players experiment and have fun.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is utterly fantastic, and I am super happy that I backed it when it came out. Let me start off by saying the devs are extremely responsive and constantly show up in the forums. Which is a huge plus, especially for an early access game. They listen to our feedback, and are quick to fix issues within the game. Just wanted throw a kudos to Red Hook. Y'all are awesome.On to the game now. The game is extremely high risk/high reward. Your team is low, but you've got one room left and you'll finish the quest. Do you risk it and attempt to see if the room is clear/fight the battle, or do you haul it back to town with your team in-tact and the treasure you've collected so far? There are interactable objects that can also save your run, or set you back which adds a lot to do while crawling through the dungeons. The game is extremely difficult, but in the best possible way.Starting off you're going to die, a lot. Until you learn the mechanics, learn how to build a balanced team for each dungeon. Learn how the abilities work and function. You will die, but that's ok. In Darkest Dungeon every death is a new lesson. The variety of heroes we've been given is pretty vast so far including the Grave Robber, Vestal, Occultist, Crusader, Highwayman, Hellion, Jester, and Leper. All of them work differentlky and do their jobs well.A tag you won't see on this game that is a major part of it is, Puzzle. Every fight is a puzzle of sorts, especially boss fights. They all have weaknesses and different attacks/combinations that mess up the enemies momentum and attacks. Got a dude sniping you from the back? Use Eldritch Pull to yank him to the front and knock him out. Got a Plague Doctor? Use Flash Powder to stun the back line while you eat their beefy front line leaving them open.There is so many to go through a dungeon and it's just an all-around fantastic game. The community is very helpful and we're all learning and helping each out. If you're into difficult, but rewarding games with a dark atmosphere, and Cthulhu/Eldritch creatures, then Darkest Dungeon is the game for you.

number of helpful: 26 of 45 people (58%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a brilliant turn based game loosely based off of lovecraftian lore. You are summoned to your ancestor's home that has fallen in disrepair and corruption to a force that is revealed as you progress through the storyline and fight bosses. With stunning graphical design and amazing voice acting by Wayne June you'll be instantly drawn in... however.From the very beginning the player is warned that this game is extremely hard, you will be forced to make tough decisions and not to grow overly attached to characters, THEY WILL DIE. Normally this is not an issue but...The game mechanics are flawed in many aspects. Your characters have an HP meter and a Stress meter. Once your stress meter reaches 100 out of 200, your characters can and will most of the time develop some sort of side effect from the horrors witnessed throughout combat. Too many times have I witnessed my healer become paranoid and refuse to act all together, and whenever a stressful event happens, ANYTHING at all stress related, all your other companions will get more stress aswell, quickly developing into a failscade, and many times these happen outside of your control. At 200 stress your character has a heartattack and immediately hits 0 HP. This also stresses out the party. I have on multiple occasions seen one character hit 200, heartattack, stressing out everyone else into a heartattack, while all four where under some sort of bleed or poison and watched 4 party members die in one go. RNG rules this game and will create nightmarish situations for you to witness. The ability for your team to failscade due to bad RNG is all too present, Heals are underwhelming and in no way will keep up with the ludicrous damage monsters put out. Debuffs and buffs dont last long enough, turn order is badly calculated and gives the "House" the advantage, stuns are lackluster and have diminishing returns (which is good) but because of turn order shenanigans, cannot be counted on or managed in any way. Due to these gameplay issues, creating any significant interesting team builds or strategies is highly impossible as nothing can be predicted and even the best team can have a bad day. The most prevalent build is a high spike damage team that is boring to play and takes advantage of the highwayman point blank shot ability. Characters also need to constantly undergo "psych" treatment to be viable in the next mission which constantly means benching and using a different team. Once a character hits lvl 3 Resolve he cannot ever go back to doing apprentice level missions (Resolve 0-2) which means you can't grind an A-team and go back to do bosses you left so you could grind, you HAVE to fight a boss at the approriate lvl. Character can also level at different speeds, meaning one member of your A-team might have to be benched while others catch up. God forbid one of them dies and you have to level them again...Ugh what else? I'm already getting tired of writing this review. Characters have flaws too, those suck and can make a good character turn into a bad one pretty quick, those also need to be managed and purged constantly.Eating in this game is a terrible mechanic that makes no sense, I've had a completely full character die from hunger. Overall, fun, crisp, and beautiful game, but an extreme grind fest with no real reward for your work and only a headache when RNG gives you bad luck and wipes your party, there will be a lot of setbacks, be prepared for them.P.S. Boss fights where designed by a demon from hell itself as they subject you to sadistic forms of actual torture both in real life and in game. Also I broke two mice and a keyboard while playing.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								If I had given a review after one hour I would have given this a thumb's up.  There are things about this game I really like and I hope this review will help the developers add some things (this is still in early release) to really make this game special.  I'll list various pros and cons.Positive - Combat positioning: Your characters and the enemy characters stand in a line (1-4).  Certain skills can only be used from certain positions and skills can only target certain enemy positions.  Some skills attempt to move an enemy to a new position.  This adds a nice strategic element to traditional turn-based RPG combat.Positive - Overall Graphics: Generally rather nice.  Game has a good feel to it graphically.Negative - Hero Uniqueness:  You basically recruit random heroes of a certain class.  These heroes stay with you until they die (very possible) or you dismiss them (can be a good idea at times).  These heroes start with a random assortment of skills and gain random quirks (both positive and negative) that separate them from other heroes of the same class.  The problem is several-fold: (1) Heroes don't have random base stats (e.g., strength) that allows separation; (2) All heroes of the same class can learn the same skills if you spend gold to upgrade them, leading heroes to be less unique; (3) Quirks don't do a great job of separation.  Sometimes a quirk is so bad you won't want to use the hero until its removed but other than that the most important thing is class composition on a dungeon run.Negative - Equipment:  The equipment system is about as rudimentary as you can get.  You don't find weapons and armor but improve it through town upgrades (requiring relics) and then spending gold.  All equipment for a certain class is the exact same, the only difference is the upgrade level (upgrading adds no random stats).  The only room for variation in equipment is two trinket slots.  While you find trinkets in dungeons and there appear to be a good number of them, the problem is that trinkets always have one positive effect and one negative effect.  While the positive effect tends to outweigh the negative effect, often I find myself not using trinkets because I don't want the negative effect.  Trinkets essentially boil down to knowing the dungeons and choosing a trinket whose positive effect will be valuable against those monsters and whose negative effect won't matter much.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game was enjoyable at first. Mostly because of unlockables and trying new abilities and character types. Once the initial discoveries have been made only a semi-insane completionist like myself would consider continuing to play. The battles are not really anything special or different from an old super nintendo turn based jrpg and the quests your characters go on don't actually vary much.I got to the point where I had four level 5 characters and took them on a veteran mission (level 6 is the max, veteran level missions are the hardest). I took a few risks because my armor and weapons weren't at max level. It was tough but no one was dying. Then I faced a fat ectoplasm with 70 health and 2 of the smaller ones. I killed the big one. A smaller one spawned another big one with 70 more health. I killed that one. More small ectoplasms were spawned since I couldn't one hit them or stun them. I also couldn't run away from the battle. After killing 3 fat ectoplasms and about 7 small ones my characters were given death blows and all died by about round 20. I suppose I should have known better and played it safe by taking other characters on another 3 - 6 quests to get the money and artifacts to max out my armor, levels, and skills.It may seem like I am giving the game a negative review out of frustration, I had done well up to that point, but losing my highest level characters and having no money left made me realize that a game that will set you back 4 - 6 hours while asking you to continue the same repetitive tasks over and over just to level is just poorly designed. Unfortunately I compulsively play games and want to see them through even if they aren't offering anything new. I thank the game for breaking its hold on me but would not recommend playing it for more than 5 - 10 hours. Why do so many games nowadays want you to keep playing them long after they have stopped being enjoyable? Is it a requirement that every game have 30 – 60 hours of playtime to create the illusion that you’re getting your money’s worth?Think of a game where you have like 12 different pokemon. At first it's interesting to test them out and get new abilities and make them stronger. Now imagine you have to level all those pokemon to progress as well as level a few duplicates since survival without a healer is unlikely. Now imagine some of those pokemon just die and you have to start leveling them from level 0 again. Aside from level 0 to 1, it takes 2 - 4 quests to gain a level. If repeating 50 - 80 mostly monotonous quests for 16 - 20 pokemon (since some will die) to complete this game sound like fun to you, then I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								My review after playing 6 hours:One of the best things about it is the setting. I really love how dark and hopeless the game feels, the available classes, skills and status effects. I also like the way you need to manage your team with 2 different health bars (hp and stress), taking care of resource management (torch, food and gold) and a big amount of status effects in battles.However, there are some issues with the current build, most notably the amount of grind required. Since you can't keep using the same heroes over and over (firstly because you need to let them rest to recover stress, and secondly because you can outlevel the content and not be able to use them anymore!), you need to train other squards, which takes a huge amount of time. If a hero dies, you also lose it forever, meaning a bunch of hours training him were tossed out of the window.I feel like a few of these mechanincs were created to make you care more about your characters and decisions, but they accomplish the opposite of what was intended. After the first time your character dies and you recruit a substitute you treat them as disposable thrash. You know that if the worst happens and a character dies you only need a few more hours playing to replace him, so he isn't "unique" in a true sense. There's also some squad compositions which are clearly supperior to others, so after you find one that work, you are likely to just repeat it over and over again, because you can't really afford to make a mistake with a "bad" squad (since a failure may means several hours os setback).Instead of the current system, I would prefer if I could have manual saves and make character death truly permanent, meaning there's only one character of each class, and if he dies you will never find the same class again. This would enable me to:1) Experiment with different team compositions, because I could load an earlier save if I screw up with a bad team2) Truly care about my character's death, and give me the choice to either keep playing without that character or lose a few hours and load an earlier save3) It would make me create other squad compositions, since I won't be able to use the same classes againI would also like if dungeons were to scale accordingly with party level, because it makes no sense that in a world of terror and disease an experienced team would refuse to do easy content for some quick cash. I also think upgrades costs too much and need to be reduced to avoid endless grinding.

								An extremely challenging and extremely addictive dungeon crawler.  Gambling on that next step in a dungeon can either leave you exhilarated with your success or crying as you leave empty handed with 4 dead adventurers that you spent hours leveling.  That risk verse reward is what makes games like these great.  The moments where you finish a dungeon by the slightest of margins against what seemed like impossible odds are some of the best in gaming and this game has plenty of them.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Tl;drPros+ Devestatingly good narration+ The best atmosphere I've seen+ Excellent soundtrack and sound design+ Dripping with Lovecraft, if that's your bag+ All characters have personalities and individual quirks+ Lots of different strategies to play through with each class+ The game isn't broken. You are broken.+ THESE FIENDS CAN BE DRIVEN BACK, THEY CAN BE BEATENCons- This game will make you either angry or upset, guaranteed- There is an element of luck that can ruin everything, but that isn't a downside for me- All characters look identical to everyone in their class, even if they do have individual personalities- This game can make you feel fatigued if you're used to faster games.- I COULD NOT BEAR THIS BURDEN"We are not the flame, we are but moths."This game is not about winning, it is about surviving. Darkest Dungeons is about preparing for everything, being the very best and brightest, or getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥pushed in. Even if you think you can keep it together, your party members are living breathing people with hopes and dreams. Can you really push them into a dungeon and force them to fight horrifying, cyclopean eldritch horrors for days on end?Yeah, yeah you can do that. But will they let you? Not a chance in a frozen hell.This is the only game that made me feel true and utter despair. Not defeat or regret. Despair. The feeling that all hope is lost and that there is nothing more that can be done except watch everything you've worked for disintergrate before you.Is the game fun? Extremely, but only if are willing to rise above instant gratifcation and push for the long victory. If you die in this place, where light is foreign, your bones will never be found.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												A lot of bad reviews for this game stem from failed runs or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG. I have a good 40-60 hours of gameplay when I was offline so don't mind the hours on my account.It happens. A lot of the time you will be ♥♥♥♥ed by several dice rolls in a row and will lose your entire party. But that's what this game is about."Mind that such mis-steps are the exception, and not the rule."The key to darkest dungeon is to plan so well that even after getting♥♥♥♥♥♥on by RNG your party will be able to remain steadfast and fight on. EXPECT the lowest rolls, EXPECT the enemy to crit every time. Be happy when it doesnt happen and push on."Many fall in the face of chaos..but not this one..not today!"If you get absolutely destroyed and find yourself in a bad place, you can pick yourself up and start again. You might lose your heroes, you might lose your trinkets but your hamlet is untouched and you can always hire a fresh four idiots off the wagon, throw them into the grinder and start again. I've lost my fair share of A-teams and ancestor's trinkets and music boxes but I've always been able to get them back and get back into it.Granted, the grind is a bit frustrating, but for those of you that aren't bothered with it you can increase the stack size in the game's files so that you get more gold per mission. If you like playing the game vanilla like me however, you can just toss an antiquarian into your runs and make loadsamoney.Play this game. Expect to be broken and crushed several times. But get back up.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												This is still a work in progress while I slowly cover topics as I come by. If you need anything make a post on the forums and I'll probably be there.The upperpart of my review is of the game below that I will address the points of some of the negative reviews.Darkest Dungeon is fairly straightforward, multiple heroes with varying skills and abilities that you send off to a dark lovecraftian dungeon to fend off creatures battling to keep your health, hunger and sanity in check. In a sense it plays a little like an old Final Fantasy game, but without any pheonix downs and every monster matters.There are four seperate dungeons (and then the end game dungeon) that each have their own unique strengths and weaknesses and thus who you send into each area is often unique. As you select your four heroes you need to make some tough decisions. Will you send the Plague doctor? The only hero to boast both a double stun and double poison skill. The Bounty Hunter who can uppercut your enemies into different ranks? Or a mighty Man at Arms who can guard another while boosting his own defense and then next round can activate a counter attack! Rather than just a simple "Me am warrior me am stronk!" teams who can work together and take out the nasty healers and stress dealers, who hide in the back rank, fast and first will leave the dungeon sane while the slow teams with very little reach into the back rows will teem with madness and disease.Darkest Dungeon features a fairly linear weapon and armor system (coupled with some reasonable D&D type factors in how speed and other mechanics work) but offers a unique trinket system that can spice up combat. A disease and quirk system, diseases are obviously bad while quirks come in good and bad qualities.The final piece is the stress system, while dungeoneering your Heroes will gain stress through various means, will they crack under pressure? Or will they stand steady as a beacon of hope?In its entirety the game offers a well known system but adds several unique mechanics to really make it stand out.I would highly recommend anyone interested in this game but still unsure to watch some playthroughs on youtube.Also, check out some of the reviews with large comment chains and you'll see downvoters calling upvoters "shills". They're absolutely paranoid that people can like this game. It's pretty funny.For a while I thought this game was too hard, that I was doing everything right and that RNG was screwing me over.Then I got gud and realized that I had everything wrong. It is tough and RNG will kick you while you're down but many of these downvotes are blatant lies and I would like to address them here."You lose 10-20 hours per character that dies" I have lost about 4 max rank characters, and a few rank 3-4 ones aswell, at time of posting this I have 88 hours gameplay. My roster is almost full of max rank characters and I beat the game. The roster has 28 slots (+12 due to end game reasons), by his/her maths I'd need about 400-800 hours to do that."I was 1-hit by a non crit" utter lies. Maybe, just maybe, they had a plague doctor in the front row with double -HP trinkets... but why have some one who is essentially protected by a tissue and as weak as a kitten in that situation and then act like it's not your fault when a GIANT hits you?Many, many of the complaints are "I don't have a good team set up and I can't hit some one at the back!" Well that's probably their fault for bringing three units who can only hit the front two ranks and a healer.Several complaints are that the characters aren't equally powered and some outshine others, but I 100% believe the characters are extremely well balaned - it's all about using the characters correctly. For example the Plague Doctor isn't supposed to deal damage like a crusader/leper or heal HP like a Vestal, but a support class that can stun and poison (even two people at once) and stop heavy bleed/poison damage. Many - if not most - the complaints come from an update that causes stops enemies at the back from instantly moving forward when you kill a front unit. So rather than an open varied team they get upset their insanely powerful double leper set up (that guy 100% strongest solo character) can't just one hit everything.I have felt their pain but I can gaurantee that many of the complaints are biased and just frustrated that they couldn't get it right - even the forums get "I attacked Wilbur and my characters said 'No don't do that you're upsetting the big one' and then the big one got angry WTF RNG I AM LEET PRO" (youtube darkest dungeons wilbur fails).I am not saying that their reviews are without merit, but the devolopers have made leaps and bounds to meet in the middle.Now you can hire higher leveled heroes, bonus XP under certain conditions and some units bring resources for dungeons and even a new class that adds some risk V reward.And if all else fails, ask for help on the forums. I sure have, the people there are (mostly) friendly and are willing to help.I have yet to find a bug or skill working improperly.If you find flaw within my review (and my review of negative reviews) please feel free to criticize or offer advice.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								DD is a strategic turn-based dungeon crawler, with a very unique art work and mechanics.The narration is really good and gameplay is filled with gore, gotic and intense atmosphere.It has some rogue-like elements , permadeath and all decision taken produces great effect, so you have to think wisely every step, every character selection and move you're going to take next.Several classes/characters to choose from, each with personality. They will "come alive" as your journey unfolds. For the good and for the bad.You've acess to a creepy town where u can heal wounds, lower stress , evolve, recruit and reagroup for the next battle. Game can be very dramatic, you will feel attached to your characters, and they will die. And you will rage.I have to mention though, at the end of 5h, that i dont feel the character stats helpful or useful, for now.. Yet, if you really want to experience something different and refreshing, grab this title. The rest.. you'll get to know. Eventually.Although being in early acess, it puts to shame plenty of AAA titles out there.  Dungeon Crawling has never been so fun.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												I own this game since early access, and I have seen it progress through several stages of EA-development, all of which I am rather fond of. I figured I might as well write a review, because why not..? Core concept	Your task is to take control of a group of 4 heroes, which you assemble on your own, and lead them through different, randomly generated dungeons, with different inhabitants, and objects to interact with. A lot of loot awaits, both powerful and valuable. While doing your dungeon-crawling, you will not only have to defeat enemies in turn-based-combat to keep your merrymen alive, you will also need to keep them from getting stressed out. Health and sanity are both valuable resources, which you will need to handle with care.Before moving out you can buy provisions, food, medical herbs, holy water, shovels, you name it. Said provisions allow you to use certain interactive objects more safely and/or effectively.Upon completing a dungeon, your heroes will be given XP, which leads to level-ups sooner or later. Higher level heroes can use higher tier armour and weaponry, as well as improve their skills.To provide the best possible care for your crews, you will need to upgrade your very own, small village, to unlock more efficient methods of curing mental deseases, quirks, or sicknesses, like the black plague, for example. Training and gearing up also takes place in town, in corresponding buildings. Difficulty	Well, this has been discussed a lot, and everybody has a different point of view on that subject. My point of view is, that this game is neither too difficult at all, nor does it contain "false difficulty" (I always have to laugh when someone uses that term. A game is either difficult or it is not, and how difficulty is "created" is purely a choice of design).What makes this game challenging is that, no matter what you do, everything is based on odds, or RNG as some might say. One does not simply hit/stun/crit all the time. Your job as a player is to identify threats, and prioritize targets according to the current state of your party at any given point in time, as well as playing the odds in your favour as much as you possibly can. That being said, even if you are doing everything "right", your mileage may vary, such is the way of things. If the thought of that happening throws you off, this is the wrong game for you. Should you enjoy having success, eventhough your heroes lives are constantly at risk, stop reading my wall of text, pick up the game, and dive right in. Heroic diversity	You have an abundance of hero classes to choose from when you want to assemble a party. Tanks, healers, dmg-dealers, debuffers, stunners, etc allow you to be creative with your lineups. All your heroes start out with at least 4 combat skills, and some camping skills for longer endeavours, but they can learn, and master seven different skills during their careers. You will, however, always have to choose 4 skills for combat, all of which define the role your hero plays in conjunction with other party members. Furthermore certain skills are only useable from a certain position.There is a lot of creative leeway here, and experimenting with different lineups is highly recommended and encouraged by the diversity of encounters in the different dungeons. Combat	The actual combat plays the most significant role as far as gameplay goes. Each area has a different roster of enemies which you may or may not encounter. Some enemy lineups are rather straightforward: A couple melee brawlers with ranged support, for example. Other lineups, on first glance, are a bit more subtle as to what what manner of threat they pose, but be warned: Some enemies are pretty much designed to "attack" your heroes mental stability, trying to drive them insane. Furthermore there are lineups which are based on certain combinations of the monsters' individual abilities. Your job is to dismantle them all. Did I mention bosses already? No? Well, this game has bosses too, so be sure to think fast on your feet, when you encounter them for the first time.Not only is the composition of your party a relevant factor, also the order in which you assemble them plays a huge role. The same logic is applied to your enemies as well. If you manage to shuffle enemy groups, you can capitalize on that by taking out high-dmg monsters with lower health quickly, for example, your enemies might attempt the same however. Atmosphere	Art-style sure is a matter of personal preference, be it visual, or audio. I believe it is safe to say that the overall style of this game is very appealing, because visuals and audio go hand in hand, add a really good narrator to the mix, and you're in for quite an immersive experience.

Early Access Review
								Reading most reviews here, the difficulty of the game seems to be the major hinderance to most players. It is true that characters (even your godly characters) are pretty much expandable, and accidents (mostly unfortunate ones) that kill them are really frustrating and sometimes unforseen (thus unfair). Yet, with the wisdom of our great humanity, the guides about this game are very abundant online right now. I would seriouly recommand any players who dare to venture into the darkest dungeon do read about those works of other players' pain and lessons. They would make you evade a lot of traps (due to designs, I feel like some features of the game are simply DESIGNED to be that horrible to go through).However, this is still a quite difficult and intricate games that require very meticulous planning and exceuting at every step. One misstep, especially at high levels, can mean the demise of your "powerful" characters. The designers want this game to be dark, gloomy, and excrucitaing, and they succeed greatly, Mistakes are not tolerated, and odds are hardly in your favor. Do I recommend this game then? It is really not the question, I would still "recommend" simply because It is a greatly designed game that deserves some respect and applause. However, please think twice before deciding to launch your adventure into the darkest dungeon, it is not a game for lesiure fun. If you want to trully enjoy the experience the game offers, you need to treat this game seriously and with respect. Doing so, you will certainly be rewarded by this masterfully crafted work of art.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon has become the unfortunate example of "The game that the devs messed up". Not everyone obviously agrees with that statement, but the almost infamous interactions between Developer RedHook and the most hardcore parts of their community have put the game in a rather unhealthy state.So what is Darkest Dungeon? It's a Cthulhu-inspired turn-based roguelike-like in which the player controls a party of four not necessarily very brave adventurers on their journeys through the horrible parts of the family estate, which has been overrun by corruption after the players now deceased ancestor opened some door to a hellish place in his crazy search for power near the end of his life. The story is very well narrated, but paced poorly, as only boss-kills actually reward the player with new lore-bits, and those boss-encounters are not only rare, but repetetive, as each areas 3 bosses are literally the same with various stat-upgrades.Graphically, this game is absolutely amazing. The artstyle, the very distinct single-frame-animations really make the turnbased and thus not exactly hectic combat feels heavy, impacts and crits sound and "feel" devastating. And a large variety of classes with customizable skills, as well as a vast variety of quirks (both positive and negative) that they acquire until their semi-inevitable permadeath is highly entertaining. It's one of those games that writes its miniature stories through its heroes and gameplay.Unfortunately, that's where the glaring balancing problems come in. Your party members need respite, otherwise the stress they accumulate in combat will make them freak out and lead to them doing stupid things, before they instantly die of a heart attack once their stress meter fills a second time. This change alone has been highly controversial and makes the game VERY difficult to complete unless you had a highly leveled bunch of characters before the patch in question was implemented. If a character is struck by lethal force in normal combat, they will teeter on "Death's Door" and can be healed, or even withstand some more blows with lucky dicerolls, or die immediatly. This creates tense but also VERY luck-heavy scenarios, especially if your characters are suffering from damage over time effects like poison or bleeding. It can be quite literally impossible to save someone who suffers an unlucky crit and then gets to take your first go while bleeding.To prevent this, the pretty much only available tactic to the player is to constantly recruit new sets of heroes, to burn them on a run that basically no supplies are bought for, and to then discard them and recruit the next bunch (for free) while investing the gained gold into the actual "main" team they're trying to progress with. This kind of grinding can be incredibly tedious.Put on top of that the fact that some ridicolous rare enemies which are by far mightier than bosses might just randomly walk into you on any mission and you have a recipe for disaster, as your entire savefile (namely your main team) might be screwed at any moment if you simply roll a 1-5% chance badly. Sure, it's not really possible to permanently lose, but having to start 40+ grinding runs all over again to flesh out a new alpha team is more annoying than entertaining.Overall, If you want a REALLY hardcore roguelite dungeon crawling experience, this could be your game. But do yourself a favor and turn off the added changes in the options menu. And while you're doing it, be happy the devs even added an option to turn them off, something the most hardcore fans of the game declared to be heresy, even blasphemy. Trust someone who enjoyed the game a lot in its launch state, you neither want Heart Attacks, nor Corpses blocking you from attacking in combat, nor permanent debuffs for fighters you rescued off deaths door if you have any intentions of finishing this game in under 500 hours of mostly grinding on throwaway freshmeat parties. At that point you might as well be using a trainer or cheat engine to generate gold instead of banging fresh recruits into pointless runs repeatedly.The problems simply outweight the enormous potential and atmossphere that the game did a great job delivering at the start. If there's anything to be taken from this game as a long term example, it's not to listen too much to a small group of your audience unless they're forking over hundreds of dollars into your budget, and to get an awesome narrator into every indie game ever. He's truely great, even after all the changes.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Doesn't matter how good your party is.Doesn't matter what abilities they have or what level they are.Doesn't matter how many resources you brought.Doesn't matter how much time and gold you've invested.Doesn't matter who you have in your party.They will all die. Painfully. You'll lose everything… and yet you can't help but love it.Welcome to Darkest Dungeon, a brutal and unforgiving turn-based Lovecraftian dungeon-crawler from the team at Red Hook. The rogue-like design makes for near infinite replay value. But your biggest enemy here, however, is RNG and, similar to the XCOM franchise, you'll watch your favourite heroes fall and suffer party wipes again and again.Having picked this up a few days after the launch of Early Access last year and knowing very little of it, the level of detail, depth and polish that the small developer team has put into this was instantly engrossing. It wouldn't be that much of a stretch to say that this is one of the most unique games to emerge in recent years, especially from Kickstarter, and DD has earned a passionate cult following to show for it, even with a modding community to boot. As one who has never really enjoyed turn-based or strategy games in general, (with exception to XCOM and some cRPGs), I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this, and still do, in fact. Must have sunk hours and hours into it within the first week; it's addictive and can't help but pull you back in for another shot at taking down that seemingly invincible boss. Darkest Dungeon is, undoubtedly, a great game, with an excellent gothic atmosphere that adds to the bleakness of your heroes' plight. The narration, especially in combat, can be repetitive at times, yet immensely satisfying when you land a game-changing critical hit as your party desperately clings to life. Classes are great and each come with unique and interesting abilities and styles, complementing the gritty and dark design nicely. The micro-management and balancing of resources also adds further to the almost survival-like aspects of general gameplay, so success depends on watching your gold deposits closely and the strength of the torch as you delve deeper still into the heart of darkness..The most fascinating addition, however, is the stress mechanic which implements psychological, (as well as physical), diseases and maladies to reflect the extremely punishing nature of the game world. These can be alleviated and cured through lore-friendly outlets in your Hamlet, (which acts as the main player hub), such as the Tavern, Abbey and Sanatorium. All these buildings and more can be upgraded, as well as your party's armour and gear in a typical RPG fashion, once again complementing the depth and just how time-consuming this can be. As you can no doubt imagine, the emphasis on such risk/reward stats in nearly all aspects of gameplay leaves you to the mercy of the random number generation (RNG) and it is this dependency on pure luck rather than skill or tactics that is the game's biggest fault.While it certainly isn't punishing to the point of being broken or unfair, how much you're willing to endure at the whim of chance is ultimately whether or not I can recommend this game to you personally. Darkest Dungeon is certainly worth a purchase at full price but is equally crippled for some by the punishing nature of the RNG mechanics. I am thus torn between both an up and down vote for a recommendation. If you've played a (traditional) cRPG before or the likes of XCOM, then you should be right at home for an immensely satisfying, albeit hard-core, experience. But for the average, "new age" gamer then it once again comes down to how much you're willing to risk in Darkest Dungeon to enjoy the gameplay reward. Is it worth it? You must find out for yourself. Proceed with caution; both treasure and death, friend and foe, await at every turn.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon drips style but sinks into rote repetition despite all of its clever ideas. It ultimately feels like a highly polished smartphone game: all treadmill and no destination.Fundamentally, the game wants you to toy with villainy, tasking you with renovating your haunted estate on the backs of an endless supply of expendable heroes. At first glance, this works pretty well. You send a colorful cast of characters through four zones of procedurally-generated room progressions, encountering spooky doodads, slaughtering monsters, and collecting loot as you protect your heroes' bodies and minds. But after a short while, it drifts into purposelessness. Clear an expedition and you're rewarded with another one that's no different. Defeat a boss only to learn that he has a palette swap (two, actually) standing a dozen missions behind him. Level up a hero and (after jumping though entirely too many hoops) raise all of his numbers a tiny amount while leaving him functionally the same. Lose a hero and replace him with another barely different one. Even the system of perks fails to individualize units, since you'll usually end up selecting for "better at the only thing this class does" traits that don't exactly scream personality.The expeditions themselves fare no better. Most of your time will be spent in the innovative combat system, which restricts units' abilities and targeting capabilities by marching order. But as before, this makes a great first impression before sinking into drudgery. Heroes generally have little mobility and even less desire for it, encouraging a static formation that spams its most effective abilities. Enemy formations consist almost entirely of meaty tanks up front and stress-inducing mage types in back. It doesn't take long to realize that every fight has you stunning a few folks, killing the back, mopping up the front line, rinse and repeat. When not fighting, you have scattered opportunities to set camp for the night and recuperate or to investigate madness-inducing curios littering the estate, but as with everything else the volume of ideas fails to hide the lack of depth. When each decrepit hall looks and demands the same approach as the last, the tension gives way to tedium.It bears repeating Darkest Dungeon presents a wealth of excellent ideas worth exploring. It's just a pity that it didn't bother to.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												You guys...don't listen to all these naysayers.This is an excellent game.I will admit, the beginning of the game is probably the hardest part. Although, I say this without having actually gone to the final dungeons yet. The trick is to spend your money wisely and to try and build up your town as quickly as possible. Once you start racking up some heirlooms to spend on buildings in town and gather some extra money, you can start upgrading your characters regularly. I would highly recommend upgrading the stagecoach first so that you can recruit more characters more often. After that, I focused on the guild and the blacksmith discounts heavily. Once those are upgraded to a higher level, you can beef up your characters without spending very much money at all!It seems like a lot of people aren’t approaching this game from a tactical standpoint which is entirely necessary in order to be successful. I would say in the last 20 Dungeons that I've attempted, I didn't have any characters come close to going over their stress limit. There are plenty of characters that heal stress in the middle of the dungeon and that's key. The Jester has become one of my favorite characters simply because he can heal stress. This also means you should be targeting the most dangerous enemies at the beginning of the battle, which tend to be those who inflict a lot of stress damage. When you're coming out of dungeons without having to send your characters to heal their stress you can save a ton of money. If you want to make this game more enjoyable, then look up a guide of what curios require which items based on location. You can save yourself a hell of a lot of headaches by doing this.People are right. This game does take a lot of grinding. But there's something satisfying about being able to absolutely ruin enemies that were previously ruining you. PROS:+ The story is fun. The monologues have great voice acting and add to the atmosphere. I find myself quoting them whenever I play the game.+ It’s challenging. I get tired of people giving games a bad review because it's hard (Dark Souls etc.). Is this game unfair at times? Absolutely. But never so much that it made me want to stop playing.+ There are lots of characters with lots of abilities. You will quickly learn which trinkets work best with which character and which characters form the best group for that particular area.+ There is very little more satisfying than a critical hit in this game. ASTONISHING!+ I would consider this game casual. I play it while I'm watching sports or movies all the time. It doesn't take all of your attention all the time. You can take breaks during the action.+ The artwork is absolutely beautiful for those who enjoy comic book art.CONS:+ Can come off a little bit repetitive at times because of the grinding. If you're grinding intelligently then you can rack up a lot of money fairly quickly.+ Without a guide on inspecting curios, you're going to have a hell of a time. They can inflict a lot of stress or negative attributes to your character. Sometimes it's just better to leave them alone.+ The boss fights can seem overwhelming at times, but if you really think, you can find a good strategy. One thing to remember about this game is that getting to zero HP does not kill you. In fact hovering just above zero HP is sometimes all you can do with certain bosses and that's OK. I think some of us are trained to panic when our characters get close to zero HP, but that's not a huge issue in this game.If you're not sure about this game, then wait for a discount. But don't let all these people tell you it's a broken game just because it's hard. Be ready to play for many hours, but don't get the discouraged. Find good tactics and put them to use. You got this.
