content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Thought I'd make a quick edit to the review now that the game has come out of Early Access.Darkest Dungeon lets you assemble a roster of dungeon adventurers and send them into dungeons in order to defeat pestilent creatures that have plagued the land in order to fully restore a hamlet back to its former glory. The game is not so much a pure dungeon crawler, but more of a dungeon crawl management simulator (for lack of a better word). You do not only navigate the heroes through a dungeon. You also take full responsibility for their wellbeing. As heroes go through dungeons, they accumulate stress and could even get diseases, and you have to make sure you bring them back to top shape in between your dungeon runs. You do not just control a single party of heroes. You have to rotate several different heroes around and pick the ones most suitable for the job at hand.There are 4 areas where you can take your expedition: Ruins, Warrens, Weald, and Cove, and each one has its own dangers and challenges, what means that you need to prepare your team accordingly. The dungeons also come in different lengths (Short, Medium, and Long) and of different difficulty (Apprentice, Veteran, and Champion). As of the final release, the final dungeon has been added too (have not yet had the bravery to try it out).The combat is really fun and in my opinion has a lot of tactical depth to it. It's not just a simple turn-based battle system, but each position within your party setup is important. Some hero classes prefer frontal positions in the squad (like the melee tanks), others prefer to hang back (like healers or ranged attackers).The game has been balanced around loads during Early Access, and though some aspects of it might feel unfair still, overall the gameplay feels pretty solid and requires a lot of strategising and adjusting to the situation when bad things start to happen. The game can be pretty punishing towards those who do not take caution. And even if you do everything right, things can still go wrong at times, and part of the gameplay is also having to deal with that. The game encourages tip-top preparation and contingency planning. That means that the game is easily not for everyone, but those who do enjoy that sort of thing will be up for a real treat.Art, music, and voice acting are also superb. Easily a cherry on an already delicious cake.I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a good challenge and doesn't mind it when a game occasionally throws them some curve balls. I can't remember the last time a game has kept me interested for 70 hours and counting.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												[ EDIT ]  As you can see below, I recommended this game prior to reaching the level 5 dungeons. After equipping my characters to maximum efforts, the nightmare of what many have described this game as 'unbalanced' has finally rung true, sadly. All time and effort battling with my characters, the last of hard earned gold purchasing much needed upgrades to venture the 5th level dungeons.. All.. for.. null. I have changed my tune and am no longer recommending Darkest Dungeon. I will put DD away until I find there is a much needed update to balance the 5th and 6th level dungeons. I can't imagine why anyone would continue playing this game. What's most upsetting is that I truly wanted to believe the negative reviews wrong..sigh-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------What feels to be a dark side-scrolling dungeon crawler - bringing to mind games of past that I enjoyed, gathering them into one tough ultra strategic D&D RPG of sorts. I've found Darkest Dungeon (through trial and error) to be very tough on the unprepared. The game is brutal to both seasoned and unseasoned player who dive in with set goal in mind to conquer with a 'record time' mindset. If you do find yourself wanting to give this game a go, then you must know that your characters will die, every time, as long as they aren't developed enough through the lower stages while finding and equipping proper trinkets, leveling, and simply understanding correct placement in the line. Placement in the line is probably the most important factor to survive and thrive in Darkest Dungeon, as there are 4 spots front to back where you will place your characters, each placement tailored specifically for different characters to maximize their individual strengths. Patience is needed to enjoy this title. If you don't have patience I suggest not purchasing this game as you will have a very difficult and stressful experience. You must study the characters and discover each of their strengths over time, while simultaneously learning by trial and error - dying, and starting over again - until you understand each characters abilities, placements and weaknesses. The game is fun, I'm sincerely having a blast, and knowing there is permadeath keeps the intensity very high.   I cannot stress enough that Patience, once again, is key to enjoying this game. You cannot rush a game of chess, in Darkest Dungeon you must understand your pieces and respect the unspoken rules of the game first before gaining any glimpse of an advantage. Take it slow and enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 58 of 107 people (54%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like rogue-like/management games with a quickly drawn dark fantasy settings that offer some depth and replayability, i guess it's an interesting game to look at but for me it was quite a disapointment.I mean, the only reason you'd want to buy this game is if you like atrocious RNG, push-your-luck mecanic and horrible dice rolls. In my opinion, the graphics tries way too hard to make itself feel dynamic and "dark" (because it's dark fantasy, you see) with an overload of camera zoom, layers of shaders and blurry, shaky effect everywhere that can become infuriating after more than ten hours in. It's sad because the hand drawn inked aesthetic was charming at first glance and could have been a great touch if the animation wasn't that cheaply done.The background starts off as a good idea but is ultimatly used as an excuse to put you in a dungeon and do stuff without really getting into too much details, making the whole game not subtle at all if not forgettable.The UI is sometimes messy and the tutorial just give you basic knowledge about generic stuff without getting into more details than just "click here to open the tab or here to move to another room", when it should be explaining you a few stuff about what's going on with every heroes you can recruit, what the hell is all these numbers and why every single usefull skill a caracter have that could help you out of combat has to proc randomly if you want to progress without pain in the dungeons. In fact, the game is all about numbers, making it more a management game with a dungeon theme rather than an actual rogue-like or dungeon crawler. And this is mainly because most of the push-your-luck and progression in the game will resolve around how balanced and prepared your party will be, how well you manage your gold in upgrades and when you'll decide to go back to town before it's too late while exploring or questing, but even that will usually get reduced to simple dice rolls and bad lucks when the game decides it's okay to whipe 15hours of grinding (and the game is all about grinding) in just 1 encounter.It's not about how well you'll do in the actual dungeon when facing dangerous enemy and defeating them thanks for a good strategy or reflexes, for there's too little skills for each character (being a turn based game) and nothing like well-timed attacks or stuff that will requires you, the player, to interract with the game to get the best out of every fight. It's all about gambling, and hope for the best.And that's pretty much where the game fail to be interesting, for me at least. Everything looks like a mobile game, from the way it presents missions with quest jauge that fills every 'run' you take and rewards when clicking things to the way it tackles the caracter and hub progression. I'm actually quite surprised there's no cash shop or, you know, a set limit of tasks to perform before being able to keep playing the next day.But it boast and advertise itself about how hard and challenging it is when it's just all extremly unfair RNG and bad difficulty.It's not about being casual or blaming tje die and retry mecanic, for i do beleive some games like that are actually really enjoyable (ie meatboy), but more about what purpose the difficulty serve to your game. For there's different kind of diffilcuty and so no, "Hard" doesn't necessarily mean "Good".You see, Games like volgarr the viking, crypt of the necrodancer, the binding of isaac or even dark souls are really hard games too but they're fair, because they use difficulty as a challenge you have to overcome instead of making it completly arbitrary and unforgiving. They don't throw you backward in your progression and tell you "it's because it's hard, it's fun !". There's a feeling of accomplishement or pride once you've overcome an obstacle that you couldn't handle by making you learn and that's what makes them good games.In DD, the difficulty is just something that randomly happens, sometimes, and you can't do things about it, making it pointless to some degree : when you finish a quest or manage to survive, you don't feel like you deserve it, in fact it just feel like that you either got lucky or that it's just the regular way the game is supposed to happens. And then you encounter a fight when suddenly everything miss and you have to wait about 20 minute for every small text bubble and zoom effect and shaking camera and death blow or alteration announcing without being able to touch or speed anything when you party just decide to kill itself, and you can't change a thing about it.It's sad because it's quite a pretty well executed indy game besides that, considering all the trash that pass through the greenlight system.Such a waste of potential.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												The art style is beautiful and the ambience and general aesthetic is strong and compelling. It has a great, quirky, Vincent Price feel that I found endearing.There's some progression in the form of skills and gear, that presumably characters can live long enough to actually use.But the RNG makes this more frustrating than rewarding for me. I get that the entire core of the game is based on this. I get it. When your character dies, if you tend to think: "awesome, this is really fun, I hope I can spend even more time and money on the next character before they get RNG'd to death!", then you'll love this game. If you don't tend to think that way, you'll probably hate it.

												The game is actually very nice. But there are several reasons why I chose not to recommend it:- the gameplay is very repetitive, there are new monsters after a time but no new challenges. Although it is fun to play, after like 12 hours it starts to feel like grinding, which is something some of us old folks just do not have the time anymore- getting into the higher levels, you depend too much on chance. Consequtive crits can and will end things no matter how well prepared you are. And therein lies the problem: skill is only relevant in the beginning of the game (maybe also in the end, I will never know). Until then you have seen most of the mechanics and somehow understood the stat system. But that will not help you anymore because too much relies on chance.I like roguelikes and I do not mind dying when it is my fault. Some chance is also acceptable on both sides, but here 'mindless' grinding AND RNG ruin maybe not the entire gameplay but surely much of the fun for older ex-hc gamers with limited time. A pity.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Despite its pretensions, this is by-the-numbers dungeon crawling wrapped in a typical upgrades grind. In theory, I like the way stress acts as a persistent form of damage across runs, but it doesn't amount to anything. Somebody's numbers get too high, and then something bad happens, and then you pay gold to make it go away. It's just another HP bar to manage. Also in theory, the fact that it forces you to swap out party members should make things more dynamic, but it doesn't. While the classes do have different abilities, the only thing that actually matters is damage output. There's no point in buffing and defending when you can just kill things before they can hurt you. Crucially, the game doesn't get interesting when it gets hard; it just gets annoying. Non-damage-dealing abilites aren't effective enough to allow you to manage stronger opponents, so there's ultimately no real gameplay outside of the grind. Which, ironically, completely kills the horror effect, because you're never really at risk of losing anything. It's all one big grind, it'll just take more or less time to finish depending on how lucky you are. This is why grafting an upgrades system onto a roguelike fundamentally doesn't work. Meanwhile, the story is generic pop-Lovecraft (pro tip: Lovecraft sucks, get over it), and whoever wrote the narration needs to have their thesaurus privileges revoked.The graphics are good, though.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												On Facebook, and bear with me on this, there is a game called Avengers Alliance.  It's a Marvel Comics game where you assemble a team of Marvel characters, choose a mission to send them on, then engage in turn-based combat against a series of enemies until you reach the boss.  Defeating that boss progresses you to the next missions, and gives you experience that levels up your characters.  Despite being a Facebook game, it was one of my favorite games for a long time.  I dropped some real money on that game.So what does that have to do with Darkest Dungeon?  Well, this game takes that same concept of building a party and advancing through increasingly difficult missions, and marries that to a Lovecraft theme.  As you progress through the dungeons in this game, you have the same tough decisions on how to deal with certain enemies, the benefits of various party compositions, and who you choose to level up.  With that, though, you also have the nail-biting events that can throw all your plans into disarray or lead your party to a miraculous victory.  I love it.The graphics are a comic art aesthetic, and as you might expect all of the colors are dark and suitably gothic.  The sound effects are evocative of the theme, and the music is chilling at times.  One thing stands above all else when I think of this game, though, and that's the narration by Wayne June.  This is a man who has narrated countless Lovecraft audiobooks, and there's no other word to describe his effect on the game other than perfection.  If you do not like an element of random chance, avoid this game.  If you do not appreciate the fact that you will suffer setbacks despite your best efforts, avoid this game.  If you do not enjoy gothic lovecraftian themes, avoid this game.  If you like watching the heroes that you've recruited slowly succumb to the insanity of your ancestral home, eventually meeting a grotesque end at the hands (or tentacles) of ancient horrors, then embrace the Darkest Dungeon.

number of helpful: 49 of 90 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Having played this for some time now I could not recommend it in good taste. There is simply too many times where the games major mechanics are shown to be shallow and unfinished, or enemy types bland and uninteresting. The stress system seems interesting at first but quickly devolves into a second health bar that you can't reliably heal back to acceptable levels, combined with every other enemy having massive stress damage attacks makes progression painful and unrewarding.Another issue is player control. In one of Valves in game commentaries for Half-Life 2 they stated that the best thing a developer can do is to never take control away from the player, even if they aren't actually in control they should at least feel as if they have some say in what happens in a situation. Darkest Dungeon takes player control away so often that it's bordering on absurdity. Randomly given quirks randomly cause your character to make random arbitrary choices in combat and at town, making it seem like you have no say at all in what happens in your party. Even if you complete a hard dungeon with 0 stress across the board theres still a hefty chance of your characters gaining up to two character destroying traits that make them dead weight and functionally dead to you.The next issue is the diversity and balance of each of the dungeons. There's a forest, a ruin, a cove, and a city for the main dungeons. Each of these supposedly has a diverse set of enemies and challenges to face, but if you examine them closely they are nearly carbon copies of one another. The ruins has skeletons that act the same as the coves fish people, the cultists have a spellcaster that has nearly the same spells as the coves fish spellcaster, the pigs have the same support abilities as the fungal growths in the forest.The main cause of all this sameness stems from the games shallow combat system, there are only two DOT's, one stun type, forced movement attacks and then normal damage with crits. This is not a recipe for replayability at all. There are simply too few ways for the enemy to fight the player, leading to stagnation. The game tries to add another layer of complexity in its stress system, but it falls flat, with it being a near unmanagable mess of too much stress and too few ways to mitigate it within the dungeon itself. The few characters that can mend stress heal it for so little as to not be worth it, why waste turns stress healing when you could be killing the enemy to stop the stress from being placed to begin with? The stress system is also very bottom heavy, it mostly affects newer characters and seems to dissappear by level 2-3, mostly serving to kill off fresh characters by having a skeleton splash wine on them for 10 rounds.The stat system is also very oddly designed. Dodge works like in most games, by serving as a way to completely mitigate damage in echange for reliability, but most characters will not high high enough dodge stats to take advantage of it, and will instead opt in for the much more realiable and plentiful PROT stat which functions as a flat damage reduction. Most enemies also seems to have either 100% accuracy attacks, or attacks that hit so hard that even taking the chance of focusing on dodge and having it fail makes prot all the more worth while. Why even have the chance of taking a 20 damage attack on a 22 Health character when you can always reduce that 20 damage to 10 or less?Sadly Darkest Dungeon is a trainwreck of balance issues and poorly implemented game mechanics overlaid with amazing art and stellar sound and voice work. It simply isn't worth the $20 in its current state, and likely never will be.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								The darkest dungeon is not fun and rewarding. Visually and Aurally it's flawless. - the dark reds and blacks perfectly complementing the endlessly grim atmosphere. As someone that collects rougelikes, I can handle random turn of events and sudden death - yet in this game there is a constant elongation of that death. You are slowly losing. Slowly being eaten away like a bunch of flies digesting a almost dead warrior with no eyes on a empty battlefield. Even in dark souls, a game known for its punishment - there is some degree of immediacy. This is quite literally - torture. I admire that. I admire that some team of indie developers went out there, made a game so far departed from the norm. There is no game that quite feels like the darkest dungeon. And for that uniqueness, combined with the flawless presentation - This review is uniformly positive. However subjectively, I don't often want to actually play the damned thing. Because my time spent will involve slowly becoming as stressed as the protaganists as I am torn apart until there is nothing but an empty husk hobbling along a worn path of nothingness. While enemies point and laugh at my feeble attempts at carrying on. And in the end, that's what you do. Even if you win. You carry on. You don't come out powerful. Or even slightly enhanced. You survive another day of stress and hate. Sounds a bit too much like my life.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wrote up a big review but apparently 16000 character is more than Steam will allow. Here's a link.http://pastebin.com/WwDbZ4ACAn outtake to sum up my review:Here is what I expected when I purchased Darkest Dungeon: a modern take on roguelikes with interesting attrition-based mechanics that require clever tactics to overcome, a variety of hero classes which can be combined into parties that capitalize on different ways of playing the game, and a challenge which was meaningful and fulfilling to overcome.I did not get these things. What I got was a sub-standard dungeon crawler with masochistic tendencies and a design philosophy that discourages strategic and tactical thinking. Alongside this is a meaningless progression grind that would make any mobile tower defense game proud.It's an exercise in rolling dice that requires a large investment of time for little to no satisfaction.You will grind for hours to kit out a team to take on the end bosses but your victory rarely feels earned - careful planning and team structure will not win the day, lucky crits and blasting everything with all the♥♥♥♥♥♥you can muster will.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alright, the fights are in theory kind of fun. But there is so much in this game that makes no sense and annoys the heck out of me:1. To much luck, to much randomness:You have no indicator at all what will await you in a dungeon and what items you might need. No idea at all if the box you look into will be good or bad. The quirks your heroes get on every corner are also something you cannot control, doesn't matter if it's a good or negative one, no idea what enemies will await you. No idea or control about who the enemy will attack in your group. Pure frustration2. Slow & Repetitive:The battles, the animations, everything is so slow. A fight could be over in 3 minutes, but thanks to the slow animations you need 15!!! Also you will want to strangle the voice who tells me the 50th time in a dungeon that my luck might be turning. Less frequent please or more tracks.3. Makes no sense:So much makes 0 sense in this game: You buy items to go into a dungeon but if you don't use them they are magically gone afterwards. And the money you paid for them with it. And because you have no idea what awaits you in a dungeon it's a pure lucky guess if you buy the right items or not. Your heroes feel more like civilians than warriors. 50% of the game consists of sending them into overpriced bars/hospitals/churches to tend to their breakdowns. And you should spend a ton of your time to look into which hero likes what best and remembering it.I'm sorry, but this game must be made by SEO, because it's formula is to frustrate and punish the player on every single corner. Not because it's hard, but because you can also let a monkey play it as there is so much luck and crap involved. Haven't played such a really really bad game in a long time. I've played it very early and did hope that after almost a year it got better, but if something it only got worse.

												Good game, but it should have ended after 30 hours then its just boring grind and repeating same actions over and over again. High level dungeons require much more time to complete becouse enemies have higher hp, prot and dodge. Fights on lvl 0-3 or 3-4 lasts about 3 turns and when you get to high level dungeons it can be even 7 or more turns. Sometimes you start a fight and game randomly place against you 2 Pelagic Guardians and some random monsters, so you finish this two monsers and then waste time poisoning debuffing and bleeding two enemies that far too tanky. Also it's ridiculous that even huge enemies like Unclean Giant with a lot of hp or Ghoul with 40% prot got improved dodge on higher levels. Debuffing mechanics is just wrong - I'm fighting enemy with insane dodge like Shrieker or madman, who i cant even hit, so i'm casting dodge debuff on them, and they dodge it xD.Some fights are far too random. The best example is The Collector, during fight he summons healer and tank to support him. If those two decides to heal and protect him you are going to have bad time, but sometimes they just do random stuff - healer buffs dmg of tank that can't even attack and tank protects healer when Collector is about to die. This♥♥♥♥♥♥has nothing to do with difficulty.Critical hits are really powerfull, when enemy crits you he can deal even 40 dmg+stress, so basically all your character HP... so in my opinion there should be like 2%-6% chance to critical hit... but its about 20% so sometimes when your unlucky you can get 3 crits in a row and get destroyed.After all i can't truly reccomend this game, the first 30 hours was great experience, art is amazing, narrator is perfectly suited for this game, and mechanics is pretty good. But repetitive gameplay and too much of random stuff makes me bored and im struggling to finish this playthrough.

content:
Posted: April 22
												I had some fun playing this game. I love the narrator and the whole style, the intro video and the art style is plain awesome. The psychology aspect is very unique, and that feature is basically the only standout aspect that seperates this game from the endless quagmire of other dungeon fantasy games. Unfortunately, the psychology aspect was never anything more than a disguised handicap mechanic to bolster the AI monsters and weaken your own people. They imply that there is this dynamic psychological mechanic that affects your characters in game. It is truly just another health bar disguised as this intricate system. The only psychological effects I ever encountered with my pawns was negative impacts during combat. Basically the enemies attack you physically, or use some kind of mental technique to damage your will. So during battle certain enemies attack will only, and they will chip away at the will untill your pawns go through a mental break. As if the game isnt hard enough already. Youll be trying to survive battles health wise, and mental health wise. Basically over time as you do more and more battles, the whole gameplay system is designed to limit your ability to recover your pawns after each dungeon raid. So it will whittle you down more and more and youll be sending increasingly weak pawns into combat over and over until you eventually start to lose them all. And this all happens because the game REFUSES to let you have any kind of rest or day off. You HAVE to send in pawns to a dungeon. I thought Ha Ill just have one guy be the punching bag and send him in alone and retreat right after. But nope you HAVE to send in four pawns. It wouldnt be a big deal if they didnt tack on enormous debuffs and penalties from retreating. Also everything you do costs gold, and there are MANY things youll have to buy just to enable the possibility of clearing a dungeon. Food, torches, healing items etc. Everything is very expensive, and to make it even more difficult they decided to make it where your supplies you find after each raid, DISSAPEAR. So if you are unlucky during a run and the only treasure you get is a bunch of food, you cant save it to use it for the next raid, oh no that would be too easy. I ended a run with something like 20 food and thought oh great ill save money next time, sadly next time came and I had to buy the expensive food all over again. Same goes for all other basic resources like torches.There is very little in the way of RPG stuff. Items, upgrades, skills. Yeah they might be there but the whole system is so ridiculously simple that it barely resembles an RPG at all. Level cap is 6. Upgrading gear consists of pressing the + button and spending gold to and other rare resources to do so. Nothing changes, no visual difference or variation in weapons or armor, just the magical invisible numbers behind your pawns stats. I say magical and invisible because never does the game bother to explain any of the battle mechanics to you. In fact youll go through most of the game not understanding how most stuff works, you wont even have the slightest idea of the whys and hows of pretty much everything that goes on behind the scenes, meta game as some say. Pray to the RNG gods, because everything is random. You might not even make it out of the tutorial dungeon in the beginning, because you may get some unholy combination of crap luck and get crit hits repeatedly. Somehow thought that never seemed to work in my favor though. Very little did I ever score and lucky strings, I only ever had unlucky strings that eventually whittled away entire teams and hours of progress. That is the recurring theme with the game. It does not respect your time and it will demand hours of grinding and grinding just to stand half a chance, and even then youll get smashed and forced to start from scratch. No save system, basically permadeath, so save scumming is not possible. I love save scumming because I dont enjoy games where a simple mistake leads to hours of progress lost, or accidentally making decisions im not unhappy with and being stuck with it for remainder of the game. I like playing games the way I enjoy them most. And this is one of those games that not only demands but FORCES you to conform to their idea of how it should be played, and theres no room for compromise. "easy" mode is a joke and is still stupid difficult. No cheats or even mods for difficulty either so hope you enjoy soul crushingly difficult moments, prepare to replace you keyboard/mouse or other accessories within an arms reach!TLDR: All frustration aside I really did enjoy the morbid charm and art style of the game. Its simple combat system can be fun and addicting. Sadly it devolves into a convoluted resource management grind fest nightmare. The grinding wouldnt be so bad if you didnt lose your hard earned pawns so quickly and easily. In the end it does not respect your time and will eat it away and spit it out, and it is VERY infuriating and defeating to lose hours and hours of gameplay to a bad string of RNG luck. Yes thats right, prepare to bend to the will of the RNG gods as they will always remind you who is in charge. No not your strategic thinking or witty planning or fighting, but they, they alone are in charge of who wins and who loses and dies.

number of helpful: 25 of 44 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 21
===========================Not an RPG, not a Roguelike===========================With Darkest Dungeon, during the 1st hours of play, you fight against the game, not within the game, in a degree I had never met with other games.The rules aren't well explained, are often counter-intuitive or just plain weird.For example, you can use your healing spells during the fight, but can't anymore outside of fight. Why that ? It's not a world logic, it's only a game balance logic.At 1st, you'll also need to get acquainted with DD world : you have a village with several buildings which are unlocked 1 by 1 after every quest you do. A quest is only crawling in an extremely basic dungeon with a team of 4 heroes. There's no real exploration as you only have something like 5, 10 or 15 rooms (depending of the quest length) connected by vertical or horizontal corridors on a 2D map. Once in a room, you select the next room you want to go, but it doesn't have any real consequence. You just want to select the rooms in the best order to avoid backtracking. The goal of the "quests" is usually to explore 90% or 100% of the rooms, or kill the Boss, or destroy a couple of altars.And for this crawling, you constantly need to light up torches, as fighting in the dark gives handicaps to your team. You'll also need a few items to maximize the looting of the different curios (eg: you need a key to open locked chest ; holy water to purify an altar, etc.), and food to eat at random intervals. At 1st, you don't know how much torches or food you'll need, and they are a bit expensive and you can't keep them from 1 quest to another. Why, oh why ? Oh, it's just to waste your money so you'll have trouble upgrading your heroes at 1st, as everything is money based.But after these few hours of adjustment, the game becomes actually quite simple. There's no gear for your heroes except 2 trinkets. There's no leveling choice either, nor anything that would look like a real RPG game. Your heroes starts at level 0 and their max level is 6. They get a random positive or negative perk at each level up. There you'll be able to upgrade their skills, weapon and armor in the Guild & Blacksmith buildings of the village. There's no choice in this. Your only choice is in a what order you'll unlock the additional upgrade level in each building. Spoiler alert : usually, you need Armor -> Skill -> Weapon.Although your heroes can permanently die, it's really easy to avoid this by playing conservatively and carefully. There are dungeons of Level 1, 3, 5 and the final one of level 6. So as long as your heroes aren't fully upgraded to Level 3 or 4 skills, armors & weapons, just stick to the Level 1 Dungeons. Simple. Also, don't go to fight the Level 1 Bosses before your heroes are entirely upgraded to Level 2 or 3. Your heroes also don't die when reaching 0 HP, they still need to be hit once more and there they still have a chance to survive. And you can run away from a fight and abandon a quest at any time.Moreover, there's no special event, no randomness that can lead to different outcome, so this game is not a Roguelike. There's nothing that looks more like your current dungeon run than the previous run and the next one.===========================Grindest Grindy Grind===========================So, it's not a Roguelike, it's not an RPG, and you keep on doing the same thing over and over again. Yup, it shouldn't have been called Darkest Dungeon but rather the Grindest Grindy Grind.Let me explain. So your heroes constantly get stressed by crawling in the dungeon and often they'll end the quest with high stress. So you have to put them to rest in the Tavern or the Church to lower their stress. Meanwhile, you are forced to send another team for the next quest.It doesn't stop there as your heroes can get very annoying negative perks that will also require 1-quest off to be removed. If unlucky, they can even get 1 negative perk from leveling and 1 from checking items in the dungeon, so you may need 2-quest off to remove both. And it doesn't stop there either because there's also diseases that you'll need 1-quest off to remove. So all in all, you need between 2 and 4 teams to roll.Another very annoying thing is that your inventory is very limited, with very small stacking ability, thus if you do a medium or long quest, you'll be constantly juggling about what to keep or not. Personally, I installed these 2 Mods that extend stacks 


Stacking Inventory 
A Workshop Item for Darkest Dungeon
By: Maester Silvio

			Hate that firewood and quest items don’t stack? Many do, and this mod will make them do so!   Gems   Jute Tapestries now stack to 2  Trapezohedrons now stack to 2  Pews now stack to 3   Quest...		


 & 


Marco's Inventroy Balance Mod 
A Workshop Item for Darkest Dungeon
By: Marcoevelle

			How often when going through a dungeon do you have issues with your inventory limit? For early levels the limit is fine, but it does not scale well does it if at all?		


 , but it's still very painful : you feel like you're totally wasting your time, as you can't even keep the little loot you're finding.And it takes many runs to get the necessary items to unlock the upgrades of your weapons, armors & skills and thus you're often stuck with leveled but not fully upgraded heroes. And it can get badder, as Level 5 Heroes refuse to go to Level 1 Dungeon, so if you didn't manage correctly your team roster, it can lead to additional headaches.I have been playing the game with latest Radiant mode, which halves the time needed to finish the game. I can't imagine the horrible grind & repetitive feeling it must have been to play with the normal mode. Or I can : only 1.4% of the players finished the game with it 14 months after release. On Radiant, we're at 0.6% 2 months after its release, not exactly great either.One note of the curios : to find the item to optimize their use and their result, you'll have to spend countless of time & tries to figure out everything, or you can head there : http://darkestdungeon.gamepedia.com/Curio .===========================Missing the Spot===========================So almost all the interest of the game relies on its combat system. It is in itself really not bad and quite interesting for 4 or 5 hours. But unfortunately, it's not deep nor varied enough to justify chaining the quests, as you're mostly walking straight in corridors, opening containers, and fighting, fighting & fighting.Most fights are only 2-3 rounds long, which doesn't allow any evolved tactic building, so you just repeat ad nauseam the same skills over and over again.Quickly, you'll figure out you need an healer in your team and a stress reliever ; as pointed above, you can't use these spells outside of combat, so you'll use & abuse of the stun to make the fights longer, to heal & lower the stress of your heroes ; after 4, 5 or 6 rounds your heroes will start to stress out, because the Devs limited that abuse.And unfortunately, the Boss fights don't bring much on the table. They are straightforward enough and won't require your brains : your team is ever strong enough to kill them or it's not.There are 16 classes, I tried 11 of them and didn't feel enough gameplay differences from one to another. Mastering a class requires not much more than the 2 minutes needed to read its different ability descriptions.===========================Conclusion===========================DD is a game that hides its relative simplicity by not clearly explaining its rules, and is based on way too much grinding and on its interesting but not deep enough combat system.=== Pros ===- Unique enticing visuals- Interesting combat system, although ultimately lacking of depth and surprises- Village with buildings to upgrade=== Cons ===- Way too grindy- No real challenge- After a few hours, gameplay gets ultra repetitive- No exploration- Enemy mechanisms strongly lack of variety- Bosses fight are a stats check and not tactically challenging- Most trinkets comes with strong handicaps, making them nearly useless- All the negative things in the game have actually very little influence on the gameplay ; ie: they don't lead to choices for the player- Dull quest system without accomplishment feeling

												Warning: spoilers ahead. This is a great game, it really is: I wish I could reccomend it. The reason I can't is because of the ending, which basically takes all your hard work as a player and spits on it. You get to the end, are forced to make great sacrafices after a long journey that has allowed you to shape your party and the nearby hamlet. But what happens when you finally defeat the great evil? *poof* You just get a "rocks fall, everyone dies" scenario where none of your actions really mean anything and some silly cycle is maintained, it's simply a lazy excuse to encourage a replay of the game. Sure, it has quite a bit of inspiration from Lovecraft, but that doesn't mean you have to make the evil unbeatable because of such inspiration. Is a happy ending after such a journey too much to ask?

content:
Posted: April 10
												I really like the atmosphere, level, character and story design. The narrator is a nice touch too.But I can not enjoy the game I paid for because it is not an enjoyable game. After about 20 hours of gameplay I've come to a point where everything is really repetitive. That would still be fine since I enjoy the game, if only the game would let me enjoy it without punishing me every time I either go in blind or fully prepared.You do a perfect quest, clear the whole dungeon and on the end screen for your quest, you get a bunch of sicknesses and debuffs on characters that you kept stress and disease free. So you have to keep your heroes in town for one or two more quests. So you take other heroes and go on with them. The same thing happens. Rinse and repeat.I do not enjoy being punished for playing a game well and thoughtfully.You make some progress (level up their gear and skills and get some cool trinkets), but you get to feel that progress very little during the actual gameplay, since soon enough your buffed up heroes have leved up beyond the maximum level for the dungeons you played. Now you take on higher level dungeons thinking THIS IS WHERE THE FUN STARTS. Nope. You get the same enemies, the same tactics, the same level design, the same curios, but it's all leveled up too, so you're back to basically the same thing. Sure, you get more money and heirlooms, but that's because every next upgrade costs 2-3 times more than the previous one.So, after playing without having a single hero die on me, by having 3 teams of 4 ready to go on quests, I feel like I'm just grinding in place WHILE BEING STRESSED OUT ABOUT WHAT THE NEXT DICE ROLL WILL BRING.The story didn't advance much, nor did it show anything original, nothing changed about my heroes nor my town except for some stat modifications.The darkest grinder.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								A very pretty game, however ultimately hostile towards fun.I love the fact the developers wrote their own engine since most general ones (Unity, Unreal) are not so great for 2D-only games. The 2D animations, instant load times and nice UI effects make for a pretty sight.However, as hard as I tried, I haven't really had any fun playing. The game is difficult, in a way where you don't really get to feel angry about your decisions and in the end learn from your mistakes. Rather, you end up feeling like you're constantly out of luck.There are 2 phases in the game : exploring dungeons, and managing your party back in the town between adventures.In the dungeon is where the luck element gets into play, and that could be fine. But unfortunately, the state of your party degrades exponentially rapidly. So you need to be in excellent shape for more than half of the dungeon in order to have a chance at finishing it. It rarely feels like you barely make it out alive; you either die far from the end, or you clearly had incredible luck / too powerful a party for that dungeon's level of difficuly.Also, there are so many events and animations that I felt I was watching the game play against itself in fights. When it's finally your turn to do something, out of the 4 abilities each of your character has, there was rarely the feeling that some tactical thinking was in order. I would more or less select the offensive ones one by one, then hover above a monster to get an idea of the hit probability, then cross my fingers. There is not really any worthwile build-up of buffs, as they are not that good, and losing a turn buffing yourself is dangerous. Fights were not very exciting to me.Finally, when your party is surprised by enemies, your order is basically shuffled, which means some characters won't be able to act at all. You then need to spend one or more turn rearranging your positions, which is madenning since you don't know in which order your characters will act, and since they cannot always move to any given position in one go. All the while getting attacked, and not retaliating. Not very fun all in all.Meanwhile, in town, some design decisions made me wonder about the developer's intentions. For example, if you need to send a couple party member to the church or tavern for stress relief, you basically have to go in each building, figure out first which slots will be available to each character, which is not really fun. But then once you commit to a slot and pay, you won't get your money back if you need change your assignments. Since stress relief can easily cost more than 50% of your income, this is kinda frustrating. Please, just let me select heroes that I want to have a relaxing time, and show me options, instead of the manual, error prone and unfun assignment.Also, when preparing to delve into a dungeon, you need to buy supplies, but anything you don't use is not refunded or kept for another go. I do not really see the point in this; there is enough reliance on the random number generator in this game without having us wild guessing how much money should be wasted on items. This just leads to grinding for more money.Pros:  Great engine, great UI, pretty as hell  Great writing supported by even greater voice actingCons:  Difficulty stems from luck rather than tactics; I'm not sure I could get much better at the game  Frustrating design choices in the Town phase  Fun is not something I would describe this game as being. Not really frustrating either, just kinda boring :(

content:
Posted: April 11
												I came extremely close to refunding this game, but I chose to write a review instead. Maybe I'll change my mind in the future, because I really did want to like the game. Art's nice. Atmosphere has a good dark gothic tone, and the gameplay tries to reflect that, but fails in my opinion.This game is a pseudo-Lovecraftian horror dungeon crawler where sanity/stress plays a part in your dungeon delving. My first experience with the game was relatively enjoyable, but game mechanics which at first seem interesting very quickly turn into obnoxiously tedious obstacles to actually enjoying the game. You gain a new affliction EVERY time you go into a dungeon because it's impossible to not get up to 100 stress for at least one party member and there's a good 90% chance you get an affliction from that. Only dodged it twice in three hours of play. And once that happens, your heroes start to think that skipping all their turns is a good idea and the entire game just becomes infuriating. Stress can only be removed by engaging in town activities, but OOPS, there's only one ♥♥♥♥ing slot per unless you spend 3 dungeons worth of heirlooms to upgrade it, and each activity costs 1000+ gold, so to de-stress all your heroes it takes all the gold you made on your last run as well. And you need to go on an expedition for those activities to take effect which means running with a second group, which is probably also already stressed, and collecting new afflictions for them as well. Gotta catch em all. Stress accrues at a rate far beyond the rate at which you can remove it, if you can at all. Most classes don't have an ability that removes stress, and the ones that do remove 6, and when you're already gaining stress every turn, and all your heroes are♥♥♥♥♥♥talking each other because that's a great mechanic, adding more stress, it's like♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in the ocean trying to abate the stress buildup, and all the while wasting turns on top of it. Saying that the stress system is more unbalanced than a one-legged elephant on stilts would be to put it lightly. You can't carry nearly enough torches to keep the light up for longer dungeons, and camping feels pitifully useless, especially when you've already gotten stressed AND YOUR CHARACTERS DENY HEALING ABILITIES. Stress is an interesting idea for a game mechanic. I like the idea, but not the implementation. Certainly not when it's completely unmanageable.This game does rogue-like wrong. There's no way to prepare for the things you'll face, or manage the problems your heroes rapidly accrue, and it all just snowballs downhill starting from the very first ♥♥♥♥ing mission. It's not challenging or complex, it's a slap in the ♥♥♥♥ing face for all your efforts, and then the game tries to tell you that you like it that way.♥♥♥♥ off. Don't buy this game. Especially not for the full price tag.

I'm going to give it a shot with some of the more egregious penalties removed, but I'm not really keen on doing missions that I spend a half hour on for characters I'm not supposed to care about.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was initially unsure of whether to get this game or not.  I was excited and nervous based on the reviews.  I'll summarize the important aspects of the reviews that I found positive or negative.Positive:1. The game is hard2. Your choices have permanent consequences (no redos)3. The game mechanics offer depth and a variety of play styles4. The atmosphere is awesome.Negatives:1. The game isn't so much hard as unfair (RNG) and tedious2. The changes that led to Corpses and Heart Attacks made it even more tedious without enhancing gameplay.Obviously, bought the game in spite of my fears.  I don't like tedium, so I figured I might turn off the most offending bits (corpses and heart attacks) but I'd try it with them first.Almost immediately, I lost a character to a Heart Attack and found the corpses annoying.  I recognized the heart attack was my fault and could be easily avoided, so I left it on, but turned off corpses.  Played for awhile, until I had level 3 heroes, went into a level 3 dungeon and got owned.  I realized at that point, however, that I had made a lot of mistakes, had learned a lot about the game, and generally (aside from that dungeon) had found combat kind of easy and tedious.  I was using the same skills over and over and didn't think I was playing the game very well (which was confirmed for me by that level 3 dungeon).I decided to start from scratch, w/ corpses on, and I like the game better as a result.  My heroes are happier and healthier, and I have more treasure.  A couple tips for enjoying the game:1. Corpses don't need to be destroyed.  If you have ranged weapons, sometimes you want to keep the enemy further away.  I would say it's about 50-50 on whether corpses make a battle easier or harder.  Sometimes they♥♥♥♥♥♥me off, but sometimes I'm glad they're there.  They certain helped push me toward utilizing more skills, which honestly helps you be better prepared for when your characters are knocked out of order (btw, prepare for that!)2. You either need to do one of the following  a) Read some guides.  Read up on the things you can interact with, what items you can use with them, etc.  Your heroes will be far less stressed and you'll get more loot.  b) Figure it all out yourself.  You'll need to treat some excursions as scouting missions (which they are...), interact in all sorts of ways with different objects, record the results, and don't hesitate to dispense with the broken husks of heroes who return to you, rather than wasting money repairing them.  This way takes longer, but can be fun.  This is true really for any new situation in the game....boss fights, etc.  If you don't read the scouting reports (guides) of others, you'll need to do your own scouting,  Your scouts will pay for your ignorance.Is the game perfect?  Of course not.  Is the corpse mechanic kind of silly?  Sure.  With or without corpses, there are silly aspects to the combat.  The combat is stylized, so it's going to be weird at times, you just need to learn the rules.  My biggest complaint, actually, is that the system of skills and characters is actually too flexible.  It would be cool if there were missions that required certain characters (4 Crusaders, for instance).  Well, maybe there are or will be...I have a lot more game to play.  However, if you're like I was and sitting on the fence, worried about tedium, then I recommend buying the game and giving it a shot.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												This game is very polarizing, some hate it, some (a lot more) love it.I count myself to the top of the pile, the people who have tried everything and seen everything this title has to offer. There is: A metric ton of atmosphere, 14 hero classes, 24024 possible party configurations, a truckload of trinkets, five regions, three difficulty levels, eight quest types, 11 bosses, some of which in multiple versions, enough stress for three generations of engineering students, heart attacks, bitter losses, sweet victories, bloodhungry dice, unspeakable abominations, the flame that lights your path, lessons of frustration tolerance and consequences of greed, unavoidable deaths, far more avoidable deaths, a psychologically challenging journey and, ultimately, ruin. If you are ready for all this, i dare you delve into this masterpiece of art, both dread- and beautiful. My final advice would be just to buy it. After two hours in the game you have essentially seen the vast majority of things that are in the game, literally. It will get much much harder later on, but it will stay the same gameplaywise. If you like what you saw so far  keep it. If not, refund.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has A LOT of potential, but falls very short of the mark. Let me give a quick synopsis of it. You are trying to reclaim your family's estate from dark forces. You recruit adventurers from the town to perform various quests, all involving adventuring in dungeons. You will have the ability to upgrade your party's skills and equipment, in addition to equip them with trinkets that can help or hinder them. There is a very diverse spectrum of character classes and builds that you can recruit, along with both positive and negative traits. Building a party of 4 adventurers whose skills benefit and support each other is key to adventuring successfully. While you adventure you will find treasure, trinkets, and "heirlooms". The latter of which you can use to upgrade the resources in the town to better support your adventurers. During your adventures your characters will not only take health damage, they will also gain STRESS. Varying factors can cause stress, everything from taking a lot of damage, enemy attacks, insufficient equipment, traps, other character's actions, your character's quirks, and even not enough lit torches. Having too much stress will cause your character to acquire quirks as they slip deeper into insanity, most of the ones you acquire will be detrimental, and hurt your character's performance, rarely will the quirk actually help them. In addition to quirks the characters can become diseased, further hurting (very very rarely helping) them. To remove the Stress, quirks, and diseases, you need to make use of the facilities in the town where the character will recover for 1 week in game (the time it takes to  perform 1 quest). Due to needing to recover from stress, diseases, or quirks you need to have multiple effective parties while the others recover. Where this game falls short:- In the dungeon there is no way to heal outside of combat other than a dubious "Camping" which is not always present and subject to the characters skill sets and quirks. You can eat food for 1 HP each, until the character gets full (3 or 4 HP total). This is next to useless as most enemies will eliminate that in one hit.- Negative Quirks and Diseases are acquired faster than they can be healed. Paying to reduce stress, and cure quirks and diseases can get VERY expensive, there is no way to keep up with it, you have to become resigned to having patchwork characters with annoying negatives.- Farming is disallowed. Finally have a party of decent heroes? Think you can run some low level dungeons to get some gold so that you can actually pay to cure and outfit them? No, too bad. There is a level cap, your heroes will utterly refuse to go on quests that are "beneath them". I can understand this, so that you don't farm until you are unbeatable. But one Levelled hero should be able to join a low level party.Basically if you don't mind completely random events trashing characters that you've put time into and become attached to, then this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 16 of 27 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												Darkest Dungeon is, at first glance, a great strategy game. You must assemble a party of four flawed (sometimes very flawed) heroes and descend into unforgiving dungeons full of traps, monsters and loot.Along the way, monsters will not only try to kill your heroes but will also spook and stress them out, pushing them over the edge. This could make your heroes "afflicted" (paranoid, masochistic, selfish...) and speed up your spiral of failure, or it might bring out the hero hidden in them and actually improve your chances. This mechanic in particular makes for some great moments: the slow, calculated combat builds up tension, which is then released all at once when a hero that you thought was a goner actually raises up to the challenge and turns legendary.This game has a great atmosphere. Everything from the art style, to the music, to the sound effects and the awesome, awesome narrator build a rich, scary and mysterious world. This isn't your standard fantasy fare - or rather, it is, but filtered through several layers of gothic horror and lovecraftian nightmares.The learning curve is great, at least in the beginning. Preparation is as important, if not more so, than combat tactics; the only way to know how to prepare, however, is to send heroes into dungeons "like lambs to the slaughter". This is fine at low levels, when you can easily get new recruits and toss them in. At higher levels, however, this builds into the game's fatal flaw.The highest level hero you can recruit is level 3, if you upgrade your hamlet properly. To have a chance at winning a Darkest Dungeon run, you need a party of four level 6 heroes. It takes about two quests for a hero to level up, and it takes about 30 minutes to complete a single quest. This means that, if your party of 4 level sixes gets wiped in the darkest dungeon, you must grind for THREE WHOLE HOURS in order to try again.This calculation does not consider weapon and skill upgrades, which you also need, and cost lots of money; this calculation does not consider recovery time, which your characters will probably need at least every two dungeons. So the three hours figure is a very conservative one.In addition to this, your party wipes can and will happen through no fault of your own. The very nature of the game, which makes it a great and unique experience at low levels, makes it so that the RNG will ♥♥♥♥ you up completely and relentlessly at the drop of a hat. All it takes is a small chain of bad luck and your three hours are gone.The developers have implemented a fix to this, in the form of 'Radiant mode', AKA easy mode. There's also plenty of mods that make the game less grindy. I still don't feel like I can recommend this game, because as it is, out of the box, 'Darkest mode' (which is the one most players will start with) is fundamentally broken and not fun in the long run, no matter how 'gud' you 'git'.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								An excellent game designed for people who enjoy procedurally created content, turn-based combat, and interesting team management systems.  An absurd amount of replayability and fun is to be had here.  Don't listen to the WoW-kids and their complaints about the game being "too random", or "too hard", etc.  This game is not designed to spoon-feed you with easy and expected dangers.  Instead, the dungeons are realistic in that they are unforgiving and you never know what will happen.  This game is about managing risk, the health of your heroes, mission costs, and the all-too-real problems associated with things not always going as planned. Similar to other team-management, mission-centric games (i.e., like X-Com, Dungeon of the Endless, etc.), this game shines.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												A lot of reviewers have already said what needs to be said.The voice acting, the game's story, the game theme, all of it is very high quality. However, the game artificially lengthens its playtime by throwing too many punishing mechanics against you, with too many random elements.As one example of a problematic random element, nailing a critical hit is massively damaging, and while it can feel satisfying for your group to instant kill a target from a lucky dice roll (along with cool narrative from the narrator), the enemy can do the same to your characters (especially with chained criticals), which strips you of any tactical defensive options you'd want to employ. For this reason, it's not really a question of "if" a character will die, but "when" the character will die. You can't get too attached to your characters like you do in X-Com in Ironman mode, for example, thinking there's a chance they might survive. You actually have to grind parties to their death over and over and over and over again until you amass enough gold to upgrade your town to the point that you can then begin creating an endgame group (or try to) after another long grind of amassing wealth with suicide runs.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
Darkest Dungeon SummaryDarkest Dungeon is at it’s heart more than just a rogue-like RPG. It’s a tale, a story, an epic if you will. Becoming attached to your characters cannot be helped and only makes those final blows much more painful to witness. You cannot go wrong with Darkest Dungeon, and here’s why!The GameplayDarkest Dungeon gameplay is slow and methodical, but that does not make it stale. Oh no, the gameplay is as staunch as the droves of monsters you’ll slay. To rush your decisions will lead your party to suffer both mentally and physically. It’s unforgiving, and you’ll probably throw a few cusses at the screen but it’s part of the experience. Gameplay Verdict: This is a turned-based strategy gem, and you’ll see that the moment you step into the abyss.Gameplay Score: 9/10The User Interface & MechanicsControls are simple, and actions are responsive. It’s a very well designed UI with enough depth to achieve what you want without feeling overwhelmed by navigation. You can literally play the entire game with just a mouse, unless you wish to name your characters after family members (not recommended). The mechanics are refined and definitely don’t lock you into one way of playing. There’s plenty to do and plenty to play around with. Who knows, you might find the next best party lineup!User Interface & Mechanics Verdict: When you remember that this is a Kickstarter game still in Early Access then you will realize why this score exists.User Interface & Mechanics Score: 9.5/10The Graphics Amazing enough to warrant the purchase of an art book. It’s orginal, somber, and macabre, but warm enough to set it apart from other dreary titles. It takes you back, draws you in, and provides more than enough character and emotion while remaining true to the art direction. Nothing seems out of place, and at the same time everything feels otherworldly.Graphics Verdict: Lovecraftian visuals like you’ve never seen them...but always wanted to.Graphics Score: 10/10The StoryA solid foundation for a rogue-like game, and more than enough narration and backstory to keep you invested. The story is not the focus, but will provide you with everything you need to understand the world and characters.The Story Verdict: Comparing the title to other games of similar genre(s), Darkest Dungeon actually stands out.The Story Score: 8.5/10Replayability Very high! There’s tons of upgrades (both town and character) and lots of trinkets to be found, if you stay alive long enough to make use of them. On top of that, there are currently (as of writing this) three distinct areas with different enemies and randomized dungeons. Add mods into that mix, like my three here, here, and here to multiply that replayability!Replayability Verdict: More than most games, honestly, especially with the wonderful modding community!Replayability Score: 8.5/10Overall VerdictLovecraftian art, a Serling-esque narrator, refined gameplay, and devoted devs; Darkest Dungeon is perhaps one of the most original titles ever made, and I have a passion for it. No area of the game is left unpolished, which says a lot for an Early Access title. I will continue to enjoy this game for an endless amount of time as it offers both an immense amount of replayability, depth, and challenge.Overall Score: 9/10

number of helpful: 46 of 85 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7
												TL;DR It's too frustrating to be fun. You're at the mercy of a dice roll regardless of good planning and decisionmaking.  Any progress you make is like driving a fuel inefficient car down a seemingly endless road with no gas stations. You know you're going to peter out eventually, it's just a matter of time. It makes you wonder why the hell you wasted your time with a doomed quest.The good: Interesting character classes and all of them are useful. Great art, great atmosphere with a heavy heaping of hopelessness. The narrator is great, adds a ton to the game.The Bad: The afflictions and the cures for them are exhausting in every sense of the word to try to keep up with. They're expensive, they keep that particular character out of the action so they cannot gain experience, and they can leave you without key party members. The combat is passable, but ultimately it's a roll of the dice whether or not you hit. With the game already having so much random crap it would really be nice if the core mechanic was not determined by luck. Player agency is a real problem. You commands to the characters become suggestions, especially when they become too stressed and fall into despair.     The stress is a separate affliction and everyone gets it over time. That can also force your characters to be held up in town so they can de-stress.      I've also had characters who have been in town for a week ( I didn’t select them for my party, but they had nothign wrong with them so there was no point sending them to do an activity) suffer penalties. That's right, by trying to save money, your character can get a debuff seemingly at random. You're punished for giving your characters a break.     Just about everything is determined by random chance.The caravan, the way you can hire new characters every week, is also random. So when you need a front line character, you could get 3 backline characters that came in on the caravan instead.      If all of that wasn't bad enough, you can't even take your higher level characters into lower dungeons to help out your low level characters. They will refuse to go. And you cannot use your characters abilities outside of combat. So you could be walking around with one of your party members an inch from death and your healer cannot help them until the next fight starts, unless you want to dump a bunch of your food into that character and potentially starve your party later and stress them all out, which is going to cost you a lot of money.There's more, but ultimately all of this makes it feel like you can never quite get a leg up and you're always sinking just a little deeper, all the while the challenges keep getting greater and your resources aren't keeping up. It’s not an enjoyable experience. I play games to unwind and have fun. I enjoy challenges, but this is like drilling into a steel vault with your d*ck.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Having now surpassed over 150 hours on Darkest Dungeon (~40 in EA, ~110 since full release), it's long overdue for me to give this game the praise it deserves.  Simply stated, I would rank this in my top 10 games of all time - it's truly a phenomenal piece of work, and for anyone who's a fan of tough, turn-based RPG combat, you really need to buy this game. The good stuff:- The game's aesthetic; fantastic art, in a very gritty, dark style that sets the tone perfectly- Really cool music that uses some unusual sounding instruments; yes, I bought the OST DLC for this one- A turn-based combat, roster management style game that never lets you coast.  In fact, the difficulty ramps up pretty steadily, and on the top level missions one slight error in judgment could easily get that high-end hero you sank tons of gold into permanently killed- Nice variety of mission length, perfect if you sometimes only have a short while to play, but with longer missions that can last up to a couple hours- Cool variety of characters, all with unique skills, and all of whom can be used in many different ways depending on how you develop them- Some of the coolest bosses in any game, ever (Formless Flesh is truly the stuff of nightmares!)Guess I have to find something bad to say about it, too...?- Could definitely seem like a grind to some....and in a lot of ways it can be, but if you're (red) hooked on this game you won't care- The lack of anything to do with the currency you use to improve your town after you've puchased all the upgrades; maybe let us trade it for gold, or find something new to use it for once the town is maxed?Fans of dark, Lovecraftian fantasy or anyone who enjoys a challenging, turn-based RPG dungeon crawler, do yourself a favor and get this game.

												When a game opens up with a disclaimer saying "This game is about making the most out of a bad situation. You will die, you will loose heroes, you will abandon expeditions, you know exactly what your getting into. This is by far, a very fun, challenging unique RPG. You know the developers did something right when you putting along in a dungeon and all is going well, too well. And then it happens. The train wreck, and all you can do is sit back horrified as the whole thing goes to pot within seconds as your party starts to tear itself apart from the inside out as they can't manage their stress, and the monsters keep on their relentless onslaught.It’s not just about managing HP (although, that’s a part of the equation). It’s managing the party. It’s managing their stress. It’s managing the torch. This is a really unique spin on a dungeon crawler. Two thumbs up.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												 Let me start off by saying that Darkest Dungeon scratches a certain itch.  The itch to grind to be specific.  That being said this game is not for the faint of heart.  Darkest Dungeon will reward you with one hand and slap you across the mouth with the other.  Early on it is evident that not everyone will be able to survive.  The ones that manage to make it to the higher levels seem to have earned some level of respect in the later game.  Which makes losing them all the more painful.  Losing a couple level ones is a sacrifice you are willing to make, but a max level character with about 150000 gold in training and rehabilitation, that really hurts.  My only advice is to use straight Darwinism, it sounds cruel, but in the end only the strong will survive.  Great game.

												When a game opens up with a disclaimer saying "This game is about making the most out of a bad situation. You will die, you will loose heroes, you will abandon expeditions, you know exactly what your getting into. This is by far, a very fun, challenging unique RPG. You know the developers did something right when you putting along in a dungeon and all is going well, too well. And then it happens. The train wreck, and all you can do is sit back horrified as the whole thing goes to pot within seconds as your party starts to tear itself apart from the inside out as they can't manage their stress, and the monsters keep on their relentless onslaught.It’s not just about managing HP (although, that’s a part of the equation). It’s managing the party. It’s managing their stress. It’s managing the torch. This is a really unique spin on a dungeon crawler. Two thumbs up.

number of helpful: 60 of 112 people (54%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I know people will just vote this down without reading it, but I really don't care.Darkest Dungeon is not a game I can bring myself to recommend, but I still find it to be an incredibly earnest videogame on the merit of how much effort went into making it -- at least as far as general production goes. The visual polish is incredible, even though it lacks variety. The core ideas are very interesting and some choices were good, such as the ability to leave a dungeon at any time to prevent loss of recruits, at a cost. The narrator is amazing and the addition of a section in the options menu which lets the player toggle certain systems such as corpses was a very good decision.That said, while this breaks my heart to say, this is easily one of the most disappointing games I've ever played.As it stands, progression-wise, Darkest Dungeon's design is very akin to your standard mobile game. Perform task, then perform task again, then perform same task again. As you do this, your funds may rise and you may inch yourself closer to... Whatever objectives the game throws at you. At its core, the game asks you to pick a party, throw the party into a dungeon where they'll hopefully succeed. After this, the player will receive funds in return for a good performance, promptly wasting said funds recovering party members from basically unavoidable mental injury and funding the next expedition's quasi-mandatory set of supplies. This will / may leave the player with a very, very small margin of profit. Since money is so important to progress, half of the game will feel like a constant grind to stay just above debt. Losing out will often imply a huge scuffle just to recover from debt. Running out of funds will almost always mean the player will be losing recruits or a great deal of time just to get back on the treadmill, let alone back to progressing.The core design doesn't help this. I love turn-based RPGs and I particularly love tough ones. My favourite RPG series ever is Shin Megami Tensei, for example. The difference is that, in those games, the player has more going on that they don't feel like all they're doing is fighting. That's more or less what I felt while playing this. I fight, then I fight some more, and then I fight a little bit more, and in the end I hope that I made slightly more money than I wasted. I'd also like to add that for a game whose narrative is based around eldritch horror, it certainly is pretty safe with its monster designs. Combat-wise, each and every enemy encounter feels designed specifically to kill or maim the player's progression as fast as possible. Some enemies are dedicated solely to inflicting large amounts of stress damage and they're often protected by beasts with over-inflated health bars and sometimes even spells to protect other members from direct harm. On paper this might sound alright, but in practice, since practically every move a player makes is subject to RNG, it's hard for the player to feel like they can control their fate.The game is too reliant on dice rolls and that's fine, in theory. However, the enemies are not under the same pressure that the player is, so they can easily form all-out attack parties and stack debuffs on your recruits because losing their ranks doesn't matter. They are more-or-less subject to the same kind of dice roll the player is, so to some players that might feel fair. But since the AI has no sense of self-preservation, they can easily throw themselves at your party until it breaks.This would also be okay, would it not be for the overwhelming odds. The developer has gone on record to state that they wish this game to feel like the player is constantly in a bad spot. I understand this mentality, but I think it didn't work out for them.The game becomes grueling to the point of frustration and tedium -- where things happen completely outside of your control and you're somehow being asked to feel responsible for something you couldn't possibly prevent. It's like saying you worked hard to win the lottery.This is one example of a new genre I call "Badge of Honour" games. Games which live and die through unfairly punishing design and are extremely contingent on clicking with the audience -- being able to say you've "beaten" Darkest Dungeon will become a badge of honour and very few people want to admit they won because they got lucky, so it creates this aura about it wherein the audience is divided by "people who got good", and "people who don't get it". Plainly, I disagree both of these are the case, so I don't feel the game should be recognized in this manner. There's nothing quite as infuriating as knowing a game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and yet being told it was intended. I'm sorry, but I can't possibly recommend Darkest Dungeon. There are those who say people like me "didn't get it", but I'm sorry. I systematically play bullethell games, I've done challenge runs in games like Contra and Megaman and I often engage in challenge runs in more modern games like Dark Souls or Bloodborne. I do get 'punishing but fair', and this is CERTAINLY not it.Seen as I'm told all of this was intended, I'll make sure to not recommend this. I can forgive awful balancing work and poor overall design due to inexperience, but if this was the vision the creator had, then they'll have to accept those consequences -- ironically.Did I enjoy my time with Darkest Dungeon so far? To some extent, sure. And I'll be playing more of it. That said, I am fully aware that this is a game a lot of people will not enjoy for this price.Once the price drops to 5€ or thereabouts, I'll edit my review. Until then, again, I'm sorry, but at this price, a glorified mobile turn-based badge of honour game isn't worth your time or investment. I've said this before and I'll say it again: Videogames are a past time. Designing a videogame explicitly to make the player feel like crap on a constant basis is counterproductive at best, and just plain stupid design at worst.If you're not convinced, then I would highly recommend downloading the Lighter Dungeon mod and then going into the game's files and adjusting the parameters to better fit your criteria. Bumping down the cost of supply items can go a long way toward making the experience bearable at best."These terrible creatures can be killed; they can be beaten!"Sure thing, narrator. If I'm lucky enough.
