content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												The good: It's challenging, if you're into that. Most of the classes seem well thought through (not sure I see enough benefit in the Antiquarian or the Abomination, but maybe that's just me.) It is very replayable, in that it is basically a RNG-fest with a lot of grinding at the core. If you enjoy it, the cost per hour will be really low. Has sort of a Lovecraftian vibe.The bad: Doesn't satisfy my explorer urge at all. The dungeons are basically RNG-generated graphs and have no interesting unique content. There is really no story here worth mentioning. I suspect how you feel about this could be predicted by how you feel about rogue-like games. I find them boring; if you are into them, you'll probably enjoy this more.Mechanically, It's an unforgiving game of tactics and LOTS of grinding to level up fighters. I thought maybe there were plateaus and the mechanics would open up in some interesting way at some point, but not so far. I think I'm done with this game. (I'm still a long way from the end.)It's ALMOST a game I could like, but at the end of the day, there is way too much tedium and way too little joy for me to want to play this game. It kind of rolls up some of the things I've liked least about D&D dungeon crawls (poor survivability of heros, no real sense of hero's journey, boring resource management) up into one package. If you like games like that -- and I know people who do -- this might be your game. If, like myself, you favor exploration, story, and unique content, well, this probably isn't going to do it for you.

Posted: July 5, 2016
												+ Lovecraft Themed game with concepts like sanity and various creatures from his novels.+ Cool classes to experiment with.- Overdose on RNG: sanity/virtue just becomes unmanagable screwing your party over.- You cannot heal between battles nor can you keep your unused supplies.Those two negetives alone will just have you going through an endless cycle of sending groups out just to get slaughtered and lose money. The only viable way to "get good" at this game is either to get lucky or send endless suicide squads just to earn a little bit, making the game about spending hours of grinding over rewarding diffculty though speaking of which.- Torches are your difficulty.This seems initally like a cool concept: more light = advantages, but less loot and vice versa. However, why could there not be any optimization at all for  the difficulty for this game? I'm not the only one whose played this game and realizes the curve for this game is as hard as eating a rock, yet theres nothing you can do about it but "get good"? But in the end, unless you're a masochist who loves dealing with being at the whim of a sadistic RNG system I would avoid it.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												A dark, turn-based dungeon crawler that will test your ability to manage a group of adventurers in an attempt to purge the evil underneath your ancestor's manor.  The game pulls most of its inspiration from Lovecraft, so expect your characters to go insane in addition to dying horribly.  No, really, you probably do not want to name characters after people you like because either A) they will die or B) they will get so messed up that you kick them out.  Do note that there is a lot of RNG involved--if you cannot handle randomness, you might want to look elsewhere.Pros:Fantastic narratorGreat theme and implementationAnimations are quick but showInsanity mechanic is well fleshed outBosses are well-designed and horrifyingCons:Not all party member classes feel well balancedRNG can be a turnoff - sometimes feels like difficulty is artificial due to evasive enemiesWeapon and armor upgrades feel a little bit underwhelming

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I have a feeling that people who complain about the game being "unfair and random" are just not very good at it, and can't accept that sometimes you WILL lose and people WILL die, because you can't savescum. The game is challenging and fun to play, moreover it has an amazing visual and audio design, it oozes atmosphere all the time, and the addition of the narrator (oh my god his voice is so good) was a great idea.I have never felt like I was presented with a challenge I couldn't overcome, even later in the game when the dunbgeons are supposed to be "impossible" and "unfair". They really aren't. you just can't go in blindly and expect to win with every team. Figure out what works and what doesn't in each dungeon, design your team accordingly. Sometimes you will get screwed by dice rolls, sure. But it's part of the course, just as it is part of the course in games like Xcom, it's all about minimizing the risks. If one bad dice roll puts you in the losing position, you are doing something wrong.The game is hard and mean, and is not going to cut you any slack. The last dungeon is a huge difficulty spike, but it's nowhere near impossible. It's (again) all about figuring out what works and what doesn't, if you keep bashing your head against the wall, maybe it's time to rethink your approach, instead of going to the internet to complain?The game is awesome, but not for people who want to succeed every time they play, that's not how it works. If you can't tolerate the fact that the game has some random elements that work for and against you, then this is not a game for you.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Lots of people are leaving negative reviews because of the incredibly anti-player RNG they added a few patches ago. Recently, they added options so that the player can now choose their own difficulty regarding enemies critting or causing a certain amount of stress. I only got this game a few days ago and I am absolutely loving it thus far without tweaking any of these settings. I imagine the lategame is what people are complaining about mostly. From my perspective, 14 or so hours in, this game is fantastic. I love the random events that can happen and I like the high-risk high-reward system in the game. I love that in one moment my level 5 Occultist with 4 buffs on him at max HP will get one-shot by a tree branch in two enemy moves, but the next I make a really stupid risky move and get 3 incredibly rare and useful trinkets. The dumb things that happen in this game are hilarious, and losing is fun sometimes. Random town events are fantastic, too. Some people had a lot of complaints about grinding in this game (which I can understand is frustrating in a rogue-lite) but there are some events that will level up your idle characters no matter what level they are. Not having experienced the end-game RNG, I love this game to death, absolutely the most fun I've had with a turn based game for a long time. Hopefully the options they added last patch makes the game fun again for the experienced players.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								EDIT 6/21/15Keep in mind this review is from Early Access.With 50+ hours into the game, I have experienced most of the content the game has had to offer. Personally, I had to restart a save file two seperate times to get the ball rolling right. If you like games that punish you when you take the easy way, but reward you if you can adapt to the curve and dwell in the darkness, then this is the game for you. Here are my thoughts, the good and the bad:Pros:- Harsh gameplay mechanics (for those who like a challenge)- The art style and gritty aspects of the dungeons- The classes and the strategic combos you can set up with the various skill sets- High risk, high reward (generally)Cons:- RNG can definitely kill a good run and be frustrating at times- End game content is non-existent (early access)- Repetitive grind to advance your characters (Randomly generated dungeons get to a point of just being giant checker boards of doom)X The inability to sell relic trinkets, the inability to sell base upgrade resources (They have added the ability to sell trinkets)Overall this is a great game with great potential, hoping to see more updates soon! Personally, I only recommend the game as I have enjoyed my time playing it, but if you are looking for a title with more content to dig into you may want to pass until a beta stage, or final release.

												A lot of people have given this game a bad rep, mostly about its difficulty and the grinding. Darkest Dungeon IS grueling, its a trying experience. You have to be careful with your adventurers, and you have to cut your losses when you can. Victory is achievable, but you have to work hard for it and grind for it. The game is about flawed characters, Human characters, who can faulter under stress or due to some character traits, so you have to take care of them. The game isn't for everyone, this is essentially the Dark Souls of Tactical RPGs; the bosses are not the only thing you have to worry about, normal enemies can also be deadly. It's about learning, and working hard for your victory, and I appreciate that about Darkest Dungeon. Also the unique artstyle, brilliant music, and everythng about the game is great to me.

number of helpful: 20 of 35 people (57%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I think at some point people just forgot what fun was.This game is designed to be miserable. There's no payoff or any sort of interesting reward for thinking your way through missions. As you play through you'll gain more reward for finding exploits than thinking strategically. I'd say something about the atmosphere and narration, but any game where your characters WILL die from a lucky enemy crit is anti-narrative, no story can be based around a group that will reliably cycle out (without exploiting the game) every few hours. And no, it's not excused by being an early access.  It's literally a JRPG where your characters misery is a stat.  This could have been an interesting feature if stress was approached as a resource, used for spells, or used for the morally questionable goal of intentionally driving your characters insane. Here it's an in-game cash sink that tries to pointlessly humanize your boring dying meatsacks. This game may be popular, but it's got a long ways to go before it's good.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is one of the most atmospheric and engaging strategy games of this decade. I'm not telling you anything new if I repeat that its artstyle and the godly narration of Wayne June sets the mood perfectly to the point where even after over 150 hours the little "OBLIBERATED!" exclamation still makes me smile every time I bid my farewells to an enemy via critical strike. The voice over, the little barks of the heroes themselves and the brooding visuals make for a fantastic world to immerse oneself in. But the point I actually wanted to adress is that after the full release many reviews and players in the forums started complaining the game would be to hard now, and not just to hard, but to hard because of RNG - or bad luck. Players complain that the game wouldn't give them any chances for success and that's just wrong. There is more to the game then just the combat. You are the manager of this mess, you have to make sure your heroes are properly equipt for the job and you have to send the right heroes for the right job and only then will your commands in battle result in victories. The learning curve is laid out pretty well to do so. Sure, you WILL lose one or even a few heroes, but the game reminds you after every lost battle, fallen hero, or abandoned quest: You will learn from your mistakes. I played the game for about 100 hours right after the EA release, so when I started a new save I knew what I was doing. I managed to reach the final Darkest Dungeon without a single death and only retreating once because of a mistake I made, but which taught me a new boss mechanic I didn't knew about, so I won't be doing that♥♥♥♥♥♥again. Many people have managed this feat, which stands as a testemony to the fact that Darkest Dungeon is a beatable game, learnable and its chances are outplayable if you take your time to observe them. Then I started to go blindly against the Darkest Dungeon Quests. The first one went a little rough and I saw some questionable team choices at the end, but the second one destroyed me. I lost 3 out of the 4 Legends I sent. That's quite a bit of playtime down the drain and the game made me more than a little upset. I could feel the stress mechanic the heroes are going through in my own brain. I was mad, I was angry, but for the most part I way actually scared to go back in again. For the next three days I spent my time at work mentally preparing for the second assault on the second DD Quest. I pitted every possible team combination against each other in my head, weighted their pros and cons and when I went back in, I devastated the enemies. It was not even a contest. I stood no chance the first time, but after actually thinking about what I had to do and developing a strategy, I mopped the floor with eldritch blood. That's the point I want to get across. It's a strategy game. Use strategy. Use your brain. Don't just mindlessly grind. The game rarely gives hand outs and if you still want to take a calculated risk, think about all the times your risk-taking, your 90% chances, have worked out for you. It's a long game. It WILL bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥ given enough chances. Your job is to act like an adult and take responsibilites for those poor bits and bytes you just sent to your graveyard. If you really read up to this point: Get the game. You don't need a puzzle game to make use of your brain. Try yourself as the commander of misfits against the armies of madness.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a procedurally-generated, hardcore-difficulty dungeon crawler in which you lead teams of four heroes into the unknown dangers of ruins, forests and caves in a desperate attempt to get as much loot as possible without losing your sanity. And without having any of your party members killed, but that is somehow less likely to happen.In Darkest Dungeon, you are the heir of an ancestor particularly fond of playing around with demons, necromancy and other rather unholy things, whose last experiment basically screwed over the entire estate. It is now your job to explore the rotten lands, defeat unmentionable abominations and reclaim, piece by piece, what is rightfully yours. Exactly why are you doing that when you could just get the hell out of this nightmare-inducing land is beyond me, but hey, who am I to judge?To aid you in your quest you will have at your disposal heavy-quote-unquote "heroes", divided on 14 classes (15 with the last update), which you will send in teams of four into the depths in order to achieve randomly-generated objectives in randomly-generated dungeons, bringing back any shinies you find in the way to upgrade your little hamlet and supply your army of disposa- *cough cough!* ... rather brave henchmen and women.Some unique features while exploring the dungeons include a position-based combat system (in which the formation your party adquires is vital, since some attacks can only hit some positions, and some abilities require you to stand other ones for them to work), and the implementation of a second "health bar", which represents the hero's "stress". It always start at zero, and it slowly creeps up, skyrocketing when things are going bad for your party. Fill it completely once, and your hero will go nuts, giving him unpredictable behaviors for the rest of the mission. Fill it twice, and he/she will have a heart attack, intantly dropping their HP to zero and putting themselves "At Death's Door", a status effect for those without hit points left, in which any additional damage (including DoT) has a chance of putting you six feet under. By the way, permadeath wants to say hello.Despite the somewhat safety net the "At Death's Door" provides by not killing you instanly when your HP hits zero and some other shenanigans you can try to turn the tide in your favor, the game is heavily stacked against you. Many RNG-controlled events are ready to screw you over when you least expect it, and the game is unfair in general for the player, punishing the slightest mistake you make, and not giving you any get-out-of-jail cards at all. The freaking game tells you in the cover: this game is about being put in the absolute worst situation and trying to work your way out. Your favourite heroes will die while you hopelessly witness the result of your own recklessness. You will be slapped in the face, repeately, for no reason. Your hard work will be torn down before your very own eyes.The worst of all is that I absolutely love it. Perhaps I'm simply turning mad.+ The dark story, the gothic hand-drown graphics and the overall stress this game puts you under really all serve its purpose to ilustrate the hopeless situation the game is trying to illustrate.+ The unique battle system and some other features make dungeon exploration an absolute joy.+ Superb OST that will get you on edge.+ Despite your ancestor being, you know, dead, his spirit follows you around and acts as a narrator, of sorts, commenting on your actions. Let me tell you, this guy has some of the most badass lines of dialogue I've listened to, specially in battle. He definetely knows how to pump you up on a tight situation.- It is a very easy game to rage quit on. It's random and unfair nature can very well cause anger on both new and veteran players. Particularly infuriating are the enemy crit-rolling-sprees when your party doesn't seem able to land a ♥♥♥♥ing hit.- The game can get very grindy at times. If you lose your beefy lineup of mains due to stupid mistakes or too many bad rolls, you are pretty much left over with rookies that you have to level up again (with takes time AND precious gold) in order to take a shot again at late-game missions, or even the final boss.This game gets a well-deserved 8 out of 10. I feel like I'm still winning in the wall-head banging contest.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												It's hard to recommend this game. A lot of the base game elements are pretty fun, but the Random Number Generator...something is seriously wrong with this. It's so easy to enter a dungeon and lose without feeling like you did anything wrong. That's part of the game's theming, but well...for me it's just not fun. It bugs me that I can half♥♥♥♥♥a dungeon and get everything I need one day, then struggle just to survive despite playing fantastically the next.It doesn't help that the game seems a lot more random now than it was in Beta. Now theres a chance of triggering mini-bosses when doing certain things, like inspecting certain items for instance. I found someone called the collector who was, quite frankly, impossible to beat. He healed for 10 damage a turn and the only person in my party that could reach him at the back dealt 9 at most. What's more the rest of the party had to contend with constantly repleshing monsters that he summoned. I think this encounter sums up how I feel about the game - it's not fair. A game doesn't have to be fair to be fun, but this isn't unfair in any way that feels fun to me.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Since I am a massive XCOM fan I assumed I would absolutely love Darkest Dungeon and for the first few hours I did.The combat seemed deep and varied. There are so many character classes such that I have not used them all let alone try all possible permutations of a four adventurer party. Managing your hamlet is just as stressful as combat when deciding where to spend your hard earned resources. I opted to boost the strength of my party by focusing on the guild and blacksmith but every so often I had to throw some resources to help my adventures recover from all the horrors they had seen.It felt like I had a rich game that I was going to lose myself in for days.But after those first few hours I realized that I felt I wasn't making any real progress. Sure I had a few adventures at level two but I wasn't really making enough money to actually upgrade their skills and equipment. I also never seemed to be sending out the same party composition more than once. The stress would be too great or some malady was would afflict an adventure and they would have to miss a week of adventuring while I spent some gold healing them up. The caravan never really seemed to bring me much variety (could I please have more than one Arbalst?) so it forced me to put together so many patchwork party compositions because I just didn't have the ones I wanted to try. Also, every time I came back from a quest I didn't really have enough money to do any major upgrades to my characters such that I felt I was ready for the next challenge.It was at this time that I had realized I had already entered the grind of the game. I had only been doing lvl 1 short quests (either complete every room battle or explore 90% of rooms) and I was already at a point where I felt like I needed to grind for hours to make enough progress to even attempt the first boss of the game.But OK this is a hardcore game right? Maybe I'm just playing it wrong. I set myself a goal of attempting one of the first bosses, the Swine Prince, and I picked out a party that I thought would work well and aimed to get them to level two with level one skills and armor (since my guild or blacksmith was not upgraded enough to get everything to level two). I grinded for four more hours and got exactly what I wanted and equiped my party with the best trinkets I had, provisioned them to the gills and out I went. I explored the dungeon and didn't even need to camp before I scouted the boss's lair. It was at this point where things went completely sideways. I managed to kill the boss but I lost three of my four party members. All of that time and energy was gone without much to show for it. All the gold I got for beating the boss was essentially a moot point because I would need to spend it all again to upgrade new adventurers to have that same level of skill and equipment. With respect to the boss battle I felt like I could have retreated and gone back to the hamlet with my spoils. But I would have to spend a lot of gold to reduce the stress and afflictions they had acrued on the quest so it feels like it would have been a moot point.But again this is a hardcore game! I just gotta git gud! I mean I made progress right? Killing one of those first bosses means something does it not? Let's pick out a second boss and try again. So I picked out the Wizened Hag, put together a team, grinded for two hours to get them where they needed to be (some this time had level two armor because I finally got enough freakin' deeds) and set out into the dungeon. It went every much like the first where I got to the boss without needing to camp and I made my attempt. This time only two of my four adventurers died, although the other two came back with such high stress that they won't ever been quite the same.And so I am back again to where I was before I decided it was time to attempt my first boss. I have a stable of adventurers that are in no shape to make any attempt on the next boss let alone an attempt at a level three dungeon. None of my healers are above level zero since they've all died so I'll need to grind them up again. But I could do it. I could pick a boss, pick a party composition, grind 2-4 more hours doing the level one dungeons and make another attempt. Odds are I'll lose some adventurers again but thats a point of the game. How does a player deal with such great loss? To me though the grind is just far too obvious that it makes it much easier to just put down the mouse and keyboard and walk away. Its far too clear that I'll have to just grind the same dungeons over and over again, kill the same creatures and then go into another boss battle completely blind where I am likely to come away with some heavy losses. And after I kill all four of the starting bosses I'll be essentially in the same position as I was before with the exception of my hamlet being a little more upgraded. But at that point I'll have to do all of this over again for level three dungeons and I think that I need something else to pull me throught his grind.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												New Updated review:So after trying the veteran missions, I have found this game to be basically UNPLAYABLE!There is a major obvious flaw in a game when my heroes are causing 3-10 pts of damage after casting debuff spells on the enemy and buffed spells on themselves (using Man-at-arms and Occultist classes), while the enemy can causes critical damage or regular 10-21 pts of damage without using any of that on my heroes.This game is BROKEN at its current state of difficulty balance (if you want to play beyond the Apprentice level missions, but then again there is little reason to even try because Veteran and Champion level missions offer mostly the same enemies but just higher stats. The only reason to try is to see what the Darkest Dungeon levels are like). There are too many things stacked against the player, whether it is:1. Your player can get ♥♥♥♥ed up in so many different ways, whether it is a disease, affliction, or just being stupid enough to gamble away your trinkets during a visit to the tavern (yes happened to me)- There are two "health-like" stats for this game in my opinion. The regular health stat and then there is the stress level stat. You will be ♥♥♥♥ed if something happens to either one.2. You only have 16 slots in your inventory so you better be extra careful what to bring for medium to long missions. Don't waste space and money on a useless provision, which can cause you to not stock up on something useful like torches or food!- Also if you want to retreat from a mission, you don't get a full refund on your purchased provisions. So you end up losing the money spent on provisions.3. Everything is so expensive! Armor, skills, provisions, and healing and stress treatments all costs money.- Also some things cost more for higher tier heroes. For example, healing and stress treatments all goes up.So in order to prepare for the higher tier missions and progress the actual game, you must GRIND MORE LOWER TIER MISSIONS to collect enough money and upgrade your heroes.In my opinion:     DON'T BUY THIS GAME!       IT IS NOT FUN!!!      DON'T BE FOOLED BY THE NICE ARTWORK AND APPEAL OF "A REAL CHALLENGE"!------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Old review:I wanted to provide a fair and honest review of this game based on my overall positive experience. Even though, I am only at 40% completion, I feel that I have a pretty good grasp of the game mechanics and what else to expect before reaching the end.Pros:1. Great presentation, unique art/animation style, excellent soundtrack.2. Great use of hero character permanent death to build tension and suspense in combat.3. Unique and varied skill system that includes both offensive, defensive, and camping skills.4. Interesting upgrade system of characters and buildings based on looted gold and other resources. 5. Interesting collection of looted items/relics with both positive and negative perks which forces you to plan carefully and balance out the perks in tune your overall strategy. 6. Unique variety of enemies (based on 5 types of dungeons and 1 "common" type found everywhere) with different types of attacks, buffs and debuffs and requiring different strategies.7. Small inventory system (only 16 slots) which may seem like a terrible game flaw but actually poses another exciting challenge for the player in terms of forcing you to have careful resource management (ie. what items to bring into the dungeon and what loot to take with you).Cons:1. Limited variety of enemies/settings which makes combat feel repetitive. There are only 5 dungeons to explore. You will never leave the setting of this one particular manor and town. There are also 3-4 mission types per dungeon (ie. exploring 90% of the dungeon, killing all enemies, questing for 3 particular items, or killing the dungeon boss). However, again all dungeons have these 4 exact types of missions. In terms of enemies, there is one unique enemy group for each dungeon and a common enemy group that can be found throughout all dungeons. Overall, there is only around 30-40 total enemy types, including bosses (which feature about 5-6 types with 3 versions of difficulty). This may seem like alot, but gets boring when you run into the same enemies over and over and can use the same strategy everytime. 2. Annoying glitches where sometimes my screen froze but the music kept going. Luckily (or maybe not) the game uses a hidden, frequent autosave system so I never lost any progress when I was forced to exit the game. Other times, I noticed that the picture for interactive items or action animation would not appear properly and I would see a white box instead. This isn't too much of a problem because if I click on the white box, another pop-up screen will appear with the name of that particular item.3. No real character development or dialogue. I know this isn't a classic RPG game, but more of a dungeon crawler game.  However, you start to not care for your heroes when you don't know their story or thoughts outside of occasional comments in combat. This then negates the suspense and tension that you feel when a character is about to die.Overall:This is a great dungeon crawler-type game requiring a lot of strategy and planning before entering the dungeons. I felt that I was spending up to half the game time preparing for each mission (making sure I have selected the right set of skills, items, and tools for my squad of heroes) and it was worth it when I got my heroes out safe and sound. But after playing for 40+ hours, this game seemed to get repetitive because of limited character development, enemy types, and dungeon settings. A lot of other people have been commenting on the heavy grinding involved in this game and I have to agree. However, I am also the type of person to play very cautiously when there is alot of risk and random chance involved, so that aspect didn't bother me too much.This is a very impressive game from a small company and I would recommend purchasing it when on sale. I hope they make a sequel with more of everything!

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												A potentially great game stretched too thin for my tastes.I found that there are two challenges to this game; difficulty and the time it takes to get gold.  The former was enjoyably demanding, the latter was a chore.I enjoyed the first 30 hours but after accumulating 7 characters of final tier level I realised that in order for them to meet their full potential and have a good chance of beating the final dungeons they'd need to have afflictions removed, have good equipment and positive traits locked in.  Which takes money, LOTS of money.  Which means repeating dungeons, LOTS of dungeons, to the point of boredom.  I already felt slightly weary with the repetition when entering 30+ hour mark but carried on since I felt the end was in sight.  However, another 10 hours later, when I realised what would be required to complete the game, I felt like I was facing another 40+ hours - mainly grinding at lower level stuff.  It's a shame since there are so many cool things to do with the characters and so many classes to mess around with.   From experimenting with and increasing certain skill sets, to paying to permanently keep certain bonuses they have earned, it's an exciting prospect.  Doing this would really individualise them, add an extra layer of depth and greatly increase the RPG feel of it all but again, this costs money, TONS of money.  Cue even more grinding.Simply put, I feel this could have been a great 40-50 hour game but the constant halt in progress to get obscene amounts of gold to heal, cure and upgrade the roster is so time consuming the game ends up artificially increasing its playtime beyond my interest and desire.  I'm guessing they made this decision in order to 'double down' on the difficulty but I find testing people's patience through grinding isn't a fun form of challenge.Having said all that, if you pick it up cheap and get 30+ hours of enjoyment before repetition sets in then I guess that could be viewed as money well spent....just take into consideration that you won't finish the game in that time frame, beat the bosses nor see your characters and township reach their full potential.  Not even close. Whether that's a deal breaker is, of course, for you to decide.  If it isn't, then have fun :)

Early Access Review
								a group of warriors are walking in a Dungeon,the group consists of a Crusader,a Highwayman,a Vestal and a Bounty Hunter.their quest today is to clear out a dungeon in the Warrens,it's supposed to be a medium sized dungeon and it'll take no more than a day to clear it.everything seems to be going according to plan,stress level is low,our group is well equipped and *BAM*......a trap,the Healer is bleeding "it's ok a bandage will stop the bleeding"they walk a little bit more and they find some books lying round,The Bounty Hunter decides to take a look at one of the books and after a few seconds his stress level goes up like crazy,apparently he's read the most terrifying verse on the planet....nothing serious,a few drinks will wash the stress away after the quest is completedafter walking around countless Hallways and small rooms fighting demonic creatures our group finds itself in front of a large door...someone slowly opens the door,this room is different,it's bigger,darker and colder.there is a large object in the middle of the room,it's really dark so no can see it clearly,The group lights up another torch and decides to walk slowly towards the mysterious object. Crusader was trained to fight in the vanguard so he has taken the lead and acts as the party's Tank,Bounty Hunter is Behind him,scouting the corners to make sure there are no enemies in the room, Highwayman is following the 2 warriors with his pistol and dagger and Vestal is slowly walking behind him,she acts as the healer of this party and  protecting her is one of the party's main priorities."it's a chest" says the Crusader."no it's a trap" says the Bounty Hunter as 4 unholy creatures appear in front of them,no one knows where they came from but there is no time to discuss that,...yep,that's pretty much how it feels playing Darkest Dungeon,most of the time you don't know what's gonna happen(almost everything is random) and during the fights even one single move can save or kill your entire party.i wanted to write a little bit more about the fights,the town,the stress system and how it can drive your characters crazy and so many other things but i'm really tired right now :| :D"this is more like a first impressions and a fan fiction and is not an actual review,this game has a lot more to offer and i will edit this review in the future"

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												*some spoilers*I have to say......the negative reviews on this game kept me from buying it for a long time. Despite the fact that I think of myself as being quite good at turn-based strategy and RPGs, the long rants on RNGesus and about how people lost their entire party...that they sunk 20 hours into....from mechanics that they had no control over...in a few turns gave me pause. I first saw this game shortly after it entered 'early access,' but I didn't buy it until a few weeks after it was fully released.Well, now that I have beaten the game with the default settings, including all of the bosses, uninstalled it, and haven't looked at it for a bit, I want to return with, hopefully, a more impartial view. Unfortunately for those who are still complaining, about half of my impression of this game can be summed up with the question:Were those people playing the same game as me?*sigh*Before some enraged noobs start calling me a shill for the developers, let's be frank. This is supposed to be a hard game. It could even be argued that this is supposed to be "unfair." You are not supposed to be able to beat it without any characters dying on your first try. If you're going to rage every time a character dies, you better just uninstall right now. If I could really pinpoint what pisses people off here, it's that this game has a treasure trove of non-obvious game mechanics that it brutally punishes you for not fully grasping. Although...the ultimate irony could be that the combination of its difficulty with the asthetics makes me feel like the narrator is actually describing the gamers as much as the characters in some sort of snickering, 4th-wall-breaking trolling. To help explain the disconnect, let me summarize my own experience with the game a little. I didn't look up any tips on this game until about halfway through the campaign. I already had multiple characters at level 6, and I didn't have a single party wipe. Did some of my characters die? Yes, of course. Up to that point, I had about two characters die from the collector on separate occasions. I had about 2 random deaths, 1 character from the shambler, about 3 characters from the Hag, and maybe 2-3 characters from other bosses. I beat the level 2 Hag on my second try. I beat most other level 2 and level 4 bosses on my first try. After multiple failures on the level 4 Hag, I felt frustrated and finally looked up some tips. Basically, I read, "Don't hit the pot. Just priotize high back rank damage and bleed." After that, I beat the Hag on my next run with no losses. And, really, in my experience, that's what 95% of the complaints about this game amount to. Again, I'm not saying this game isn't difficult and/or isn't punishing, but people will continuously lament that RNG killed their party when, upon further inquiry, they killed their party. Sure, "git gud" has become a cliché, but seriously, some people just need to "git gud." People will rage that the collector is impossible when they didn't have any reliable DOT or stun. They'll say, "Antiquarian sux. What is she even for?" and "I can never make enough money." in the same post. Or, "The swine king is stupid OP," when they killed Wilbur. Or, "The houndmaster, arbalest, and occultist are all worthless. I typically run: vestal, highwayman, bounty hunter, and crusader in every region." Or, "Trinkets are barely even worth it. So, sometimes, I don't even use them." Seriously, once I had a lot of trinkets, I NEVER went on a run without full trinkets. Even cheap common trinkets are extremely helpful. Is this person playing the same game as me? These aren't hypothetical posts; I've seen all of these at one point or another. You can read most of them right now in the negative reviews. And this is just the tip of the iceberg.To be fair, I do think it took too long to make money before; too much grinding was needed to make up for the loss of a high level character. However, I believe that has been resolved. I completed half of the game before they patched bonus rooms, and I was on the verge of assaulting the Darkest Dungeon before they added antiquarians. Grinding has become a lot more rewarding with the later patches. And additionally, I am indeed the type of person that beats Civilization on the hardest mode by micromanaging all of my workers and explorers. I am a very patient gamer, and I don't rush into things. I actually enjoy studying my party for extended periods of time, pondering whether one party synergy is better than another, checking whether I have reliable stun, guard, heal, DOT, etc. If you're the type of gamer that requires constant adrenaline and jumps into things without thinking, this game will grind you into dust.By the time I finished the game, I could beat any level 1 or lvl 3 dungeon while asleep. I focused on grinding lvl 5 dungeons for money because I could beat any normal lvl 5 dungeon without anyone even reaching 100 stress over 90% of the time. I had one party wipe my entire time playing this game, and it was intentional! I sent a party of noobs into the Darkest Dungeon just to check what it was like and to get the achievements. It doesn't matter if they die because they're free. My first time experiencing a heart attack was in the second Darkest Dungeon, when the game was almost over. You know what goes through my head when I run into the collector? Yay, more loot. I'm sorry. This will sound rude, but if you can't consistently beat any lvl 5 dungeon or the collector without someone dying, you're just bad. If you can't beat most bosses on the first try or at least second try, you need to learn what you did wrong and try again. If you repeatedly experience party wipes and heart attacks, you need to be more open-minded, be more flexible, be patient, and play smarter, because you're just bad. Now, you can make all kinds of excuses. You can say, "not everyone is as OCD as you, butter," and that's true. You can say, "the amount of effort that it takes to achieve those kinds of results makes the game not fun." That is a subjective statement, and I don't care. I had fun. Furthermore, do I need to point out the irony of saying you don't enjoy putting in the effort to beat a game that is supposed to be hard?Whatever you think about the RNG and whatever your excuse is, if I replayed this game right now, it would be a piece of cake for me. If you don't share that opinion, you're not as good as I am.So, git gud, son.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												I just want to start this review by saying to give a little time dilation for those of you paying attention. I bought my copy of this game waaaaay back when, at the same time as I got Hand of Fate. Tried to play it a couple of times, had a really hard time getting into it. Big part of the reason was how early the game still was back then.Flash foreword to now. I couldn't sleep the night before last so I decided to start playing something on my laptop, thought of this awesome game that I never touch/could seem to get into. 24 hours later, I'm super into it, finally seem to have a good sense of how to play the damn thing. It's really simple once you get a hang on things and not nearly as painful as it used to be. If anything I think the game developers reduced the difficultly just slightly enough to make the game approachable. For those who don't know what the game actually is. You play the son of a man driven to insanity of Eldrich (read Love Craft/ Cuthulu) heights, as he plundered the deep dark arts and catacombs of his own estate. After which he eventually took his own life. Which he leaves as your duty to now finish what he started! Oh goody for you! So how does one go about doing this you ask? Well, he built this Manor on top of a hill behind a city named Hamlet. Here, over various levels, which are handled as hubs that increase in difficulty as the game progresses. You take four of your hired help to crawl through dungeons, fighting terrible beasts of the uncommon variety, pillaging artifacts that help you unlock more abilities for your heroes (and heels) and buildings in town use them as upgrade currency. It's a fun little game. I can see why some people think it's "too much" but really, take my word for it, be patient, do what the game tells you to do and you will get the hang of it and boy is it rewarding to get good at this one! Dark Souls still your beating heart, my dear fellow. Graphically I find the game to be gorgeous. It’s not like you need a powerful computer to run it but man it looks so stylish in action, sort of in a, how cool Sin City was the first time you ever saw that film’s style, sort of way.Also, totally worth the 20 dollars through and through, you will not be simply breezing through this one. You’ll get your money worth. I recommend this game to people who like Binding of Isaac, on a couple of levels… I see a lot of negative reviews at like 90 hours in and let me tell you something. In my book, a game that gets you to spend 89 + hours on it before calling it quits must have been doing something right. Right?    I have a copy of StarDew Valley that I put around 65 hours in easy. I randomly stopped playing it one night and haven't felt the need to go back since. Why, you ask? Because, I saw most of what there is to offer, but for a game that only cost me five less then this one, that's a lot of game time. And let me just say this again, part of what makes this game so tense is the fact that unlike Demon/Dark Souls where you might loose an hour here and there, in this game you might lose a character you love forever. I get it. I totally get it. Love hurts. But sometimes it's good to learn how to also let go and let live. I love this game and if you can get over loosing a few (more like a football team by the end, I'd imagine) you'll like it too!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Genuinely surprised at how salty people are over RNG, and how negatively received many positive user reviews are. The only real flaw with the RNG is that you can go hungry several times in the span of minutes, which does not reflect any reason or logic conceivable. Missing several times in a row is possible, getting critical'd over and over is possible, starving after every other battle is not. Despite that, Darkest Dungeon is a better example of coping with stress, death and the inevitable randomness of despair life offers than most games in recent history. People say this game is more fun as an "experience" rather than a game with fair rules or challenges, and they're completely right. Darkest Dungeon is unfair in a way to remind you that life is unfair, a trait that most games lack for the sake of defining "balanced combat engine" as "let me beat the game". Darkest Dungeon is not about winning. Darkest Dungeon is openly and intentionally a stress simulator.The skills this game really tests you at aren't traditional video game skills like timed dodges and attacks, but psychological skills like patience, diligence and mental composure. It's not about a win-state as much as it is about learning how you react to struggle and adversity, and learning to make the best of it. It teaches you the difference between victory and diligence, each one its own virtue and reward. If you can't handle that, go play an easy game like Minecraft or Dark Souls.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												The atmosphere in this game is amazing. If you like Lovecraft you'll love this game. Friends I have who don't generally like turn based RPGs still like this game. Combat is fast and action packed. When you press attack you get immediate satisfaction. Skills and heroes are varied and so are bosses (8 bosses + 2 mini bosses + final mission mini bosses and bosses).RNG is utilized to its fullest to make every dungeon potentially dangerous and to keep tension up. You can never feel completely safe and the awesome narrator will remind you of this. A couple of crits in a row can totally tun the battle around, be it to your favour or detriment. In tense fights when your hero gets stresed out but become vigorous rather than afflicted (strong buff rather than severe nerf) you can feel the stress relief yourself.I see a lot of negative reviews focusing on the length of the game calling it a "grind". Let me compare it to a soccer game: In those games you can usually change the length of a match and usualy also the number of matches per season to fit different players. You can't do that in this game but you wouldn't call playing matches in a soccer game a "grind", after all that's what you bought the game to do.Beating a dungeon takes around 30 min. Beating the final boss (ie completing the game) takes around 60 dungeons. 100% completion (except the 104 weeks achievement) takes around 90 weeks and you have to beat the game once first (to unlock "new game plus"). Is this too long? It is of course up to personal preference. I think there's plenty of content to justify 30 hours. Heck, I'm still playing it after 150 hours and that's excluding all the time I played during the alpha. Just like in many sports games the management aspect is not very big. It is all about dungeon runs. If you don't like doing dungeon runs you should not buy this game. Some peole continue to go into dungeons even after they have beaten and upgraded everything just for the fun of doing them. About 4% of players have made it to week 104 (104 dungeon runs in a single game).Some people list money management as a negative. I actually think it is a positive. Having a lack of resources adds to the tension and it forces you to take risks. Do you go for that last treasure chest? Do you dare bringing a high stress hero into the dungeon in hopes of removing it for free with hero skills? It of course punishes those who refuse to (or can't) learn money and risk management, but since there is only one difficulty setting you can't satisfy everyone. Some people will find this aspect too easy and some will find it too hard. There's no vac ban for cheating though and you can mod the game to be easier too if you want.

Early Access Review
								This 2D turn based RPG is one of the best surprises to come out of early access in a very long time. The fact that it came out already a good game is something of a godsend in the sea of unfinished products that we seem to be getting more and more off lately. Having your heroes and a town you slowly upgrade and bring into their own is a very good feeling, as you always feel like you are doing some amount of good at least.However a game is not without its flaws as the game doesn't really progress all that much, though it takes a heck of a long time to feel it since you need to constantly have the same heroes. Another problem I found is a slight lack of attachment to the heroes, as they may all have their own drives and wants, but... They hardly ever stick around long enough for you to attach to them and soon you become appthetic to their deaths "Oh well another one for the corpse pile" And that just shouldn't be in my opinionOverall a lovely game and well worth the money.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Darkest Dungeon is a treat. The game itself is great, but the developers are rockstars. Frequent updates, problems quickly addressed, community input is considered but doesn't stop them realizing their vision. So what is that vision?Darkest Dungeon is a game about stress, glory, and adventure. Your goal is to reclaim this manor from the horrors discovered below it. And you will do so with pure management, dungeon diving, and perhaps a few trips to the brothel, pub, church, and asylum. You will care about your adventurers, because only so many will consistently gain good traits. You will care more becasue any worth keeping will need care to have bad traits removed and stress reduced. You will still care about losing bad adventurers because you need every one in a run to have a shot at getting the loot at the end.The game is RNG heavy, and it gets some bad press for it, but don't listen to the whiners, just do your research beforehand to see if it is for you. Any game with rogue-like or rogue-lite elements has RNG elements, and any game with RNG elements is about overcoming adversity. Just keep in mind this isn't a linear game with a carved out path and progression curve. This is a game that will try to kill you(r adventurers,) and you will try to conquer it. Sometimes this can result in a bit of tedium or grind, so don't be afraid to mix up your playstyle.The enemies are varied and fun to deal with. Some are very stressful as they are currently, but again, that's a PART of the fun of a game like this. You will still see the same mobs a lot, but it's like meeting an old friend, the fun sticks because of having to deal with them in different combinations and formations. Also, you can be surprised and have your party shuffled about, and they could be surprised and you get a free turn. So this game likes to encourage mixing things up, experimenting, and at its core, is very much a management game, but still seamlessly blends in dungeon crawling, and rather beautifully at that.The art style is refreshing and fun, for me. I love the aesthetic, and between it and the sounds, it sets the tone well. It's not lavish, it's not hyper-detailed, and it isn't supposed to be. It's supposed to be vague and dark. One thing I can say though, is if the screenshots don't impress you, there's a chance the art will still work its magic on you while playing. The little bit of motion, the way everything ties together, and the feelings associated with trudging through the dungeons personally can add a lot of impact.This game has depth, accessibility, polish, great devs, good art, and great sound. It's a wonderful offering, even with a few shortcomings or the stress of RNG, and I wouldn't be surprised if the devs address that, too.The best part is, while what's there is so well put together, there's still more to come!

number of helpful: 121 of 230 people (53%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												The constant RNG will test your patience, not your skills.The game's presentation is really good and charming in a macabre way. The stress system really keeps immersed in an hostile enviroment of people going mad and unholy monsters lurking in the dark. But when it comes to actually -play- the game a few glaring issues comes up.In order to make the game difficult and "hardcore" the developer have turned to cheap tricks which only function is to frustrate the player, not making it enjoyable or rewarding. Granted some of those -can- be turned off but nothing is beign done about the elephant in the room: The RNG system.You will often go in with a completely leveled and geared group, and lose them to weak monsters you shouldn't be losing to. Because all of sudden you are missing the shots and they are spamming critical hits. No warning, no chance to react and you will most likely fail to flee the battle and even if you do, your adventurers will need to recover stress and diseases for a long time. You lose your main characters and now you are stuck with "the rest" of your roster in a phase of the game where everything does triple the damage they did at the start. Leveling from scratch in there will be a pain because your adventurers get stressed and needs constant attention. You will eventually recover, sure, but you will not be progressing anytime soon and once you get a new team ready to go, they die again. And again. For reasons outside your control or skills. A dice rolls and you lose, start from scratch once more.Another game that is notoriously hard: Dark Souls. You die a lot but you don't seethe like you would in here, because every death in there is your fault. And you die over and over until you learn how to dodge and poke your way out of the place you're stuck into. That dosen't happen in Darkest Dungeon. There is no learning from your mistakes, no getting good other than in the estate management. You roll the dice until you and your characters are too rich and overpowered to have any challenge anymore. It's not fun.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I've played alot of good and bad games and usualy never wrote any reviews cause I'm lazy.But, when I write a review it's because the game is awesome or totaly sucks.Never again. What a time waste.I finished the game using a save game backup background program. Cause otherwise it's just too reta.rded.Count 40 to 100 hour to finish the game. 10 hours of fun and the rest is a painfull chore. I've got so bored so i speedran the NG+ with some uber trinkets.I dont have any game presentation. Go read some positive reviews that somebody wrote while having less thant 10 hours of gameplay (sarcasm).So there is my review:Grinding grinding grinding gold and heirlooms ... boring boring boring.At the start you'll be amazed how this game is great but later you'll hate everything about it.Get 4 new chars, send them for quest without supplies (as long as at least one of them survives to bring back the GOLD GOLD GOLD ) then get rid of them. Repeat 100 times. or just hack the gold.If it's not grinding then RNG plus retar.ded logic of devs will get you:When you see the achievements you may already see that there is something wrong with the game. A lot of achievememts are based on you to misirably fail. "Lose you heroes this way, lose your heroes that way". Have you lost your mind! I've spend 10 hours grinding gold to build them...wtf.Some of these achievements require some RNG conditions that you may never meet even intentionaly. After restoring or healing, heroes may get a TOWN penalty that won't go away until you complete a run with them. And there is no other way to remove this debuff.Ohh...dungens are tough, here, get some -10 to accurancy,  be useless in battles.At levels 5+ enemies may kill one of yours chars without you been able to react. Enemies may land heavy crits and one shot any of your heroes then any additional hit or blight / bleed will terminate him.Shambles...shambles everywhere. There are some rare curios that may be used to summon these minibosses. BUT you won't need em cause every fuc.king second dungeon will spawn one as a random encounter and ruin your run.Criticals, these damn criticals. It's all good... your heroes will do some then they may take some in their faces. The problem is  a retar.ded additional stress that all yours heros will get. One hero takes some misirable (0-1) damage rolled as crit and becomes 2 (yes TWO) damage and every one gets 1 million of stress.Food consumption is totaly random and you never know when it will happen. When your team need to eat, you have only two choises: feed them or starve them (health and morality penalities). Another major problem is that they may never eat or eat 5 times in a row leaving you with no supplies and pushing your run to a fail.One dungeon run take supposedly several days. Therefore you need provisions, food and torches. Your team consumes torches while walking through a dungeon. Battles  takes no time comparing to the whole exploration because torches dont burnt out. During a battle you heroes may heal and buff themselfs but they can't dot it outside the battle. Moreover, in a battle the game forbids you from keeping stunning or ignoring an enemy while healing and stress releaving. The game will react by sending in reinformcements and blasting you heroes with stress damage.Game has no game over. So if you lose yours high level heroes all you need it's just 15 more hours to train new ones. Why not add a save game you dumb sh.it devs ? I have better things to do or games to play.Conclusion: The game suffers from some major grindfests witch are exponential and also of tons of BS RNG.Play it at your own risk of wasting your time for nothing. Or wait for some major balances or  MODS / hacks

Posted: February 10
												I LOVED this game initially. It was very challenging, but also very fair. Then, when my characters hit Level 5 and 6, I grew to DESPISE the unfairnes of this game.You start by building up some money running Level 3 dungeons with an Antiquarian. You spend that money to ugrade your level 5 and 6 characters. Then you equip them with trinkets, enter the Level 5 dungeon and it goes something like this:Cast a debuff --> Mob resistsAdd a dodge buff to your group --> Doesn't matter, the mobs hit you anywayHave your tank swing at the mob --> MissTreebranch smackdown --> Hit for 40+ right off the bat, first toon on deaths doorBefore you can heal it, it gets hit again with Deathblow by another mob.You try to continue on with just 3, but after the third fight you have to abandon the quest, return to town, and start running Level 3 dungeons again. After about four times of repeating this pattern, I erased the game because it's completely rigged against the player.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												What a game.After some time of playing this, you just get the feeling like you are being pulled in to a fantasy world, so dark it will haunt your dreams and make you think about it at night. Before we talk about the gameplay, I must add, the Soundtrack of the game is a must for every fantasy freak out there. Tense, well placed and executed perfectly, it is one of the staples of the game... not to mention the gameplay.Gameplay, simple, but yet so complex, it is a gem in the sea of lookalike games.Side scrolling, nothing new, but the amount of detail and calculation required for to go into a dungeon is huge.Also, this game has one little thing everyone thinks is neglectable, and that is perma death.You die, you stay dead, no going back, and that, alone, makes the game a tension bomb.You will die, and you will most likely cry afterwards, due to the fact that you invested time in the characters.All in all, Awesome game. A must have for Dark Fantasy freaks.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												After just five hours (the amount of time I put into a game before I decide if I want to continue playing), I can honestly say I'm hooked.I'd say this is the perfect game to binge for a few hours, set aside and revisit once in a while.  Since so much of it is based on luck, to play this like a traditional RPG would be self-defeating and frustrating.  The goal is not to achieve the perfect character build or the perfect team as it's impossible. The goal of the game is to progress as far as you can inspite of that. 40% skill and 60% random things hopefully going your way more than not. Some may say this is flawed design to make a game unnecessarily punishing.  I just choose to treat this like an elaborate game of roulette.  It's fun and addictive because there are no guarantees.  I just try to cover my bases and hope that I go on a good run.Bottomline, treat this for what it is.  It's a game of chance where you're able to control a few elements that may push the the odds slightly in your favour each round.  Treat this like linearly progressing RPG and you'll pull your hair out.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really like the music, the aesthetics, and the world gives me a Diablo-esque grim kind of feel that when done well can be enjoyable. I'll try to keep this short but the stress mechanic needs reworked if I'm to ever enjoy the game. RNG dictates far too much the outcome rather than skill or strategy and it kills any enjoyment for me. I don't want victory handed to me or anything but at least make it feel like it was my fault instead of just bad luck. I understand this game isn't supposed to be played very casually and you're also expected to lose and that's fine. I'm okay with losing if it's my fault and I deserved it but everytime the game starts bending me over it just feels like all my efforts make no real difference.I think there is so much to this game to admire and I'm somewhat conflicted about giving it a thumbs down but if it was simply made to reward skill more than luck it'd be better. I'd suggest making a masochist mode for those who like the stress mechanic as it is whilst people like me can enjoy themselves. You can even call it casual mode or something if it makes the dedicated fans happy, I have nothing to prove to anyone and I feel like I'm missing out on a world and spent money on a game I can't even get through without crossing my fingers and wasting hours doing the same dungeons many times over.

								The game got pretty bad once they added corpses so I stopped playing for a while.As of December 26th I've started replaying and it's now well balanced and fun to play. If you complain about RNG you are just terrible at this game, they fixed every issues I've had such as the long grinding for low level characters and the corpses that took ages to clear. It is worth a buy in my opinion for anyone who likes good rpgs, it's ruthless, you will often lose 1-2 members during a boss fight but it is satisfaying. The only thing I don't like about the game is there should be more customization, for example it would be nice to pick up swords and armor parts to add more depth but I can understand this would then make the game a lot harder to balance properly.There is already a lot of content and with the full release coming up you are looking at around 100-120 hours of gameplay. Don't listen to the autistics cry babies reviews, the game is challenging but fair and a lot of fun.Note : I actually have a lot more gameplay time than it shows since I play it mostly on a computer with no internet connection.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon was a game that came to my attention almost as soon as it came into steam. The concept seemed interesting to me and I indulged in watching a few streams and YouTube videos of the game. Turned off by the early access label I decided to withhold my purchase and buy it some other time. Recently it came to my attention that the game had been "finished." I had seen numinous glowing reviews from critics I trust and I was convinced to make the purchase. To me the game looked like Xcom: the RPG with a dark graphic novel H.P. Lovecraft aesthetic. I am a fan of HP's stories and the narrative to me is clearly inspired by 'The statement of Randolph Carter' and of course the classic 'The call of Cthulhu.' I even encountered a rather on the nose reference to HP's work as my rambling arbalest asked my crusader "have you ever seen a colour out of space?" Referencing the HP Lovercraft story of the same name. I didn't even have any truck with the controversial ending (that I spoiled for myself, more on that later) it's as hopeless and grim as many a Lovecaftian tale. The visual and sound design are excellent, The character sprites are very graphic novel-ly and well-drawn, the music is well composed and the disheartening ambiance that gets louder the darker the torch gets is a nice atmospheric touch. These well done aspects of the game added to the exclusively positive media i had heard up to that point convinced me to buy the game. While this did not cross my mind when i first made my purchase I now remember a certain youtuber saying something along the lines of 'those people who played for 300 hours and hate it.' This should have sent off warning signs in my head but sadly I did not research enough. I made my purchase and began playing. I did well (I think) initially and had a good time. I only lost 3 party members in 15 hours and I managed to beat 4 bosses and both the encounter bosses. I'm not exactly sure if I did anything wrong or if I was just unlucky but I started lousing, lots. Most of the time I would lose one or two level 3 party members and flee, But then I had my first party wipe, I lost one level 4, three level 5 heroes and some incredibly rare trinkets (including the drop I received of my hard won shambler fight). Up to this point I had played the game akin to the way I play Xcom. I had named each hero after someone I know in real life and had upgraded all my heroes as much as possible in an attempt for them to stop dying. This caused my string of losses to be quite costly both emotionally and financially, I understand that I may have been playing it wrong but the way the game punishes you for losing high level heroes breaks the fun of the game for me. Falling back on my Xcom instincts I started a new save file and started playing that. At this point my friend linked a video showing why he wouldn’t be purchasing the game after I had stated I had a good time with the first 10 to 15 hours and I realised why I would not be revisiting this game until it is significantly patched. The game is SUPER grind focused. Not only that but the core gameplay loop is repetitive. The same missions: scout(search almost all rooms), exterminate(finish all room battles), and an item mission where you must find 3 'curios' and interact with them with 3 provided items repeat over and over. For some reason Red Hook have padded out the game with completely unnecessary repetition and a slow progression system that will set you back HOURS of grinding a replacement hero if you are unlucky and lose even one or 2 party members. Boss fights are repeated 2 more times at harder difficulties for seemingly no reason and the final straw was seeing what was in store for me in the final missions of the game. One your party beats an incredibly hard level in the Darkest Dungeon they will all refuse to ever go there again forcing you to grind even more on easier levels to produce max level and well equipped heroes in order to stand a chance.This revelation I had has killed any desire for me to play the game. I am familiar with challenging games, even ones with RNG tied to them, I beat Xcom on ironman classic. But Darkest Dungeon is not 'challenging'. It's not really. You can’t even lose. It just takes up your time to make it feel like its challenging. If the game was shorter, had more variation in the core gameplay loop and removed unnecessary features like the 'Never Again' mechanic then I may of recommended this game. But in its current unfairly grindy state I do not recommend. Hopefully with the alleged addition of the steam workshop soon someone may just fix the game instead of the devs.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. I gave it a fair trial. The central problem lies with sheer randomness. You simply cannot know when an enemy attack will inflict a massive critical hit, taking one of your heroes from full health to "death's door" in a single blow. In my final attempt to send a fully-outfitted expedition to destroy the "Formless Flesh," I encountered a troup of common rogues, the kind I'd fought many times before. This time, a couple of critical hits took my knight and my bounty hunter down to death's door, and a bullwhip multi-strike killed both of them before I could take meaningful action. Random chance of so wide a range is simply not fun in a game.Mind, I like difficult games! For example, I thoroughly enjoyed Alien: Isolation. But there, one dies because one fails to understand the antagonist and anticipate its next move. In Darkest Dungeon, no amount of preparation or strategy will save you from the true enemy -- sheer dumb luck.Additionally, while the bosses (the necromancer, the Formless Flesh, the Swine King, the Hag, and the Ghost Pirates) are all well-conceived and executed, the game demands you fight each no less than four times, making the game repetitive. The campaign long overstays its welcome.The creators have created an involving game, with many fun elements. If they made critical hits far less frequent and less devastating, and trimmed the tedious recycling, I would try this again. But I sadly cannot recommend it in its current state.Addendum: I have now tried many mods in an attempt to rebalance the game. Unfortunately, the latest patch appears to have rendered existing mods obsolete, as most of them now cause the game to crash or lock.

Yes, the first hours are fun. But this changes very fast...

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												There's not that many negative reviews, so I'll give it go.  I'll sing some praise first, since the game is ok.  I won't list everything that's good about Darkest Dungeon (DD), but it does have a lot of goodness tucked away inside.  I really love the artistic style, and turn based combat for example.  These two things drew me to DD.  Stress is a gimicky mechanic, I could take or leave.  It works and adds something to the game play, even though there are times I wish it didn't.The real problems for me is game pacing, variety, and length.  I've found that pacing is one of those things that rpg's in general have a poor time getting just right.  DD over complicates it by using five different currencies, and then in a rather miserly fashion not giving them out in any quantity.  To add to the worries, bag space is extremely limited, so even if you find some great hoard you might not profit by it.  Oddly enough, the exp gains might be spot on, but without the other resources your party will quickly be outmatched so there's no way I can tell for sure.  Essentially, you'll be forced to start over at some point and rebuild a team with fewer flaws, and hopefully higher earning potential.The rebuilding of a team isn't bad in itself.  I think it fits the atmosphere the game is going for.  This does lead to problems though.  All of the heroes are rather cookie cutter.  That's not bad presuming that you'll be burning through a lot of expendable characters.  On the downside, there's no reason to be invested in any of them either.  Additionally, every dungeon run is more or less exactly the same.  There are, I don't know, three, four different quest objectives?  Each zone a handful of unique mobs, plus a handful that could appear in any zone.  It leads to dungeon runs where the only objective is to smash and grab while min/maxing the curios and bag space as best you can.  It's too expensive to take stress damage, or risk a negative quirk.  So you find your little strategy, and more or less do the same things in dungeons you could hardly tell apart.If this game clocked in at 20 hours from start to finish, I'd feel better about it.  It's not.  There are eight bosses, each of which requires some number of zone specific dungeon grinds to open, and has to be killed three times, at slightly more difficult levels.  Why?  just because. . . I'm almost through now, and I like the game enough to finish, and possibly restart it, but come on.  Have some respect for my time.  I've also read some spoilers about the ending.  All I can say is for real?DD is a good game mired in poor design.  Everything seems to work, which is a big plus.  Guess it's suppose to be hardcore?  There are times it just feels like a hardbore, or a hardchore.  It's not at all bad, it just isn't that great once you get your teeth into it.Overall, I'd recommend a pass on this one, unless you can get it on sale.  There are some neat things to see, but once you've seen them, you'll see them again and again, and again.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								RNG Review, for those that are curious about how heavily the RNG affects the game.You can die outright in the tutorial.You can die in the first two missions because your replacement party members are useless due to RNG selected skills.You could literally not buy this game and just roll dice on D&D tables and get the same experience of gameplay.  Just without the art.======TL;DR for people with reading comprehension problems:It is a nearly finished productIt is not necessarily ready for broad consumption as an early access pieceIt is worth your support if it is a game you would like see reach its full potential.If you are going to support it, be involved with the community and developers, don't just throw money at it.=======AMAZING aesthetic. In its current state, it is a fully finished art piece, which will be regarded as a gem...When the rest of it is finished.The mechanics of the game are fully realized, the systems and etc are fleshed out, functional, and understandable (if not a little obfuscated behind menus in some cases), so that's not necessarily the issue.The problems you will find will relate to the game design and the user experience.  Yes, the game is hard, in ways that you may even find unfair due to randomness, but that's kind of where the fun is, in this reenvisioning of the popular dungeoncrawler idea.  What you'll find is a game that, in many cases, doesn't care whether or not you're having fun, which is a real shame, because the developers clearly care about making it a good game, but in its current state you will be hit, full force, with the sense that they don't, amist an equal amount of force saying they want to make a great product.While I am giving this a negative recommendation, I say this:If you think you would enjoy this game, or this is a game that you would like to see succeed, do buy it.  However, don't just buy the game, but play it and provide good constructive and analytic feedback to the developers about the areas that need it.  This is an early access game, which means it is technically an unfinished product, but while early access is often a variant form of a kickstarter money grab kind of thing, this game is a near complete product, and if it's something you would like, the best thing you can do is support it not only with money, but with the intention to beta test it the way early access is somewhat meant to be for.Do not entertain ideas of fanboy hype and vapid support of various features of the game, because that is only appeal to enthusiasm and emotion.  If you feel something is wrong with the game, take some time to analyze it and understand how it affects the game, how it fails to benefit it, or, maybe, how it actually does its job well, and use these understandings to notice the cracks that need to be filled.  And then communicate them.

												If you have taken any time to read the reviews on this game you have a pretty good understanding of what to expect. Great atmosphere, character design, story, voice acting, art work, class design, etc. all great ingredients for a fantistic dungeon crawler only to be completely ruined by the combat system. There is no rhyme or reason to the way combat plays out no matter how hard you prepare or grind your characters you end up losing a level 5 character to a level 1 boss because of bad luck. The game play is so repetitive that the extreme difficulty it takes to make an inch of progress is not worth repeating the process for hours just to be dissapointed time after time. Altogether a great start but the finished product is just not worth your time. If things could be patched or modded to make it more playable than it might be worth revisiting.

								This is violence porn for accountants.Sadly, with the recent patches this games was turned from a difficult game which made you take tough decisions based on a careful risk/return analysis into a masochistic grindfest based on luck. All too often you see your carefully groomed, max-equiped level 5/6 chars killed in a single round of combat. From full health a hit/crit combo takes the character to death's door, leaving a nasty ticking damage on the character killing the character off as soon as his/her turn is up.One has to understand that the death of such a character is an enormous setback because you have to grind a replacement through several lower level dungeon runs. The loss of gold and time is substantial. Basically, most of the time you grind through content you have already done ad nauseam in order to have another shot at a dungeon you actually want to play. And did I mention that the loss of a character early in a fight means that you have to quit the fight leaving all that hard-earned gear behind?This isn't a game anymore. It is an experiment on how much frustration, pain and tedious time sinks people can suffer through in order to MAYBE achieve a particular goal. If that is your jam then by all means come and join the club!
