content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This isn't like most dungeon crawlers you've played. Although it shares a lot in common with most "rogue-like" games (i.e. death in permanent, life is cheap, dungeons are randomized) it also has a number of unique features that add spice to the game play. There is no resurrect spell, dungeons aren't overflowing with loot, dungeon items can yield unpredictable results, and the character's stress levels are as important as their hit points. Also, it's not a game where you have the straightforward classification of "tank,healer,thief,mage," there's a number of unique classes that combine different aspects of all three classes. For example, Amazonian "Hellion" can heal herself, and a properly equipped mage "Occultist" can hold his own in front-line combat. It's probably the only game where a lute playing Jester can die of a heart attack from burning books.All this makes for a refreshing twist on the typical dungeon crawler experience, but it takes some time to orient yourself to the game. What initially seems like a brutal game turns into a strategic challenge as you learn the classes, their tactics, and how they all work together. This is not a game that ceases to be a challenge at higher levels, unlike other games where a top-level tank can laugh off most opponents.So, for me, if you are done with the old, tired dungeon crawlers but like the "rogue-likes," then this is this year's game for you. If you are looking for one of those games where your 53rd level Cleric can resurrect a person from a corpse to a fighting machine in the middle of combat without skipping a beat, this is probably not the game for you. It's different, it's challenging, it's fun, you shoudl try it.

content:
Posted: April 21
												I do not recommend this game to others. Like many other games nowadays the games try to use 'difficulty' as an angle to entice players. This game as a result is more tempting because of the morbidity the game contains. Things like the narration and reactions from characters is neat too however that's basically where the enjoyment ends.Welcome to the land of RNJesus. Whether you are a good stratician or not makes little to no difference. The resources you need to upgrade your town and maintain it are dependant on the amount of risk you take in each dungeon visit. The game talks about sacrifice but if you send any of your parties to the dungeon and they are wiped out you get nothing. So it's not a sacrifice at all. For the first 3 visits to the game's dungeon you will find it difficult to barely hold on which at first seems like difficulty but it is actually a balance issue. There are torches and with them lit dungeons are easier however loot becomes scarce and you cannot sustain the cost of having parties go out for you. There is a system that allows you to gain new adventurers at a decent pace but they do not scale with the difficulty of dungeons you need to do without huge amounts of upgrade and even with that upgrade it is chance. It is also chance which new adventurer you get in the system I am talking about.If you are not begging and pleading mentally for an Antiquarian [A character whom's abilities aren't even shown in text anywhere that can allow for mass gains of cash] you will find yourself hitting a wall repeatedly. But that is just the first wall!Once your characters hit Resolve level 2 they will be able to fight 'area bosses' at the apprentice level. Which happens to be most of the starting ones. However if you have a favorite party and use them frequently they will outlevel the requirement and become moody and no longer want to fight the bosses of those areas making leveling up have less value. Then when you do level up areas so that you can do Veteran quests for them, they will be grossly outmatched by most mobs they fight even when they are fully upgraded and outfited. Basically the game is imbalanced and is using horrible statistic gaps to emulate difficulty.People have also said that once you get to late game [pfft] it becomes easy and boring, which only proves what I am saying ot be true. When getting used to how brokenly unbalanced it is the quirky narration loses value and the interaction between your party members becomes interchangeable as other characters will say the exact same thing, again taking the purpose of the dialogue away. So despite it being in beta... I just don't think this is worth. I was enticed by the earlier levels of the game but it takes being hardheaded, not skilled to get anywhere in this game. Which if balance were a thing they understood it would be fun, but since it isn't...

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I fist got this game I found it amazingly fun. I would summerize the game as a rogue like party based dungeon crawl with some city building aspects. This game introduces a stress system that acts as a second bar of life. As the bar raises party memeber resolve is tested and can lead to some nasty effects. When the bar mexes out the character dies from a heart attack. Characters gain stress from going to dungeons and relieve stress through services in the city. Services take take time and force you to leave them behind to recover. I started enjoying this mechanic as it forced me to diversify my party, level up multiple people, and continually experience different class combinations. The dungeons are difficult and various mob and boss fights can easily get our of hand. A lot of the game turn into managment of city service slots, money for services, money for upgrades, money for dungeon supplies (these are important), and character stress.I did really enjoy all the management aspects of the game until I finally was able to start leveling my pary members to level 3. Once a character reaches level 3 they can no longer run level the starter dungeons to help raise other party memebers. This ruined the game for me. The game is difficult and stress can kill characters of any level fairly easily if things get our of hand in an ambush. I did not ming struggling to unlock new tiers of content in the game but being forced to struggle in the lower level dungeons to attempt to level a new party memener to replace a higher level party memeber that died in the higher tier dungeon ruined all the fun I had in the game. Gaining levels in this game did not make a large difference in survival and allowing higher levels characters to shepherd lower level party members through dungeons for no XP gain would not be game breaking. It would not have been much easier but it would at least make the catchup process muchless stressful. The highest unlocked content would have been no easier by allowing this. This restriction just turned the game into an annoyingly grindy and unfun game in what appears to have been an attempt to make the game continually difficult and stressful. I am ok with diffiuclty but I think that it is ok for lower tier content to become easier as you progess the game.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								There are plenty of good elements in this game so it is definitely not all bad. Things just turn from interesting into rather stupid quite fast. Your party will suffer from mass hysteria all the time and usually for no good reason. Healing spells only work during combat and not outside combat. Pretty much everything gives a huge dose of stress to your chars and pretty much nothing relieves it in the dungeon. Getting a scratch is an end of the world but getting it all healed up means nothing and so on.You also have to carry a ridiculous amount of torches even for a short trip and any gear that gets left over from your mission is apparently thrown away. Like keys, shovels, bandages and all that. Overall this game has a great concept but in the end the implementation makes no sense at all. Due to the unbelievably erratic nature of the game a manual save system would increase playability. With automatic save system this ridiculous amount of erratic behavior is just *boring*.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I actually dont like the game.Stress damage is just much too dominant. I moved my team through the first dungeons. They where well equiped for the task, No one got low on healt - they just butchered everything.Well exept 1 of them went insane 1 maniac and one - well I forgot. At the end 3 had to take a forced "vacation" from wreckig havoc on a bunch of zombies. Maybe they took stress damage from beeingoverequiped?But let's just ignore this. Let's assume, you can live with that. How does the game work (at least to my experience...) What did I do?0. Starting Point1. I crawl dungeons2. Build Fortune, Level, Equipment3. Your heros get Bad Traits, Sicknesses, etc.Here one has 2 options:A.4 Pay the cure / whateverA.5 You are low on money=> Result: GOTO 2 (Money)B.4 Dismiss HeroB.5 You need more heros / higher levels==> Result: GOTO 2 (Heros / Levels)So it all amounts to a grind for either money, hero levels or a mix of both.So yes: The game is def. punishing. But what is the punishment? Well it is you having to grind back up to the point where you where. Cant recommend the game.  Sorry. I really liked the idea.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I'm really torn on whether to recommend this game or not. But for the reasons very well articulated in the top negative reviews, I can't do so in good faith.Which is really too bad. This could be one of my favorite games. I'm not turned off by the difficulty, the RNG, or the  lack of gameplay variety (I'm a big fan of rogue-likes though). It's the grind that makes this game painful to play after the first (awesome) dozen hours. With just a handful of small changes, this could be a phenomenal 30-40 hour game. Instead, it's about an 80 hour game where the last 50 of those are grinding away to level up enough heroes to play the last level and collect enough money and relics to buy upgrades.I checked out some past and current discussions, and the developers do look like good guys that are trying to make the best game that they can. I just don't agree with some of the high level design decisions. That's okay. They've produced a beautiful, smart game that unfortunately overstays its welcome with mechanics that turn it into a grindfest.

Early Access Review
								Hard but FunThis is one of those games that does not hold your hand, in fact, it's a challenge but a well designed one.The world is beautifully made and does a great job at depicting a dark and desprate land.The combat is challenging but has a good element od strategy allowing you to get out of tight spots.The game overall feels like a bit of a grind as you repeat a lot of the same events but the large variation of characters/items makes up for it.It feels very rewarding seeing your troops go from lowly bums to brutal warriors.If you like the artstile and are prepared to lose a lot, try it out.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I understand the game. There's a lot to like about it. But it needs to go easier on healers. All my healers have been dead for a long time, meaning I can't use any of my high-level characters. The entire game has become a futile effort to level healers. This weekend I went back to the game, to check out the Cove, and spent hours leveling, and losing, healer after healer. Do not give me advice; I know what I am doing. In the end, it's way too grindy, and punishing in a way that is not entertaining. A lot of what appear to be interesting abilities and mechanics are simply not worth using; the opportunity cost is too high. Meh.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Played this game almost a year ago, now. I loved it so much! Back then there were like 8 classes and only 3 dungeons and 3 bosses.I come back to see almost double the classes and 4 new bosses!!!AWESOME!! I loaded up a new save just to figure things out again before I try out my ancient save file... died in the tutorial to 3 crits in a row...ok no big deal. just bad luck.Tried again! Beat the tutorial... went onto the first dungeon and lost my entire party. WTF? I miss 2x more than I used to, 20% blight resistance apparently means 85% blight resistance because plague bomb never ♥♥♥♥ing worked, I got hit by crits nonstop leaving my entire party at around 150 stress before they were all killed. "Screw it", I thought, "I'll just load up my original save with like 10 maxed out warriors". I'm not even kidding right now, I ran into 4 walls in the first 6 halls and I only brought 2 shovels... so right off the bat my stress was high as♥♥♥♥♥♥ Long story about this plunge, short, I lost 3 of them. 3 maxed out legendary warriors that I spent forever with in that game. Why? Am I bad? Well being that when I first played the game, I NEVER lost a single warrior and completed the entire game fairly easily. I'd wager that I'm not bad. So why then?Crits, debuffs, RNG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, once-useful trinkets are now garbage trinkets. Oh, and I learned something! Apparently, if your party is injured and you try to heal them up so they don't die, the game punishes you!I'll let you guys figure out what it does for yourselves :) It's a hoot!This game is just stupid now. The devs suck. I wish I could just play the game as it was in the past. This♥♥♥♥♥♥is just garbage now. 4/10The 4 points come from art, music, design, etc.the -6 comes from the game being unbalanced and stupid now.Buy it?Nope. Don't reward devs like these with money. It just teaches them that being stupid is rewarding. Let them starve for cash so that they're forced to fix this game to get the income back. Supply and Demand. We demand good games. These guys can't supply one at the moment.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								The art and tone for the game is very appealing, as is the Old School dungeon delving theme. Art direction and story for this game are top notch. What it all boils down to is cool edgy art, great tone, fair story and quality voice acting, on top of a 2d side scrolling dungeon crawl. Sort of like graphic rich side scrolling Rogue - no wait.... huh? Yeah if this was the 80's, this game would have blown my mind. Even as an app this game would be credible. No app yet.      The game is actually...predictable... Every time you enter combat you use your best skill - the first one - to out dmg the enemy (the game is simply about the combats, there is very little else to the game, a little bit of managing another HP counter for "madness" which essentially enables the monsters to take down your toons two ways instead of one). Yes its perma-death. But its not. You have a stable of toons to use so they are basicly just foder. At the end of the day gp/gippers/gold/money, is what's going to kill your game and make you restart. That's probably not going to happen if you play in beatstick mode.    On madness: its really just another resource. It acts like even worse hit points. You take madness from attacks and from being in the darkness and other spooky♥♥♥♥♥♥ Only not only do you gain madnes points and eventually die from a heart attack, you get hard to remove character traits along the way. Yes you can have a TPK from madness and heart attacks. so like I said two hit point tracks both of which can kill you.   There is little to no synergy between the character powers. The nuanced powers - bleed, blight, all the fun little tricks, are less effective, than simply using each character's first direct dmg skill. With the possible exception of stun. As a result the game is extremely... predictable..? Pretty but simplistic. Oh and random, its got a survival shtick going on, and the randomness is meant to be something you manage ... but the gameplay feels too random and chaotic. Player agency is apparently very low, UNLESS you just use your beatstick pwr ..in which case ... no actually player agency is very low. What could have been the interesting part of combat, the synergies and combos, are unfortunately lackluster, when compared to outright beatstick powers. Instead as it stands the game could nearly play on autopilot. Beatsticks + Heals wash, rinse, repeat. Go old school!!! Or not ....    The strategic resource management is ham fisted and basic - you have to provision your expedition, and any provisions mysteriously evaporate on successful mission completion, with no return or refund. Its not flavourful, it just looks like a programing error they turned into a "feature'. There is little in the way of actual real, exploration, logistics or strategy over long term in the game. This would make a fun pen and papper rpg, or maybe a smart phone app. as a PC app its lackluster.

Posted: February 4, 2016
												This game gives the illusion of being hard through unforgiving RNGs.The game has a great atmosphere and feels special in that regard, but to enjoy it to its full extent you need to be...lucky.You can finish missions without a scratch with new characters with default equipment as easily as you can fail horribly the same missions with hard-boiled badasses armed to the teeth and trained with min-maxed abilities.Combats are just a series of hits traded between two teams. Most will seem even untill one side misses or the other crits, and just like that your fate is sealed.It's a shame really, there are tons of varied classes with dozens of different abilities but all of them seem so meaningless when each fight is played with the flip of a dice.

number of helpful: 242 of 466 people (52%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Madness takes digital form in your quest to grind your brains out in Darkest Dungeon. On the surface, you will find elements of city management, a complex party system that requires you to balance not only classes but their post-spelunking ailments and illnesses, multiple tilesets with a variety of bosses that require different strategies, and a bevy of trinkets and baubles with equally weighted good and bad stats. All these elements (despite the RNG) combine into an enjoyable experience for the first dozen or so hours.All this is fun and games until you clear the first boss for each dungeon and the problems with randomness and luck really show their ugly faces. RNG holds every gameplay aspect of DD in it's iron grip; from miserable combat accuracy (for both you and the enemy), interacting with curios, suffering from permanent debuffs, and even being able to run from battle are all randomized. I love board & card games so I'm used to rolling dice and suffering for it but when the entire game is determined by luck it gets infuriating. Imagine playing Monopoly: you land on an unowned property only to have to roll dice to determine if you can buy it, roll again to determine if you can put a house on it, and then your opponents get to roll when they land on it to determine if they have to pay you. Every step is a roll of the dice (not even counting traps) with your characters gaining stress randomly while walking and sometimes forcing you to interact with obviously bad curios because of a permanent trait they have. Of course, RNG can always be brute forced because this is a video game and anyone who has played an RPG before knows how to brute force any kind of difficulty: grinding. In order to beat anything above the first tier of bosses, you are expected to have the best gear possible on all your characters in order for them to survive. With a max roster size of 28, characters running away or suffering from multiple crippling ailments, and permadeath (because why not?), you're looking at spending several hours grinding "easy" dungeons in the hope of bringing back some cash without your party suffering from any more permanent debuffs or dying. Near the end of the game, losing a max level key party member can spell the end of your progression and send you back to the grind mines. Since launch, they added the ability to upgrade your recruiter to occasionally bring you higher level recruits, but this also requires grinding up multiple buildings just to have the chance at buying non-unleveled heroes.These are all complaints about how the game was "meant" to be playing though. Through the options menu you can choose to mitigate some of the RNG but it still leaves a lot to be desired. Most of the miserable elements above aren't covered in the menu and removing & replacing them would completely change the game. I don't hate the individual elements that bring this game down but when combined it just feels like Darkest Dungeon despises the player and is actively trying to stop you from playing it. I'm sure the devs thought this was some kind of clever meta-torture based on the Lovecraftian horrors you run into but I didn't find it amusing. There will be a small, masochistic audience that will sink their teeth into this and grind it for hundreds of hours (only 1.3% of the people who have bought it on Steam have beaten it, including SAM users) but for the average person I would not recommend it.

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												TL;DR I imagine Darkest Dungeon is Dark Souls the RPG.Man, this game is not meant for me. I don't know how people like TotalBiscet or NorthernLion make it look so fun. Maybe it's because I'm not the one playing. Maybe it is because they make it look easy. I don't know.I just start a game and I'm already having a salty time. Getting constistently hit by crits and consistently missing attacks makes combat feel very unnatural, despite the fact you're combating supernatural beings but that is not the point. It doesn't feel like I'm being slowly whittled down bit by bit like a #2 pencil in a hand-cranked sharpener, but more like I'm a #2 pencil being snapped in half for funsies.I feel no sense of escalation. Like instead of throwing monster fodder at me at the beginning like most RPGs do, it's more like every fight is a mini-boss, which means that one team of skeletons at the beginning of a mission will end you if RNGesus doesn't particularly like you that day. I can't settle in on one save file because I can't trust the game on anything, like gambling since my luck is about as reliable as getting kicked in the groin. I know there are options in the setting menu that will decrease the risk, but I'm afraid that will decrease the authenticity of the experience of what the game is suppose to provide. Which is a delema to me. Do I want to enjoy PLAYING the game, or enjoy playing the GAME? I'll probably just leave it in my Steam library and leave it alone ad infinium.Darkest Dungeon is a game about making the best out of a bad situation. But if the best I can make out of a bad situation is effectively nothing (poor roster selection, essentially no gold, bad luck with RNG) or worse, what is the point in trying?

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really, really wanted to like this game. Really. In theory it sounds great: a combination of Cthulhu with heroes/anti-heroes, a dungeon crawl and RPG elements. The problem is the game is SO weighted against you that it ceases being fun. If your party isn't wiped out first, chances are really good after a couple of missions your "primary" characters will be useless due to their stress and negative quirks and you constantly have to start missions with Level 0 characters. There are mechanics for you to reduce stress and remove quirks but it is so expensive to do so it renders the option useless.I understand this used to be a fun game to play before a recent patch that tilted the odds to "unfair" against the players. I did not get a chance to experience this "fun" version. I can only hope the devs recognize they are frustrating their player base that they will clean this up. There's a good game lurking beneath the surface. In the meantime, Fallout 4 awaits and is much more worthy of my time than this game in its present state.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a dungeon crawler in which you must grind to survive. The game sells itself on the fact that heroes will die and that you won't always finish quests. Fine.However, what you notice is that this makes the game into a grind fest. Expeditions cost quite a bit of money, especially due to the harshness of some of the combat and any attempt you can make to make up for that. This means that, without the quest reward, you're going to be looking at a net loss if you decide to retreat, even if you grab a fair amount of loot. It also means your heroes will gain no XP from the expedition, which is the means for upgrading them to complete more difficult missions. The difficulty to obtain money and heirlooms required for upgrades, coupled with the lack of rewards (even most items have fairly harsh negatives) and potential loss of a high leveled character (which is more common in higher dungeon levels), makes for a game that can easily stall and leave you grinding in lower level dungeons. This makes for a rather dull, gameplay wise, and repetitive experience.The upsides are that the combat is fairly interesting when attempting to make synergies between characters, the world seems to have depth in terms of character development, and the game mechanics are fairly unique. However, the synergies between the characters don't seem to be particularly interesting or impactful, character development quickly washes away when you have 16+ different expendable heroes/weirdos, and any trait can be quickly swapped out for another, since characters get a trait on almost every adventure (the swapping mechanic is new, though, at the time of this review). I would maintain that the game mechanics remain unique with little qualifications in these regards.The gameplay isn't the worst part, though, and it would probably be tolerable if the aesthetic and world weren't so atrocious. If I were to describe the feeling the game was trying to impart upon the player, it would be "hysterical panic." I don't know about anyone else, but that is probably the single worst attitude to attempt to get a person playing a video game to feel. Panic is bad in and of itself, but the hysterics the game attempts to impart upon you make it intolerable. I had to mute the music because it was mind-numbingly obnoxious. All so the creators can impart some cheap, shallow interpretation of H.P. Lovecraft (the mentally-deranged racist that so many gamers have taken a strange liking to). I would say that the visual art design is well done. The characters look interesting and the world looks unique and well crafted. It really gives you a sense that you're living in a world, and I would say the game's attempt to give you that sense of living in a world is well done. However, a game is much more than that and my interest in the world quickly faded once I actually engaged the game mechanics and started hearing the horrible music.Darkest Dungeons is a game that had some promise, but the grinding required to play it and lack of reward coupled with the sense of hysterical panic it attempts to impart, and does a good job imparting, make it not worth playing.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												This will probably be the best game you don't want to play. Honestly, I love the game, I love the atmosphere, the artwork.. but, the game yearns to be difficult. The difficulty of this game isn't based on skill or knowledge or preparedness. It wants to be difficult and brutal so bad that it cheats. The stress system makes what normally would be minor enemies potentially the most devastating in the game. Enemies will crit you and you will miss and there's nothing you could have done differently. Your healers might kill you and all you did was try to heal yourself. Long story short: Good game, marred by developers who wanted to make a "hard" game a little too badly.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												Rushed the game a bit to get a feel.  I enjoy hard games, but ones that are difficult for the right reasons.  This is not one of them.  The game is a great concept that falls flat in my opinion.  Getting to the point where you can attempt the darkest dungeon, you will probably have 2 or 3 leveled teams.  Finish the darkest dungeon level with them? guess what... you're starting over from scratch because you can't go back there with the same characters!  The game creates a progression wall where you have to spend days leveling up a new team each time you want to attempt this dungeon.  That's artificial difficulty by adding time.  That's wrong, and the publisher should feel bad about it.  Art is great, story is a bit all over the place, combat is interesting.  I like the pieces of the game, but when it boils down to it, the fake artificial difficulty added into the already difficult game just turns it into an annoyance instead of fun.  Can't recommend that.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												I really ... really wanted to love this game.  But.The early game is oppressively difficult for new players.  Thanks to a savage RNG system, permadeath and no effective way to strategically "level up" your new heroes, level 0 and 1 dungeons feel next to impossible to complete.  Going broke in week 5 while littering a graveyard with heroes as you "learn" the game through the extremely vague tutorial system is not the way to endear new gamers to the title.  Beginning the game in this way doesn't immerse me into the story or make me want to get better at the game (as there seems to be no real, strategic way to do this) it just makes me want to punch the monitor.Very disappointing.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												This game is infuriating.  In other games with similar management you get a bit of leway and aren't riding by the seat of your pants 24/7.  The odds are always stacked against you and if there's even a small chance something bad will happen,  it will.  What will usually followi s that one event will probaly kill your entire party.   You can spend hours playing this game, and wih one toss of the dice  your entire party wipes and you have to start from scratch, since there's no way to recover reasonably anywhere other than early game. This is because it autosaves your pogress,  so it's possible to completely fail the game and have to start from the begining.  It's not a difficulty setting,  it's how the game is supposed to be played.   For example,  my veteran team managed to kill a fairly hard boss,  while on the trek to a neighboring room  my party chain died of heart attafcks.  My first attempt at a boss in my first save game ended with a party wipe too in which i had to start the game from scratch,  an "easy boss" did enough damage to kill my entire party in one hit despite the boss being marked for my level,  although I was NOT ALLOWED to take my strongest party memeber along because he was somehow not challenged. There's a lot wrong with this game, another BIG problem with it being the RNG. The rng is absolutely batshit insane and not worth your time to fight against.  Buying trinkets and upgrading your party would help things along, but ultimately isn't worth your time,  nor is it viable. The reason being, it takes an obscene amount of items to lupgrade your crafters. Any trinkets that  might've helped you eek out some progress will run you your entire stockpile of money.  About the only manageable thing is , ironically,  stress relief......when that jackass caretaker isn't taking up the only spot you need. You're in a constant state of being stuck because you can't upgrade your team because you lack materials,  but you can't get the materials because they're locked in a dungeon that you can't beat because you're weak.  The rng also contributes to ANOTHER unfair and blatantly stupid mechanic,  party hunger.  You can be treking througha  dungeon,  and have fed all your team mates, but you'll get a prompt that'll tell you your team is hungry.   But since you've just fed them,  you sometimes won't be able to feed them all again,  which will result in your ENTIRE PARTY taking 20% damage from hunger despite having eaten just moments before.  Taking this much health and stress damage  usually leads to one or more of your party having  a heart attack.  Aside from all those issues,  the narrator  and music is repetitive.  While the music and dialogue is great,  there's barely more than one track you ever hear,  and after killing a few hoardes of enemies you've heaard nearly every line the voice actor has to say aside from story realted stuff.   It's as grating as the game itself.If you're looking for a decent turn based look elsewhere.  This game needed some more polish,  and a lot more testing befoer it got released.  As is it's just an aggravating mess of a game that could've been a winner.   Maybe they'll fix it with the second game, but this one'll make you wanna taear your hair out.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I can not recommend buying this game. I really want to love this game, but I can't suggest to anyone to buy it with a clear heart. First lets give points where it's due, then I will talk about the shortcomings. Positive points : -very atmospheric (great narrating voice and music)-the art style is fantastic-the story is interesting-town events really add to the game-real sense of loss and/or accomplishment after missions Negative points : -horribly unbalanced gameplaySeemingly the positives are overwhelming the negatives, but anyone who ever played a dungeon crawler or rogue-like knows how important balance is. Here I am not talking as someone who dislikes hardcore games, it is not simple whining about the game difficulty. My concern is the lack of options the player is given to combat the challenges the game sets for us. The character skills and identities are just lacking. An example : : you have a single character (the jester) who can manadge stress level of the party, making them camp and preparing a feast using all your time on stress relief is far from enough, even with the torch lit bright you have no real way of combating the problem. Even striking 3 critical strikes will only give the benefit of a single one, so you can not even depend on luck)Stress level is just one, the party lockout (a leper refusing to serve with a moster, because reasons) and level capping are ridiculous concepts, not to mention you MUST bring 4 people at any time, forcing you to keep at least 4 people of every level in your roster, and if you overlevel 2 of them your party just broke up and you can not use half of it until you somehow level the remainng guys up with a makeshift party.Forcing players to lose with setting impossible goals and forcing them to try and complete them is not a hardcore game, it is just lazy design. Real challenges can be solved, even if you ahve to spend a lot of time on them. If no sollution os presented it is not a challenge, it is a timewaster.Until the horrondous balance gets fixed in a way, turning the game into a real hardcore game from the current state, I can not wholeheartedly suggest this game to anyone. That is why it gets a downvote from me.

Fine.However, what you notice is that this makes the game into a grind fest. Expeditions cost quite a bit of money, especially due to the harshness of some of the combat and any attempt you can make to make up for that. This means that, without the quest reward, you're going to be looking at a net loss if you decide to retreat, even if you grab a fair amount of loot. It also means your heroes will gain no XP from the expedition, which is the means for upgrading them to complete more difficult missions. The difficulty to obtain money and heirlooms required for upgrades, coupled with the lack of rewards (even most items have fairly harsh negatives) and potential loss of a high leveled character (which is more common in higher dungeon levels), makes for a game that can easily stall and leave you grinding in lower level dungeons. This makes for a rather dull, gameplay wise, and repetitive experience.The upsides are that the combat is fairly interesting when attempting to make synergies between characters, the world seems to have depth in terms of character development, and the game mechanics are fairly unique. However, the synergies between the characters don't seem to be particularly interesting or impactful, character development quickly washes away when you have 16+ different expendable heroes/weirdos, and any trait can be quickly swapped out for another, since characters get a trait on almost every adventure (the swapping mechanic is new, though, at the time of this review). I would maintain that the game mechanics remain unique with little qualifications in these regards.The gameplay isn't the worst part, though, and it would probably be tolerable if the aesthetic and world weren't so atrocious. If I were to describe the feeling the game was trying to impart upon the player, it would be "hysterical panic." I don't know about anyone else, but that is probably the single worst attitude to attempt to get a person playing a video game to feel. Panic is bad in and of itself, but the hysterics the game attempts to impart upon you make it intolerable. I had to mute the music because it was mind-numbingly obnoxious. All so the creators can impart some cheap, shallow interpretation of H.P. Lovecraft (the mentally-deranged racist that so many gamers have taken a strange liking to). I would say that the visual art design is well done. The characters look interesting and the world looks unique and well crafted. content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												::tldr:: (Full Review below)IMO, great idea that wasn't quite executed correctly. With great challenge should come great reward. This quickly becomes not fun because there is tons of challenge but no reward. 6/10. If they could find a way to keep it challenging but tweak it some this game would easily be a 10/10 in this price category.::tldr::First of all, let me say, I couldn't wait to buy this game. It's one of the reasons I decided to get back into PC world and build this computer. I'm no stranger to long, tough games. I love a challenge! I was hoping to add this to my list of favorites along with the Civ series, the Dark Souls series, Evil Within (Nightmare difficulty), Everquest (back in the day), and a few others. I also enjoy rogue like games such as the Binding of Isaac and Hand of Fate.Overall I love the whole concept and gameplay of DD. I'm okay it's grindy, rogue like/luck based, and just downright mean at times. What I have come to find is it just doesn't feel rewarding. I'm okay getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me, like in Dark Souls, but if you improve your game play in DD you are actually punished. If you do too well with your heroes you will end up fighting tough enemies with weak weapons/armor. So you'll end up just tossing your mentally damaged hardwork on the next wagon out of town and starting over. Theres no way around it. I get the feeling you're suppose to play the game in a specific way (ie Spending resources on specific buildings in a specific order) or you will hit huge roadblocks. I guess you could consider what to upgrade a mini game in it's self with a winning way and a losing way. There's no play your own style.Ends up just not being fun. I'm a person that HATES to not finish a game. I've finished plenty of games that I didn't like, but unfortunately DD is going to be on a very short list of games I just cant muster the will power to finish... maybe. I'm going to revisit it later on. Again this is all my opinion, 17 hours worth.

number of helpful: 17 of 30 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Its disappointing that after re-visiting this game after so long it has only been patched and updated with more non-sensical and RNG based punishments for players. The classes are still largely unbalanced, even more time and money is now required to purge the endless stream of new diseases and debuffs, and trinkets are either net positive or net negative making only a select few worth anything. Near constant attacks to your moral and severe and often permanent punishments for looting anything in the level put me off experimenting in the game extremely quickely, including trying the new classes. The investment of time to train new units up from 0-2 is boring and unrewarding, and it's often easier to simply dismiss new units and recruit fresh untainted ones. To succeed I had to run the same team, use the same ability combinations and ignore as many RNG based elements as possible to avoid a majority of the games 'difficulty'. Even for a roguelike Darket Dungeon likes taking control away from the player way too often.I'd hoped more skill and squad composition mechanics would be explored as the game progressed, maybe even some relief from the frustrating requirment of destressing and purging abilities after almost every single run. While I understand this title is invested in being as crushingly hard as possible, many of the mechanics come across as merely stalling for time and forcing players to repeat low level areas.

								I really love this game.  I feel like theres so much at stake all the time.  The rewards feel great, the losses hurt, and getting lucky in the game is extremely satisfying.   The creatures and heroes are creative and not simply old cliche classes.  The artwork is gorey and immersive. The music is haunting.  It is challenging and painful.  The battle system is lots of fun. content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Game starts out like a difficult RPG but quickly devolves into a resource management sim similar to a Facebook game like Farmville or Vampire Town. The reason for this is the much-too-punishing RNG over which the player has little control and there is simply no strategy to overcome. Because a single surprise attack can instantly destroy any character in your party, the only sensible way to proceed is to avoid taking any extra risks whatsoever. In the language of this game, this means sending out parties of throwaway characters and deleting them.The game advertises itself as "difficult" but a better explanation is that it is "grindy," and the player forced into the role of an HR manager of a fast food restaurant where employees quit at random. Doubling down on the resource Facebook-game aspect of DD, the game forces the player to "gamble" prior to each mission and expend money on tools. This aspect of the game feels like a money trough. Overall, game has some nice graphics and some promising features, but feels more like managing a Wendy's restaurant than a horror RPG.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. The graphics are amazing, the idea behind it is fresh and interesting, but sadly I cannot reccomend it. o) It becomes repetative fast, mostly because it is very punishing. You have no time to get attached to any of the characters because they'll die anyway, and every character is simply their class. Meaning if your one healer dies you probably have 2 others, that look the same except for maybe a different colour scheme and you might have to unlock one of the skills you prefer using. o)The AI is too smart. While I appreciate enemies that actually fight smart, it's a bit frustrating when they constantly and effectively kill your characters. When your characters all have about the same health they will spread outt heir attacks but as soon as one of your characters health gets too low they will usually gang up on this character and attack them until they're dead.o) Because it's so punishing you almost never get to finish a quest. I still only went to the apprentice levels, I had leveld up party members, and still I had to retreat a lot because either half of them died, were so stressed out that they were about to have a heart attack, or it was clear I wasn't going to finish it. And to make it clear, I'm not complaining about the fact that this game is difficult, what I dislike is that I feel it is difficult just for the sake of being difficult. Bloodborn is also difficult, but there are no random elements to it. You have to figure out how to get past certain enemies, how to kill them etc. Dark Dungeons has too many randomized events which makes it impossible to truly learn what to do. Especially when half of the party that you needed for that strategy just died. I would consider changing this review and recommending that if the AI was a bit more balanced.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is not an experience I would ever think of myself describing it as being as therapeutic as it is enjoyable and demoralizing. This is said from someone who gets too paranoid when playing horror games and deals with anxiety issues, and I have come away feeling more at ease when playing than I ever thought I would.For the longest time, a lot of the things I had heard kept me from DD. The "grind", the artificial difficulty spikes ("Never Again"), and various aspects of it being a rouge-like experience kept me unconvinced until I saw a steep enough sale. Now that I've put 23 hours into my first 52 weeks, I think if you know a few things about DD you will find a game that doesn't suffer from its repetition and that justifies its infamous difficulty.In many ways, if I were to recommend this game to a specific audience I would suggest it to people who want to understand/get-into difficult games (like XCOM) but who also don't like the idea of failure-states after 15+ hours into a game. You cannot fail DD at any point in the normal mode—NG+ adds a time-limit of 90 weeks and a character death quota of 13. Games like these understand its shortcomings from RNG, so to alleviate the pressure the developers provide you with many ways to live with your mistakes. The only way you will lose to this game—excluding NG+ modifiers—is if you give up or constantly make bad judgment calls. No other game that uses RNG has ever made me feel as responsible for my errors. The inevitability of screwing up will happen, but you'll learn to deal with it to finish the game. In many ways, DD teaches you how to deal with issues one catastrophe at a time.Not Your Common Rogue-LikeOf all the rouge-likes/lites out there, this one is my favorite design. In most cases, the presence of RNG ruins these games into being more reliant on luck than actual skill/knowledge, and the repetition of doing all the previous content over-and-over will tire you out from ever succeeding. DD, however, mitigates these problems in various ways. For one, the RNG here is tastefully applied to heighten the tension in and out of combat. Unlike the 99% of other rogue-likes, you do not fail the whole game from one encounter; your progression is kept at the Hamlet. Human lives are a free, expendable commodity never in short-supply—something you can exploit for min-maxing. You may dismiss party members because they're too expensive to "repair" or you can deal with their quirks, which are never game-breaking or are impossible to remove. (The exception being "Never Again.")Another difference is how the gameplay prevents you from screwing up from one turn. One example is the "At Death's Door" (0 HP)  mechanic where you can take an additional hit(s) before your character dies. The percentage chance to resist death is given to you, and you can avoid this mistake by either moving him/her out of harm's way or use skills that protect, heal (for 1 HP minimum) or other tactics to draw attention away from the character. You can always flee-battles (which counts as exploring a room) and abandon quests to save your party and return with the loot you have. Stress-management, a vital thing to master, can easily be handled with a "stress-healer" when in dungeons or by careful management of your whole party roster at the Hamlet. And because death is permanent, you should never have one A-Team, B-Team, etc. but a selection of skilled adventurers with various synergies available to you. The infamous  "Never Again" quirk shouldn't ruin the game because the whole experience is about making the best with what you are given, so you have to learn to be flexible.In many ways, the tactics DD teaches you is similar to card games where you have to know when to bluff to risk the odds and when to fold and take your winnings. Even if you abandon a quest, you will most likely earn enough gold to be a net-gain. The difference between both games is that winning at DD is inevitable, only that the time required to finish it is based on how eager you are to challenge the odds.The Developers' Divine ComedyDifficulty is something of a double-edge sword. If the game is too demanding of the player, the player becomes apathetic of success though s/he may find the success more rewarding; if the game is too easy, it becomes a slog to replay tedious content but beatable. I want to say that DD finds the happy medium in its "safety-net" grind, but I don't think every player would agree that it's flawless.As previously mentioned, the game lacks a final fail-state outcome where you have to start over until you beat the game once. The fail-state, at this point, is tolerable because you will have to understand the mechanics and how the game wants you to play it in order to win. The only way that the game keeps you engaged from this system is if the game keeps its punishments as an ever-looming threat from the tediousness of doing the same five mission types (Clear X rooms, Find 3 X, Restore 3 X, Slay X Boss and Darkest Dungeons.)The difficulty reinforces the developers' intentions for you to play the game as they wanted you to play it, which hasn't always agreed with its Early Access community.Based off my experiences, I see nothing wrong with all the changes. Corpses add a risk/reward to using skills that may destroy the body (and loot); heart-attacks emphasize the penalty of not managing stress or taking too long in battle; the reinforcement addition discourages stun-locking enemies to heal the party entirely in battle (you can't use skills outside of combat)—this last mechanic I've never seen happen to me, so it's not too demanding.  All of these changes were made to cut out the cheap tactics and make the experience more risk/rewarding, which I am personally fine with as the game feels designed for these changes. However, I still wonder why they took away the option to add/remove these additions.All of these elements contribute to the game staying interesting from a 35 - 40 hour playtime (average for a 90 week playthrough for NG+) in spite of its limited content variety. The three-tiered layout of the entire game (Lv 1, Lv 3, and Lv 5) areas help foster a sense of scaling difficulty for the Lv 6 Darkest Dungeons (4 of them). Lastly, the other updated changes like transferring heirlooms for one-another helps cut down on the grindier aspects of the game.The problem, however, is if you are a completionist or too conservative of a player, which may make the game take 70+ hours. In that regard, there is not enough variety to keep the game compelling for that length, even if you're a die-hard for turn-based squad-strategy games. You don't have to complete the Caretaker's Tasks to beat the game as the bosses only give you a different mission type and Trinkets as rewards. The process of rebuilding a lost-squad member is somewhat randomized by both the class and level assigned to them from the caravan. (The highest you can unlock is a chance to get Lv 3 heroes, out of 6). But the process of rebuilding the team isn't that long as missions give you a substantial amount of XP to rebuild a Lv 6 team in 2/3 hours. Ultimately, what separates a grind from progression is what is the end goal. If you set mile-stones to slay one boss to get that one trinket, if you vary up your party-arrangement to level them all up, and if you focus on building certain structures in the Hamlet to improve your whole roster, etc. then you should never feel as though you are slogging through the game."Math, I'm Not Your Psychologist; Solve Your Own Problems"	As someone who is a fan of reviewers like Joseph Anderson—and he has done a good critique of DD with a lot of complaints I agree —I want to reiterate that this game is not going to be for everyone. But I think a lot of people who would be interested are dissuaded by EA adopters and people who take as few risks as possible.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I keep coming back to this game over and over, and as much as I love roguelikes I just can't love this game. Nothing I do in it seems to matter. I like the theme, but they take it to an extent where even the gameplay becomes meaningless. The chest is trapped so you don't get to open it? What a ♥♥♥♥ing waste of time. "Oh but it's the theme dusty, despair." Purposefully making me feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥doesn't make it fun. I've played tons of balls-to-the-wall hard roguelikes and at least a sense of ADVANCEMENT after all the grinding is satisfying. Nothing about this game satisfies me. Characters will randomly go down the toilet, the artifacts you throw on your characters are a roll of the dice, the stress system is dumped all over your characters, and all the resources you recieve are drained by the ridiculous prices to the point where this game is a giant ♥♥♥♥ing windmill of a grinder. It's literally Roll the Dice to Grind: The Game. You will spend 2 hours preparing for a mission only for it to fail miserably, and the slog is only exemplified by the insanely slow crawl through Random Number Generator-ville. If I wanted to pop back in Dragon Warrior, or Final Fantasy 1, and fight♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over running around, I would, but at least I'd have an overmap. These are just very pretty hallways that don't interest me with anything other than lots of GOTCHA moments. GOTCHA DUSTY....OH WAIT 5 SECONDS LATER GOTCHA AGAIN! Repetitive and entirely too frequent, too ♥♥♥♥ing soon.I also couldn't give two-flippin-♥♥♥♥s about the "upgrade your base" system. This is a dungeoncrawl. I'm not here for sim city.My point is, they didn't try anything new with the genre, and instead made it HALF of the genre game, and then filled it with doodads and other systems (stress), and then the UNECESSARY EVIL OF ALL: stretched the levels and combat so much so that instead of taking 2 hours to get through several dungeons, you're taking 2 hours to get through 1. And don't give me that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about "careful planning," there's a point where it gets way too ♥♥♥♥ing autistic. Go play Stone Soup, NetHack or Dwarf Fortress if you want something with a little more substance and just about as much rng. I was just playing and I'm like "man I would rather be spending my time playing Dungeons of Dredmor, or FTL, or Rogue Legacy, or Risk of Rain or ANYTHING other than this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; because the change of scenery and the character ascension factor (despite whether you screw up or not) is at least satisfying to me. It gives me pleasure. Like videogames should. Unlike this game, and Super Meat Boy. No thankarino, Arino.~There's a point where "challenge" just becomes a buzzword for people's taste in fun. Let's be honest guys, it's pretty colors, themes, a guy who does really good voice acting, but at it's core it's a game with a lot of elements, potential, but they executed it poorly in order to make the Kickstarter fans feel like they bought something with a lot of content by stretching it out. That's what most developers do when they make an "Insane" difficulty in their games. They stretch it out. I WANT to love this game. Everything I want is in it. The only problem is the guy behind the wheel won't get the ♥♥♥♥ out of the car and let me drive the damn thing.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												As many others have stated, the game is garbage. The RNG determines the outcome of a dungeon raid and nothing else. The problem with the RNG is that the only effects are negative. Progression is soooo slow with this crap. So if you are a masochist, buy this game. You'll have loads of self punishment with it. Many people; including myself, enjoy building and keeping characters and using just those. This game however, uses characters as disposable tools that you just throw away every few dungeons. I'm not a fan of that mechanic. The game lacks any useful options to tailor the game towards your desired game-play as well. No difficulty or "please remove X from the RNG list" options. Another major problem is the UI doesn't give the user everything that they need to know. Even people on the forums will give you the wrong information because they don't even know. Example: have a skill that works on religious characters? Great! Which ones are religious? Game wont tell you. People on the forums will tell you that "God fearing" quirk will make them religious because that makes sense... NOPE! Not at all true. The Devs have all but abandoned adding or changing the content of the game and are only releasing patches to fix basic bugs.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I could think of a million good things to say about this game. Everything from the visuals to the sound design to the gameplay is stunningly wonderful, and accomplishes its goals with ease. This is certainly one of the few early access games that more than earns its somewhat inflated price, and which you should play if you enjoy hard core RPGs.I see a lot of people posting negative reviews for this game who have less than 10 hours on record, complaining that they've just lost their best heroes or that a boss totally destroyed them, and so the game isn't recommended. I find it bemusingly appropriate that the game, which sets out to create an oppressive and worrisome atmosphere even for the player themself, appears to be doing its job well; the Dungeon is defeating many with its steep difficulty curve. The game warns you up front that heroes will die, and that bad things will happen no matter what. If you play this game, indeed prepare for the worst, but don't throw in the towel the first time it happens!Don't listen to them, and become Hopeless! Instead become Stalwart, roll up your sleeves, mourn your dead, and push harder through the Darkest Dungeon!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												I am very sad about this game. I had such high hopes for it. It is a great concept, it has great art, it has a great vibe, the voice acting is terrific so what could have gone so wrong?The gameplay.It all boils down to one problem. If you want to have a game about psychological damage the most important thing is that the player should care about the characters, a lot. You have to set it up to say "you are stuck with this guy however insane it gets". You have to feel like you are on a minecart ride to hell where then only way out is to go all the way down.Instead what this game does is throw hundreds of characters at you. You need 4 per week to make an adventuring squad but you can get up to 8 replacements! So yeah you end up with a massive squad of 16 adventurers whose names you don't even know. Has one of them gone insane? Chuck them out and get another to fill their place. Everyone is disposable.Drowning in characters means it's impossible to care about any of them. It's such a shame because this game could have been a true great, instead it's a complete fail.If they just made it so that you had a small squad which you needed to cherish, with maybe a replacement every once in a while. If only you had to sit in the town thinking "I really want to stay here for another week to rest but I need to keep pressing on deeper into the dungeon because I have to beat the timer" this really could have been a huge win.Instead they bungled it.

number of helpful: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												I've been meaning to write a review for some time now.I understand why people like this game and I think it's well made, but it really isn't for me. It is not the elements of extreme difficulty and surprise mixed in with the factor that the game is incredibly unforgiving if you make a mistake. I actually love that concept. This game has so much depth and so much to discover that not even 100 hours of gameplay should be considered enough to actually feel like you know the game. Every time you feel like you're starting to learn a pattern and you're managing to breeze past dungeons, that pattern changes and you feel like you're back at square one again. You feel like you've only just scratched the surface and only played a small amount of what the game has to offer.My criticisms are that the game just feels repetitive and it's not engaging. The gameplay quickly becomes stale and it doesn't have any exciting factor that wants me to keep playng. I suppose the critical strike factor is nice and all in addition to being able to draft your dream teams and test builds which are more optimal than others so you can succeed, but there is nothing there that encourages me to play more. Everything just feels... wrong? I don't know how to describe it but I just honestly did not enjoy the game. I think if you're a fan of games like this then go ahead and buy it, but it caters to a very niche audience so be sure to watch a bit of developed gameplay or a play through of it (don't start watching it from the beginning, that would be boring). Then you should make your decision.

Posted: November 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Random everything generation makes this game ridiculously hard. The concept and gameplay is great, but you will die...alot...and never have any control over those deaths at all. Everything from your character access to whether or not your skills work is random. Its very much like watching someone get struck by lightning 30 times in a row, or hit the lottery everytime they play only to always get hit by a meteor when they pick up their ticket. Lots of potential here, but doesn't quite make it to being playable...unless masochism is what the devs were going for. In which case they hit the bullseye.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't review many games, but I came here after a fit of almost punching my computer screen.  This game has so much potential.  Stunning mood, artwork, and gameplay concepts.  But it is HARD.  I don't mind difficulty, I think only difficulty can bring a truly rewarding play experience.  But this is randomly unfair, keyboard-throwingly hard.  You can work for hours to build up a killer party grinding easy missions and buying tons of gear, only to get to a very small, easy fight where one mob crits your whole party and they all go insane and die.  You lose everything you worked for in an instant because of a fluke of bad luck.  You can put a hero out of comission for a week to cure one mental illness, only to pick up 5 more illnesses every single week on every character that participates.  You upgrade your town to make it better, but what's the point?  Nothing seems to make it any easier or less grindy.Or, there are a couple interface hiccups, like what just happened to me: Find an object which you can use a shovel on, and the interface LOOKS like you're going to use the shovel, but no, it's slightly greyed out and you messed up.  Your party digs through the thing barehanded, and (yes) goes insane and dies.I want to like this game, I kickstarted it many months ago and I've really been looking forward to it.  But the sheer sense of constantly losing an impossible battle is really too much for me.  I want to have at least some kind of fun playing videogames.  This is just this overwhelming downhill slide of frustration and failure.  I feel like I'm one of the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s inside the game, trapped and doomed.  I'm really sad that I'm not enjoying it at all.

Posted: April 6
												Random.Random.Random.Random.Random.That's what it feels like to play this game.Everything, everywhere has a % symbol.I like being good at things.It's pure frustration for me to have so ridiculously little influence over the game I'm playing.It honestly doesn't matter at all if you are doing EVERYTHING right.Even if you have a well balanced team with upgraded skills and healing capabilities, you manage to keep EVERYONE'S health a very close to maximum all the time, while still hacking through the enemies, because it ALWAYS, ALWAYS, ALWAYS comes down to random outcomes anyway.Suddently an enemy makes a MASSIVE critical hit that both instantly knocks down 2 of your members to last-stand (where one more hit kills them) AND stuns the entire party, leaving you COMPLETELY HELPLESS to do ANYTHING to keep them alive.Hard, skill-based games are awesome, becaue it's so rewarding when you finally get good at them.Games that are hard, just for the sake of being hard, just for the sake of being able to boast about being hard, are the worst ♥♥♥♥ing games that you can possibly make...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
Early Access Review
A few fortnights back, in the darkest annals of the internet, I came across a singularly striking dungeon crawler by the name of Darkest Dungeon. It had not yet been released but I was wooed by it's beautifully sinister graphics and sanity mechanics.The day the game was released on Steam for Early Access I immediately purchased it and never looked back. This game is incredible even in its unfinished state. The art, music and narration combine so effectively to create an eery, oppressive atmosphere. This is best experienced in my favourite of the current dungeons, The Warrens. You are beset by disgusting, malformed pig creatures that vomit on your adventurers to break their morale. When your torch dies out you can hear a constant chorus of squeeling in the background. If you make it through alive you really feel like you survived a traumatic experience, and your adventurers will be similarly scarred.There are a few minor design squabbles I have: one of them being the way hunger works (or doesn't work) and another being that some of the classes are quite underpowered. But for the most part the RPG mechanics are very well thought out and implemented.Overall I would r8 this gr8. 8/8

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												"At last, in the salt-soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations, we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil."  That's from the (frankly brilliant) introductory cut-scene of this game, and it just gets doomier and darker from there.    Tired of the "lighter" fantasy elements in RPGs?  Hate hobbits, for example?!  Here, have a claustrophobic crusader (who's also a kleptomaniac) instead.  Weary of kindly old pointy-hatted wizards?  Here's a plague doctor for your grenade-lobbing, disease-spreading pleasure.  How's about a bounty hunter with bulimia, to fill the party out a bit more?  Oh, and I hear that your vestal (cleric) is suffering from stress?  Perhaps I can suggest she spend the rest of the week flagellating herself in the abbey for her sins?    This game by and largely takes a Call of Cthulhu (the tabletop RPG) approach to dungeon-hacking...which is to say, don't get too attached to your characters, as they're gonna die pretty regularly!  It also has a wickedly black sense of humour, wonderfully charming graphics, more-than-serviceable sound, a genuinely interesting "skill"-based approach to combat, and is one of the few games I can think of where permadeath and irreversible auto-saves are actually JUSTIFIED.  In a genre of video gaming all but literally done to death, it's quite amazing how many (relatively) fresh tricks this one has up its sleeves.       I gave in to buying and playing this prematurely due to the amazingly positive reviews and ridiculous amount of playing hours wracked up by some players for such an Early Access game - if that doesn't speak of its quality, I'm not sure what does - but another look at the Store page tells me the game doesn't yet have a proper ending, so I might wait 'til it's officially finished before playing any further.  But MAN, am I impressed thus far.  Definitely shaping up to be one of the all-time best games of its type, especially for those of us with a heavy bias towards the gothic and horrible.  Verdict: 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This as yet unreleased game received some of the most glowing reviews from the gaming press that I have seen in quite some time.  I have to disagree.The game has a great atmosphere and wonderful graphics and sounds that perfectly fit the mood, however, the core elements of class skills, combat, and leveling are lacking.Class skills are simple and generic leading to few relatively simple strategies for each class, which makes combat mostly about RNG, not player choices.  Since skills are cast from certain positions and hit pre-determined enemy positions, another element of player control is lost.  Accordingly, you could probably write a fairly simplistic algorithm to replace the decision making involved in fighting and not lose anything in the process.  Considering that you have do a very considerable amount of grinding to create a party capable of higher level zones, and considering that those higher level party members can no longer help in lower level zones, what you end up with is excessive repetition of tedious content where success is mostly up to the RNG gods.No amount of chanting 'hardcore' or 'permadeath' or 'roguelike' will do anything to help with flaws like this.  To me, a good rpg requires that in game challenges be responsive to player decisions more than they are to random rolls.  In old 'roguelike' games such as Nethack, player knowledge contributed to victory at least as much as RNG factors.  A good player was one who knew the options and the capabilities of the creatures they encountered.  They were not simply lucky. RNG was a factor to overcome by foresight, preparation, and knowledge.I hope that as the game develops, this issue can be addressed.  I would happily grind away if I felt like my choices in battle made much of a difference, but, as it stands, I'd be better off placing bets with myself and rolling a d20.

number of helpful: 21 of 38 people (55%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Do you like having yourself dodged every attack but not be given the same priviledge? Do you want to be doing decent, and then, have events well beyond your control and not even playable around destroy what would be a 'mediocre' run and turn it into one where you delete your save and just start over? This game is so poorly tuned right now it's not even funny. The damage difference is enormous between you and mobs, there are no tools in place to even 'allow' the idea of a group not comprised of most of your frontliners. If they have to be benched, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. Plain and simple. Why might they be benched? Whatever rng gods have in store. Things you can't play around. You just accept. I've deleted my starting game after artbirary dogshit that is impossible to prevent more times than I can count at this point. Oh, you can't also spend precious time using abilities that buff yourself. That is precious, precious time that the enemy gets to attack you through so if you pause and miss MAYBE eliminating one of them for some +15 accuracy (that still doesn't negate dodge) buff then odds are you take damage that makes completing the mission impossible. And that can happen in the first step of the dungeon.What a poorly designed♥♥♥♥♥♥hole of a system.When damage, when skills, when stress is balanced maybe you can get this game. Right now? No. Don't give a dime. I like rogue-likes, this is just like a Cthulu run through DnD basically forcing you to die for no one's amusement but the AI with literally no hope of preventing it.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Below you'll find a gameplay video on the game with a written impression


YouTube™ Video: Darkest Dungeon: First Look / Let's play - Early Access Gameplay - 01 

			Views: 224		

			Darkest Dungeon: First Look / Let's play Darkest Dungeon is the latest in rogue like/lite RPG. It's still in early access but we're going to dive into the darkness and dangers of so we can hunt for...		

Darkest Dungeon is a tough as nails turn based RPG with  procedurally generated scenarios and dungeons. The game has tons of replay, deep RPG mechanics, a great gothic comic art style, and rip your hair out difficulty. The game will screw you when ever it can, it's like role playing murphy's law.It's in early access, but to me it already feels very polished and full. The game feels quite complete even in it's current state and I simply can't wait to see future updates.It's hard for me to find any flaws as I've thoroughly enjoyed what the game has to offer. It's take on the genre is some thing very enjoyable. I can not recommend Darkest Dungeon enough.Pros:- Great aesthetics - Enjoyable take on turn based RPG- Deep with a high skill ceiling- Very polished and playable as an early accessCons:- Can be frustrating to some- Don't expect a fleshed out narrative like other RPGs

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I very rarely play rougelike games. Or at least I didn't start playing them until recently since they weren't my cup of tea. I've heard of Darkest Dungeon from game reviewers and it grabbed my attention. Even though its an early access game I have to say that this is by far a worthwhile purchase.The game offers quite a lot to do and it doesn't hold your hands. If you can die in the so called "tutorial" (which happened to me once) it just goes to show that it has great potential. The dungeons can be long or short, the quests vary and your party is "paper". You have to be careful with them, you have to pay attention and think on how to proceed. In this game, you or your party aren't immortal or godlike heroes. Its best to say that you should not get attached to any party member as they will eventually die. But this makes the game much more interesting. I definately recommend it even at this stage in development.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												To put it simply, I'm still in love in love with this game.The art style is akin to a Mike Mignola comic, right down to the usage of shadows and the color palette. The music is eerie and foreboding. The voice acting--the narrator--draws me in. I find myself walking around the house saying all these big words in a deep voice to annoy my wife now.For an early access game, it plays like a complete game. The character classes available are well polished, the creatures and encounters unique and moderately challenging (I’ll get to that), and the interface bug free.The game itself can be unforgiving. I find myself cheering when I land a much-needed crit, or yelling WTF when I find myself missing over and over. I've had my share of deaths, but as I reach the higher levels, unless I really go against the grain with roster selections for encounters, I have no trouble. After reaching Level 2, I've had minimal deaths since I'm playing a low risk, low reward style of play as I learn the ropes. I can imagine that if you brought little in the way of torches, food and bandages to a dungeon, the difficulty and loot would scale upwards (and you could carry more home..)I can't wait to try and new classes and start playing around with more rewarding party combos.If you are looking for a different, immersive, dark RPG style game, pick this up. Don't blame me if you utter "Cruel machinations!" in a radio voice as you step on a Lego in the dark in your kid's room.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Whats the most important criteria to decide wether or not to buy this game?Its the thrill of challenge. This of all things is what DarkestDungeon provides imo the most. I am not going into the gameplay too deep, but it mostly evolves around a continuos onslaught on your physical and mental health during dungeoncrawling (go watch some gameplay-videos on youtube or so). And let me tell you, the word "fair" is lacking in the dictionary of the DarkestDungeon (which is on the other hand extensive beyond the measures of everyday communication - Wayne Junes voiceacting is just on point in this game). There is no such thing as an "irrelevant miss" from your frontlines, or a "harmless Crit" from the enemy, and most of all, not even the slightest mistake is forgiven. Sometimes, your biggest enemy is chance.But exactly this aspect is what makes this game so exciting - to win against the odds, to make the best out of a bad situation, as the game tells you in the very beginning. Many People complain that the difficulty takes away the fun, that they feel restricted by it, but its a key element to the game (otherwise it wouldnt be called the "darkest" dungeon, duh). And by that I knowingly include all the ridiculous RNG. Because thats when true heroes emerge. Getting that one critical hit that turns the tides of battle, that one positive resolve-check when you almost felt all hope was lost, is just glorious.Also, as you start to learn the combat system, expeditions will become more consistent, and team-compositions adjusted for specific quests are able to overcome most of whats thrown at them. Yet the game keeps challenging you. Bosses requiring a planned takedown. The final DarkestDungeon-quests (especially looking at you, second one) with insane difficulty level. And once you are even proficient enough to master those and win the game, beware the horror that is NG+And that concludes my (subjective) analysis of the joy this game provides. If you are willing to accept the challenge, answer the letter, brace yourself, and venture into the shadow of the DarkestDungeon. Because...RUIN HAS COME TO OUR FAMILY

												Have 200 hours clocked in this bad boy.+ Art design is great+ Addictive+ Narration is amazing+ Well thought out mechanics+ Consistent overall atmosphere+ Low amount of bugs+ Adult themes that arent gratuitous- RNG (random number generation) hell- RNG hell- Makes you quit the game because of RNG- High focus on economy (not what I'm after in this kind of game)- Some UI inconsistencies from time to time- 7th circle RNG hellIf you have 2 monitors, you'll wanna load up a wiki page with a guide to objects in the game and their interactions on your other screen as you dungeon crawl.On sale of 33% or more, definitely worth grabbing.
