content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												One of the best games I played, some of the complaints are unfair imo it depends on how you view the game are you playing for fun or just to win? Saying that, there is very little RNG in this game, the fight is won before it begins, it's all about picking the right team comp and skills and knowing what to do in a fight:Some spoilers below:I'll give you one example: I was going through a lvl 6 dungeon ( the infamous event ) and all was going well until the final fight, to cut things short I lost the first fight, looking back it wasn't because of RNG, my first few turns I decided to focus the wrong target, by the End of the fight the Boss barely needed one hit but because of the mistakes I did at first my team died before I could finish him off if I hadn't done those mistakes my entire team would have survived, and I would have walked out with insane loot.What i'm saying here sometimes you might get screwed over but a good 95% of the times if you look back, you will see that you did some things wrong ( I should have stunned that, I should have went for a heal etc.)Before lvl 5 and 6 dungeon you can go with whatever and make it work, afterwards you can still do it but it will require a bit of planning and a bit more investment in your characters if you want to pick randomly, and the more you play you'll see that there is barely any RNG in this game and that it's only their to keep you on your toes every once in a while.Different fights can be done in may different ways, you can go out all dmg, or have a traditional comp of "healer+tank", you can go all out debuff + guard, you can make anything work if you want, that's the fun of this game trying out different compositions, hell if you get mad you can cheese some fights for the hell of it.My advice is don't be alarmed and don't listen when someone says you MUST use a certain hero, it might make your life easier it might not it all depends on your playstyle and which heroes YOU prefer using.I recommend this game if you enjoy dungeon crawlers and you enjoy playing games for fun + challenge, because if you're only playing it just to "beat it" you might rage more if you get a severe loss in game, but everyone's got their own reasons.I honestly can't wait to see what these devs will do next.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a 2-D roguelike dungeon crawler that tasks you to put together a rag-tag group of misfits, crusaders and bandits to raid neighboring areas in preparation for the largest raid into the Darkest Dungeon, which is narratively built to be a festering, climatic and brutal playground of destructive beasts and traps. The title's core gameplay involves 3 pillars at various stages of your raiding excursions: preparation, exploration and combat, supplanting these core aspects with a variety of nuanced systems that enhance its difficulty, strategic necessity and more. You prepare for your dungeon raids in Hamlet, a small, decrepit town of hollowed out buildings and decaying structures. These buildings serve various roles to your team, from recruiting new team members, buying new equipment, visiting saloons and cathedrals for stress relief and blacksmith and guild workshops to upgrade their talents. You pay gold to obtain their services and utilize other collectable trinkets to permanently upgrade their efficiency, cost and number of teammates that can be serviced at once. It’s also in Hamlet where you do pre-mission preparation and provisioning for items you’ll need for the upcoming mission. Party order and composition are extremely important here, since particular characters are skilled at building basecamps, healing and even scouting rooms at random to give you a better sense of the challenges headed your way. Since there is no chest system for storing items you don’t use on missions either, you can quickly spend yourself dry on key items if you don’t carefully micromanage your gold.Once you embark on a mission, you’ll begin in a random room in the chosen dungeon. It’s at this point you’ll walk right on a 2-D plane and explore, coming across different optional items, obstacles as well as traps and enemy encounters. These items range from chests, corpses, old books, torches and many more, and each occasion you can choose whether to interact with them or not, and each object could hurt or hinder your team, from a sudden bleeding or poison effect or even a new permanent characteristic or loot/gold. Barricade obstacles are unpassable and must either be removed with a shovel or with your team’s bare hands (taking some health away as well). Traps can often be spotted on the ground, but are invisible depending on your constantly draining torch meter at the top of the screen, which dictates your visibility and can confer advantages or disadvantages depending on its level (ranging from pitch black to radiant brightness). Opposing teams can even get the jump on you and attack first if they attack with no torch equipped. It also affects how much stress your team will accumulate, which is an actual statistic the game keeps track of for each party member and will often affect their combat abilities, their quotes and even their performance off the battlefield. If left unchecked, a character with a tremendous stress level may begin to disobey your orders, loot a booby trap without you clicking and several other unintended negative effects. You must complete the objective in order to leave the dungeon, with the goal often being exploring the majority of the dungeon, clearing every room or even defeating a particularly strong adversary.Finally, once you run into a combat scenario, the game’s varied and cinematic combat begins. Your team stands in a row, with the one farthest to the right typically your melee fighters to stay up close, and the one on the far left your ranged fighters who prefer to keep their distance, although you can choose and party members placement to your hearts content. However, their placement affects what abilities can and cannot be used. There is a speed stat in the game but often times it is random who will strike first¬¬¬. Enemies often have additional attributes to their attacks, like poison damage, stun and knockback/shuffle, which forcefully displaces the party member’s original position to a different spot, often putting melee fighters far away and so on. Other moves can heal, buff or de-buff characters on screen and even do a much stronger attack in exchange for detrimental effects in upcoming turns.  Once an enemy is defeated, corpses are left on the battlefield that can either be destroyed for easier access to the remaining foes or left to loot later for additional rewards. Taking a major hit, being cursed by certain incantations or certain party members being near a particular type of foe will stack stress on your character. Stress affects combat in a number of ways, but the most nefarious ones are characters at high stress levels receiving afflictions, which instill random negative effects like auto-attacking a random target, passing or even shouting to stress out neighboring party members. At its worse, stress can even result in a character permanently dying from a heart attack mid-battle, removing them entirely from your game.Darkest Dungeon offers a grim but striking and appealing Gothic art style, with every corner of its game world dripping with disgusting monster effects and sounds, occasionally disturbing character dialogue and an atmosphere of brutality. The art style perfectly captures this feeling, with even the character designs feeling worn down and battle-torn, from the healing cleric’s tattered robe to the abominations vulgar appearance. Everything feels well placed and methodically tuned to deliver a mood of foreboding. The dungeons as well feel aged and mysterious, although repetitious at times with their similar setups of traps and set hallway lengths. This tone is complimented further by a bombastic and epic narrator who voices many of the proceedings, whether it be the end of a battle or key event, a particularly gruesome kill or just a well written quip of battlefield dialogue to enhance the mood. The narrator greatly accented my enjoyment with the game because he always made the events transpiring more interesting and eventful. There are tons of other smaller touches you may use to personalize your quest as well, not least of which being able to name each member of your party. While a small touch, I ended up naming the best of my squad the names of some of my closest family and friends, which in some ways was quite a mistake as I approached higher difficulty areas. My most palpable moment of dread and overwhelming exertion with Darkest Dungeon came with my encounter with that first boss, who due to my drastic underestimation of his abilities was able to decimate my entire team, with the 4 members lost consisting of the real life names of my sister, cousin and 2 best friends, all while my self-named character was resting comfortably back in Hamlet. It’s a shocking effectively blow to my morale, self-perceived skill level and pride, never feeling so defeated when I returned to Hamlet knowing that I had gotten several of my “family and friends” killed. I even started building my own stories on how my remaining party members would be reacting knowing the losses we had incurred. While not everyone may end up having that experience, it was one of the most sincere moments of shock I felt while playing.Darkest Dungeon hits all the rights notes with its methodical combat, Victorian gothic visual style and its sense of mystery in exploration. Preparing for missions felt worthwhile and necessary, with optimum planning essential to keeping party members alive and as unstressed as possible. The story was a bit disappointing but creating my own narrative and character personalities by naming my characters gave the fledgling tale much more weight and personal depth. The number of options and factors at play in any given gameplay scenario is often breathtaking and overwhelming, but remains fun and challenging in all the right ways. Darkest Dungeon is a superb title and a truly fantastic start to 2016 for me. I highly recommend it.

Preparing for missions felt worthwhile and necessary, with optimum planning essential to keeping party members alive and as unstressed as possible. The story was a bit disappointing but creating my own narrative and character personalities by naming my characters gave the fledgling tale much more weight and personal depth. The number of options and factors at play in any given gameplay scenario is often breathtaking and overwhelming, but remains fun and challenging in all the right ways. Darkest Dungeon is a superb title and a truly fantastic start to 2016 for me. I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Highly Recommended. As a general statement, if you enjoy tactical games that force you to think, stay engaged, reward planning, are challenging, allow significant experimentation and variability and give a strong sense of accomplishment, this is the game for you. I have played a lot of tactical games over the years, such as both XCOM's, Fire Emblems, Dungeon of the Endless, many playstation era tactics and RPG's, and this game is argueably one of the better ones. While each is different, the aspect I enjoy probably most about Darkest Dungeon is that even when you get later into the game, it will never allow you to go on auto-pilot. By that I mean that I find with many tactic games, once you get a party to a certain point, enemies start to die much quicker and the challenge is gone; it makes you think back to when you first started the game and it was better. Darkest Dungeon captures that enjoyment as each run through a dungeon feels like its own game. Losing champions is definitely frustrating and sometimes it feels like the game is against you, but once you get a feel for it you will be suprised how quickly you can recuit and train up new heroes.  Some context to the above:- The planning and attacking phases are very well laid out. By this I mean before you enter a dugeon you have a significant control over: Who your party will be, what items they will take, what map size you want, what consumable items you will buy and what skills you will use. Have a short amount of time to play? Play a smaller map. - The heroes and dungeons are created in such a way that they give you a lot to think about and experiment with. Even 50 hours or so into the game I was still experimenting with party and skill combinations. This helps keep the game fresh as you will likely always have a favorite party, but the mechanics will force you to play will different groups.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon."My obsession caused this great foulness, and it is shameful that I must rely upon you to set it right."Set within an victoria-fantasy setting, this gothic infused rogue-like dungeon crawler will without a doubt have you on the edge of your seat. A game, not only about expending resources to benefit the greater good of YOUR party, but the newcomers that arrive washed up from days of trecking.Horrors beyond your wildest imagination will strike you at every corner and crevess, leaving you scampering on the tip of toes as you search room to room for gold and prized possessions. Not only do you have to manage the stress your heroes will overcome, but the vitality of the town you so predominantly dwell in. Will you scarper and abandon all hope? Or persevere and fight the monsters that seek to destroy you, head on? This is no place for the weak for only the strong will survive -- The Darkest Dungeon.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												I love this game. I don't play early access games, since I'm more interested in the finished product; I made an exception for Darkest Dungeon prior to its release. It's atmospheric eye-candy that captures an oppressive tone and mood I could only replicate in my dreams. The sound and art design are to die for, honestly. The Narrator sends chills down my spine.It's hard. You have to sow time and energy into learning the mechanics of the game-- but I think that's fun. I like trial and error learning; I feel accomplished when I assemble a team that works well in a dungeon where I'm not entirely sure what to expect. If you enjoy, say, Nuzlocke runs of Pokemon, I feel like the two are similar when it comes to developing strategies. (And when it comes to accepting that RNG does play a role in your success and failure.)Darkest Dungeon is really one of my favorites. You will have runs that go down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but that's the exception, not the rule. It's a matter of taking things slow and just playing the game for what it is, I think. It's not everyone's cup of tea, but if you are intrigued by what the game offers, I strongly recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Facts: turn based dungeon crawler, great art style, monsters design, clever mechanics (for example stress, quirks, roster shuffling), synergies, a metric crapton of strategies to succeed. So for mechanics, presentation and overall quality of the game 9/10Now I want to adress some issues that majority of people seem to have with this game:1) difficulty spike in champion (and further) dungeons - what people seem to not understand or rather refuse to adapt to is this subtle change of balance in the later game. At the beginning you're good to go with 4 pure damage units, just bashing everything into oblivion. But the further you go, the more it changes to strategy focused game. The battles get longer, enemies get tougher and all you have in your disposal is your creativity and 'on the fly' way of solving these combat puzzles. People seem to think that you just need a crusader or hellion who will crack skulls with sword or axe. That's not the case brother. Think and solve the puzzle or die. That's the name of the game.2) grind - there are essentially 2 currencies - one for town activities (gold) and others (deeds, crests, etc) for upgrading your town. Again, at first, you need both. But after upgrading the city to the max, you can just abandon the second currency completely. There's no lose state in this game as far as I know, so the only matter here (as I understand) is that you have to go through lower levels dungeons to level up new rosters. Well, isn't it what you like? Playing the game? If not, what the hell are you doing with your life? It's like I would say - 'well, I don't like Disneyland, so let's go to Disneyland and whine about it later'. You don't like to be punished for stupid mistakes that you made? Well, why in the love of ♥♥♥♥ do you play difficult games then...(not to mention - developers are going to make it easier for people like you and update the game today (08.03.2016) with 'more gold from quests class' and couple of town tweaks to make it less 'tedious' to level up heroes)Maybe the problem is not in the game, but in the public. People don't like challenge these days, they want to have everything served on a silver platter. This game doesn't do that. It rewards careful planning, thinking and shifting your focus from certain strategies the further in you are. People don't like to think, people don't like to learn on their mistakes. That's why they can't handle the game. Or is it unfair RNG's fault? I'll tell you this - I lost ONE character in about 70 hours of gameplay because I couldn't do anything about it. And it took really unfortunate string of enemy crits and bleed/blight damage combo to make it happen. But it's life man, stuff happens, deal with it :P Or maybe that's because I'm 80's guy. I was raised on difficult videogames that didn't give a crap about my feelings. They made me tough player that can appreciate cool, merciless gameplay :P And Darkest Dungeon delivers!Darkest Dungeon ladies and gentlemen - 9/10!

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												Solid, innovative party-based dungeon crawler.The difficulty and learning curve is a bit steep but that's the main point of this game. Foreboding atmosphere, good character design, thoughtful visual style and nice graphics.But what stands out is the sound of this game. The narrator did a top notch job on the voice over. Other effects are great sounding too. And that soundtrack, suits the game!Innovation like stress impact on your heroes force you to manage your party instead of just throwing in a team and embarking on a quest, the difficulty could have been a bit less but still this game is fun.And all the above mentioned aspects will combine together .. to own you.EDIT:Okay, this game is quite .. unfair. Its heavy reliance on RNG renders this game unbalanced. Losing a party that you've invested a lot of hours in is too frustrating, which ultimately pushes you to grind more to bring another party to the required level. I'm not going to change the recommendation, i think this game still needs to be played to appreciate the fantastic gameplay, artwork and voice work / sound effects. I just hope this game is properly balanced in the future.Looks like updates have made the game much more accessible.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I really dont understand the negative reviews of this game and all the folks that say the RNG is terrible and the game is all luck.  My experience was exactly the opposite.  I lost, in grand total, 2 characters across my playthrough.  One was because I deliberately sent 4 level 0's on a 0 light run.  Basically it was a suicide run and still only 1 died.  The second I sent a very ill equipped party against a tier 2 shambler.  The shambler is no joke and you really, REALLY shouldn't fight it without a porperly prepared party.  I didn't lose a single other character and beat the game in under 99 weeks (an acheivement).I keep reading these reviews and I see people saying the antiquarian is terrible...just wow.  She is the single most useful character as she completely solves the money grind.  I started playing before her patch and that was the biggest gripe I had but she completely solved it.  A few antiquarian runs leave you in piles of gold and you can afford to kit out your squads without issue.I keep reading and I see a bunch of folks complain about stress.  I feel like they have completely failed to understand the tools that have been given to them.  There are three classes that can remove stress and camping skills to help as well.  Between those factors I virtually -never- used stress heal buildings and I only had trouble with people reaching 100 stress on late tier boss battles where you cant afford to stall at all.Also yes, I played with all default settings.  I did not turn any of the cheats on.Honestly...if you are terrible at tactics and strategy games sure then this game is unfair.  If you actually think about how to form good parties and make good decisions this game is wonderfully rewarding.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												If you want a challenge, this game is for you. If you want a game that doesn't hold your hand, Darkest Dungeon is for you. If you love playing Bastion, this game is NOT for you. Darkest Dungeon is a semi-rogue dungeon crawler that asks what it would really be like to be a hero in a story, movie, or game. Form a roster of heroes, each with different strengths and weaknesses, and take four of them each week to fight the horrors of the abyss. Your heroes will get hurt, they'll get stressed, they'll learn to fear the terrors they fight. Maybe your favorite hero comes back with the Black Plague, maybe he becomes Paranoid while fighting. And your heroes will die. But in death you will learn to pick up the pieces and try again. Darkest Dungeon kicks you when you're down, laughs at you and calls your mom fat. No hero is safe, and no dungeon is "easy". The bigger the beast, the greater the glory, however; if you persevere you may just find yourself at the end of the Darkest Dungeon. You will be laughing still... and the end.

matter what you do, someone will die.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												An absolute triumph of indie gaming and, by far, my favorite Early Access title (or so it was when I bought it). The simple, yet aesthetic gothic-style graphics work well as a visage over brilliant mechanics and complex characters. The animations, while subtle, contribute greatly to the overall flow of the game, as do the comic book-esque attacks and movements.The characters' individual lines were clearly written by someone with great experience in the English language, and the narrator's voice exemplifies the feel of the game while playing. There clearly was a lot of thought put into character lore, from their backgrounds to their outlooks on the situation from room to room.Rougelikes are inherently difficult, and the addition of rising stress paralleled with falling health makes Darkest Dungeon's gameplay a serious challenge. And while there is certainly a degree of luck prevalent throughout, there are thousands of ways to conquer each region through the tweaking of characters and their skills. This point is particularly potent through relics (especially those that are class-restricted), camping, and even wise disease use. Want a powerful Rank 1 hitter? Let him get rabies, and then stand the hell back.This game demands a tactician. Those who can't succeed in this title just... well, aren't tacticians. Without proper party assembly and skill synergy, this already-daunting title because almost insurmountable. There is a steep learning curve, but it's the most delight I've had in dying repeatedly since Dark Souls. Truly a masterpiece of its kind. I can't recommend Darkest Dungeon enough.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game !  Lots of fun with a unique art style.   Game balance is much improved over the earlier builds.  It's challenging but without the frustrating party wipes due to bad luck and poor design.   While you can start multiple campaigns, each campaign has only one save that the game auto-updates.  Characters can and will die and there's no bringing them back.  With that said, once you know the game mechanics, you have to be overconfident or unlucky to get a character killed.   What's more likely is that they will become so riddled with afflictions and phobias that you start wondering if it's worth the time and money to cure them. "Alas, poor Dismas.  He grew un-well."The game mechanics appear simple at first, but the more you play, the deeper you realize the strategy elements go.With multiple classes, quirks, afflictions, equipment levels, learned skills, trinkets, and character position, there are a lot of things to consider when putting together a party.  There's also a limited amount of supplies you can carry, so you have to consider carefully what to bring. Supplies and loot occupy the same space. Bring too many supplies, and there's no room for loot.  Bring too few supplies, and you starve in the dark.Visually, characters of the same class look the same.  Crusader Bill looks just like crusader Bob. You can change their name and choose an overall color scheme, but they look the same.  You'd think this would make the characters feel generic, but it doesn't.   Over the course of a campaign - for however long they survive - each character will develop differently.  Bill is smitten by a worker in the brothel and that is the only place he will go to de-stress.  Bob finds religion and will only de-stress in the abbey.  Bill becomes paranoid and mutters constantly when in a party. Bob becomes vigorous and regenerates a bit of health.  Visually the same, but in character totally different.Is Darkest Dungeon a perfect game? Hard to answer. I think it is a game that is perfectly itself - and that self is very engaging.If you're looking for a turn-based, dungeon experience with a unique art style, challenging game play, and a lengthy campaign ( broken into manageable bites ),  give Darkest Dungeon a try .

number of helpful: 40 of 75 people (53%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game !  Lots of fun with a unique art style.   Game balance is much improved over the earlier builds.  It's challenging but without the frustrating party wipes due to bad luck and poor design.   While you can start multiple campaigns, each campaign has only one save that the game auto-updates.  Characters can and will die and there's no bringing them back.  With that said, once you know the game mechanics, you have to be overconfident or unlucky to get a character killed.   What's more likely is that they will become so riddled with afflictions and phobias that you start wondering if it's worth the time and money to cure them. "Alas, poor Dismas.  He grew un-well."The game mechanics appear simple at first, but the more you play, the deeper you realize the strategy elements go.With multiple classes, quirks, afflictions, equipment levels, learned skills, trinkets, and character position, there are a lot of things to consider when putting together a party.  There's also a limited amount of supplies you can carry, so you have to consider carefully what to bring. Supplies and loot occupy the same space. Bring too many supplies, and there's no room for loot.  Bring too few supplies, and you starve in the dark.Visually, characters of the same class look the same.  Crusader Bill looks just like crusader Bob. You can change their name and choose an overall color scheme, but they look the same.  You'd think this would make the characters feel generic, but it doesn't.   Over the course of a campaign - for however long they survive - each character will develop differently.  Bill is smitten by a worker in the brothel and that is the only place he will go to de-stress.  Bob finds religion and will only de-stress in the abbey.  Bill becomes paranoid and mutters constantly when in a party. Bob becomes vigorous and regenerates a bit of health.  Visually the same, but in character totally different.Is Darkest Dungeon a perfect game? Hard to answer. I think it is a game that is perfectly itself - and that self is very engaging.If you're looking for a turn-based, dungeon experience with a unique art style, challenging game play, and a lengthy campaign ( broken into manageable bites ),  give Darkest Dungeon a try .

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								It started out well BUT shrtly after getting into the game I found some serious problems. The game doesn't seem to allow for mission selection (meaning you have no control over where you go or the difficulty of the missions being undertaken). This wouldn't be a problem if you could aviod more senior members of the team dying but you can't, leaving you with rookies getting smashed on missions far to hard for them and your coffers quickly empty. Once this happens you cant get back into the game and the repetition of start well, get smashed, everyone dies, fail dungeon, return to town, rinse, repeat... it just gets old quickly.I like the game, I like the design, I like the ideas and the spooky voice over, the commentary and the captions from characters, the psychological and medical quirks, ALL GREAT... but the difficulty curve and the risk reward are totally out of whack diminishing the playability and amping up the frustration way beyond fun into simply annoying.This could be a really good game, but alas it falls short on playability, where it excels is in the exceptional design, sound, visuals (all top notch)... if you don't mind the overwhelming urge to smash your machine, this may be a good game for you. I was left feeling hollow and teary... I want to love this, I really do... it's SO COOL, but I just can't... perhaps I'm playing wrong... but I dont know if I'll come back

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first hired Reynauld, a wet behind the ears crusader, and his highwayman Dismas, I had my doubts if we would even make it to The Estate.  On the road, though, they quickly proved capable - dispatching a small company of bandits who camped on the only road to my isolated inheritance.  Our arrival was met with little fanfare - I heard the tavern keeper remind Dismas that he was not allowed at the gambling tables.  Reynauld refused to leave the transept of the church while in town.  While drinking at the tavern Dismas made friends with an old man at arms named Machel, a man who spends as much time in the brothels as Reynauld does in the transept.  I asked Reynauld if he and his misfortunate band of three might be ready to start excavating and clearing out some of the old ruins beneath the manor, to which he responded that they would if they had a fourth, someone to help keep them in good health.  I told him I knew of just the soul and sent for my old wrestling partner Bretel the vestal.  An old injury that had ended her career in the ring had left her with a weak grip and a torn rotator cuff, but she could still raise the spirits of any soul, bless her heart.With a full company, the small band set out to explore a small section of the ruin.  To this day Reynauld and Dismas refuse to give account of how their first encounter with the occult and undead went.  All three of them had to spend weeks in isolation, drink, and prayer before they would speak.  Bretel will not be in the same room as either of them, calling them selfish and masochists.  None of them will tell me what happened to Machel.(x . x)This is a great game, especially for being in Alpha.  It might be a little on the expensive side, but it's a very well balanced and playable game at this point.  It's challenging, especially at the very beginning or when starting with fresh characters.  As they level up and you unlock higher levels for your characters abilities and gear, and as you get a better sense of what classes go well together, the difficulty eases off a bit.  A lot of the mechanics which seem to be unfair and do nothing but punish you in the beginning do so much less as you learn how to mitigate them (basically, stick in there if you're having trouble, it gets better!).I'd recommend this to anyone who likes dungeon crawls, rogue-like games, and/or D&D players.

								Okay, so this game is only about 25-50% complete, and there is a lot of missing content (early access OFC), but it still packs a good 40+ hours of questing, looting and burying fallen comrades. This game is INTENSE, and it will make you feel things. Some of those things are frustration and anguish. -- a lot of those things are, but you feel them in a good way. Just when you think you have this game figured out, and you have a clear path to victory, it rolls back the curtain and shows you how utterly doomed your characters are.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Darkest Dungeon is a lot like Rogue Legacy where you have a constant influx of adventurers and a randomized dungeon ahead of you. If you're lucky, your runs will yield a tonne of gold, but if you are not then you'll drive your party insane or dead.The game is about pushing your luck, and managing wear on your party members. There is fun in building a very competent team and taking longer embarkations as you build up. Buy this game if you enjoy:1) turn based combat2) character progression and customization3) pushing your luck4) discovering new combinations and interactions (try not to read too many in-depth guides)

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								An excellent game that's well on its way to a successful release after early access.  Its roster and party based gameplay, with the macro game of upgrading the town to improve your squads, is akin to XCOM, and you may find yourself getting attached to specific characters!  Its turn-based combat is deep, with many customization choices of skills and character positioning.  The game's difficulty level can be intimidating at first, but the fact that it's easy to continue with new party members means you will learn for your mistakes and your hard-fought victories will be all the sweeter.  Overall, I highly recommend this game if you're looking for a strategic turn-based game, especially at its current 14.99 sale price.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												Great, inspired game that falls short due to too much unexplained randomness.Edit: I gave this game another shot and am having much more luck and fun, but problems still exist. Currently at week 30-40. I will say the randomness is not as much an issue as much as a lack of agency and the fact that the game does not give the player enough info to learn how to get better. In addition many of the challenges are simply asanine. Playing with higher level characters becomes unmangeable because it costs more to do even essential things such as treating for stress. Most of the time I see challenges being shoe-horned in just to be challenging rather than being clever, thematically relevant, logical, fun, etc....Other examples:-How is hunger processed? I had to eat twice on one run in the first 5 rooms, while in other runs with same team I ate once after many more rooms. If I spend 8 food in camp and then 1-2 rooms later have to eat again, this seems very illogical. It just doesn't make sense at all.-Why does my character with 50+ dodge get hit several times in a row when my character with 5 dodge succeed 3/4 times?You can get many hours of fun from this, but be warned that at a certain point it starts to feel like a time waster rather than a engaging challenge.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
 "Great is the weapon that cuts on its own."This game is a masterpeice. With six hours played I only nearly scratched the surface.This game is about if heroes in RPG games were more human. Characters get stressed out if attacked or if its dark. There is a bar that is called the stress bar. If this fills up you can become afflicted (most likely) or virtuous (rare). This is one of the main draws.Another main draw is permadeath. Like real life, if you die, there is no respawning. If a character dies they are DEAD.Also there is the torch. This mechanic is my favorite draw. If the torch is darker that means you get more stressed out, get surprised, and even get crits if the torch is low enough.The combat system is siple yet complex. You pick an abilty and it has a certain amout of damage, targets, and special feature. Like the Vestal's judgement: it heals her after hitting an enemy.There is just so much charm to this game and more things i can't write down.So far this is my GOTY. 10/10

Posted: July 3, 2016
												So much death, so much amazing narration; so much mockery. 10/10 would buy just to fill another graveyard with the corpses of my poor minions that venture into the fray.If you're a fan of side-scrolling RPGs and map crawling like the old classics/ tabletops, this is up your alley. If you want an unforgiving environment with level caps and a large portion of RNG, this is also up your alley. If you're a fan of good gore, and music, and a dark flair to the genre, akin to Dark Souls (except less life ending) this is up your alley.I would also add that you'd be wise to invest in the current mods that assist with just general UI overhauls, and town buffs. They're nice, and don't intrude too much into the ambience of the game.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												As a bored college student, I have two very limited factors in my life: time and money. As such, I try to find games that are cheap, have plenty of content, and can be picked up and put down in a small amount of time. Darkest Dungeon delivers all of these aspects as well as a great setting that is only bolstered by the art, music, and narration.Gameplay:Darkest Dungeon is a Rouge-lite 3rd person horror rpg that puts an emphasis on struggling for resources and the mortality of your party members. Combat is turn based, and offers a ton of challenge due to the game's stress feature which can cause your party members to gain quirks, or have heart attacks and die.Art and Music:Darkest Dungeon's art fits the name quite well: gritty and dark motif that takes ideas and concepts from the likes of H.P. Lovecraft and Clive Barker. Not a moment is spent without a sort of grotesque abomination, or some sort of foreboding scene. The music is hard to describe, but it does its job perfectly. In your town, the music gives a desolate feeling, while in one of the dungeons the music is non existant until a fight happens at which point the music is grating and fast paced, giving a sense of urgency.Narration:All of the games story is done through narration in the style of Bastion. The narrator's voice is beyond a perfect fit for the setting, and there is no shortage of lines he says to either make you feel empowered, or hopeless in the middle of a battle.Length of Play:Each dungeon takes about 10-20 minutes to complete depending on what level of dungeon it is and what the objective is. This is perfect as it allows for breaks to be taken and ample opportunities to quit without losing any progess.Price:The game is $20, which I think is a good price for this game as it holds many hours of quality content. If it's on sale, then it's just even more value right there.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Wow. There are many negative reviews, and i understand it, but i fell in love after five minutes. But the storytelling, the varietiy of hero combos, and the fact that i could be interested even when every map is, more or less, the same (each hall is 4 squares, each with a possibility of battle, item, etc. and then a room). If you like XCOM, this is a game you will love. there are a lot of classes, and certain teams have fun names. You have to level huge numbers of people before you get anything serious done, but the layout of the game offers so many opportunities to change your style. There is so much to explore, and you can risk it all or risk very little. Sometimes it does seem ridiculous that there are so many crits, or so many dodges, but you will get just as many, if not more. Items are sparse and you will lose or anbandon a few quests, but there is always a chance to come back. Anecdote (don't read this if you've decided against this game or don't care): I had an entire team going into a battle against the Swine Prince. Healers, big damage, damage over time. Everything. The battle started with the Swine Prince and a little pig next to him. During the first turn he marked several people, who subsequently lost about half their health. So I killed the little pig, which afterward turned out to be a horrible idea. Every turn my heroes reminded me not to hurt the little pig while the Swine Prince was landing whole team attacks with big damage and stun. Looking back, the little pig murder was a bad idea, but i managed to win with a Leper at Death's Door. Thsi game is exhilirating and unique. The art is incredible and the story draws you in like few other games i have experienced.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Saying this game is like a side-scrolling Dark Souls is inaccurate, because this game is much harder. Darkest Dungeon is an old school turn based, party combat strategy RPG. The plot isn't too deep, but is enough to keep it going. A search for mystical power underneath your family's house opened a portal that unleashed monsters upon the surrounding areas, so now it's your job to recruit heroes and send them out to complete various missions throughout the area. Now, make no mistake, your heroes will die. A lot. So really, don't get too attached to any of them. Now, this game is a dark, gory, brutal, and balls-grindingly hard journey and is not for the faint of heart. Examples of this are illustrated in the stress mechanic and the art style. The art style is a beautiful hand-drawn style, highlighting the shadows, scars, blood, and insanity on people's faces to give off a very grim, dark, and sinister look to represent the game's themes. The other highlight is the stress factor. This game's big selling point is realisitcally showing off how fantasy heroes are regular people too, and they have their quirks and flaws, as well as how dungeon crawling and fighting skeletons, demons, and other unspeakable horrors would affect a person's sanity. As characters are injured and exposed to certain events, their stress bar fills, resulting in either an "affliction", causing them to gain personality traits that will hinder your party's effectiveness, or even raise the stress of other characters, or a "virtue", a buff that allows the hero to lower their stress and the stress of other party members, or even randomly heal themselves. The heroes themselves consist of a vareity of classes. They include but aren't limited to: The Vestral, which acts as the healer, the Plauge Doctor, a DOT/Debuff character, the Leper, the game's tank, and the rouge-esque highwayman. Every character also comes with their own "quirks", traits that can alter combat stats, damage resistances, susceptibility to stress, and even restrictions on how to relieve the character's stress. The combat is turn based, with party positioning a strategic choice, as characters must stand in certain positions to be fully effective, causing you to sometimes sacrifice certain character's ablilties because they can't stand in the right slot, as you need that slot for another character to be effective. Some enemies will throw this positioning off, forcing you to spend turns righting the order instead of attacking. The only two cons I can think of consist of an audio problem and an annoyance in gameplay. In cutscenes, the audio will cut in and out at random, causing me to skip most of them altogether. The other is the ease in which you can land in a "mosquito bite" spiral. You'll lose gold for failing an expedition, which means you won't have enough to outfit another expedition, whch means you'll fail, causing you to lose more gold, leading to a game-wrecking and vicious downward spiral that renders the game almost unplayable.An overall expertly crafted RPG with unique mechanics, great atmosphere and a new twist on dungeon crawling.9/10

Posted: January 30, 2016
												Hello everybody,I like the game very much and am "diggin in" in this dark hopeless amtosphere! The combinations of different heros with different skills provides a high variety of play fun. The challenging difficulty forces the player to think carefully in each dungeon wether it is short or long. The frustration in the bossfights are able to compete with those in DarkSouls ;-)I think the game is pretty balanced - the favor is even a little bit against the player which fits into the set context of the game - however I may see some little room for improvement.I highly recommand some way of increasing the item slots for the player, because I think that long dungeons have a little disadventage compared to short or mid dungeons due to the limitation of the item storage.I dont want the game to simply bow before the player, however I would like to see a new implementation of possible itemmanagement. I could imagine some kind of possible expensive luggage which can be bought at the beginning of the journey for each hero together with the other equippment. In order of sacrificing one relikt slot for one or more champions they may be able to get one item slot for torches, money or other stuff.I think with luggage implemented in the game the players would be able to get even more options in case of win/lose calculations.Cheers, Ansvin ;-)

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I would highly recommend this game to any fan of roguelikes or RPGs alike. I find myself playing this almost daily and getting my butt kicked about 50% of the time. But you keep coming back, "Should I do one more dungeon?" The answer is usually yes. It is very punishing difficulty-wise, I recommend maxing out the companion wagon as soon as possible, if you have 1 or 2 bad runs in a row, you might find yourself basically starting from scratch. At least if you can rehire 4-6 people each time you can ammend that problem.The game is with a few cons, I find the graphics very flash-like, I still really like them, but that may turn some off. I also found the early game pretty grueling. Took me at least 10 weeks in-game to really get the ball rolling.Other than that, great game. The difficulty is more rewarding late game. I found mid-game a breeze, so once I got to the hard bosses, I appreciated the butt whoopings again. 8/10, love it. Unique, addicting Fantasy RPG. I would give it a 9 or 10, but it gets a little too hard once you reach the later dungeons, its not fun to have to grind an entirely new party back after losing them all due to a spike in difficulty.Edit: I should mention if Status effects got on your nerves in RPGS...this game is totally going to get on your nerves.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This game is a blast. And, as it tells you, is about making the most out of a bad situation. As with every chance based games, you have to "game the RNG" by consistently making the right choice at the right time. Stun or damage? Heal or Attack? A single bad choice can cause a massive chain reaction. But when you get how to play the game (ie: always account for a neutral or bad scenario; interact with the environement only when you have the % on your side; and so on) everything starts clicking in place. And you learn it quite quickly too, the hard way :)

								A good old dungeon-crawling romp through 'Ye Olde Eldritch Nightmareland'. Purge the realm of undead, tentacle monsters, spiders, bloodthirsty brigands, and cultists, or just go insane.Can be more unforgiving than Hand of Fate. Where that was a game about building up your singular hero in a relaxing, tavern-esque adventuring tale, Darkest Dungeons is more about resisting entropy--knowing to recognize when your group is headed the way of a complete nervous breakdown, while facing a dungeon's monstrosities.The combat is Turn-based, but with a unique system of class and position management, and a stress system that will utterly destroy the cohesion of your group if you're not wary. This would almost make for a horror game, if it weren't mildly humorous, and tactically-minded. Each of the different class characters will eventually go paranoid, steal from the party, become masochistic pain-freaks (the plague doctors in particular remind me of the TF2 medic, if they take enough physical abuse), or start hallucinating calls to action from their God, that make your entire party come alive in a random, somewhat prefab, but nonetheless characteristic way.Of particular note, I enjoyed the resting mechanic, which basically lets you pick a good time to rally the party with food and firelight, and offers a number of abilities each class can use to maintain the party's cohesion. For instance, if you're carrying a leper, you can have him considerately confine himself from the rest of the group, at his own expense, to help reduce the team's stress. Or, you could just have him lift his mask and get some physical relief, putting everyone off. The crusader gives pious rants, the barbarian can curse and swear for personal relief at other's expense, the rogue can scout for monsters, the priest can say a prayer for everyone or put up a protective ward around the camp.Resting almost becomes like its own recovery-based combat round, and the varied options for each class felt fresh and neat. It puts cRPGs to absolute shame, with their rest-spamming cutscene to forget all the party's wear and tear in one instance. (Obsidian and Bioware could take a page from these devs.)The soundtrack isn't anything unforgettable, but like Monaco, the music conjures elements of tension, fitting your gamestate. Unlike that game's ragtime jingles though, in Darkest Dungeon, when you're on a mission, you get tense metal, percussion, and ambient noise that intensifies the closer your torch comes to sputtering into total darkness. Of especially horrific note, is a sewer/catacombs themed level, filled with emaciated pigmen to put Amnesia to shame. When things go pitch black, the soundtrack fills with the echo of their distant squeals. It's a fantastically chilling touch. Meanwhile, your narrator, in the spirit of Cthuulhu callback games like Eternal Darkness--is a dead ancestor with an ominous voice like an evil Don LaFontaine, egging you on with encouragements, and grimly announcing your stumbles into starvation or  mortal injury.The game has a nagging issue with difficulty, in a similar sense to X-Com: Enemy Unknown, in that you'll be dealt a starting tutorial prefab that gets you utterly ♥♥♥♥ed the first few times you play. In particular, your starting crusader always has Kleptomania, and will often deprive you of loot you try to scavenge, until you take him to the Sanitarium--a facility that doesn't unlock for you for a few adventures.Additionally, you do not gain access to a balanced assortment of classes all the time, and there's definitely an ongoing resource-climb that you can fail, if you spend too much on the wrong things. I would compare it to luck rolling underground steam vents and UFOs in the resource-management portion of Enemy Unknown--a bit of a merciless crapshoot that might demand you scum the whole game.All in all, Darkest Dungeons captures the bleakness of Lovecraftian horror in a fun little procedurally generated, resource-gathering dungeon crawl. The kind that takes breaks in the style of X-Com or Patapon, but reminds you that starvation or defeat is only a few bad moves away, nonetheless. Enjoy it if you like that kind of thing. I did.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Only after many crippling losses, frustrating encounters, unfortunate outcomes, and landing myself in a situation where even the most mundane quests seemed impossible to complete did I truly fall in love with this game. To say that Darkest Dungeon is a hard game would be an understatement, as disaster is always a possibility and dare I say inevitable. What makes this game different from other RPGs is that luck is more involved than any objective mechanic, as anyone who has played more than ten minutes would be able to tell. With this in mind, anything is possible at any point, whether it be searching through an inconspicuous bookshelf or in a chance-encounter with a boss. In a way, you the player are in the same position as your heroes fighting for your estate, but whether you prevail against adversity or crack under pressure and end up leaving a bad review is not up to RNG. Ultimately, Darkest Dungeon is a game that demands a lot from the player mentally, and it is understandable to feel hopeless, fearful, or abusive as that is all a part of the game, but unfortunately this frustration can lead people to hate the game for being what it is; an unforgiving and unrelenting RPG that will refuse to allow everything to go in the player's favor but instead require the player to react to a poor situation.Before buying, it is vitally important to understand what it is you're getting, and that is true with anything and is no different with this particular game. Aside from outlining the gameplay, the artstyle is incredible and I would be remiss to not mention it. The art alone was enough to entice me into buying, and I was not disappointed by that aspect of the game. All in all, everything is subject to opinion so I can only hope more people get to enjoy this game where others would not.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												The apparent commercial success of this title is the best example of style over substance I have ever seen in the context of PC gaming. There's a lot of style in this game and it is compellingly presented. However, the game that lies beneath the presentation layer is tedious and grindy. It's not a difficult game; it doesn't particularly challenge your intelligence, or memory, or reflexes or anything like that. What it is is a tedious and frustrating game. There is a difference.If you are easily amused and like shiny things you may like this game. If you are easily bowled over by a slick presentation, and don't notice or care that you've been doing the same thing again and again and again - for hours - then you may like this game. A lot of people seem to. But if you are a more discerning person, well... I'll say no more. I just wish I had gotten a poster for my 20 dollars instead of what is essentially a gothic-reskinned version of Cookie Clicker.BTW check out this critical review (it's not me, however I absolutely agree with what this person says):


YouTube™ Video: Darkest Dungeon Review and Critique

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is not about playing to win, or even developing characters. It is about setting you up for a frustrating exercise in futility and leaving you with absolutely no hope. The items that bestow stat boosts also carry penalties. The money and resources spent developing your hamlet will leave you without resources to purchase items for quests. You will experience random deaths and afflictions of characters, which you will be unable to cure because you lack money needed from finishing dungeons. In other words, this game has been overweighted to such an extent that it is designed to cause you to fail at every turn. And not matter how careful you are, you will lose. The worst part is that you will be unable to level any characters up high enough to advance in the game, because they will likely gain so much stress and affliction they will die of a heart attack before reaching level 2. I appreciate the lovecraftian elements of this game. However, the developers have weighted the game to such an extent against the player, that it isn't even enjoyable to play. That said, if you simply want to play to see how long you can go before all your characters die, then this game will provide at the least a lot of entertainment value because of the narrator commentary and creepy graphics. To be fair, I think the developers have a decent basis for what could be a very versatile game to the broader gaming community. But at this point, it is purely designed for graphic visual value, because it isn't even challenging - it's hopeless. If anyone in the company or development actually reads this review, I would urge you to consider programming some variability into the in terms of challenge levels. It would probably have a broader appeal to the larger gaming community. As it stands now, I think it is likely a very small niche group of folks that would actually enjoy the gameplay. Examples of in-game issues: Want to heal outside of combat? Nope. Healer skils are only available during combat. And food only heals one lifepoint at a time outside of combat - while penalties like bleeding and plague continue to linger outside of combat. You can cure them with items, but if you don't have the money, you don't have the items. You can only camp to restore life in certain dungeons, so if it's a single-shot playthrough dungeon with no camping option, you have no heal ability outside of combat. Treasure drops in the dungeons are so random and rare as to be not worth it. And healing abilities in combat are somewhat random in the amount they restore. The game is designed to kill your heroes. Period.  You can leave a dungeon at any time. But if you do, it may disappear, which means you lose out on the item rewards for completion. Further, you don't get to keep provisions purchased but not used for the next dungeon. And the costs to remove and heal heros who are likely crapping themselves when they return to the hamlet means you have little resources for provisions in the next dungeon. I like the concepts in the game. And I appreciate the developers really aren't going for a game that's playable to win - it's more about sacrifice and how far you will push to complete. The problem is, if you do push then your heroes will likely die and you won't finish the dungeon anyway - and you can't advance in the game if your characters don't have higher levels, which require money and resources gained from dungeons, which cycles back to the basic problem. Psychologically, there's very little positive reinforcement in this game, and a whole lot of discouragement and negative reinforcement such that if you are attached to your characters or advancing in the game, you are in for an excercise in frustration. This type of psychological situation doesn't affect everyone negatively, so if that isn't a consideration for you, you may very well enjoy this game. I don't recommend this game to the broader gaming community. However, if you are the kind of gamer that appreciates the dark, twisted, and impossible to win kind of game that leaves you breathless and frustrated (and I know there are gamers out there like this), then you are in for a treat. This game won't disappoint. Improvements that could help this game are healing abilities being active outside of combat, or having food restore far more health. But then, I suppose that would mean your heroes might not die as quickly, which would defeat the whole purpose of the game probably. At the least, it would be good to have variable levels of challenge settings in the game in order to help players at all levels truly enjoy and appreciate the dark storyline and potentially awesome gameplay. Right now, however, it just isn't there outside of a niche group.On another note - I spent hours investing time carefully cultivating characters to be able to take on the first boss (the hag). The turn system in this game is so random, that the hag ended up having multiple turns before I even got a shot off, and she wiped out my whole party with her pot (which she puts your heros into to cook them). The whole battle was a joke. To say that I think the game developers have a tremendous amount of work to do on this game is an understatement. The part that upsets me the most is that I cannot get my money back. But certainly, it is the last time I will ever buy a game from this company.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								A unique dungeon crawl experience with exceptional atmosphere and brutal, roguelike mechanics to ensure that every encounter is dangerous and meaningful.  The stress mechanics alone are enough to make the game stand out from its predecessors, but the game goes a step further with interesting line combat mechanics and customization options which serve to distinguish the game from any others like it.  The game drips with atmosphere from the outstanding artwork to the enriching, if at times sesquipedalian, narration.I feel the game stands out for its emphasis on resourcefulness.  Due to the randomness of recruitment, character trait assignment and dungeon generation, it's extraordinarily rare to put together an optimal party for all situations.  There are times where your primary healer will be nursing her paranoia in a tavern, or you'll design a team to defeat a boss only to have it ripped apart by an unfortunate monster spawn.  Each class has 8 active abilities and 6 camping abilities, of which you can only take 4 and 3 with you respectively.  As a result, you often find yourself assembling teams and kits which aren't great for any situation, but are good enough for every situation, and therein lies the beauty as you tend to scrape by tough encounters more often than dominate them, making those encounters memorable and engaging.My critique in its current form are tied with the volume of information you must keep track of.  Each character in your group may possess as many as 10 traits, both positive and negative (and might have some diseases on top of that) which can have various impacts on their abilities.  These traits will also change over time after each successful dungeon run.  Add onto that having to manage equipment, skill and camping skill layouts for numerous party members and it can be a bit daunting to remember what role each character plays in your group and which dungeons they would best serve in.  Consequently, at least for me, most of this information ends up being ignored.There is some commotion over the new mechanics introduced by Red Hook, but I personally feel the game has continuously improved over the course of its time since its beta release.  To cover some of the more recent changes, corpses present another opportunity cost question to your party (should I scrap a more general purpose ability for one that's not as useful, but clears corpses) while heart attacks further test your risk/reward assessment abilities.  Increased PROT for monsters adds value to blight/bleed effects, which themselves require planning around as enemies might be more resistant to one or the other.  I do not endorse early access games by in large, but I will endorse this game.  If you are looking for a dark, unforgiving game that tests your resourcefulness and willingness to take dangerous risks for the promise of substancial rewards, purchase this game immediately.  For $19.99, you are getting an exceptional bargain for the entertainment you'll get with this title.As a bonus, the game's narrator will also likely improve your vocabulary.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												The problems with the Darkest Dungeon since it got its full release is not that it's harder. Or that the RNG is against you. For me, the problem is if you don't look up youtube videos and read the wiki cover to cover, the gameplay sucks. There's no trial and error, because your party will be wiped out, your gold reserves emptied and you'll have to start again and go through the painfully long tutorial. There are so many times where I've found a boss, tried to fight them only to realise that they endlessly summon. By the time you've worked out that this is indeed a bossfight, you've lost. I'm all for no hand holding, but DD seems to delibrately deny you any clues on what the hell is going on until it's too late.EDIT: I wrote this review quite late and upon looking at it again, see I've left off the end. There IS a good game, once you get past the ridiculous learning wall. The aesthetic is brilliant, the difficulty, once you've thoroughly read the wiki, is just right to be always challenging. The gear upgrade is a bit pointless, as are the skill levels. However, it's rather made up for by the plethora of trinkets you can equip to tweak your characters' stats.Overall, this is a good game if you have the patience to persevere, but I couldn't recommend it as it is with so much vital information witheld from the player.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I am very excited to see where this game is going.  I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys classic tabletop, dark themes, and testing their luck against difficult odds.Atmopshere / Theme / Art:I love the non-traditional art style of the game - the character and background art is cartoonish but it manages somehow to add to the charm of the game, not take away from it.  The narration is spot-on and well-done and I found it to be an enhancement to the game.  The atmosphere is consistent and nicely executed.Gameplay:I found gameplay to be enjoyable, personally.  I love the simple but effective UI - it plays like a casual game but there's much more to it under the surface and you can really feel that.  It has all the pros of a point-and-click and none of the cons.  There's no twitch, which I like, and I absolutely love that your decisions are well and truly final.  There's no save-game trickery, no way to go back on a bad choice.  You live with what you do no matter what.I find the game to be a great diversion and will be playing the heck out of it :)

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								 Alrighty, adding my opinion to the many already here! DD does a great job of taking a classic set-up and giving it a good spin! You and your characters travel through an atmospheric world that perfectly captures the feeling of despondence felt by the towns folk and your long suffering party members. The upgrade system in the game is scaled very well and the enemies are also well suited to keep you and your characters in check as you go up in level. Balancing stress and health, especially when camping, is an important part of the game and really gets you invested as some enemies attack physically and others make your characters really feel the psychological strain of the quest. The enemy types are also quite varied so each new attack feels interesting as you plunge through the depressing landscapes. On the other end of the spectrum it is sometimes hard to keep track of your characters. There were several times in the game where I tossed high stress individuals into my party because I didn't notice they were already at 100 but I do blame that more on my own inattention than the game itself. I also find myself getting angry at the characters when they fail a saving throw, again, it's an important part of the game and it does really well in making you think about human nature and all but the 3rd time your Hound Master becomes Selfish and steals 2500 worth of loot you're going to wish you could order your highwayman to shoot him. There are also a few bugs for me but it is in early access so I'm not worried, they go away when I restart the game(which takes about 1.5 minutes).All in all I thought it was a great game! Sorry for my disjointed ramble, hope it helps you decide if you want to buy the game!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is not for everyone, or really most people. You'll like this game if:1) You like having to replace party members due to death or them not being able to function2) You like misleading probabilities; 70% misses much more than you would think3) You like having to contstantly manage your group's inability to function after a few encounters4) You prefer debuffs to buffs. Every enemy gives you a debuff with almost every attack.5) You like failing missions or having a high chance to fail every mission6) You like very slow progress which can even--and does--go backwards7) You like being punished investigating your environment8) You like having to frequently and involuntarily rearrange your group order; group order determines what skills you can use9) You don't like using high level characters on all content. Level 3's can not do level 1 and 2 areas. Level cap is 6.10) You like playing games that feel stacked against you in every part of the game11) You like every item to have a negative stat to balance the positive stat it grantsBasically, play this game if you don't care if you succeed and want a hard game that is hard because it is unfair. You will be frequently punished, and it will be completely unavoidable and random. The game mechanics are interesting, but they beat you down so much that it makes it really hard to stay motivated to play.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a rougelike tactics game where all of your adventurers are expendable and playing long enough will allow you to win, however how glorious your victory is largely depends on how you manage risks and rewards.  For example having to think about how much food to bring while exploring a dungeon or if you should throw out anti-toxin in favor of gold is a fascinating mechanic.  Considering whether you should just dismiss a hardened adventurer instead of spending weeks and thousands of gold restoring their sanity.  It's a fun time if you don't mind having expendable characters die for you.

Early Access Review
								Listen, this game is hard, it is unforgiving, but it is fair.  Darkest Dungeon may screw you with RNG every once in a while but for the most part it is a tactics game of planning and skill.  It is easy to play, easy to understand, but difficult to master. Redhook studios has done such a good job sticking to thier vision of a dark and difficult game that is taxing, you will feel excitement, you will feel your heart pound out from your chest as your team stands at death's door and one hit could end it all. You will scream in anguish win they die, you will  shout in victory when they win.This game does everything right, and the sound design is on point as is the art. I warn you this is not for the faint of heart, but if you take the time to learn it, you will have a great time.

Every enemy gives you a debuff with almost every attack.5) You like failing missions or having a high chance to fail every mission6) You like very slow progress which can even--and does--go backwards7) You like being punished investigating your environment8) You like having to frequently and involuntarily rearrange your group order; group order determines what skills you can use9) You don't like using high level characters on all content. Level 3's can not do level 1 and 2 areas. Level cap is 6.10) You like playing games that feel stacked against you in every part of the game11) You like every item to have a negative stat to balance the positive stat it grantsBasically, play this game if you don't care if you succeed and want a hard game that is hard because it is unfair. You will be frequently punished, and it will be completely unavoidable and random. The game mechanics are interesting, but they beat you down so much that it makes it really hard to stay motivated to play.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								So Darkest Dungeon....So far I have truly enjoyed this game. It is difficult and unique enough to want to continue. It feels very close to the difficulty of 1st Edition Advanced Dungeons and Dragons. However, there are a few key aspects that make this game actually impossible.1) Most enemies have attacks that target the entire party. No one in your party has any attack that can hit more than two people except the highwayman. He can hit three. Also, some of the party wipers that are multi unit hits have afflictions (I.E. Blight, and bleeding.) The highwayman hits people, that is all. You have single unit to two unit afflictions at best.2) The Bosses are unreasonably difficult. The level one boss in the ruins, against the Mad Priest hiding behind pews is too difficult for a party that was level 4, with level 2 equiptment and rank 2 abilities. He is a level one rated boss.3) The loss of sanity is like taking a bottle of water, taking off the cap, and draining the bottle to 7/8 emptiness and then complaining that you're thirsty and it isnt enough. If anyone in your party is sane after a dungeon, you should probably go to a casino immediately to capitalize on the new found super luck you have acquired.Aside from horrible balance issues, literally impossible boss fights, and god awful suicidal standards of heroes...It isn't a bad game. It is in early access, and there is room for improvement. That does not mean i do not love this game. Totally worth it if you hate yourself or enjoy watching guinea pigs (cough, i mean adventurers) wander aimlessly into suicide and failure, or want to have PTSD like flashbacks of Dark Souls moments.8/10 so far.

number of helpful: 25 of 46 people (54%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Very compelling game - at first. You can (just) live through and rebuild, expecting to lose heroes fairly often. At first you can buy or find junk items. But after a while, it starts to dawn on you. EVERY item you find is basically junk - you can power up but only by making yourself too weak to live in another way and the negatives on the items are much more than the positives most of the time. I've had dungeon runs where I begin and before I have a turn half the party is diseased with crippling afflictions, yes before I've clicked a single option. Well, that is the RNG I suppose - but you can also have 100% light, have camped to obtain maximum chance to surprise monsters and scout ahead. So by being tricky and careful, you've got MAXIMUM odds and walk into a known encounter - yet right at the next-to-last encounter, your whole group is surprised and decimated before your turn begins. That's undoing everything you've achieved and it feels extremely cheap.And it doesn't get better, it gets (much) more futile. I've faced off against a boss (recommend level 5) - not the max one - with a full maxxed out level 6 group, with zero negative attributes (which is EXTREMELY expensive to do), maximum positives after 20-30 hours of building them and with max power items. Used luck and strategy to enter the final battle in PERFECT shape with maximum power from the camp right before and hey, I'm surprised. Again. So all my heroes are diseased, bleeding, afflicted and stressed. One is at "Death's Door". Before I get to do anything.Gee, fun. Your actions matter zero. Your preparation matters zero. Your time mattered zero.Now that is fine if you're party is weak, or if you didn't enter with EVERY. SINGLE. THING. PERFECT.But come on...So, gee what a surprise your perfect conditions matter zip. Within 3 turns had 4 deathblows occur because ALL your attacks are "Dodged". And your mage healer does "0" but makes you bleed. Twice. Really?Yeah...Right.But hey, it's only another 20 hours to try again to smash your head against the same boring wall. Again. And Again. And Again.256 hours of play, lost against the SAME boss more than 20 times, telling myself it's just horrifically bad luck. And that somewhere I will unlock the fun part, because there's hints that this could be a GREAT game.But it doesn't change. It's every goddmaned time. So this monotonous march to machocism is fun?!?Nope.It's not from poor strategy - the group has half debuff powers to reduce the big boss damage and maximum chances to occur against an enemy where mathematically you have 70%+ chance to succeed. But every, Single. Attempt. Fails. And the enemy criticals you. Every. Single. Time.At that point I uninstalled because that's bull. It's not a question of "keep trying" or "bad luck" but of "stupid, rigged game". Instead of adding more content, they jimmy the supposedly "random" odds just to make it impossible, I guess from a sense that you'd use up the (very) limited content if not.Your strategy - even if you somehow pull it off - matters ZERO.So then why bother? That's a failure of a game. A beautiful failure with amazing sound. But that's even more a reason not to bother.There's difficult challenges and then there's a game where you look in disbelief and say "give me a !@#$$% break". I played for more than 200 hours so it's definitely fun - at first - but after a while you simply will be frustrated by "random" (really?) events that undo every bit of strategy and make the entire experience a frustrating farce where nothing you attempt matters anyway.But hey, they did update something - added an encounter you HAVE to do which kills off ALL your best guys. Oh and if you retreat, you lose 2 of them. You can beat that enemy if you can debuff him. But he dodges or it fails 90% of the time.But you don't HAVE to do the encounter. It just ruins the town you've (had to) pour all your cash into. As in - ruins it.And it reappears 5 turns later. So if you want to have anything built AT ALL you HAVE to do this fight and win it. If you somehow survive it, you MIGHT have one character left who is crippled and has 3 diseases.Good luck doing it 4 turns later.The realtiy is - you can't. And you won't. And you can't stop the same stupid encounter appearing over and over and over.So the town you build up gets destroyed. Over and over. And you can do NOTHING about it. Except waste your time watching your heroes die before you can click anything.And if you do somehow totally luck out, you get to "win" an item that basically screws over anyone who uses it. Funnily, the game says "are you SURE you want to enter the dungeon? You have no trinkets equipped?" Well, yeah I'm sure because they all suck so bad you're better off without the supposed "treasures".I've tried both - and you do better without their crap.And that's basically this game to a T. You're better off without this supposed "treasure".Don't waste your time on this f---- pile of absolute futility.Two thumbs down.
