number of helpful: 25 of 46 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Three major problems exist in this game that are highly frustrating and ruin what is otherwise an enjoyable and interesting game.1) The costs for removing afflictions and reducing stress are FAR too high. No one enjoys throwing 50-75% of their earnings into a gold-sink mechanic after every dungeon.2) Battles and game mechanics in general are too reliant on RNG. No matter how well made your decisions are in battle, you are regularly put to your knees by crits/dodges/resists and other such nonsense. RNG is fine, but it needs to be used in moderation if the player wishes to maintain some sense of control.3) If you level a character quicker than  you complete dungeons, he becomes useless as he refuses to enter a dungeon that is a level below him. There are several mechanics that the devs could have implemented to stop high level characters farming dungeons. Simply making a character unusable and forcing you to draft a newbie is frustrating as hell.Good things to be found here, but not enough. Bought it on sale, still regret it.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a great game, but not for everyone. If you enjoy a game that forces you to figure out mechanics or fail spectacularly this is the game for you. Alternatively you can watch videos / read wikis / whatever, but the fun in it, for me at least, was the game + needing to figure out the ins and outs of all the different skill and battle mechanics to succeed. The only issue I have with this is that it is just sort of dropped on you at the end. It essentialy goes:Easy dungeons: You can get through with almost any party comp given you aren't particularly unluckyMedium dungeons: You generally need to understand what team comps work and play the classes to their advantages OR have weapons / armor / skills fully upgraded.Hard dungeons: Bad luck can ruin a run the first or second battle, but the key is to always retreat when this is the case. Other than that you have to be a lot smarter about how you maintain your heroes health and sanity by using down turns to keep everyone healthy and to strategically use camping and items. The Darkest Dungeon: Pending you don't read a tutorial before hand you will almost inevitably fail your first few attempts at each of the four levels simply because you really do need to understand all your heroes, the enemies, and the bosses to do well. One thing you'll notice about the hardest and end game dungeon is that it sounds like you will likely lose heroes. You probably will. If you get really into the games you play and attached the characters you build up or realy just want to use specific heroes and play only one particular way, you will get angry at the game and you probably won't enjoy it. If you are also prone to rage quitting the game probably isn't for you. Bad things will happen and half the game is figuring out how to salvage the situation or in the worst cases how to build back up to where you were in the most efficient way possible.All that said, I love Darkest Dungeon. It was everything I hoped it would be when I first saw the original trailer.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												I want to get this out of the way right now. If you dislike RNG heavy games then this might not be for you as pretty much everything is RNG. You can tip the scales in your favor but everything is all about the roll of the dice.With that out of the way, Darkest Dungeon is one of my favorite games. The presentation as a whole is so wonderful. The gloomy atmosphere, the dark artstyle, and the music all come together to bring a masterfully made world.The gameplay is hard to compare to anything else. The closest I can think is like, (classic) Final Fantasty mixed with X-Com. Turned based battles where the position of your characters matter greatly. This game makes you think about every move you make before you make it. Even healing because you have to think. "Is it worth healing my characters over killing this monster that could make my heroes stressed?" Speaking of that, the stress system is what drew me into this game in the first place. An RPG where it explores the themes of the stress a "Hero" would go through when exploring these dungeons filled with horrors and fiends. It had me hooked as soon as I first heard about it.As it says when you start it up. "Darkest Dunegon is about making the most out of a bad situation." This game takes time to learn and even when you do learn it there will be stuff out of your control. Much like life there will be things you can not predict. Even when your whole team dies, you must stay strong and continue your quest to drive the evil back.... or give up and become one with the Darkest Dungeon.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I bought it as kind of an experiment, because I've seen a friend of mine playing it a lot and I was somewhat interested how can it be that my friendlist constantly shows Darkest Dungeon under his name - I did't see a screenshot of the game before buying it.Glad to report, I regret nothing. Darkest Dungeon is a point and click dungoneer rougelike, where you are controlling a wide variety of heroes (4 at a time) with the rest of them living in the ruined town above the dungeons. Each exploration attempt in the 4 differently themed dungeon (seamonster caves, bandit road leading to town, ruins, and the darkest dungeon) you'll recieve loot that you can use to rebuild the town, restore it's buildings that provide your heroes equipment, relaxation, new heroes, cure and training, with each upgrade opening up a better option or making them cheaper. The combat and exploration is turn based with the latter being "real time", and the distance you make equals to turns per specific sections.The cartoony looks is really working, the audio effects are nothing special but do their job well calling the deathly atmosphere to life. The strongest and most essential part here is the Narrator, the only human voice you'll hear in the game aside from the accusations of that damn depressing risen who hides his mouth. The Narrator has an interesting speach pattern, not shakespeare english but similarly "higher" poetic, really being the icing on the gothic cake. So the atmosphere is a perfect hit, but how's the gameplay?At first, you are going down to all the various exploration trips out of curiosity and wanting to see everything, but once the 4 (really 3, because the darkest dungeon is far, far endgame content) different enviroments become familiar and you spent all the at first seemingly plenty resources, sooner than later you'll face that for your next desired upgrade you have to clear 3-4 dungeon runs. I understand that some kind of scaling is necessary to keep the game the longtime fun it is intended to be, but the scaling is way too harsh. I consider myself lucky I upgraded my town in a way I did because after a point the dungeons won't offer low level exploration trips anymore, and make no mistake, you WILL die in this game, you WILL see your favourite heroes die a horrible death in combat, fall to madness, have a heart attack, and the endless resupply of newcoming adventurers to the town can leave you with amateurs who have to face that they don't have low level challange to beat anymore, happy that did not happen to me... yet. Also the game works towards almost entirely unavoidable failure of your heroes though the stress mechanics that cause a wide variety of mental illness / personal flaws such as addictions, selfishness, mazohism and these lead to uncontrollable actions that futher stress the entire party, so you have to put away your "sick" hero and throw in a lot money on his/her cure, which means somebody has to take the place in the meantime, so you'll have 2-3 full set of heroes varied all the time. More countermechanisms to pressure would have been nice, and could have been done without making it "comfortable" for the user, but having 17-25 stress points added to all 4 heroes per turn vs some enemies when you can "heal" those in the dungeon IF you are lucky on top of IF you are landing a critical hit / multikill with one move to heal 3-7 points on one or two heroes is ridicolously unfair.One thing that I think is just a minor thing on the end user side but a major flaw from the development side, is having so little visual custimization options for your heroes. You can choose from 4 premade color patterns and rename them, but that's all. Having the option to choose from 3-4 different armors, maybe hairstyles, or just the actually visible clothes / armor upgrades at the blacksmith change the looks on the hero too not only on the armor in the inventory, would have a HUGE boost on being connected to your favourite heroes and caring for them, making their fall all the more painful (which the game intends to do so, just could do better. After a point I see them as easily replacable throwaway tools, a bunch of statistics that help me along, that's it).I really focused on the negatives here, but that is only because the game otherwise is so good, I love it so much that I cannot help but want to make it even better. Among all my recent purchases this year, this was definitly the most worth it.

Posted: March 17, 2016
												Dazed, reeling... about to break.The game is tough, but it has a reliable set of rules you can work with. Like any game with "rogue-like features", failure is desired, nearly guaranteed and eventually predictable with experience. Combining with a campaign you basically cannot lose, Darkest Dungeon lets you come back into the game and learn to adapt. It's a shame it does indeed get a little tedious and repetitive at some point, especially when some sort of major setback hits you and your roster of heroes. Apart from that, especially due to flavor, developer effort, unspeakably awesome art and sound direction and the strategic playstyle paired with some hardcore elements to punish mistakes very harshly, I personally deem this game to be one of the best indie titles of the century.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												Not a bad game but the main opponent is the RNG.  There is a warning screen which tells you that your party will die throughout the game.  The problem is that most of it is out of your control.  In combat there is no active role, you pick what your people do and they do it, which means any damage you take and whether or not you hit is completely up to the computer. Taking too much stress damage? Your character isn't high enough level.  Not dealing enough damage?  Your weapons aren't upgraded enough.  Trying to do some easy missions for money to upgrade your characters?  Too bad.  They leveled and will only do harder missions.  All in all it's not a BAD game but there is too little control over the mechanics to make it feel worthwhile.  Go play Paper Mario or Fire Emblem.  Maybe buy this on sale.

number of helpful: 26 of 48 people (54%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a 4-slot position-based RPG wherein you are tasked to continuously send frightened explorers and warriors into nightmarish wealds and slovenly brackens, with the sole purpose of rebuilding your ancestral home back up, brick by bloodsoaked brick. Your chosen party members and reserves are not hired and outfitted with the expectancy that they will live for the 90 or more times you dive into another excursion--this RPG is roguelike in nature, meaning death is not only expected, but it it imminent if you wish to fight through most of the tougher bosses. In sacrifice, there is radiance--your stressed-out heroes have equal chance to find  either middling madness or courageous zeal. As a bitesize roguelike, Darkest Dungeon will have you sending 4-person parties consisting of a handful of diverse classes and skills into horrid ruins, with the aim usually to do something like exploring 90% of an area, fulfilling all room battles, or slaying a boss enemy. In battle, there's a quaint selection of status ailments, movement shuffles, debuffs, and heals to be slung about, varying depending on your characters. But, there's also the element of Stress--a value that increases or decreases depending on how dim you keep the torch you bear, how many sickening critical hits you take, or what ailments and entrapments envelop each characters. At the edge of Stress lies the maw of madness; a Fearful hero may skip turns, while an Abusive one may hurt itself or berate others with increasing Stress. On the flip side, some characters will have the chance to rise up, becoming stronger and wiser as the tide of the fight turns. This singular feature alone is a wonderful addition to the RPG formula, and adds a lot of strategy to the scope ahead, as well. It serves not just as a thematic difficulty weight, but to also insure you consistently play with and utilize a variety of different teams and playstyles. it's quite a brilliant way to put forth the idea that each encounter with the unknown and the eldritch has a palpable effect on your poor adventurers, thus necessitating a visit to the bar or an internment at the medical asylums between missions. When you aren't imploring your mercenaries out to the evil realms, you're constantly upgrading your haven. Early on in Darkest Dungeon, the focus is less about your adventuring roster and more about preparing your former hovel to a battle-ready home. Eventually, you'll be able to not only pay less for cures and heal more people effectively, but outfit leveled characters with better armor, weaponry, and buffed skills. As upgrades grow and characters get stronger/better, so too does the knowledge of how to better tackle traps, examine weakness of each enemy type, and formulate teams with synergy. It's an expertise that comes with both time and effort, since your stronger teams will not likely emerge until a few areas in your town are updated permanently. In this way, I've found this game much more accessible than other roguelikes like FTL or even Binding of Isaac, which gave you more options on each playthrough but did not guarantee what you could carry on. In Darkest Dungeon, even if you manage to wipe out your entire roster, the progress made in your village will ensure that the following adventures you have go by smoother due to the capability to actually upgrade stats cheaper and faster. Thematically, Darkest Dungeon is beyond excellent; from the initial mood that narrator Wayne June dregs up like a thick fog of horror, the grim resolve permeates everything that is said and done throughout your journey. The notes and quotes of your ancestor litter each major boss fight's foreword, and with every strike and discovery there's a notation of victory--or defeat. Rarely is there something so notably incomprable when it comes to presentation, but the narration here is so enjoyable. Equally enjoyable is the fantastic art style, a kind of Gory/Mignola mashup that isn't quite hyper-real but still manages to be unsettling and shadowed with something sinister. A great many monsters are legit gross and abhorrent, which goes a long way at encountering some of the more disgusting bosses and knowing you're in for quite a match. I'm not a roguelike guy at all--I've never even come close to beating stuff like Isaac or FTL or even Invisible Inc, much as I love those games and enjoy their mechanics. However, I've clicked with DD mainly because the "failure" of losing characters, even after a great many victories to build them up, doesn't cause me pangs of extreme grief. I am not the character--I am the descendant, and the township is my legacy, not the life of the mercs. This format allowed me to accept that the future excursions would become less fraught with peril, although the threats and stress therein will always consistently provide some sort of challenge. It's that roguelike everyone has where you can put 100 or so hours in, doing convenieently menial or repetitive tasks yet always curious what's next. What team composition can I try next? What lurks beyond that threatening curio on the map? Which quirks and diseases should I heal--or spend a fortune to lock? When it comes to "that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t rng" claims--I have to laugh, as this is no different from any rogue/rpg/etc. The real elements of distress and fear of death are what seperate this from most smaller roguelikes, though this game's really no different in handling RNG-based tragedy than Fire Emblem or XCOM--both games that I love. Sure, there was rarely a boss that I beat without a significant death from my team, but again--this is a slow march towards getting better and building smarter. As far as options go, for those who are not a fan of systems like enemy corpses affecting slots or heart attacks making stress potentilaly more taxing, the devs have chosen to give normal runs the ability to switch those features on or off. I admit, at first I found those features a bit overwhelming--before I began paying attention to the upgrades that would even the odds. I've played with all the normal features turned on since and never felt like they hindered me immensely. Darkest Dungeon has been a pleasure to play, from its early access inception to its ultimate released form. There have been stumbles along the way, particularly nerfs or buffs that made me initially think that the game was on very thin ice. However, Red Hook's willingness to be flexible with toggled options and updates have won my trust, and I've found that there was more advantage given to the player over time when it came to things like debuffs and movement options. That I've played almost nothing else the past few weeks since their latest flurry of updates and upgrades says a lot about how fantastic I think this stress-inducing, mind-melting jewel is. What I love most is that even at the lowest point, I've been able to start again and stronger than before--not just due to the progress of the town, but based on what I learned from each triumph and failure before. That, I believe, is the mark of an outstanding roguelike. I've stood gallant and fearless as my Vestal withered into madness, depending on the Leper messiah to slay the Formless Flesh--and cheering silently as he proceeded to hew through the horrid menace with a much-needed hit. I've seen my entire force slaughtered and boiled to bits my the malignant Hag, cursing my fortune and vowing to return in due time to turn the tables on the morrow. I've watched entire parties crumble, only to rally around one lone Crusader who decides to get Focused at the peak of his stress. And I've accepted defeat at the maw of the malicious Shambler, foolish in my confidence that my rank 1 group could possibly outwit the Lovecraftian beast. DD is as much about the stories and failures gifted as it is about slowly accepting your knocks and eventually besting the opposition. The match is struck; A blazing star is born.

Early Access Review
								After all this time, this game still amazes me. Developers really put their heart and soul into it and the last Radiant Update polished everything to the last bit.Yes, it's difficult, it's reckless, it punish you for small mistakes, but it's like it should be. There's RNG but if you plan carefully, if you pay attention and take your time, you will succeed. DD is not like any other games I ever played. You always want to enter that extra dungeon, check that additional room, kill that last boss, even if you did that hundreds of times, and sometimes you pay an horrible price for it.I recommend this to anybody that wants a slow paced game in which you need to calculate every move, every party combination and every skill. Can't wait for the Crimson Court.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Some rougelikes are fun, challenging, games with a interesting stories that reward long-term planning and lateral thinking. This is not one of those games.Darkest Dungeon is pointless and arbitary. If the it seeks to invoke an atmosphere of hopeless depression, it succeeds, but not by any merit of gameplay or writing. It is existentially boring. The forced-horror of immediate and irrevocable character death forces an attitude of detached nihilism that creeps into deep ennui after twenty minutes. Quests amount to "Fight the Palatte Swapped Sprite of Lazy Game Design" and no real motivation or incentive is provided for finishing, or even playing the game.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I read the earlier reviews, and I like a challenge, so I thought, "what the hell? I'll give it a go."No, do not. It is brutual, right out of the gates. Fatal actually - you have ZERO chance of surviving. You will not finish this game, you won't even finish a chapter. Not for lack of skill or planning however. Read on.I'm hoping perhaps a patch in the future will resolve this - but as it currently stands, the game is impossible.PLAYABLITY ISSUES: There is no "recovery" once in the dungeon - where you could fight to a certain spot, then return to town and resupply or recuperate. A rational person would say, "we can't go on, we must retreat." Retreat means failure and penalty. And the mission cannot be reattempted. It's first try, or fail.It's a death match to the end of every mission - and because so much of the game mechanic  depends on random chance and blind luck, even a well prepared party can have one bad battle, and  literally be doomed.INTERACTIVE ITEMS: Don't bother, my experience was 99% were traps, diseases, or stress inducing maladies inflicted upon my party. that these typically occur right before a battle was no accident either. I was badly injured, defeated before the fight even began. Did I mention there is no retreat to recuperate?Want to start a fight poisoned, blighted, or bleeding to death? Go ahead and open that book, crate, or sarcoghagus.RANDOM LUCK, NO SKILL INVOLVED: As others have stated here earlier, you can go through a fight with out a scratch against a superior opponent, only to be taken apart by a pack of maggots that all score critical hits the next fight. It's maddening.There is no healing AFTER battle, (And your healers forgo offense to heal during) heavy wounds give a variety of diseases and stress-related offenses, and of course nothing tops the battle where a necromancer hit my entire party with a massive stress-inducing spell ("6 feet under") and they ALL died due to heart attack. In the same round...simultaneously. Wheee....On many missions you can camp - ONCE - and recover a slight amount - but you'll never return to proper fighting form. If I was lucky, I might get back to about 50% of my original strength. And this was typically after 2-3 fights!VERDICT: This game shows a lot of promise, but currently the game mechanic renders it  unplayable. I'll leave it in my library for a bit and see if there's a patch in the near future. Otherwise, it's done.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
 I'm sorry, guys. I need to gush. Look, I'm not a big fan of RPGs. I have no patience to play through a Final Fantasy nor a Mass Effect game.And yet this has easily landed in my top 3 favorite games I've ever played.Let's start with my pet peeve in RPGs (or any game for that matter): lengthy story. This factor is non-existent in Darkest Dungeon. The intro to the game and opening to a new playthrough both have cutscenes that last roughly 4 minutes altogether. I can easily live with that. From here, a lore is sprinkled throughout the game by a wonderfully gritty narrator that speaks during gameplay. That being said, more is revealed about the enviroment just by the interaction in the game. Interacting with objects and seeing enemies allows the player to imagine what happened (or is happening) to the dungeons they're fighting in. I adore this. There's no lengthy dialogues or other cutscenes to keep you from playing the game, let alone have a story. Granted, it's not a masterpiece novel; however, with all due respect, I gladly take this over an Assassin's Creed game where there's almost as much cutscene as gameplay (yes, I have played Assassin's Creed II, and this is merely an opinion).Let's get to another great factor of this game: it's sure challenging. Overall, it's a challenge. It's not I Wanna Be the Boshy difficult, but it's harder than your average game. I say "Overall," because the difficulty changes throughout your playthrough. First-time players to this game will find it BRUTAL (I did). Enemies could do as much damage as you (if not more), dungeons are filled with events and hazards that greatly influence for units for that current dungeon and possibly even for the rest of their lives. What do I mean by "rest of their lives?" Well, your units will die, and death is permanent in this game. Your level 3 Highwayman is gone; go pick up a level 0 at the stagecoach. Throw in some financial issues, and you got yourself into quite a pickle buying this game.And yet you will learn.You will learn what the best combination of units are. You will learn what hazards are in each dungeon and how to resist them. You will learn that not all the equipment in the game is bad and ultimately use it. You will learn how to manage your units' stress (I'll explain later) inside and outside of battle. Eventually, you will find yourself with a roster of decently-leveled units and some gold to spare on some supplies and neat-o upgrades. And yet you will learn (about bosses).Regardless of your units' levels and skills, all the bosses in this game will leave you either dead or scrambling. No, it's not just a big enemy with 100,000 health that deals 100,000 damage. Every boss has a unique mechanic, and you will need to learn them quickly if you want to survive your first attempt. For example:  At the beginning of every round, the Prophet will predict that a "catasptrophe" will happen in certain spots in your party. What this means is by the end of the round, units in those spots will take massive damage. This makes the player make a decision: who to put in these spots and take the hit? This is a problem, because moved units cannot attack the Prophet. It's a matter of survival or desperate attacking. Let's go on to one of the more prominent factors of the game: stress. Dark enviroments, recieved critical hits, and stress-inducing attacks all give your units a certain number of stress. When a unit's stress reaches 100, they will gain an absolutely awful trait. These range from paranoia to selfishness to plain insanity. Each of these traits does something different. Fear causes a unit to either move back or refuse to fight. Abusive units will constantly insult their comrades. Irrational units...are irrational. In a new update, if a unit recieves 200 stress, they will die.Not all hope is lost! Despite all this,  there is still a small chance a unit will gain "virtue" when his/her stress hits 100. This means they will gain a GOOD trait, and stress is greatly reduced. I could go on about all the interesting mechanics this game has to offer, but then this review would rival the length of War and Peace. I am leaving a lot out to say.Now, if I could take a more personal turn, this game has genuinely changed my way of thinking. This game is all about making the best of a bad situation (they even tell you that), and the odds will almost always make you cautious or even be flat-out against you. Every little thing that happens could add up and ultimately destroy you. Or do they?When I first played this game, I felt very pressured every time a trap was triggered, a unit was blighted, etc. However, I learned these are things inevitably will happen as I play, and I will have to deal with them and/or get rid of them if I wanted to succeed playing this game. Heck, many things in this game could be easily solved with clever thinking or even a single item.(This is where it gets a bit sappy, folks) In my personal life, all the littlest things would stack up every day and often drain me, but playing this game made me realize that these things just happen, and I should accept them and figure out how to surpress them or remove them from my everyday life altogether. It's rather easy now that I actually try instead of take the hits from the minor drek.And for now, I am out of things to say. All I can say now is I love this game. I am more than happy for paying the whole $20 for this (it's apparently $25 now, but I would happily pay that price as well).By the way, everything in this game looks hand-drawn, and that is g-e-u-d goooooooooooooooood.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Great concept with a few serious short comings. The initial apprentice dungeons and intermediate veteran dungeons are difficult, yet well balanced and rewarding. This isn't the case for the champion dungeons. I understand the game is based on the concept of "making the best out of a bad situation", but the late game difficulty spike is ridiculous. Basic enemies encountered in champion dungeons are seemingly on par with previous boss fights. My best heroes (max level, equipment, and skills) we're more often than not getting hopelessly roflstomped 2-3 battles in...even on short scouting quests. To make matters worse, management mechanics become increasingly skewed. For example, the weird level cap system prevents heroes from partaking in quests below their corresponding level, making it unnecessarily difficult to train badly-needed replacements and raise funds. Overall, late game play feels less about exploring dungeons/smighting evil  and more about bolstering lost gold and manpower (tedious/unrewarding grinding). After a couple hours of frustration, I threw in the towel. I doubt I have the motivation to finish it in its current state. Total shame, I really enjoyed it up to this point. I realize Red Hook has plans to implement a short mode. Hopefully they address some of these issues/give the game more mass-appeal. Until then, I can't recommend this to anyone but hardcore RPG fans.....casual gamers stay away!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is an outstanding game.  The Lovecraftian and other influences from weird tale authors make for an extremely enjoyable story, and the aesthetics are equally appealing. The gameplay itself is easy enough to pick up, and once you do you'll find that there is quite a bit of leeway allowing for a variety of game styles and strategies.  The expeditions you take with your parties can be fantastically cruel sometimes, and people WILL die, but I've never ragequit so far, which is a testament to how addicting the game can be once you get into it.  If you like anything similar in this genre, I definitely recommend getting Darkest Dungeon as well.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a grindfest, but addictive as hell! It's simular to Rogue Legacy in the sense of repeatedly playing the same dungeons over and over again, slowly gaining the resources and upgrades to proceed further the next time around. There's actually quite some roll playing going on. Although sometimes assigned too random, the positive and negative traits of your heroes, as well as the many distinctive classes, makes the characters come alive. They'll slowly gain experience and improve, and you care for them because once dead they're permanently gone and all progress is lost. The game isn't too hard though, although some bosses can be ruthless at first try because you didn't prepare the right squad to tackle it. The combat might appears generic turn-based, but there are enough subtle mechanics to keep it interesting.The art is like a dark fantasy comic book and the briljant voice over is the finishing touch.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Darkest Dungeon is the best real life simulation I've seen in gaming!Everything constantly goes not as planned, the odds are oftimes against you, your team often has to run without completing the quest, even when the goal is nearly reached; game punishes you for being rash and greedy... I understand that the devs' goal was to deconstruct dungeon crawling RPGs with unbreakable fearless heroes who constantly walking from one hell to another without even breaking a sweat. Well done on that! Game absolutely destroys many a videogame cliche.It's one of the most depressing games I've played, in a good sense! I feel very very bad for my heroes and their constant sad talk is not making things any easier.And I get infinetely butthurt by the whining of some players 'meehh, my heroes are always stressed', 'meeh, game is too RNG'. Son, your life is RNG as hell. And trying to accomplish something is stressful. Especially in the ♥♥♥♥ing Lovecraftian hell with living skeleton jelly and human-pig hybrids. Deal with it. Or go back to your games about mighty heroes who kill armies singlehandedly. This is not a game for you. This is not 'Press X to win' title.This is more than a game. This is a whole new look at dungeon crawling genre. Definetely recommend, even Early Access. The game has some flaws, but overall awesomeness negates that.10/10

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												If you can't stand turn based combat similar to the old Final Fantasy games, then you won't like this game.  If you enjoy that turn based strategy style of combat I believe you will LOVE this game.  You basically assemble a party of four heroes and go exploring in the dungeons of the game including "The Darkest" of the dungeons.  There are traps and enemy battles along the way.  The various character types have different abilities and you have to think about your choices.  Each charater has permadeath so when they're gone, they're gone.  The game has persistent saves so there's no going back and loading an earlier save state.  The art and style of the game is unique and beautiful.  I am writing this review with 11 hours into the game and I can see many more hours being poured into this title.  Don't let the price tag scare you away.  $19.99 is a good price point for a game like this.  The game is quite challenging by the way.  I got frustrated early on until I figured out some of the finer strategic points.  Easy to grasp, hard to master.  The enemies are interesting, the mood is dark, the game is fun.  I suggest it.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												This is a tentative recommendation. I've logged many hours myself, but I still find the game tricky to recommend. It's a really a "you'll like it if..." kind of game.What draws me to the game is its artwork and atmosphere, as well as the strategy and tactics of managing a team of characters. The aesthetics in particular are fantastic! Very inventive and compelling dark fantasy stuff. And there isn't exactly an abundance of turn-based team management games, either. Both strong factors for the game.However, Darkest Dungeon has abundant frustration, and not just the challenge-based or stress-based frustration you would expect, but sheer irritation due to the way many of the otherwise clever game mechanics have been executed in practice.The root cause of that frustration seems to be that the game's designers are incredibly paranoid that the player won't play the game 'correctly'. It really can give you the feeling of a judgmental game designer hovering over your shoulder, telling you that you're doing it wrong.-You shouldn't extend a fight against a weak enemy in order to have extra turns to heal your weakened heroes. Doing so will cause your team to become arbitrarily stressed out.-You shouldn't set up a control-heavy team where you try to keep dangerous enemies stunned. Many of the more dangerous enemies are very stun-resistant, and even if you do land a stun move, that enemy will gain extra resistence to the next one. Meanwhile, using stun moves instead of dealing damage means your fights will take longer, leading to the same issue as above.-You can't grind out easier levels with your best heroes in an effort to afford upgrades or further level them up. Heroes of a high enough level will flatly refuse to go on easier missions. Once a team crosses this threshold, the game difficulty suddenly ratchets way up because they will actually be underleveled for the new bracket they're restricted to.-You shouldn't put together a team that focuses solely on killing the front two enemies quickly, because there are corpses that block your way. Attacking the corpses to clear them out of the way doesn't count as proactive behavior anymore either, so your heroes will again get stressed out as if you were intentionally trying to delay the fight.Frustratingly, none of that makes any sense in practical or thematic terms for the game's dark fantasy world. It also limits the variety of options available to the player, instead shunting you towards more "developer approved" playstyles.So, the game has the awesome and rare core design of being a dark fantasy team management game, but seems to be designed by someone who's absolutely paranoid that you will Play It The Wrong Way. If you can get over that it's pretty great!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												When your heroes become too strong for the early quests, they refuse to go on any more of them. So you're forced to jump up two difficulty levels—I think that's a very artificial way of forcing difficulty, but fine. So I'm a couple fights into one of the harder dungeons, and I come across some standard-looking mobs. In the first turn one of them crits my healer for all of her health—ALL of it. She's the only one who could have healed herself back to life, so I'm ♥♥♥♥ed. I try to flee—failed. The bigger mob does an AoE that crits my ranged dps for all HIS health—now he's "on death's door" too—and finishes off the healer. Fail to flee again. They kill the dps. I don't know what would have happened after that because I closed the game, and I'm not going to be opening it again. Permanent deaths and one-shot critical hits should not exist in the same game. If you're stoical enough to bear massive losses from a string of unlucky dice rolls with equanimity, then you are a bad enough dude to enjoy this game. I'm not.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I saw Darkest Dungeon I felt in love !And I rarely buy a game at first sight...But let me explain what is Darkest Dungeon. [Long Review]Plot:After his suicide, an old relative in his last will reveals that you will inherit of an estate cursed by an old evil dungeon.You decided to claim your property and bring back order to this land.But on the way your coach is attacked. Leaving you and your body guards surrounded by cutthroats and bandits. After having dealt with them, you arrive at the miserable and gloomy village that belongs to you.Now starts your adventure, you will bring back the old stability of the village and purify the land and, maybe, put an end to the terror lying in the nearby ...  Darkest Dungeon.Layout:Darkest Dungeon is a dark and mature rpg. You mission is clear, get rid of monsters that threaten your estate with the help of warriors and the village that belongs to you. The ultimate goal is to reach the guardian of the Darkest Dungeon to put to an end the madness that curses the land.The main aspect of the game is psychology. Indeed, every character is affected by its environment, especially in the dungeons. The light in corridors, actions like opening a chest or triggering a trap, resting and even fighting can stress your warriors and make them weaker with debuffs called: Quirks.Of course you have many ways to reduce it, the most important is the village where you can unlock and upgrade buildings dedicated to relax your characters.But beware, death is inevitable and permanent. And it's a part of the game to create teams of 4 characters with different   set of skills/ classes and be able to cycle between them to explore and accomplish quests effectivelyVenturing into dungeons needs planning, you can select characters, their skills (4 max per warrior), equipment and supplies because into dungeon they need to eat, to light their way and use items to counters bad events such as debuffs after fights or random encounters like when you are stuck in front of rubbles and you need a shovel to go through with ease... but the shovel is expensive and takes place in your inventory like loot.Even loot is a problem because money takes precious slots in your inventory!To move in the dungeon you can use a little map to choose your direction or even see what you may encounter if you had the chance to scout the sector (random event), and after to progress in corridors using movement keys or mouse. Your group  walk in order until they find something and you will need to select one of them to activate an item that in general trigger a dice roll influenced by the skill of the character, the item you used with it or maybe the both.The game is set around few phases: Recruiting and management of your characters, Management of the village, Planning quests where you have to buy supplies/gear for your team, Exploring Dungeons and be back alive to take another team while the last one needs to go to the bar, brothel, abbey, sanitarium... to recover from the horrors they lived.Gameplay:Darkest Dungeon works around a good fighting system. Each party has 4 characters, they are ordered in a straight line where placement is important. Even skills depend of this placement. In general close combat fighters are in front line, slots 1 and 2. And healers and range units are in slots 3 and 4. This system is great especially in front of stress which is one of the most dangerous attacks your warriors will receive. Indeed some enemy units stay behind their buddies and send attacks that fill stress quickly. So even if you have a nice combat team with good damages and restorative effects, you will need someone capable to manage the placement of the enemy. By talking of the enemy, this is a real devil capable to focus on the weak ones, ambush you or even flush your team composition, leaving you in chaos and hurry to find the best formation to endure the fight.The feeling during fights is extraordinary. At the beginning you will have problems to grasp the subtleties, like for the plague Doctor who is a marvelous crowd control that will save you if you use him correctly.But when you get the overall idea, you will enjoy counter attacks or even some fights where the enemy is just unable to reach you. By the way it's a part of the game to stun enemy and use this moment to heal your team and go further.Even light is important. It's a bar that shows the light you produce. The fact is, the more light you have, the better you heroes will be (less stress, less enemies). The funny thing is some items are related to this "light meter" and even spawn rate of monsters. You want more challenge and money ? Try your luck into the darkness!It's one of the many funny events this game has, like when you can camp in average and long dungeons to recover some health and reduce your stress and debuffs. During camping you use a completely different set of skills for each character that you can modify and upgrade like regular combat skills. The moral feature of the game is really funny especially when your team is totally exhausted and one of you characters (it depends of the class, Hellion is my favorite for that!) is inspired and during battle brings back his comrades moral and give them strength to win.And when your team is mad it can be the contrary, like when one of your guys does little damages or misses and one of his buddies humiliates him. Even passing the turn of a character makes him angry and increase his stress ! Consider that everything I said can be applied when things are right but in a weaker mesure, like when a monster die, good events/discoveries, criticals and you have a good idea of this system.Graphics:Darkest Dungeon is a gem. Art work is amazing: you play in a comic. The game is in a beautiful 2D and sprites are very cool. Only the Dark design might disturb some but the game stays correct all the time. Not too gore or vulgar. I hope more developers will follow this way and give nice atmosphere and design for unrivaled gameplay.Music:Nice and greatly participate in the gloomy atmosphere of the game. I love the intro video where the narrator is excellent. But more voices would be great.To conclude:Darkest Dungeon is already a gem, even if the game needs some balancing in combat, for an early access it's amazing.Everything is cool  and original, even the difficulty is correct if you consider that the enemy uses the same strategies, like in Dark Souls. The only aspect in don't like are the speech bubbles of characters that appears too often and when your team is mad it can be really annoying to wait each time they finish to talk to be able to act.By the way I would like to see more interactions between characters, like friendship or the contrary. To make things more realistic and reward you when you succeed in keeping your teams alive and your characters in good shape.You can notice few bugs in the game but the autosave is enough present to keep your progress saved.Okay, so if you read my review, go up , search the green button, press purchase and enjoy.N.B: If you think the game is in general based on luck (don't believe players reviews) it is not.In fact if you take some time you will understand that taking risks or being too greedy brings bad luck.Few exemples: Maintain your light meter around 75% before entering a room. A team of monsters may ambush you.  Openning everything you find on your way, without knowing the appropriates items, characters will receive quirks and  stress at a higher rate.  Ambushed, retreat from the fight and come back to have a regular start, don't forget to rearange your team. Be ware or food and torches. 10 of each will save you, especially considering that meals are random event that can trigger even after a previous one... And torches reduces stress rate. So spare your money on blight and bleed items.

number of helpful: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								The immersion of this game is friggin' fantastic. Everything in this game fits together so well: the music, the atmosphere, the action... It all works together. That cinematic trailer for Darkest Dungeon? It really captures exactly how the game feels.In combat, the music is tense, and the camera zooms into attacks for effect. It's very quick, so no time is wasted, but it makes every attack feel exciting and apprehensive. There is a narrator that really pumps up the excitement as well, commending a crit or a kill... or a loss. When your stress limit hits 100%, the hero's resolve is tested... and there's a brief pause... will he become Courageous and rally his comrades? Or will he become Hopeless and become the doom of everyone? Town mechanics are pretty neat too. You upgrade the town facilities using these items you collect from your adventures, but you upgrade/fix your heroes using the gold you have accrued. This separation of resources is nice, because it lets you focus your gold on party management. Party management is pretty nifty but simple. Between adventures in dungeons, you can put various party members in the tavern or abbey to relieve the stress they have added up through adventuring. You can also slowly eliminate negative afflictions that your heroes have.The game's main gimmick is "Stress". As your heroes fight in the dungeons, they will become stressed after witnessing unsettling things or taking critical hits or being debuffed by the enemy. The higher one hero's stress is, the more susceptible he/she is to the enemy's attacks. This can also trigger the hero's quirks (ex. Stress > 50: -2 Speed). At 100% stress, "The Hero's Resolve Will Be Tested". When this happens, RNG will happen to see if your hero can overcome this or not. It's quite epic to see your hero get a perk out of it and display his/her heroism. It also feels incredibly hope-shattering to see them become 'Hopeless' or 'Abusive'.In addition to "Stress", there are also "Quirks". Each hero can have good quirks (perks) and bad quirks (afflictions). These are permanent attributes to a hero, and there are ALOT! There are several ways that a hero can earn a quirk. At the end of a dungeon, there is a chance for a hero to earn one. During a dungeon the hero may learn something from a book or an altar. Quirks include things like "Slugger", "Evasive", "Slayer of Eldritch" or "Syphilis", "Creeping Cough", "Deviant Tastes". You can even get quirks in town!. For example, your hero enjoyed meditation so much that they gain the "Meditator" perk which makes meditating more effective. Or perhaps they went to the bar to relieve stress but earned the affliction of "Tippler", making alcohol their only method of stress relief. There is a building in town that lets the player pay gold to rid afflictions one at a time, but it will cost gold and put the hero out of commission for one adventure.The last gimmick of the game is the in the Dungeons. There is a light meter that continually drains as you make progress in the dungeon. The darker the dungeon is, the more dangerous and stressful it becomes (but more rewarding as well!). Before you enter the dungeon, you will buy and bring provisions with you such as food (to heal or feed your party when they get hungry) or torches (to increase the light meter as you consume them) or other misc items like shovels and bandages. As of this review, the game has a few bugs, some more noticable than others. Notably there are bugs regarding gold and text. It's relatively stable in my experience. I had two crashes on Day One but have not had one since. There are a few questionable balance decisions that are being pointed out in the forums, and hopefully they will be weighed and addressed. Definitely feels like it's in beta, but it's very playable in it's current state and it's lots of fun. I can only imagine how this game will look once it leaves Early Access. I have high hopes here!There's also this thing that people are butthurt about, and it's a kickstarter exclusive class. Though I am a kickstarter, I was not in the donation level to get it. I have no idea what it is and I totally forgot there was one. The game as-is is awesome, and the lack of one class was not detrimental to my experience. Might be the principle of the matter I guess, but I can say at least that this game is not broken without it.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												I decided to give another rogue-lite a try, see if I could get past the old issues I had with them and I have not. So I can't in good heart recommend this title. It is one of those kind of games where everything is based on luck. RNG all over the place. Quite frankly I don't find that to be "difficult" at all, just unfairly unforgiving. Difficulty is giving the player a goal, the means of completing the goal and then allowing the player to show their skill and accomplish what is set in front of them. If the player has to rely completely on RNG to favour them then it is not difficulty. And there are far more RNG's that favour punishing the player than there are RNG's that favour giving the player a helping hand. The scales are tipped too heavily on one side and I just found it frustrating. The art design is great, I didn't pay much attention to the story as it felt too background'ish to care about, the combat is interesting and has potential, the setting is drearily neat, the sound design is ok I suppose. What I'm getting at is that the rest of the game is pretty much fine. It is really good in some ways. But the RNG mechanics of the game just kills any enjoyment I could squeeze out of it.

												Decent game at first, then it just gets to the point where it's not fun any longer.  The RNG doesn't seem so random, and you really get the short end of the stick a vast majority of the time. Whether you are getting critted constantly, getting a lopsided amount of negatives added to your character at the end of each run, or encountering an enemy that can just blow themselves up (and placing your entire team on death's door), the game is just too frustrating to enjoy for me personally.  I don't mind when games are difficult, but when the difficulty is increased exponentially by the computer getting "lucky" way too often on what is supposed to be "random" rolls, it's takes the joy out of the game.If you play games to have fun and not to get more stressed out than you already are from work/school, then I would recommend stearing clear of this game.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Step 1. Hire level 0 adventurers and give them no items.Step 2. go as far into a dungeon as you can collecting loot.Step 3. Fire all of them and hire new level 0 heros.Repeat forever.Darkest dungeon has no way to lose the game and most upgrades just reduce prices by a negible amount. And everything costs large amounts of money. I'd swear this was suppose to be a buy cash mobile game with how much everything costs, how grindy it is, and that is just impossible to lose.The first thing you will want to do after your first day of playing is turn the narrator volume off. He repeats himself CONSTANTLY and just plain ticks you off stealing slots at the tavern or church. He doesn't act insane or woe is me at all, and neither would I spending all my time gambling, drinking, and sleeping with a brothel. I'm not sure what is more annoying. The fact that after each dungeon run up to all 4 adventurers might gain a negative trait or how often enemies can dodge, especially enemies in the back that like to use sanity lowering moves.The game does have items called trinkets, but most have negatives that rarely seem to make them worth using. You can't even sell them, yet the game will offer to sell them to you for high amounts.Theres camping that can heal or boost your heros, but your likely to get attacked after in the dark. So the advantage camping gave might go right out the window and end your run right then and there.The fact that heros gain zero exp from battles and only from completing a dungeon. Makes battles just feel pointless. Completely 100% pointless and worthless. The time I spent in that battle I could have found and open 4 treasures or more.Its not a hard game, its not a fair game, its not much fun. I'm always loading it forgetting its not fun and then one dungeon later I remember and turn it off. Lots of rougelikes/lites have unfair enemies or traps, but they are usually consistant. Not miss every attack and every enemy gets a critical vs the same groups you always stomped before. Going from 22,000 to nothing because I upgraded 4 of my heros is not fun. This is the only game I can remember where after an entire day of grind my characters are level two. Making it possibly the most grindy game I've ever played, worse than silk road.The money grind just ruins it for me. If I wanted this much money grind I'd play a ftp mmo. The money isn't even spent on fun things, its fixing negative traits that my heros will just pick right up again.

												It was enjoyable in the beginning but the game has become too difficult to enjoy. With some games, the added difficulty makes the overall experience more enjoyable and makes victory feel rewarding. This game however, is difficult just to be difficult. It doesn't matter how well you prepare, your team could get wiped out in battles you should have won handidly because the enemy managed to crit your healer three times in a row. Speaking of RNG, the RNG in this game is bull****. Attacks that have a 100% accuracy rating miss fairly frequently, it's like the actual accuracy rating is 30% less than what they tell you it is. I know this happens a lot with other games that have RNG (Hello X-COM) but no other game has infuriated me quite like Darkest Dungeon has. The purpose of video games is to bring enjoyment or satisfaction to the player, not bring up repressed anger management issues.

								Obviously this game has some flaws. And it's nowhere near done yet.That being said, what is out so far is amazing and unique. It's remniscent of old fashioned D&D, with a ton of horror thrown into the mix. This is my go to game whenever my net is down. I've actually got closer to 100 hours on this baby. Believe me, it's a thrilling experience. The difficulty of this game is way up there with Dark Souls, but it's rougelike and if your people die they die for good, so in my opinion it's even harder. I doubt many people who weren't at one time old school gamers like me will be able to get far in this game. It requires tons of strategy, tactics, gambling on outcomes, and judgement calls.Truly a unique experience and I can't wait for more content to be added!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Addendum: So now the game is released and many changes were made since this first hit Early Access. I am glad to say the game is still awesome. Very well polished, though some of the classes could use some balancing. The mechanics are solid and the gameplay is as addictive as ever. Corpses really make no difference to me. I find them to be pretty easy to deal with to the point that, IMO, they are inconsequential. So my recommendation remains the same. By it, especially if you like games with brutal difficulty. It is rewarding to play and satisfying to overcome the odds.  One of the most polished Early Access games I have ever played, Darkest Dungeon is a gem that deserves your time. A wonderful mish-mash of genres with the addition of the excellent Stress mechanics make this one of the most brutal RPG/Strategy/Rouge-Lite games in recent memory as well. The art style is beautiful as well, conveying the gothic atmosphere well. In fact, I can't find to much bad to say about this game. If you are interested in a challenging game that is only going to get better as it gets closer to its projected summer release day, you now have your game.. The addicting gameplay will bring you back for more, More of your adventurers suffering brutal deaths and mind-crushing insanities. Managing the stress that leads to insanity is one of the more gripping and complex of the mechanics in the game. In my opinion, it is one of the defining traits of this game.Even if these types of games don't exactly appeal to you, I still recommend it. The addicting gameplay will bring you in and the amount of polish will impress. Go buy this game, it will be some of the best 20 bucks you spent on video games.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Man, since the latest update, it seems like every single review is "whaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa it's too hard now that I have to actually master mechanics!"  The game is still great, you just have to make more use of ranged characters and shuffle attacks to maneuver around the corpse mechanic and the damage-over-time effects bleed and blight, which ignore monster protection.  Before the updates you could smash virtually every single jungle with two melee solid bruisers, a healer, and whatever else you wanted because who cares; now you have to pay attention to the zone you're questing in and pick a well-designed and appropriate party, as well as placing more thought into hero selection.  I mean seriously, people are complaining because the classes like the leper, simultaneously in contention for the title of toughest tank and highest melee dps, doesn't also have a way to hit enemies in the back row.  He has a freaking ability that clears all corpses so that, with the exception of a few boss fights, you sometimes have to waste a single turn!  That's so unfair!!  The next update better give him a rocket punch and the batmobile or else I can't recommend this game as I am unfamiliar with the concept of party balance.I really hate to say it, but perhaps people who did not like the recent update should considering making an effort to get good.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												The Winning Move is Not to Play.Summary:  The experience is similar to playing Dungeons & Dragons with a somewhat goth and very depressed version of Debbie Downer.The main problem is *not* the difficulty, it's being around depressed characters.  When you go into a dungeon your characters  go from "Let's do this!" to "Why the crap am I here?" to "Life sucks and is utterly pointless, and I might as well kill myself now."  Further, when you do conquer a dungeon, the game is very lame about it ("Well, i guess you didn't die *this* time...") and your characters are so PTSD'ed out with neuroses (becoming suicidal, stealing treasure, etc.) that they need to de-stress.  So how do they do this, you might ask?  Gardening?  Hunting?  Playing frisbee?  Nope.  You have to send them to go drinking, gambling, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, or to flog themselves, etc. which is actually not nearly as fun as you might think since you just move the character icon to another slot and have to pay $$$ to try to bring them back.  (More on economics below)I am used to old-school games that are hard, where you die a lot, and I wanted to like this one based on the art style and old-school interface.  On the difficult/balance: if you have a few missions go sideways (which is extremely easy, since your characters can randomly die of heart attacks during battle), then you find that the $$$ situation has gone so wrong that you are actually *worse* off than you were when you first started the game, and you are better off just deleting your save file (game auto-saves) and starting all over again.  Conclusion:  *IF* you like wearing black berets and saying things like "Life sucks and then you die" in a French accent (even though you are not actually French) while chainsmoking for no apparent reason, then you might enjoy this game.  Otherwise,  save your $$ and go do something fun with your friends.

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
IntroductionDarkest dungeon, is shortly saying a game that is played against you. The game itself is a rpg- turned base stressfull game. Its at this point it's in early acces. Section Title*the story : The story itself is quite witty, wich makes it fun if you appriciate that kind of humor. Your hero's mention some witty comments about themself or how they go insane. *The graphics : A diffirent style then what you would see in most RPG games, It is quite darkbut then again the game didn't steal it's name.*Gameplay : well... What can I honestly say? The game is made to make you go insane with frustration and anger,It is build to go against you, Wich makes it really addicting because you really want to beat the game. Somehow one of your hero's gets rabbies, or gets scared and therefor moves to the last position. You just start cursing on how they react and wish you where in the game yourself. But the more frustrating the more you get into the game. The longer you play the more you realise how hard it is, how hard it is to collect gold, to delete the negative effects from your hero's. give it positive effects,and so on.In the end you can let your hero's gamble- drink-rest. everything to make them happy right? They can sing to eachother peacefully next to a campfire, or be selfish and take all the food for themself. You will need some strategy tho, see what fits together. So theorycrafting is also fun in this game  with strategy I mean more : with what hero will you pick up the bookcase, Will you leave it? or will you take the risk? It is something you will need to think about. *Soundtrack : Just like the graphics, it isn't something you find generally in an RPGIt is quite stressfull music when everything goes dark, a little bit halloween style. *Money-wise : Do I think the game is worth so much? Yes I do, the game is something you can play for hours non stop. You can start over or you can continue. so the time you would put into this is for me worth the money. Overall VerdictIf you are willing to have patience, anger, frustration, sadness (because oh no all your effort) then this is tottaly worth it. Do not forget this is an early acces game, things can still change. There will still be some bugs, and changing incomming. Overall Score: 9/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I started playing Darkest Dungeon about a month ago, soon after the Houndmaster update.  The gameplay and narration are excellent and I think the graphics/battle animations are superb, as well.  The storyline reminds me of H.P. Lovecraft's "The Rats In The Walls" and that's a great thing!  Kudos to Red Hook on capturing the same dark, dreary feel. I found the game to be very difficult early on because I was trying to save all of the party members after each mission and didn't have enough gold to fix all of their problems.  Once I accepted that the level 0-1 characters were simply cannon fodder to use for the greater good of the Hamlet (sending out on no provision runs to gather gold/resources and then dismissing the entire party afterwards), the game became easier.  Using the gold to fund real mission and item/ability upgrades for my main characters, I slowly built up my roster and continued doing no provision runs when my core teams required rest.       Now, I have a full roster of upgraded (though not max level) characters.  The days of no provision runs with new recruits is over but they served their purpose.  My "A-Team" (Grave Robber/Vestal/Crusader/Man-at-Arms) is level 5 and has completed several Champion runs; the remaining heroes are level 3-4 and are capable of completing the Veteran runs in various party combinations.  In my opinion, the best classes are the Man-at-Arms and the Vestal; I haven't had any success with the Occultist or the Plague Doctor.  It seems like the Occultist's heal fails at a critical time and isn't worth the risk, the Vestal has proven to be a more reliable healer.  The Plague Doctor hasn't been a strong enough healer or damage dealer in my expeience; I'd take the Vestal/Crusader for healing or just about anything else (Arbalest/Bountry Hunter/Grave Robber/Highway Man) for damage dealing, over the Plague Doctor.  Would I recommend this game to others?  Absolutely!  For only $20 (about the same price as a movie or two at the theater), I've had over 70 hours of enjoyment and I am looking forward to the next 70+ hours of gameplay.

												It had potential early on, but it's turned into a huge grind where way too much is left up to rng. So much of the game becomes recruiting fodder to send into the dungeons with no supplies so you can grind gold and other currency to heal your main group. Once the main group is healed you send them in to go for a boss, hoping that RNG doesn't bend you over and ♥♥♥♥ your♥♥♥♥♥ forcing you to retreat and start the whole grind process all over again. content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												To open up: If you hate those times where RNG absolutely screws you over despite your best efforts and you are shrieking with rage because of it... this game is not for you.New players beware: The games difficulty in the beginning is deceptive. Early on you may not notice it as much but the game quickly creeps up with the difficutly spike if your not careful. Maybe its just me but the difficulty progression feels "off".Don't get me wrong. The premise, the atomsphere, the narrator and the artsyle are all very nice. However the gameplay elements turn the game into more of a grindfest which is a shame as this game from what I remember in Early Access wasn't actually like that.A good tip I would recommend to newplayers is once you are in the Hamlet, go to your gameplay options, click Darkest  Dungeon Configuration and turn off Corpses. It will save you a few headaches. Another tip is if one of your party members is getting close 100/200 stress, leave the dungeon. As unless you have the proper quirks and trinkets, your character is usually going to be hit with an affliction and these afflictions stress out the rest of your party and cause them to get afflictions or worse... heart attacks which can kill your party member.I honestly cannot recommend this game unless your honesltly looking for a real challenge.

												An okay game I can't really understand why people like. I like RPGs and I like exploration, but this game tries it's hardest to make the game not fun. I'm not a big fan of games where your characters die all the time (as to me story is interaction between characters and if they die before they are developed what's the point).This game is really a Dungeons and Dragons luck-of-the-die-roll type of game with a very low budget. This game did not appeal to me at all, but try it on sale if you're curious, you may like it.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												First thing's first.  Don't buy the game if you don't want a challenge.  Don't buy the game if you hate a little bit of grinding.  Don't buy the game if you hate turn based strategy games (they really should include strategy as a tag).  Don't buy the game if you want an immersive storyline.  Don't buy this game if you're not willing to invest a little time failing in order to learn.  RPG's are my genre.  I don't think I would call this an RPG.  It's something else.  Difficult is obviously a very subjective word.  If you plan to buy this, assume that it will be very hard.  If it fails to live up to your difficulty expectation, then you're in a very small minority I think.There's been a lot of bad reviews gaining traction for this game since the full release.  I never played it in EA, but I've enjoyed the game thoroughly since I've had it.  I can't say whether or not the quality of the game was affected since EA ended, but I've definately got my money's worth out of the final release, and enjoyed every moment of it.The only reason I'm wrting this review is because I agree with what everyone has to say about the game's positive attributes.  Most of the the negative reviews bring up luck, RNG, grinding, and "unfair".  I don't know what to say to that.  I've never once thought the RNG was out of balance or that the game was unfair.  However, the game is pretty tough.  There's a decent learning curve as well.  Once you know which party compositions fit your playstyle, who to bring where, how to interact with dungeon objects, when to kick a hero to the curb, which trinkets are worth finding and using, and how to manage the different enemies in the game..... There's no more problem.  The game remains a challenge, especially the final end game push, but once you're familiar with the game, the farming that is necessary is almost risk proof.  The game did ruin my night once, but it was my fault.  I chose to engage a champion level mini-boss.  It didn't go well.  It didn't go great on Veteran the first time I fought him either.  He wiped my party in the Champion level dungeon.  I lost 8 ancestral trinkets.  All gone.  4 resolve level 6 heros.  Gone.  However, it was my fault, and I learned from it.  It was not "unfair".  Also, crits happen.  I'm not sure why people complain about a string of crits against their party that snowballs into disaster.  I mean, think of all the monsters that constantly get wrecked by your heros.  Over and over and over again.  Surely they should be able to ruin your day every once in a while.  That's what I think.Yes, farming is necessary.  Yes, there is grinding.  I've enjoyed every minute of it.  I enjoy the dungeon crawls.  I think if one were to approach this game as a turn based strategy game, there would be less hate.  Also, the game isn't as random as people have stated.  You can mitigate the chance of just about anything happening as long as you use the right trinkets and skills.  Mitigate, not prevent.  But you can't mitigate everything at once.  As the player, you need to decide what would be best to prepare for depending on your group composition and dungeon.Full disclosure:  I haven't finished the game, but I'm close enough to have a full oppinion of the game.  I will finish this first run with strict (default) settings, with all caretaker goals completed.  I have two final pushes on the Darkest Dungeon itself left, and one boss left in the Cove.  Final note:  If you find yourself truly finding this game "unfair", try running vestal, plague doctor, hound master/ crusader/man at arms.  Now you've become the one who is playing unfair.  Very final note:  You don't have to play the game the way the dev's intended.  Most things can be toggled on or off in the menu.  I urge you to try to play with strict rules, but If you truly dislike them, then by all means turn some of that stuff off.

Posted: January 29, 2016
												With the upgrade paths in the different buildings being so linear, I feel like there's actually very little variance in this game and it's purely a matter of endurance instead of randomness: max everything out and go for the final dungeon. The problem is that this form of progression just isn't masked well enough to make the game endearing to play until the end, and being able to see what skills you'll get for each character makes it more of a chore and less of a reward.The narration is interesting, but gets old fairly quickly. No way to turn it off either, just mute the narrator itself. The game's art style, easily being the highlight of this game, is striking and conveys a sense of dread and despair, but there's not much else propping it up in my opinion.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Main complaint is you can't send higher level characters into lower difficulty dungeons. So, for instance, if you have level 4 characters, they can't play through a level 1 dungeon. Instead you have to send them to a level 3 dungeon, which will likely result in a total party kill. If this gets fixed I have no problems with the difficulty or even the game's stinginess with gold.*Edit*I sunk another 30 hours or so into this game, thinking I'd been unfair the first time. Nope. The game is the only thing that's unfair. The level capping ultimately prevents this game from being worthwhile. In addition to the complaint above, you can't level up past level 6, so sending high level teams out to level 5 or (God forbid) level 6 dungeons will just get them party wiped. Really wish they'd allow higher levels to grind through lower level dungeons. Until then, the game remains a waste of time.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												While gameplay seems to be appealing from the beginning, the scaling to the later stages of the game is poorly designed. I'd even say it is simply abysmal: every lvl5+ battle turns into RNG fiesta with little to no ability to mitigate or prevent randomness on a side of the player. For example, a group of ~6 SPD monsters all went before any of my 7+ SPD party and killed my lvl6 position 3 hero. Just like that. I was unlucky. But the main problem is that the every high level "unfortunate event" of that type has the only consequence - more boring repetitive grind in leveling up another hero from 1 to 6. This game in its core is just the same old poorly designed RPG with the only way to victory - through tedious, boring, and repetitive grinding of the same content. The only difference is that the old games forced you to grind until your characters are OP enough to beat the game, and here you grind until you happen to be lucky enough to beat the game.

Posted: June 3, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I even poured hours into it. I now regret them. 1) Random crashes are infuriating. How hard is it to build a stable game? 2) The random number generating. It's as bad as playing Risk. Far too many battles turn around because of a single "Crit" from the enemy. The Crit puts someone at Death's Door, then makes them afflicted, etc. all in one go. I can't count how many boss attempts ended the square before the boss because the dungeon decided to throw a Collector at me. Seriously? Additionally, too many of the mechanics are poorly explained. Scouting is obviously the most important mechanic in the game yet nothing ♥♥♥♥ing talks about it. And it can be absurdly unreliable. 3) I believe *this* game is more about gameplay than story, that being said I find the story just not worth it. Initially I cared but the story pieces before each boss dungeon just don't hook me. Also, for the emphasis placed on the gameplay it all so poorly explained and the learning curve is steep.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												The concept seems interesting and thoughtful, but it's not. The Cthulhu-based story drew me in. The terrible design drove me away. Challenge comes only through non-sensical design choices and the intense over-use of RNG.Want to do something? RNG will stop you. Want to heal out of combat? You can't, even though you are a healer. Want to kill monsters? Well, you may get an occasional kill, but bodies just pile up, even though you are killing less than 3 at a time. Said bodies will block you from attacking. Everything is range based, and the game keeps finding ways to randomly change your positioning. The monsters can get though the piled up bodies just fine though, for some reason. If this were an action game, zombies and skeletons would be more nimble than humans. All of this doesn't entirely matter though, because your party usually dies from massive amounts of stress damage, which can't be mitigated much, in a handful of fights. It can be mitigated, sure, but you take about 500 damage in a dungeon, and you can mitigate about 20.Party members are essentially canon fodder, and your goal is to build up your estate as they all die from horrible deaths. Yet, you will not be interested in doing so, because it's an excessive RNG-based grind fest where you see the same tiles and the same monsters over and over and over again....I tried to return the game, but they won't let me. Maybe there's $2 worth of original ideas in this game, not $10 or $20+, not nearly so.

So it is easy to go downhill from that point.it's incredible difficult to lower the stress beside going to a town.Losing characters, getting bad threatments, and everything else that is negative. That i am inside of a dungeon and then later i decide to leave. How can that give me stress? It should be a relief! Like "Aaah Finally!" But these weirdo's are getting more stressed for leaving! Do they really want to leave? Fights are turn based and dependant on luck. (like throwing a dice)-------------------I Give this game a 4/10
