content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												*DISCLAIMER* I'll admit that I haven't exactly spent too much time with Darkest Dungeon, so I've read up on some other user experiences while also presenting my own. I plan, at some point or another, to go back and give the game another try and see if I just dismissed it too quickly.While my time with this game isn't much, I do believe that I've seen and heard enough of it to give a solid opinion. Darkest Dungeon stresses realism at its finest and at its absolute worst, bringing a mariad of interesting mechanics and solid designs, but overall presenting us with a very, very frustrating experience. I had been looking for a dungeon crawler-esque game for a while now that could satiate my thirst to test my greed whilst diving for treasures and loot, and Darkest Dungeon seemed like a nice fit at the time. Unfortunately, only four hours later, I felt completely defeated and a tad bored of what this game wanted me to accomplish. The developers want you to go into various locations that seem to be procedurally generated and complete whatever mission you choose. Most of the time it was a "Complete 100% of the battle rooms" or "Explore 90% of the rooms" or something of that nature. There's the occasional random battles or what have you along the way, and I enjoyed that part.Initially, I enjoyed every second of combat. It was diverse and very strategic, keeping you on your toes and thinking steps upon steps ahead. Every battle was a fight not to just keep your team healthy enough to venture on, but to survive. It was thrilling and it was made even harder through the stress mechanic (which I will get to later). After a while of going head-to-head with hordes of bandits, undead, and demons, I started to realize something very grave about Darkest Dungeon in that, for a game that stresses realism, RNG has some very heavy influences. Random crits made your life either a lofty cloud to rest upon or a hellish nightmare to barge through. Every crit landed against you felt like being pushed even further down a hill of an uphill battle. Then, to continue with this discussion of RNG, there's the largest offender: the stress mechanic. Stress in this game is manageable through various skills of different classes and two locations in the base town. The concept in itself is interesting, but already too overbearing as there's already so much you have to worry about. Every hero or whatever you would like to call your characters has a stress bar that reaches to two-hundred points. In just one mission your heroes, if you don't play your cards right, could very well easily get over one-hundred points of stress. Stress isn't just triggered through combat either; there are a lot of tiny other things that will add up over that period of time that you spend in the area. Once a hero reaches one-hundred points of a stress, a very heavy fifty-fifty will take place that could possibly make or break a character, deciding if they get some virtuous perk that reinforces heroism or some negative effect that just hinders the rest of your group entirely. The stress system is just a dice roll that I dread every single time I'm notified of it.The game of chance that you play whenever you find a new treasure (called "Curio" in Darkest Dungeon) kind of adds just an unnecessary step of risk and reward. Not to mention running away from a fight is also determined by RNG...but I think that my point has been made clear enough. Ultimately, this is one of those decisions on whether you're willing to put forth the time and effort that this game requires of you to press on. And you have to be accepting of the fact that your best team could very well be wiped out in a single mission if you're not very careful. I enjoy that cautious and looming feeling that you really should have whenever playing a game like Darkest Dungeon, but with its heavy reliance on RNG when it really matters, it takes away from that experience and oppresses the realism that Red Hook Studious is trying to convey. I give Darkest Dungeon a solid 4/10 so far. I plan to play the game further and it might give me a better viewpoint if I just give myself more time to bask in the dark fantasy world that the developers have conjured, but I'll always have a sinking feeling that knows that there's always a very large chance of my characters being lost to random crits or afflictions. And unless there's some type of fix in the future, I don't see my opinion chaning all that much.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game was great at first, in terms of early access when I bought it 7 months ago. I decided to wait after a bit to get the full experience, but it seems that's never going to happen. 7 months + of early access is a joke to the video game industry, and it appears this game will be in early access long after people have forgotten about it. Leonardo Di Vinci said "Art is never finished, only abandoned." The developers need to get over the fact that this game will never be perfect and accept when a game is good enough to say it's finished. They can patch the game, add expansions, or release a HD hyper delux directors cut version with everything they want included in the game later down the road, all while making money off it.  Early Access is just Beta Testing but you pay to test the game.  This Early Access business model only serves greed, and gives a reward to people that didn't fully earn it yet. Stop supporting Early Access.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								At first this game seems great, it is difficult but managable. However, after the first two hours it starts showing all of the things I hate about games made artificially difficult. You can have best team ever with combos and skills all mastered and some random dungeon encounter with a skeleton will kill half of them with cheap tricks like constant crits and dodges of the enemy. I guess when I got the game I was hoping that it would be difficult but in a way that is ment to motivate the player to get better, not as one of those meat boy style games where the game is frustrating just because it can. My biggest regret is that I actually spent over two hours in game so I cant get my money back, definitelly dont recommend if you dont like getting frustrated over cheap tricks the developers used to make the game harder than it really is. Lastly it becomes a grindfeast pretty quick as you need higher level heroes for later quests but those heroes tend to die at random, so now you have to get new ones and grind lower quests over and over again...

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Six small reasons I can't recommend this game until they are fixed or adjusted:1. You can't use abilities out of combat. The developers want to be realistically harsh, but not realistic. Pick one. It's easy to implement a system where you can use abilities out of combat. Just like bleeds still do damage per movement after combat, so should abilities. And we all know that movement increases stress. Done. I just fixed the game. No charge guys. I'm nice that way.2. Some town events do not work like the autoleveling of idle classes. Doesn't do anything. I'll fix this bug free of charge too if needed. Call me.3. If you overshoot the door at the end of a passage by 1 cm, you have to backtrack to click on the door. WTF? All you should need to do is walk to the edge of the screen and it should automatically load the next room.4. The enemy shuffles your party order when you are surprised, but the enemy party is never shuffled for any reason.5. Using an item (like a shovel) on a curio that doesn't accept the item (like a stack of books) the game will consume the item and do nothing but tell you it had no effect. You don't get your item back as if the stack of books swallowed the shovel. WTF?6. Some curio events have extreme penalties that pretty much force good players to not be curious. Myself and other youtubers don't even touch most curios anymore unless we know 100% that we can force a positive outcome. Even using the wrong item on a curio will waste that item. RIP sense of adventure.

content:
Posted: February 12
												This game has amazing potential, but it is incredibly buggy.I lost 4 campaigns in a row due to fatal crashes.  Despite going through tech support with the developer, I could not get the game to run without crashes and loss of data.With the latest update, I cannot even start a campaign without the game crashing immediately.  Because I exceeded the 2h of play time (the crashes only happened after about 6-8h in to the campaign), Steam refuses to refund this game.If you are one of those who this game works for, great - it's a fun, engaging game.  But if you are like me, and lose hours of playtime, and then end up with a non-functioning product, it's worth exactly nothing.  Be prepared if you buy this game - your save files can become corrupted, especially if the game unexpectedly shuts down, and you have no way to continue your progress, and no recourse for a refund if you are one of the people affected.EDIT:  After additional contact with the developer, I was able to get the game to start a new campaign.  If I can get this to run without crashes and loss of data, I will revise my review to reccommend this game - it IS a fun, engaging game.

number of helpful: 18 of 33 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I always thought about getting this game but didn't want to spend 20€ on it, so I grabbed it on sale.I saw some gameplay on streams already but most of the game I figured out on my own. Difficulty:The difficulty varies from extremly easy to slightly challenging. I am only in week 30+ however. Some people say the the game's RNG is making it impossible to play, but I can't agree to that at all. I have never had a fight that felt impossible to win. I haven't lost a single character yet and beat about 5 bosses. Most of the fights is just you gathering all the information about the enemy, doing some simple math and then make your move. If you don't do that and use your abilities willy-nilly then the game is probably a bit harder for you.Atmosphere & Game Mechanics:The atmosphere is great, the game mechanics are new and refreshing. The addition of stress on top of your standart HP-Bar is nicely done and it manages to capture the horrifying experience that is dungeon-crawling. The art-style is very fitting and combined with the differen't light effects the dungeons feel completely different depending on your light-level. Not only does the light level determine the scariness of the dungeon by looks aswell as sounds (which are awesome) but it is also a shift in playstyle. Running around in the dark is high-risk and high reward, while running around with the torch lit can make your dungeon safer but you get less treasure. Characters:There are 15 different characters to choose from, each filling different roles and some being very unique. So far I have used 14 of them, but I would say more than half of these characters are great and about equally strong, depending on your team and the dungeon you're exploring. Once again, if you choose your characters without paying much attention, the game gets a lot harder. But with a little bit of observing I was able to find out quite quickly which parties make which dungeon very easy and what combinations work well together. Town Management:There are 2 major currencies in the game: gold and heirlooms. Heirlooms are needed to improve your town while gold is used to buy provisions for your dungeon parties aswell as upgrading and maintaining your adventures. This is actually a quite challenging task, since the higher level your adventurers get, the more gold you will have to spend.For now, I have been able to win, or at least be on par in the arms-race with the dungeon enemies, but as a result I am almost always low on gold. Final Conclusion:One thing that had me worried about this game was that it might be too repetitive for me. After playing for a good bit, I can say that with many different characters to choose from and 4 unique dungeon locations (Darkest Dungeon still locked) I am still not bored of the gameplay. I feel like even though I have a pretty good grasp on the game, there is still much to discover, be it in creating the best possible party for each dungeon, defeating all the bosses or optimizing each characters quirks and trinkets. I am sure that this game still has many secrets to be uncovered and I can already say that the purchase, especially since it was a sale, was well worth it! If you liked my review, I would appreciate a thumbs up so others may enjoy it aswell!

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's a few things you don't do in game design. A pretty important one is that you shouldn't take the players' hours of work and investment and then roll the dice to see if he or she keeps it.In this game I designed a fun, powerful composition and was having a lot of success with it. It took me somewhere around 10 hours to feel confident and prepared, and the team was blazing through dungeons. Seeing my team was now far over-levelled and overgeared I decided it was time to take on the second boss. I entered, went through the dungeon unscathed and finally reached the boss. Then he immediately hit my entire team with a massive critical hit, permanently killing two of them and essentially erasing hours of work with no warning or counterplay.The best example I can think of the compare how that feels is to suggest how one would feel after 10 hours of adventuring on skyrim, only to have the game say "Woops! We decided to delete your save file to keep you on your toes!"Artificial difficulty is thrown around a lot these days, but this is a perfect example. It's poor game design that punishes the player for doing everything right. In what way does this kind of thing inscentivize the player to continiue playing? One could argue that events like this add to the overall horrific feel of the game, to which I respond that events like that add to the overall feel of me wishing I had spent my money on something that didn't make me feel like I wasted the last 10 hours of my life. The game has a lot of possitive qualities, but I can't recommend it currently.

number of helpful: 20 of 37 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
												God, I love so much about this game. Really, I love it. But it's soooo hard to recommend this game because I would like to keep my friends.WOW, is it stressful. And that is the point, I get it...most things are challenging but a few things in the game are incredibly unfair (don't confuse the two). On the one hand, I love that the game designers made a real challenge, but on the other hand they take full control way from the player. The actual gameplay is great! It's challenging, dark, has a lot of strategy, and it is a lot of fun 90% of the time. I loved the setting, the stories, the difficulty of the actual fights, and the upgrading system.BUT there are THREE things in this game that make is just plain unfair. Pull-your-hair-out unfair. Like, “what were they thinking?!” unfair. 1. You can’t use your skills outside of combat. So no healing unless you’re being attacked. No mana bar, no healing potions either. This doesn’t make sense from a role-playing perspective. I get why it’s there, but it’s…frustrating. It's managable, but it takes control away from the player and breaks the fantasy immersion.2. You don’t keep the items you buy! This drives me insane! You spend so much money on provisions every time you go on a quest and any left-overs just…vanish. It doesn’t make any sense! It's stupid. It’s just stupid. It’s here for the sake of being hard. No other RPG has this, and real life doesn't have it! Game designers: if you can see this, screw you for this one.3. You have to bring food with you and that heals you a teeny bit when you eat..okay, fair right? But if you don’t eat it when the game tells you to...you lose HP. So you can’t eat early or you risk getting hungry…which again makes no sense! Everyone gets hungry at the same time even if they have eaten so you might as well never heal with food. And when you eat you gain 1-3 hp but lose 6-8 hp when you don’t!!! This is so stupid!People who like this game…I like it to, I really do. I love Lovecraft, I want to keep playing, I want to enjoy it more, but every time I play it I get really stressed out and I need to de-stress like my characters. Games sholdn't feel like second jobs that are harder than your actual job.

Early Access Review
								Ignore everything you hear about this game being difficult... because to say this game is "difficult" would suggest that this game is also fair. There are plenty of games out there that challenge reflexes, or strategic aptitude, or even sheer amount of patience... unfortunately, this game doesn't demand any of those. Instead, it demands tolerance for randomness. The only thing worse than having to say "wow, there was no real way I could have survived that" is having to say "wow, there was no real reason why I should have won that". It takes away any real sense of agency, which is one key feature I look for in a game.The game is gorgeous, sound/voice-acting is moving. At this time, however, the game is NOT worth anything beyond a Steam sale.

												I love this game, yes it can be cruel, frustrating and downright unfair at times but if anything that makes me love it all the more.You start out with a duo of hardy adventuring types off to right the wrongs back at the family manor, DONT MAKE THE MISTAKE OF GROWING FOND OF THEM! no matter how long they last, no matter how many times they pull that critical out of nowhere at the last moment or dance back from deaths door they are doomed to a grisly end in these dark halls, as are most of those who will follow them into this hellish place.Insanity death and disease are constant threats, the whole place is filled with traps and treasure that can be as much a curse as a blessing...And yet it still manages to be great fun.So if you fancy some truly lovecraftian style insanity give this game a try, it will make you regret it and love it in equal measure.

number of helpful: 21 of 39 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's a bit fun at first, but it gets old very quickly.If you wanna try playing something almost identical to it, there's a way to do it for only one cent. Simply flip the coin; if it's heads, you win and everybody is happy. Tails, you lose and you can try again.Seriously, though, 90% of the game is dictated by dice rolls. There are certainly some levels of strategy, team building, and upgrades, but overall it's just dice rolls. Unlike good RPG's, you can't do much of anything to affect those dice rolls. It's quite possible that it becomes more affected by choice later on, but certainly in the beginning, choices don't matter at all. Why play a game where your choices make no difference? You get just as much enjoyment out of watching someone else play, because choice genuinely doesn't matter.I had really high hopes for this game, and it looks so great - both the art style, and the gameplay in general. But in practice, the game completely fails to deliver. I wish I had a game that was exactly like Darkest Dungeon in every way, just it punished you for having poor tactics instead of punishing you for simply playing the game. Every time I play, I hope I can find what others apparently see in the game, that same ideal that I had hoped for when I first bought it. Instead, I can't help but feel that the developers are laughing at me for buying their game.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												As much as I enjoy challenging games where failure is another lesson learned, Darkest Dungeon is pure rewardless masochism. There is no light at the end of the tunnel. There are no great rewards for heroism. You will not "learn" the game like Dark Souls or Dwarf Fortress, because everything only gets constantly more unforgiving if you make any progress. There is no way to improve your gameplay, no way to learn from your mistakes, and no real reason to keep playing as time goes on when every new enemy feels like more of the same or an even more unfair concept.Darkest Dungeon is very well made, spectacularly designed, and should be a glowing recommendation... but I can't bring myself to recommend a game that flawlessly executes being utterly unenjoyable.

number of helpful: 21 of 39 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												If you like games that will make you miserable.....I have to strongly warn any and all interested that it will produce in the player massive levels of anger, frustration, and salt the likes of which you would not even find playing the likes of Dark Souls on a bad day. At least in a game like Dark Souls skill takes precedence and makes the game gradually more enjoyable. In this game, you are never not a victim to the RNG. When things go well, they go very well. But when things go bad, it honestly feels like the developers are giving you the finger and kicking you in the balls with a smug smirk for good measure.I've pushed on through this game and managed to defeat every beginner and veteran boss with two of the intermediate bosses (the dreaded Swine God and the Hag Witch) under my belt. But I've recently thrown in the towel and decided I can't push myself any further. It isn't simply a matter of the RNG either; the intermediate dungeons are too difficult with enemies that will frequently have both high dodging AND protection stats making each battle a slow grind and a fight for your life. That there are ways to mitigate the enemies ability to survive your attacks with debuffs barely helps when the debuffs tragically miss, making that character's turn wasted, or when you simply don't have anyone on your team available to do such a thing. It doesn't help that you can't ever go anywhere without a healer, whose healing skills are so hit and miss you're constantly on the edge of your seat whenever they attempt to patch your crumbling team together.Where the difficulty goes overboard is with an enemy called The Collector that you are guaranteed to fight at least once randomly in EVERY intermediate level dungeon. These enemies are the biggest asshats due to their ability to continually respawn allies which can either heal or protect it while it too heals itself by draining life from your team to refresh its already huge pool of helth. The reward for defeating this enemy, an item worth a lot of gold, won't even cover your losses at the end of the quest when you have to send your team to the tavern or the abbey to undo their accumulated stress (assuming you can even survive).Where I quit was in a dungeon where I had just barely survived an encounter with this most dreaded of foes only for TWO of my high level heroes whom I had already invested much money into upgrading, BOTH died, in a game with perma death no less. That brought the toll of dead heroes to ten and caused me to delete my save file in frustration. I don't mind (too much) if a hero dies valiantly while fighting a boss which I then proceed to defeat, but when it happens randomly due to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG it brings my blood to a boil and I have to fight not to hurl my laptop across the room.It's sad, because I like this game. I really, truly do. But it is TOO F&%#ing hard!!! Would it honestly kill them to dial down the difficulty just a bit? Even to allow you to purchase disposable healing items so you're not constantly relying on healers who can only heal during battle? When every quest becomes a desperate roll of the dice not just to progress the game but to just get yourself out of the black so you can invest in hero upgrades then it becomes more of a painful chore than a thrill. Especially when you see all that hard work go down the drain due to some random trick of the RNG. (Like missing four times in a row when trying to kill even a single enemy!)I like hard games but I'm getting sick and tired of this meat-head "git gud" mentality which is plaguing games lately and making people feel ashamed for just wanting to have fun.This game is too hard. Not hard but rewarding kind of hard, but hard and painful, like the worst day of your life at the worst job you've ever had and when deep in debt to boot. Would it be such a bad thing if they just make it a little more forgiving?????

number of helpful: 22 of 41 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												The level of art is very high and graphical design of the user interface is as intuitive as it is appealing. The narration and sound effects are simply awesome, and the narrator encourages you with quotes of wisdom with his deep resonating and enchanting voice as you go along. This is one of the most enjoyable and best aspect of the game, which really distinguishes it and compensates for the negative aspects. If the negative aspects are sorted, the devs are looking at a block buster.What I didn't like is there is no difficulty setting, just an radio button option to switch corpses and heart attacks off. This makes the game a lot easier and you don't seem to be penalised for switching these off, nor is there a reward for enabling them, so there is no incentive to switch em back on.Combat is one of the main aspects of the game but a lot of luck is involved, and this will get you cursing and shouting at times. A lot of people have already reviewed this aspect so, briefly, the computer has been made to cheat to increase difficulty. But I would rather fight a tougher enemy i.e with more HP, rather than a weaker enemy who cheats. So enough from me on luck. But the silliest aspect of the game IMHO is time wasted during combat. In between in each character turn there is upto a 10 second of animations starting with a loud drum beat, then the character gets blessed, stressed, buffed or debuffed, bleeds, blighted or resists and then he/she says something which you expect given the stress/quirk e.g. "I... this...can't". Given 8 characters must play each round that is 80 seconds per round, then 70 sec, then 60 sec as you kill the enemy etc. Given you could play 20-30 rounds per combat (especially if you take your time to kill the last rogue to heal your characters) that's typically 15 - 20 minutes of time wasted per battle. Given you play a battle almost every other room you are looking at typically an hour upto 2-3 hours of pure-time-waste per mission, just to watch some animations. I haven't even counted the time while the characters are actually attacking/defending let alone the time travelling in between rooms. There is no option to speed up combat and cut the faff. Playing one mission enables you to heal your resting heroes, and to collect about 10-15k gold, 20-40 heirlooms. Hence, it is a sad time waster. I think twice before launching the game because I know I will be immersed for the best of 3-4 hours just to complete 2-3 repetitive missions, of which half the time I'm just watching animations. Do I really want to spend a few hours just watching my computer play out a battle while I interact a little? I recommend you to wait till this is fixed, because waiting for a better build could save you many many pointless hours.EDIT Jan 2017: After uninstalling and hiding the game for over a year, I decided to give it another try and re-install with all updates . Turns out they have improved speed a little. But one of my best level 6 man-at-arms was first to die against a random undead party, despite having a hard-earned UNYIELDING quirk with 2 rare deathblow-resist trinkets, full armour, dodge etc!!!! he died even before any other heroes with lower DB resist who reached Death's door!!!!! Turns out Death Blow Resist is NOW CAPPED AT 87% meaning even if you have UNYIELDING quirk plus have 2 non-identical trinkets each with 12.5% deathblow resist you max at 87% instead of 97%!!!! So first they disallow combining 2 identical trinkets, THEN even if you worked hard get positive quirk and to find 2 non-identical trinkets to add more resistance, they spoil your fun by CAPPING the resistance value. No other towns to play in except Hamlet. No MP. No difficulty levels. ABSOLUTELY FED UP. CHEAP. TIMEWASTER. UNINSTALLING THIS STUPID GAME AGAIN.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												after spending the last 3 days playing this game until the early hours of the morning, I unfortunately have found myself in the "waste of time" camp in my opinion of this game. It's infuriating because as many others have pointed out the game absolutely nails the dark desperate tone. But unfortunately the RNG gods are just TOO cruel. There's no respite. and when you level up your favourite character he can't undertake low level adventures.... low level adventures which you have to partake in to level up weaker characters. The most frustrating thing is all the developers would have to do to make this game feel more fair is introduce a difficulty level. Put a few of the enemy creatures at a lower base HP and lower attack damage, maybe ensure the player has more critical hits etc. That way I could at least choose if I want to continously go up against enemies and get slaughtered at every turn. I'm currently stuck on the swine prince, who has an attack that hurts every party memeber about 8-12 damage, and stuns them. whilst the most potent healer can heal up to 12 damage, rng could also mean he heals absolutely nothing. It's just unfair when a boss can take half ot the health of your whole party with one attack, stun them so they can't retaliate, and you can only do pot shots of like 9 damage whilst he has a health bar of over 140+I finally caved in and changed the default options of how the game is played (you have the option to remove enemy corpses which block your positioning for fighting other monsters) I unchecked an option which meant sometimes if I fled from a fight my attempt would be unsuccessful, so of course when a fight was going awry I chose to flee.... only to be told my fleeing attempt was unsuccessful. Why did they give me the option to disable that game mechanic if the game just ignored it anyway?If the game ever gets a few edits to allow some kind of difficulty option, or they give you more customisation in general IE allowing the player to choose if they want to bring higher level characters onto quests, then this would be an immediate buy from me. As it stands however, I don't think I will be able to ever see the any more content in this game which is a shame because it is so well crafted.

content:
Posted: January 1
												I read alot of reviews before I bought this game, and mostly heard things about how it was unnecessarily unfair. These reviews turned me off to the game (which I'd been interested in for awhile). I finally picked it up, and I wish I'd never listened to a bulk of those reviews. Most reviews went on about how the game was brutally relentless, hating the player at every turn and ALWAYS stacking the odds against you. However, upon having played the game myself, I say this is a pro rather than a con. The thing about Darkest Dungeon is that the game wants you to loose (there is even a warning message every time you start the game). And not just in the aspect of RNG. Of course, everything in actual combat is stacked against you. Powerful enemies with powerful moves call for planning at every encounter, and even then, RNG will still bite you. But beyond this, the game is designed to hurt you in the long run. From negative quirks and diseases your heroes pick up, to over stressed heroes, to a lack of funds, to a lack of valid heroes, etc. This sorts of things are meant to build up over time and will lead you to lose unless legitamte effort is put into compensating for the things you will run into. But that's not the whole of Darkest Dungeon. The challenge Darkest Dungeon presents is that no matter how well you play this game, the previously stated difficulties WILL catch up to you. They will hurt you, kill you heroes, and possibly make you lose your playthrough. I think this is why Darkest Dungeon recieves the criticism it recieves. Most gamers nowadays expect a "right way" to play their games, to maximize the good and minimize the bad. Darkest Dungeon firmly throws that idea into the pits, and says, "You are going to suffer, then lose. You will continue to do so, until you win at immeasurable cost." If this is something you can accept, and are willing to take on, then you should give Darkest Dungeon a shot. Gameplay's fun too. Good ole' turn based action

number of helpful: 24 of 45 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												First up, the presentation is top notch. I love the writing, I love the narrator, the graphics are suitably grisly and good looking. The atmosphere really draws me in and feels perfectly oppressive.The game is very fun at first, and figuring out how everything works is a blast, picking up the new characters and working out their playstyles and strengths and weaknesses. Some of the mechanics are interesting, and it is genuinely unique in how it brings character weakness and trauma to the fore, I found that very interesting, and it made me think.HOWEVER, as much as I really like Darkest Dungeon, I'm not playing it, because it's such a time sink. Progression is very slow and often frustrating, and I feel like I've seen most of what the game has to offer. I don't feel like the game is rewarding at a decent enough rate to respect my time. Your patience may stretch further than mine.I'm looking forward to seeing what the DLC offers, and maybe what the short mode does to improve progression. I may well pick it up again.It's games like this that I feel like I need more than a thumbs up or a thumbs down. I have mixed feelings about it. I say, yes it's a wonderful game to start and explore, and drink in the fantastic writing and presentation. No, it's a bad game to play long term, and get your bang for buck.I feel that it's expensive at full price, for what you really get.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game a few weeks ago and have been having a blast playing it, at least up until the Inhuman Bondage update. Playing after that update it has turned into nothing by a pointless meatgrinder that spams you with stress and doesn't seem like you are doing anything other than playing a slot machine. The Devs have been very clear that they only want you to play the game the way that they want and have spammed the game with ridiculous mechanics changes in order to punish players; the most prominent is the 'Stall' mechanic that punishes you for trying to heal your party in combat, the only time that you can heal them. Setting aside that they are giving the finger to people that prefer a slower, more cautious playstyle, the mechanic itself is broken it will hit you if you don't manage to kill a single remaining opponent before the round ends and you can completely sidestep it by leaving 2 weak monsters alive instead of one. TL;DRThe Devs seem to be hellbent on taking a great game and ruining it as thoroughly as they possibly can. Don't buy unless they release the final version with all of their bad decisions undone.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												The game was very fun pre-release during early access when the developers weren't trying to screw the player at every turn adding things like corpses and heart attacks... Now the game is an exercise in frustration with the enemies having high dodge, protection, and what seems the roll of the dice on their side.   Enemies focus down your heroes who are low, or have high stress, they will always seem to go first each round, unless you stack speed trinkets which do not appear that often.  Your healer classes will never be able to keep up with the damage of the enemies, no matter how many rounds you sacrafice to healing unless you get lucky with the RNG and get crits.  You get stress on every character when an enemy scores a crit on your heroes, but when the reverse happens and your hero crits an enemy you lucky to recieve any stress relief on the hero who crits, much less every hero.All in all if you like being ♥♥♥♥ed by an RNG then get this game.  If you like strategy dungeon crawling do not get this game.  Oh yeah the art and sound is great too, probably it's only redeeming quality.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												It looks pretty and has an appropriate atmosphere, but if you're the type of gamer who revels in the feeling of meticulous calculations leading to triumphant victory, take a pass on this one.  This just isn't a game for some people, because the RNG is omnipresent and one unlucky dice roll often has catastrophic consequences.  To give you an example, in every single game I've attempted so far, I've lost one of the starting characters due to sequences that would go like this:-Enemy makes their 10% stun save-Enemy makes their 5% chance crit on party member, dealing over half his health in damage and sending him to death phase-Party member takes damage from another source and fails his death save (2/3 chance of success) on their first try.And of course, death is permanent.  So any of your treasured all-stars are subject to this system.  There is no save-scumming because the game continuously autosaves any time anything happens.  I can appreciate that for a game like this, but it does mean that your party is always at risk of being shattered in an instant because an enemy rolled a 20 on a 20 sided die.This has happened 4 playthroughs in a row now, and I'm sick of it.  This game does reward thought, sure, but other times it just kicks you in the ♥♥♥♥ing balls regardless of every little preparation you make.  If you can deal with that, have at it, but me, I can't stand to play a game where regardless of what I do, the fate of my party fundamentally comes down to a series of coin flips, one of which eventually will go wrong.

number of helpful: 25 of 47 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												If you are the type of gamer that is okay with leaving a game unfinished then there is 10-20 hours of great turn based dungeon crawling to be had. I had a lot of fun with this game getting my characters up through the initial stages and into medium and hard dungeons. Unfortunatly the game becomes a huge grind at this point.  Because death is permament and sudden a few bad encounters or even a couple of bad rolls within an encounter can kill a character that can take upwards of 3 hours to replace, and that is just the for the xp. Currently the best stratagy for seeing end game content in a reasonable period of time is to take a set of 4 newbies from the stagecoach (they are free and how you replenish lost heros) and tossing them into a dungeon with no supplies and getting rid of the survivors.The RNG in this game is really heavy, and don't let people explain it away as skill. Every attack in the game can miss, can be dodged, can hit, or can crit. Dodges and Misses do no dammage while normal attacks have fairly large ranges, a level 4 hellion hit for between 9-19 dammage on normal mobs who had health in the 20-30 range. So you could concievably crit and 1 shot a guy or miss twice and have 2 low dammage rolls and have him still alive on turn 5. Even outside of combat the RNG is pretty random. The one that gets me the most is the hunger checks, before you enter a dungeon you must supply your group with food, torches, and utility items like keys and shovels.  You eat food while crawling to replenish small amouts of HP and when camping in medium and long dungeons.  You also need food randomly when moving between rooms, doesn't matter when your previously ate, or if your party was full (you get full by eating 2-3 food). I have gotten 3 hunger checks before i cleared 5 rooms and have never had one in long dungeons.  Makes everything you provision for exept torches a gamble.But all that RNG is in the spirit of a dungeon crawler like this.  My real issue with the game is the late game grind.  In my experiance it takes 11 sucessful runs to get a hero to level 6, on top of that you will likely need to rest a hero at least once between runs to reduce stress, cure diseases, and purge negitive perks, you can only do 1 of these at a time and they all cost increasing ammonts of gold as you level up.  You also need to upgrade, linearly, a heros skills, armor, and weapons. I would love to see what ammount of money i put into my A-team members, a wild guess would put the number in the neighborhood of around 70,000 each.  And considering the most money i have ever pulled from a dungeon was around 25k means losing 1 or 2 of them like I did on a hard boss makes me quit the game because i am unwilling to grind out the multiple hours of repeditive gampleay needed to replace them.I still play the game in short sessions now but i seriously doubt i will ever have enough time or energy to finish it.  There is a core of a good game here that is padded out unnessaraly to the point that (as of now) only 0.4% of people have finished it (according to achievments) and only 0.2% of people have completed without changing any of the settings to make the game easier.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												How to completely ruin a perfectly good game in 5 easy steps:1: Start a Kickstarter, gain a significant following for a unique game with all sorts of lofty promises.2: Get your game into Early Access, Steams Sales for everyone and whatnot. Game delivers great experience while still being challenging.3: Let it go to your head. Start adding artificial difficulty because a small minority of players decided the game wasn't hard enough.4: Nerf the drop rates for essential items. RNG spawn rediculously difficult enemies on low level dungeons. Make the game even more grindy in order to artificially extend the game.5: Make any party that undertakes a mission in the final dungeon unable to enter the dungeon again, essentially rendering that party, and all the time and energy put into them, completely useless, extending the grind even further.3/10 Grind simulator 2015

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stress management 101Do you like to micro manage?  Then this is the game for you.  I can't even focus on enjoying the game because I'm constantly having to manage all the stress, diseases, and negative quarks the game throws at you.  95% of the books and chests result in negative stats.  The attacks miss a lot even though they should be hitting 80% of the time.  After every venture down into the depths, you have to send your warriors out for stress relief or you risk losing them to a heart attack.  Does this sound like fun?  Well it wouldn't be so bad if the damn stress meter didn't fill up like Bill Gates bank account.  I had a warrior gain 100+ stress in one random battle and die of a heart attack 5 minutes into a level.  If you manage to make it out alive, you have to send all of your warriors with high stress (so basically all of them) on to stress relief hubs, where you have to pay extremely hefty fees and lose them for the next round.  Then you run out of money and cannot buy food and torchs, so you're forced to go into the level with base stat recruits with no money, food, or torches.  Sould like fun yet?  And that is with the level being fully lit up.  Did I mention the torch mechanic?You have to constantly use torches to light up the room or you risk packing on the stress.  How long does a torch last?  ooooh about 3 seconds.  A torch costs 75 gold too and drains your bank account.  This stress mechanic is not innovative, fun, or interesting.  I want to play a rogue-like gothic RPG, not a %%%%ing stress management simulator.

number of helpful: 26 of 49 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												The Darkest Dungeon prides itself on its difficult and yet it doesn't realize that "difficuity" is the singluar reason why it fails as a game. Dark Souls might be hard but it is rewarding and doesn't erase hours of work by chance. This game doesn't realize that players don't want to be punished for trying out new rotations and left to rot because their team wasn't strong enough to stand against the over reliance of the game's RNG. While the beginning might be wonderful, but when the honeymoon is over the player will quickly realize that everything turns to a monochromatic grind for the sake of a one single team whose luck outlives the games whimsical system.Do I recommand the Darkest Dungeon? Only to the people who likes grinding for chance of a lucky run and have the stomach of losing, repeativily, hours of work.Edit 1: Just to clairfy this game has this weird thing where it likes to jump difficuity levels to keep you on your toes. That means when you've finally get a team to level 3 you have to directly jump into a level 3 dungeon. Level 2 dungeons don't exist therefore you can't even choose to play slowly and careful. The game makes you put your party in danger. So, if the run doesn't go well not only does your hours of hardwork to train the level 3 team go to waste in the best case scenario your game progress is impeded by a large margin. Therefore, prepare to grind mutiple teams to level 3 before you attempt a level 3 dungeon otherwise with one bad run, then your back to grinding level 1 dungeons.

Characters' "quips" and unnerved rants quickly shift from fun to being a pure annoyance - the single good change the devs made to the game since it was first shown was to allow one to turn them off. That of course is a selling point of this game and generally would not have discouraged me from continuing to play it. The problem is how repetitive and uninteresting the actual gameplay is once you've familiarised yourself with the basics.

number of helpful: 27 of 51 people (53%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Please dont take to heart a lot of the negative reviews, a lot of them are pre-update on what they are writing about. The corpse update has been fixed with an option to turn them off, Damage and stress has been worked on. The game is in early access right now, the developers have even said, "We are just trying new things to see what works and what sticks" (I am paraphrasing, but you can find the actual quote). Its a real fun solid game. As of now worth its price. A lot of people also say the game sucks because they are bad at the game. It is hard as hell yes, but not impossible, thats part of the fun.     In this game (As of my reviews update Holiday Cheer Update - Build #12331 (PC and Mac) ),  You start with a tutorial on how fighting works, how the town works, then you are free to pick where you want to battle to find resources. With them you level up "shops" so they have better equipment, are cheaper, reduce more stress, level skills etc.      As you go on, you fight harder enemies and bosses, oh and people will die. If you are good, you can save a lot of people from death (I'm talking party members) But it will happen, I'm sorry in advance. Dungeons are generated at random as are what is in them, loot, enemies, traps. You have the option to ditch out at any time at a stress loss, but that sweet loot..... maybe one more room...... F*** a trap.... no we are ok, just one last room. No why the bandits with the whip, you fat- NO NOT THE HEALER! OH GOD WHY, maybe we can win still..... focus on the archer in the back hes the biggest prob- OH GOD THERE ALL DEAD! NOT MY TEAM! WHYYYY!     Greed is the biggest killer, or perhaps instigator fits better. Still, you need to do some serious, risk vs reward assessments. The game is fun as hell, in early access so it will only get better, and the Devs do listen, thats why when corpses came out and everyone was like "how about no", they put in an option to turn them off. Give it a chance, worse comes to worse, wait for a sale. But only if you like a challenge.

content:
Posted: January 8
												TLDR: Darkest Dungeon is an extremely shallow, bloated and repetitive grinding simulator. I bought this game because I enjoy (classic) CRPGs and dungeon crawlers as well as tactical combat and strategical gameplay. Suffice to say I am pretty disappointed with what the developers offered me with this game. The little existing content is extremely bloated to give the illusion that the game has more content than it actually does and this in turn makes it very repetitive.Once you figure out which classes are good (most are completely useless and exist simply for cosmetic reasons) then the game is essentially over, because you will do nothing else but grind in a repetitive fashion with the exact same party compositions until you reach the end game. There are also only very few really useful skills and they are good for practically every enemy, which makes the game very shallow.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								So, in short.Pros:+ Great viusals.+ Challenging start.+ Good "dealing withs stress" mechanics.+ Lots of classes with unique abilities.+ Tight and simple combat.+ Adventure mechanics are good.Cons:- Early access. It always is. End game not ready.- Stale progression system. Basically, raw stats grow, without new mechanics.- Game is easy once you nail it.- Item customisation system is, again, stale.Overall a good RPG/manager game and obviously one to look forward to. Combat is simple, but satisfying. Manager aspect is good, but not great, because customisation options are very limited. I hope dev will revamp item system entirely.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a game in Early Access, there's a lot here that you can sink your teeth into. It makes you wonder why fully priced AAA titles can't be as polished as this game is right now, but I digress.This is a game as much about party management as it is exploring dungeons. The more you use each member of your pary, the more stress they gain, gain enough and they're unusable until you remove it. This forces you to use a wide varity or party members, running the same random generated dungeon doing different quests to get rewards.This is not a game for those who want something light and fun. You'll lose party members (permadeath), you constantly have to balance each members positive ance negative attributes, watch their stress and weigh weather continuing with almost no health and dying is better than escaping early and putting one or more of your party into a fully stressed state, not to mention watching your supplies.This is not an easy game, but it is damn fun and well worth the investment if you're up to the challenge.  Seriously, even if you're against buying games in Early Access, this is one of those rare exceptions where what you're getting is already getting enough content to call this a complete game by many peoples standards.EDIT; In the interest of fairness, there is one aspect of the game pertaining to combat that I dislike greatly. That is how your party will get rearranged if suprised. It's an annoyance since you need to spend turns getting people back into position where they're most effective.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								It was a stormy night that I and Dismas came to this camp; a blood streaked letter clamped in my hand told me my dead uncle had left his estate to me. I remember it from my childhood; a beautiful land full of colour, surrounded by warm fields and swaying trees...Now I stood, letter in one hand and gore soaked sword in the other as I looked upon what had happened to this land. I found the caretaker buttoning up his trousers as he left a ♥♥♥♥♥ to greet me in the centre of village. Welcome, he rasped, to the Darkest Estate. With that greeting, he began to fill me in on my new duties as Lord of the Estate. I suppose that made me Lord Darkest. This grim sense of humour would become commonplace in my world soon enough.The forest had become a land of bandits and mutant swine, their Prince and King strutting and rutting and ruining the land, poisoning all they touched. What had once been a place of beautiful harvest had become nothing more than a land of danger; food supplies could no longer get through and what few rangers he had sent to scout didn't return.He discussed the old estate, filled with monstrous creatures and the undead, led by a Necromancer and his kin. The caretaker dared to imply a connection between these and my late Uncle, but a quick look put that line of reasoning to its end. These would have to be taken care of, as well.And to the ruins in the south, a coven of witches (hags, he muttered between swigs of whisky) had taken over and what few survivors returned spoke of great, sweaty and cackling loonies who ate those who dared to confront them. Their cannibalism had long since driven them insane. He began muttering about how they had come to my Uncle in a guise of beauty, but soon began to splutter and rant without reason or even words. I left him to his ramblings, and his mind.When the latest camp arrived, three nervous individuals had come. One, a woman with a similar faith to myself, a large mace, and a dour grimace. Another women, wrapped mostly in bandages and utterly unrecognisable without her phlaegm coated voice laughing at some joke no one told, echoing inside the bird mask of a Plague Doctor. Lastly, a Bounty Hunter, who simply handed me a picture of a large man in red. When I inquired further, he said he'd help me take his head with the non-expression of a sociopath. I stopped inquiring.We began on this estate, exploring the ruins. We packed food and torches, but little else. Our goal was revenge, although the bounty hunter said it left our pockets empty for recovering assets. The Sister frowned at him, and said donations to the church. The Plague Doctor kept laughing to herself, but I noticed she would pick up whatever diamonds we found.The torch began sputtering immediately, as it fought to hold back the darkness. I held it ahead of me, as much as weapon as the sword I held in my hand. I tried to sheave it, but the idea of not having it ready terrifed me more. The flickering firelight gave movement to every shadow, and every shadow an evil eye glaring at me. It was with a shove that the Bounty Hunter pushed me aside, an arrow flying past me and burying itself in the meat of the Sister's thigh. As we looked ahead, I saw skeletons charged at us down the corridor.No, this is true. Actual skeletons, like inside of you or I, but these moved with a foul purpose, carrying swords, armour and even one in robes with a staff. As he raised it, a dark light surrounded our Plague Doctor, and she began to laugh a little more maniacally. Stuffing her hand in her pocket and shouting about traps, she threw a glittering powder over the the skeletons, which exploded in pops of light. The Bounty Hunter charged ahead, using the dazedness of the skeletons to take the head of the first. Feeling heartened, I picked up my sword and purpose and smashed the largest one in the face with my hilt. It seemed they still felt pain. As he reeled, I pulled a scroll from my belt and banished whatever foul magicks animated him back to hell.The Sister prayed to her god, and a green grow began to close our wounds. However, the damage to our minds remained fresh, and for the Plague Doctor, lethal. We just didn't know it yet.At least, after a night in this place, we found the Necromancer. Foul smelling thing, with a rusty red robe and its face hidden in shadow except for a malign glint, he brought up the bodies of fellow fighters to face us. The Bounty Hunter shouted that the Necromancer was his; poor fool. As I and the Sister contended with the skeletons, the Necromancer surrounded the Bounty Hunter with darkness. As his mind broke, the Necromancer then began to break his body.The Plague Doctor used this time to surround the Necromancer with a special poison gas, and the Sister tried to heal the rest of us, as we watched the Bounty Hunter die. It took an agonisingly long time, and when he was done, all that was left of him that I could recognise was his dying screams in my ears. The Plague Doctor continued laughing. The Sister started praying. All I remember is screaming. Mine or someone else, I don't know.The torch went out. We fought in the dark.A few days, we three came out. The caretaker threw me into the temple, a run down thing, to begin prayer. The Plague Doctor apparently shut herself up in the brothel for days at a time, only leaving for more beer or meat. The Sister whipped herself bloody; I could hear her moans of pleasure echoing through the walls.After several days, they let me out to greet the new arrivals. More had come, apparently word has spread of adventure. I smiled. Welcome to the Darkest Estate. I promise you, there is gold enough for everyone who is brave enough to fight.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								New review:I am addicted to this game. Buy immediately.Old review:Wanted this game for a long time and couldn't bring myself to pay the $20 for it due to it's reviews as "Dark Souls"-esque in its difficulty.  I hate the Souls series of games, ever since Demon's Souls back in the day.  They started as a bad 3d action game with horrible controls and terrible balance, and then grew into a bad 3d action game with horrible controls and terrible balance _"on purpose"_ because "anyone who doesn't enjoy dying 1000 times to complete the first level is a casual and blah blah blah."I want to like this game, and probably would if it were made more clear what the order of operations is of a typical round from start to finish. As it is, you get a loose tutorial that gives you the gist of a few aspects of the screen as they come up.  In a world where we have stupid tutorial screens for simple things, and then this type of instruction on what seems to be a pretty complex game, it would be nice to strike a balance between hand-holding and whatever you would call this.  The best way I can describe this game is that it is a low-class citizen simulator.  You send your characters off dungeoneering, and the system is stacked against you.  Sometimes because many disparate interacting systems will cause inherent imbalances, and other times because the people in charge of those systems hate you and want you to die.  Every day you have to get up and go to work, but this work you have to pay for.  And if you don't work then you'll lose the job, visitation rights to your kids, and the box you live in. You make $5 a day, but the cost of living is $3.50. Every time an enemy hits you he does $2 in damage, and your job is "guy who stands in front of enemies." Try not to go into debt with that formula.The interface could use some polish. Why do I have to click and drag heroes all the time? And even still, why do I have to drag them EXACTLY to the box, and not just the region that I'm very clearly working with? This is like having to click on the checkbox instead of the long♥♥♥♥♥sentence attached to the checkbox. Sort that out.The game idea is cool, but it needs some balance tuning at lower levels so you're not piling corpses against a wall because somebody forgot to install a gate.FTL is not fair, and can be daunting to new players, but that is lauded as a classic game. Darkest Dungeon is talked about mostly for its art style.If this game didn't look like Mike Mignola came on the computer screen far less people would give it a shot.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								A wonderful game with a beautiful art style.  Darkest Dungeon is one of those games that's simple to grasp the basics of but difficult to master - add in the randomly generated dungeons and you have a recipe for instant chaos for the unwary.  I hesitated when buying it at full price, but for a pre-released game it is suprisingly slick with very few bugs - running better than some fully released games!The dark, lovecraftian story breeds an atmosphere that will get your own heart pounding as your heroes adventure deep into the dungeon.  My advice?  Read everything, upgrade as much as you can and don't forget your torches.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a really good game!I was actually very surprised. I really like what the developers have done here and where the game has the potential to go with regards to its continued development, expansions and sequels. It's a hard dungeon-crawler, but it is not impossible to complete once you have an understanding of all the mechanics. I like the looting system. I like the tension the game builds as you become more and more attached to your characters. I like how your characters have distinct personality traits that actually impact gameplay. Basically, this game goes places that are beyond the limited brains of most committee-run, AAA game development companies.    So, Darkest Dungeon is a rogue-like (not rouge-like) dungeon crawler with great art design and excellent immersion. It is definitely worth the money. In actual fact, it is the best purchase I have made in a while. Bravo! Seriously, this game is worth it for $20! It would be worth it for $40!

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game starts out incredibly difficult. Your heroes die in droves. Then from the ruined mounds of failed heroes true champions arise. Suddenly they're cleaving through enemies like chainsaws through hippies. Enemies fall, bosses die, you're steamrolling. The loot is piling up, you suddenly have nice items to equip to your awesome champions. Then suddenly you get into the veteran modes. You go in the dark. You fight guys with giant trees. They crit. Your champion goes down. You barely eke out a win in that fight. Then suddenly it's alright again. You miss that champion but he is soon replaced. Except this time your new champion somehow gets syphilus from a dead body.That's why this game is amazing.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								On my first play through of this game, I thought it was brilliant. I got to week 19 before I ran out of cash after a couple of bad runs. I thoroughly enjoyed the games setting, mood, and mechanics. I eagerly started a 2nd run, and that's where things just went bad. I found myself failing on the first quest I set out on, before I had to restart a new game, and this happened at least 8 times before I packed it in. The game is HUGELY unbalanced at the moment, and is very reliant on luck. The first quest you go on should ease you into the game. Now, while I understand this is an unforgiving roguelike, you need to at least be able to get your foot in the door before your good or bad decisions in the hamlet start affecting your survivability. On the first quest, you have no options, no chance to improve your party, you just get 4 guys and off you go. Literally every first quest I've restarted since my first playthrough has been littered with misses, enemies dodging, whilst they constantly crit crit crit. At the end of the first quest, if I even made it that far, they were all maxed on stress and bleeding out. Back at the hamlet, you spend all your gold treating them, only able to take 2/3 people with you next run due to stress, and then die. Also, why would it recommend on the provisions screen to take just food and torches, when on the first screen...the FIRST screen, I'm faced with 2 piles of rubble. No shovels! Great! That's 50% stress on all characters just after getting in to the dungeon!Eventually I gave up. Today I tried another 2 playthroughs, but each time on the first mission, as badly as it went, I now started getting a crash error when walking near a lootable object which prevented me from proceeding. So never mind the RNG royally screwing you over constantly, now there's game ending bugs in it. The game needs rebalancing hugely. I must have been very lucky my first playthrough, but since then, just extremely unlucky. There doesn't seem to be a middle ground. When these game breaking bugs are fixed and the game actually gets balanced, it would be a very very enjoyable game indeed, but until then, based on how random the game is, it doesn't even allow you to play it, and cannot be recommended.Immensely disappointed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								 WHY THIS GAME IS UNIQUE:I recently picked up Darkest Dungeon because it appealed to my inner masochist and fascination with the whole medieval/gothic atmosphere thing. As an avid veteran of Demon's Souls/Dark Souls series, I came into this game literally prepared to die, but mostly aware of the challenges I would probably face. I also knew that being in early access development, some mechanics may be a little off or missing altogether. That is why I was so surprised only a couple hours in by how engrossing and complete this dark world felt. Immediately, the narrator steals the scene, reminding me of something akin to running commentary in Bastion. This constant audio companion (voiced by Wayne June) comments on your adventure at nearly every turn, whether in town to tell you a random tidbit of lore, or in battle to convey the sense of the turning of the tide. It is exciting and easily the most unique aspect of this game. Honestly, this man was nearly enough to keep the whole game going on his own.Eventually, though, the glaring problems arise, and they had me scratching my head as to why. The biggest enemy in Darkest Dungeon is not the end boss, the unpredictable fights and traps along the way, or the growing list of mental problems besieging your heroes. The biggest issue is gameplay balance during what you do most - fights. It is curious because these mathematical equations that they have in place are possibly the easiest thing about the game to fix because they are not design hurdles, but rather poor ratios and percentages that might be fixed in a patch. As a veteran of XCOM, I was prepared for the occasional "how is it possible to miss a shot at 97% three times in row?" However, Darkest Dungeon punishes the player, so much so that it actively forced me out of my initial fascination and into realizing that this is poor design by choice. You stop believing or even caring about this difficult world to live in because it turns into a Game of Thrones on steroids - a punishment just for punishment sake. You may realize this when you are fully prepared for an "easy" dungeon, just to see your crew ambushed and critical hit 3-4 times before you can do anything about it. Before you can even make a choice, half of your party is dead. That 2-3 hours you put into keeping those characters prepared and well-equipped destroyed by some meager random encounter. This is what you must be willing to face in Darkest Dungeon. No measure of preparation can save you, no measure of finesse. The sad state of balancing extends to the characters, whose abilities range from average to completely useless. Upgrading, leveling or any sense of progression here doesn't do much other than raise your chance to hit, something that the monsters in these "dark" dungeons have no problem doing.To further exemplify my point that this is not just a small balance tweak, but a poor design choice, is the game's forcible handicap system. Even if you get stronger and finally, by chance, nurture your champ to the height of power they were meant to claim, and you go back to that dungeon that has kicked your♥♥♥♥♥time and time again - guess what? Your character is slightly too high a level and will refuse to accompany the rest of your team. "You cannot adapt and overcome," the game says, "you must die."CONCLUSION:It is an active decision that is being made Darkest Dungeon - one that is so deranged that it simply is set to do one thing and one thing only - hurt you. In the end, a challenge that cannot be overcome, if only by chance, is not a challenge worth having. Indeed Darkest Dungeon is too dark and its forlorn estate not a place that will keep the attention of this weary adventurer.PROS:    The narrator, Wayne June, perfectly delivers the audio narrative and pacing in battle    Atmosphere is tense and engrossing    Initially sucks you in    Turn-based system has potentialCONS:    Battle system is a game of roulette at its current state    Progression is slow and mostly involves meaningless upgrades    Navigation system in dungeons lack any meaningful plot events (missed opportunity)    Current system forces you to play handicapped    Enemies almost always hit you first, and they hit hard    Difficulty balance issuesYOU MIGHT LIKE THIS GAME IF YOU:    Enjoy rogue-like games    Interested in gothic, fantasy setting    Can look past punishing difficulty and roulette-style gameplay

Your character is slightly too high a level and will refuse to accompany the rest of your team. "You cannot adapt and overcome," the game says, "you must die."CONCLUSION:It is an active decision that is being made Darkest Dungeon - one that is so deranged that it simply is set to do one thing and one thing only - hurt you. In the end, a challenge that cannot be overcome, if only by chance, is not a challenge worth having. Indeed Darkest Dungeon is too dark and its forlorn estate not a place that will keep the attention of this weary adventurer.PROS:    The narrator, Wayne June, perfectly delivers the audio narrative and pacing in battle    Atmosphere is tense and engrossing    Initially sucks you in    Turn-based system has potentialCONS:    Battle system is a game of roulette at its current state    Progression is slow and mostly involves meaningless upgrades    Navigation system in dungeons lack any meaningful plot events (missed opportunity)    Current system forces you to play handicapped    Enemies almost always hit you first, and they hit hard    Difficulty balance issuesYOU MIGHT LIKE THIS GAME IF YOU:    Enjoy rogue-like games    Interested in gothic, fantasy setting    Can look past punishing difficulty and roulette-style gameplay

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Review Nov 2016:Fantastic game with critical design flaw that ruins it. When it was in early access I tried to warn everyone about this flaw, and it wasn't addressed, and now, well read many of the reviews, its the flaw that kills the game: it doesn't respect your time. I'm the biggest fan of roguelikes. But roguelikes do not work for very long (100+ hours) games, like this. THe forumla does not work. Roguelike gaming sessions should go from 30 minutes to 4 hours -- a roguelike where you can be 100 hours in and ruin your game is bad design. Amazing game but I'd only recommend playing it if you have 120 hours to spare of your life. I have never played a single player game with as much grinding as this one. In this game, you could seriousely put in 60. 70.80 hours into it, and than have two or three unlucky quests and be hooped -- you are set back real life time of 30 hours to regain your position. It is just unacceptable to me.This is the best game that I ever have NOT recommended. Honestly, would only get into this game if you don't work or go to school, like if you are a retiree or unemployed or something, and don't feel guilty grinding for 50 hours. More stuff.WHERE IT WENT WRONG: I'm 100% sure this is the flaw with the game design process. The flaw is that the designers never had to play their game as players do. It would be impossible to play test of course, without giving themselves unlimited gold. But in doing so, the designers completely lack the concept of how much time it would take to play this game. Progression is glacier slow. And if you are cheating in testing, then you don't feel the frusturation of sinking 50 hours into a bunch of characters and then have them killed (and unrecoverable). If you can just respawn from saves than you lose that sense of annoyance that the actual players have playing the actual game. Earlier review from June 2013: Really divided on this game. I'm anxiously waiting for the final release. As the game is now, I just can't recommend it, I think more than half the people playing the game will find it more frusturating than fun. The game is potentially fantastic, but as it is now, it is just too punishing. I love hard games but this is punishing in the sense that you may spend 10 or 15 hours of IRL time developing a character, and then you may lose him permantly if you get two bad dice rolls in a row or through no fault of your own. I just don't have 200 hours to put into this game, its becomes more of a grind than it is fun.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												The Darkest Dungeon is a classic dungeon crawler, with brutal difficulty, yet very carefully balanced mechanics. It is extraordinarily hard but never to a point of being unfair. However, you will have to go through a certain amount of grind in order to reach the endgame dungeons. Despite being slightly repetitive, I enjoy this kind of gameplay which reminds me of the days when games were not a widely spread form of entertainment such as it is today. The Darkest Dungeon gives a tribute to this bygone era, and on top of that provides fresh and crisp visuals that stand out in comparison with other roguelike indie games which prefer the "x"bit visual styles. The audio is superb quality, with an atmospheric soundtrack and a punctual narration. I would reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers, challenging games and gothic horror atmosphere. This is not for the faint of heart, or for people with no patience.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Darkest Dungeons is a unique game, it's so unlike anything I've ever played before that I'm not sure that there is one genre I could describe it as.  As I'm lacking a genre, I'm going to make one up.  Darkest Dungeon is a strategic Lovecraftian themed resource management game with elements of dungeon crawling.  It's quite a mouthful, I know, but it's the most accurate title I can create.  Popularly this game is referred to as a roguelike dungeoncrawler,  but I've played many roguelike dungeoncrawlers and would not describe Darkest Dungeon like that at all.You play as a relative of the now deceased owner of an estate.  It is your mission to cleanse the estate of the many horrors that lurk there and in the surrounding countryside.  This is accomplished through expeditions that reward you with resources that can be used to restore the hamlet to its former glory.  As you upgrade the hamlet and defeat bosses further details of the game's story slowly unravel.For each mission you choose a team of four heroes to send off.  Which heroes you choose, which skills they have, and what position you place them in are all important for combat.  In addition to the heroes you take, you must also decide what supplies you want to bring.  It reminds me of Oregon trail in way, except it's far more terrifying.  What's really interesting about Darkest Dungeon is the stress mechanic.  As you traverse through dungeons the stress level of a hero will slowly increase.  There are also enemy attacks that inflict stress.  Once stress reaches 100/200 a hero will either gain an affliction or become virtuous.  A hero that becomes afflicted has effectively lost their mind and will be a detriment to the party and a virtuous hero overcomes their stress and becomes a positive actor.  At 200 points of stress a hero will have a heart attack.  Stress can be reduced by camping, from certain skills, and through activities in the hamlet.Stress is something that I don't recall ever seeing addressed in a videogame before.  It makes a lot of sense really.  You frequently see games starring a hero that spends their days slaughtering hundreds if not thousands of people/monsters/robots/whatever.  At the end of the day it seems likely that they'd have quite the case of PTSD.  The stress mechanic also factors into the resource management aspect of the game.  Heroes in Darkest Dungeon are somewhat disposable, but it is still in your best interest to keep them alive.  This means that at any given time it is likely you will have a number of your characters assigned to a stress recovery activity and locked out use for expeditions.  The end result is that you will want a roster filled with possible teams rather than one dedicated group.Maintaining a roster with multiple teams is more involved than one might expect.  Dungeons have max level restrictions, and you can only enter a dungeon with a full party of four.  If you don't have enough characters within the level range for a mission you will not be able to attempt it at all.  In an effort to make sure everyone is at the right level at the right time, I found myself doing hundreds of expeditions.  The real issue here and main flaw with Darkest Dungeon is that once you've done two or three missions in each area, you've seen almost everything the game has to offer.  I found it to be extremely repetitive.  The tedium of doing the same missions over and over is compounded by some late game events (nothing specific to avoid spoilers) that ultimately increase the amount of repetition.Darkest Dungeon looks and sounds excellent.  The characters, enemies, and town all look very impressive.  I don't know what the name of the art style is but it  reminds me of a pop-up books.  I'm not sure where they found the announcer, but he really makes the game.  His booming disembodied voice shouts memorable quotes as you battle your way through dungeons.  I had some of his phrases stuck in my head weeks after I finished playing the game.Darkest Dungeon was difficult for me to review on Steam.  The restriction of recommend “yes/no” is too simplistic.  If there were a “maybe” option, it's what I would choose to give this game. In my mind the graphical style and sound are so strong and so memorable that the game gains major points in these categories.  The idea of stress affecting adventurers in a game is creative and something I haven't seen elsewhere.  It's implemented in a very clever way that is very logical if you've had any real life experience with stress.  I loved how heroes resort to vices in an attempt to relieve stress.  Unfortunately the gameplay falls a little flat.  I found it to be somewhat easy, simplistic, and tedious.  This is a game that I would cautiously recommend, and only if it is on sale.  For those looking for a dungeon crawler, be aware that this is more of a resource management type of game.Click here to see my other reviews.
