content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								An excellent, unforgiving, and frustratingly luck-reliant game that still manages to be absolutely worth playing, even though it's still in early access.  Just plain fantastic art design and aesthetics along with some really interesting gameplay concepts (the Stress system as a companion to the standard Hit Points really makes combat interesting and nuanced) make this a game at least worth watching, though it's also quite fun to play.It's best to go into DD with an XCOM mindset - low level characters are completely expendable and should be viewed as just another resource like your gold and your heirlooms, used and then discarded once they've served their purpose.There's still one more basic area to be unveiled - the Cove - and then the final area of the game, the Darkest Dungeon, so any existing balance issues (and there are plenty) will likely be solved by then.  There's also an enterprising person working on a "Deepest Dark" mod for the game that in many ways echoes some elements of the XCOM Enemy Within mod, Long War, by making the game more complex and much more difficult while also making it less reliant on luck and more reliant on good tactical decision-making, something the vanilla game is a bit light on.Even without Deepest Dark, I got almost 20 hours out of the game before it started to get a little old, and that's pretty damned good considering it's only about 2/3 complete and it's only $20.  If you like XCOM or Roguelikes, Darkest Dungeon is worth your time.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								     After years of playing online RPG’s, this game has done something none of the other games possible could do….gave me insight into the selfish mindset of the NPC quest giver.      At first, I sent my adventurers into each quest well provisioned and quick to send them to the inn or brothel to refresh after each return. I emotionally waivered over fixing a quirk that my impulsive clicking gave to a beloved character or splurging on a larger brothel.      Then after failure, and failure, and failure…. That empathic worry calcified into scorn over an individual’s weakness to succumb to stress. I stopped worrying about paranoia or massive outbreaks of syphilis as I unremorsefully sent adventurers to their deaths. Again and again. Even if the chances were remote, if  they succeeded, my town (and brothel) grew. If they failed, their names were etched with the others in the graveyard that was more populated than some small countries. But hey -- there was always another wagon of fresh volunteers.       No matter what villain lies at the end of this game, I relish in the fact that it is unlikely to have a higher bodycount than mine.  Oh yah – great game 10/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
Early Access Review
tl:dr - If you want a challenging game that involves preparation, risk versus reward management, tactics in a lovecraftian setting with great narration and music, GET THIS GAME. Darkest Dungeon is an adventurer managing game that mainly has two phases.  The first phase is your Managing phase where you upgrade equipment, buy trinkets, teach skills, and watch your adventurers relieve their stress by meditating in calm seclusion, praying to whatever deities exist in this land, drinking til they get drunk and lost for a week or two, or just go out wenching (hey, whatever works), etc...  While your adventurers are relieving their stress or getting rid of a bad trait, they are unavailable for the next phase, the Adventuring phase.  It is in this phase that your adventurers head into a procedurally generated dungeon with an objective (scout, find specific quest items, clear rooms, kill bosses, etc) to find loot, glory, fufillment, or just get their brains scrambled by stress and die while gibbering in fear.Your success during the dungeon phase primarily depends upon how prepared you are and what risks you are willing to take.  Certain heroes are better than others in certain types of dungeons and will give you an easier time.  Your party composition is extremely important along with your heroes' positioning and selected skills, as most skills can only be used in certain positions.  The last part of preparation, which also ties into risk management, are the items that you take with you into the dungeon.  Before you head in, you can buy usable items such as food, torches, bandages, potions, medicinal herbs, etc.  They cost money so it'll cut into your gains (and possibly create a loss) and might be a waste if you buy too much and don't use it.  However, buy too little and you'll run into RNG risks non-stop.  If you run out of food, your heroes will lose hp and gain stress when they're hungry.  If you don't keep your torchlight more than 3/4 full, your party positioning has a chance of being switched around when you enter combat (the less light you have, the higher the chance of your party being surprised by the enemy when you enter combat and that switches your heroes around).  However, you can also prepare for this by equipping skills that move your hero around so that you're not caught completely with your pants down.  Most of the interactable objects you encounter in the dungeon are NOT completely safe unless you use a certain item (such as bandages for a rack of blades, if you don't use a bandage when you interact with it, you MIGHT get some items OR you can get injured and start bleeding).Don't stay too attached to your ALL of your heroes (especially early on in the game), as death comes rather easily if you tend to take risks.  Sometimes, you just don't have the proper counter item in your inventory as you approach an interactable object; you'll have to make the choice of whether to risk it for loot or just walk past it (Of course, we risk it and end up getting diseases which gets our hero killed).  If your heroes build up too much stress, they can get an affliction which makes things rather difficult, as they might start doing things that are out of your control, such as automatically repositioning themselves, refusing to let other heroes heal them, increase other heroes' stress, etc...  At some point, if you're not confident you can complete the dungeon, it's sometimes better to retreat (your heroes will gain stress from failing however, and if you don't have enough money to help them relieve their stress, you'll have to recruit new heroes and try again).The game can be rather unforgiving, but the more you play, the easier it gets, even after failed ventures.  Venture into the dungeons and you'll find heirlooms that you can bring out with you, and this will allow you to upgrade your facilities so that you can recruit more heroes, have more openings for relieving stress, relieve stress for cheaper, upgrade to better equipment, etc...  Eventually, it'll get cheap enough that sustaining some heroes and removing their bad quirks becomes viable, so you can keep the heroes you like.  The downside is, when your heroes' levels get too high, they refuse to take on the easier dungeons, so you'll need to rotate some fresh blood into your hero pool to do the easier missions.Pros:The game's ambience is incredible.  The art style, the music, the characters, etc...  Everything just ties in so well to make you feel the sense that horror does stalk this land.The narration is one of the best that I've heard in a video game and seriously adds to the Lovecraftian feel of the game.Challenging decisions - In other RPGs, choosing a skill, leveling the skill, and upgrading equipment just bumps a number up so you can kill something 3 seconds faster.  Here, choosing the right thing to level with your limited resources means the difference between life and death.  All optional equippable trinkets have a positive and negative aspect to them which makes choosing even more important.  Inventory management is another challenging decision, as you need to decide on what to keep, what to hold on to, whether you should toss that counter item for a possible interaction, etc... Combat - You're almost always on your toes in combat, as even the easy monsters can ruin your day by adding serious amounts of stress to your heroes.  Even more so if you ran out of light and your positions get switched around, or if you were ambushed while you were making camp.Replay value - Many different ways to play.  You can play safe and carry around enough torches to maintain your party formation, or play risky by bringing only heroes that have skills that reposition themselves while attacking for more loot from the darkness.  Or you can constantly make short incomplete trips into dungeons while switching and discarding heroes left and right.  It's up to you how you want to play.Cons:Early Access - At this point, there's only 3 areas for dungeons.  Can't sell trinkets yet either so your trinkets chest just gets increasingly cluttered.  The Hero list also gets slightly cluttered if when you have lots of heroes and it doesn't stay sorted the way you want it too.  If you've upgraded all your town buildings (this might take a while though), your heirlooms are useless.  Occasional bugs here and there.Bosses - Difficult in a bad way.  Namely a "if you don't have the right team composition, you'll probably lose" bad way.  You'll probably either have to look them up or lose a party to them to figure out what party composition you should bring.Not being able to bring any of your higher level heroes on lower level runs is designed to make things more difficult, but kinda makes leveling unwanted since I can't play with heroes that I've grown attached to.Lack of inventory space makes it so that there is less incentive in running the longer dungeons.  You either spend so much money buying supplies to last through it, that you won't make as much of a profit (and you can't carry as much loot out), or you end up not finishing it, which means that doing the shorter dungeons would've been more profitable as you can get the quest rewards for finishing it (and you don't have to deal with failure stress).  The only incentive for finishing the longer dungeons then is possibly for the trinket.Time only progresses when you go adventuring. Even if you have excess gold and want to take a week off of adventuring because your main heroes are spending a week relieving their stress, YOU CAN'T.  At the very least, you'll have to send a team into the dungeon every week, even if you immediately abandon the quest as you enter.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Still in early access but definitely shines.  It is the type of game you play for a few hours at a time, not all day or you might end up breaking a keyboard.  I backed the game from Kickstarter and am eagerly awaiting updates.  The developers keep their backers up to date and allow us to give input.Sale or not...buy it.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Post Retail ReviewGreetings Everyone!  Thought I’d give some continued thoughts on this game now that I’ve beaten what is the retail release in all its glory!  If you just want the short hand, yes the game is still great; yes you should still buy it immediately.Let me start by saying the game is brutal, but honest (despite my emotional outbursts at it from time to time).  Randomness is a thing (RNG is a cruel mistress even more on this game) to the point of disastrous defeats and (less common) the miraculous victories.  The one thing you must understand is that your adventurers are disposable, all of them.  Equipment can be reacquired, afflictions cured and stress removed.  When all is said and done your hamlet is the real ‘you’ the important thing you need to focus on.Graphically the game is beautiful in its own way, yes it is not Triple A graphics or cutting edge but it is beautiful and well done.  Game play is simple but solid; actually would make a great tablet or even smart phone game.  Yes, it is a very simplified RPG, but like all great RPG’s the magic comes in the form of the interactions.  Balance is more or less spot on when it comes to the classes and yes, some classes feel useless (Antiquarian) and some feel essential (Man at Arms, Bounty Hunter, Vestal) but over all you can build your own unique groups and have a decent success rate.My one real critique is that the ending is a bit…well, meh.  I loved what they were going for (no spoilers) but the way they could have implemented it felt a bit lacking.  Again, I LOVED what the ending implied but felt it could have been better implemented.  The final dungeon felt a bit too easy too.Ultimately, if you like RPGs, Tactical Games, or even just Horror (specifically Lovecraftian) then you owe yourself at least a chance at this great game.  Would buy again, would back again (KickStarter) and in hindsight wish I was even more involved in the creation!  Buy it, support this company!

								SO FAR THE BEST HPL COC BASED GAME ON STEAM!!!Pro:1. The art style is unbeatable! 2. Dumbed down SAN system (stress system) that still keep most of it's taste, a really good starting point for all new comers to pick up the feeling of a COC game... Going insane might not be a bad thing in dire time...3. Risk And Gain! The torch system allow player to balance their way of play, you can ether play safe by keep your torch fully light most of the time, or take the risk by dim it down for harder fight but better loot.4. This game is HARD, not hard to control or learn, but just that when you venture into the dungeon, that simply becomes 4 adventurers against then entire world of evil and shadow. Everything want you die, even the lootable chest and bags might kill off half of your team and force the rest of them to run with their tail between their legs... And level up might not always be a good thing, other then getting perks, there are chance that you will get sickness or weakness as a reward for leveling up... 5. In the land of lurking shadow, there are no such thing as safety... Anything out there or a slightly not so welly thought decision might become the downfall of your adventurer... Welcome to the domine of The Old Gods!!!6. If that old man speaks the truth... We shall have a really cute silvery hair girl waiting for us at the deepest part of the dungeon... Nyaruko ist mine~~!!! \@o@/ SP-99Con:1. Err... This game is hard... You bound to lose team after team of adventurer, or have them withdrew barely alive and on the brink of insanity, This might be favorable for some player, but might also kill off some other player.2. Dev is still testing out different coding for the game, so every patch some part of the code might be changed, this results to fix bugs for some but also breaking game for some, so if your game is not working after a patch... it is normal, just keep an eye on the forum, as people will be working on a way to by pass the issue and make the game playable again... Usually through endless screaming, cursing, murking, trolling, noob calling, insult tossing, crying, jumping up and down on their bed... Err... That was another forum, the Darkest Dungeon ones are slightly better then that...Well... I don't think i have another else to say about this game anymore... Now I need to find some way to restore my SAN, it is -37 now...Will go insane for this game again! 10/10 -HPL

Posted: February 11
												This game is the best and worst of the turn based genre. Unfortunately, the WORST part is WORSE than the GOOD parts. A lot of the bosses feel downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. They don't match their difficulty listings at all. "Level 1 - Medium" Party of level 2s with max gear and rare relics gets obliterated in under 3 turns at full hp. My party randomly didn't get to have their turns, even when they weren't stunned. The boss would take his turn with all 4 of his actions, then do them all over again. Bug or not, it has RUINED my opinion and experience with this game.Like the mannor you're supposed to restore, I hope this garbage rots in hell just the same.EDIT: I forgot to add this little tidbit:If your hard work actually keeps your group alive and gets them to certain level markers, they flat out refuse to do anything that wouldn't instantly kill them. Hit level 3? They refuse to do level 1 missions. It's not even a quirk. They're all just arrogant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. For a game so focused on quirks and unique personalities, this is a pathetic attempt to keep the game "Challenging". This just takes away from the game's immersion when a character with a cowardly trait says the enemies aren't worth his time. WHAT!?

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ah, this game, this game... Where to begin? I like a good turn-based dungeon crawler and I like Lovecraft, so solely based on atmosphere, art style and voice over, this game is worth 10 € and a few hours of my time.The difficulty never really bothered me, although it did cause me to sit up straight, swap beer for tea and just really try.If you apply a well planned strategy, take the time to understand the game, and prepare well for every mission, it can be done. There is just a steep, steep learning curve and every new patch will throw you off-balance a bit because they add new bits and bobs that you have to incorporate into your strategy.The Constant-Save forces you to think before acting, but the game is forgiving in that sense, that even when you've really arsed up, you still have the other heroes on the roster to try and fight. It's not a game ender, like in some games (I'm looking at you, Don't Starve!). Just remember, never think you can just click 'n kill in this one, because that's when you loose three heroes that were perfectly fine going in. Love it!

content:

Early Access Review
								Ok first and foremost, im not particualarly a fan of Roguelikes. I love to be able to start from where i left off. I get emotionally attached to my characters and i like being the savior of the universe, with no help from some stinkin friends!! That said, i love this game. Bought it yesterday and played it,non stop, for about 10 hours afterwards. The only bug i have had so far is i got shorted on one trip into the dungeons and somehow only 3 characters showed up on a trip to kill one of the bosses or mini bosses. I thought after reading all the comments on the game that id be meat. Turns out  i  must have had a killer 3 party members(one lvl 1 2 lvl 2, unsure of the exact party makeup but def had a vestal for healing 2 of the 3 were def maxed on armor and 2nd lvl spells) I believe the boss was the necromancer. But with stuns, which i expected to fail half of the time, it was a pretty easy beatdown. (one hit would stun first 2 combatants) Im sure it was also combined with the luck i had in finding the boss in one of the fist 5 rooms. and so far, i am loving the gameplay, style, music, voiceovers and yes even the banter amuses me wholeheartedly. Sure its rough at the start, but shouldnt all games be? Yes you have to run from battles and possibly give up on quests before your done with them and either retrain or party up your toons to get rid of stress/personality disorders you can accrue, and you WILL accrue A LOT of them if your not careful. Someone likened it to an adventuerer simulator? Not a bad analogy. You can expand your roster(so far i have a pool of 13, 3 to choose from at any given time, but also can be expanded), build your city up to be able to get rid of personality traits that can cripple you in battles, releive stress after a dungeon crawl and build your abilities.  I reccomend getting all the different classes and having fun with each, as they all have differing enough abilities that they all have SOME use, albeit, not all are as fun to use. (and im sure everyone has a favorite/least favorite class, which is what every game SHOULD have!) At this point ive only "lost" 1 starting character and 1 character from stupidity of not running. Any other than the ones ive re-named for myself have been "let go" by me because of the playstyle or just not wanting to relieve their stress. ;) Ive found if you have a deep roster of characters you like and some throwaways, you can run dungeons to stock up on cash and prizes while using said cash and prizes to upgrade your "mains".  Do be aware once your mains hit a certain level they will not go back into beginner dungeons. (veteran 3 was when i found out that they refuse to go back into lvl 2 and 1 type dungeons) So if youll probably end up not using your mains when you hit up some of the bosses for the first few levels. I also realize im just scratching the surface of the game even after 10 hours of romping around dungeons, sometimes barely making it out alive, and sometimes..well not everyone makes it out. Do you have to pay attention? HELL YES.  Can it be frustrating? also HELL YES. Is it SUPER HARD? I wouldnt say so. Its a CHALLENGE, something that is sorely missed in alot of the AAA titles nowadays and i thank god we have a few indie devs that get that and make the games THEY want to make while hoping we as a community like it to. And for whatever reason this game just has "it" for me.

Early Access Review
								Usually I try to avoid early access. Mostly it is just rubbish that just gets tossed out in an attempt to make lots of money. But this is one of my favourite games already. I've got to say if it hadn't said early access, I wouldn't have noticed. The game feels well thought out, solidly coded and bug free so far.I truely enjoy the gameplay and the difficulty. If you like turn based strategy combat, this game will be a great addition to your library. Having to juggle so many unavoidable things, such as resources, sanity and health. It is almost impossible to keep everyone in your party in the best conditions.Controlling a ragtag group of adventurers through a dark and dangerous ruin is far from easy, but it is fun. Be warned, this game is not for the faint-hearted. The environment is against you, enemies are against you, and sometimes even your party is against you.Heartily recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Darkest Dungeon is one of the best games I've played in recent memory. It's hard to believe the early access tag.This game aims to keep the player in a perpetual state of discomfort. If you're looking to play an indestructible badass then stay away. Your party of heroes will be fighting in the dark, often bleeding and slowly losing their minds. As the game puts it "It's about making the best of a bad situation".The classes feel unique and combat flows well. There's just enough numbers to give the system depth while trying to keep things simple. Debuffs are easy to understand and the importance of positioning quickly becomes apparent.The game's not perfect by any means. The characters talk often and it wouldn't be so bad if the game didn't stop you from doing anything every time a dialog bubble pops up. My only other gripe is being subject to the randomness of available missions. Since specific mission rewards are needed for upgrades, not having any control is frustrating.Then again, the game is about making the best of bad situations.TL:DR Buy this game. It's maddeningly good.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Roguelike dungeon crawler with a lovecraftian flair.=early access review=  (build 7635)Did you play Darksouls?  Did you enjoy the difficulty but think to yourself "Gee, the only thing that would make this game better is if I had to start over every so often from the beginning?"  Because if so, then you might enjoy Darkest Dungeon.  This game is no joke difficult.  Don't walk into it and get attached to your characters, they will die.  When they do die, they're gone, for good.  Not only that, the ones that do might be the lucky ones.  A plethora of madness and pain await the never ending stream of new recruits that arrive every week by carriage into your cursed town.  The plot is pretty great and you can build up your town, allowing your fresh meat to possibly walk to their deaths slightly better equipped than the last group you sent to their deaths.  Further more, even though I swore off early access games after the Spacebase DF-9 fiasco, I'm glad I didn't pass on this one.  I find myself venturing into the maddening dark over and over, and gleefully awaiting each new update.  With promises of new classes and 2 more dungeons, I forsee this being on my 'play' list for a while.For the price, if you like roguelikes, oldschool D&D vibe, with a splash of Lovecraftian horror, you will not regret buying Darkest Dungeons.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game... Wow.. This is a rogue like I can get into. Name each recruit after a steam friend and watch them all develop, it's good fun (sorry a few of you have died..). But seriously, great game. It's hard but fair, crits seem to control combat a BIT too much. I also feel stress needs to have additional way when inside a dungeon to be controlled. Some runs it skyrockets so quickly and early without any method to contain it.It's a roguelike that will make you pull your hair out, but once you understand the mechanics you'll have no one to blame for killing your heros but yourself... Unless the enemies by fluke kill your hero by focus firing and critting multiple times in a row (RIP nyri).Pros:-Artstyle is fantastic-Insanely Difficult, but fairly so.-Each class is unique, and discovering the synergies is fun.-Dying is rage inducing, but not the end of your game nessisarily.-20$ game in alpha that has given me more fun than 60$ AAA titles, in ALPHA its more complete than most games!Cons:-Crits control the game flow too heavily-Stress needs more ways to be managed-Upon maxxing stress, the odds of a negative reaction seem WAY to high compared to a positive.-Dungeon difficulties is not properly lined up with your character's hero levels, meaning sometimes you have level 3 heros but only lvl 1 or 5 dungeons to do... meaning you're stuck in a bad spot.-Some heros are too weak (Jester and Grave robber)What I'd like to see for this game to be great:-More heros introduced-More dungeon/monster types-Different skins for heros to make them unique-More narrirator voice options

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Probally one of the funnest burst enjoyment I have had in a game for awhile now. I have not played the game heavily as of yet but definitely plan too in the future. This game allows you to actually show sympathy towards your heros, actually caring when your favourite character is on deaths door. Or when they cheer up the whole team with their amazing bard skills. Regardless this game made a brilliant first impression with its amazing looking hand-drawn art style and the narrations is top notch! The game always keeps you on your feet and requires you to carefully think about your actions instead of mindlessly trying to take on bosses without carefully considering there move set and positioning. From personal experience I can say this game is both unforgiving and so rewarding at the same time. There have few occasions when my characters have died, but theese were to silly mistakes or being too confident and forgetting to bring a bandage.Overall, this game is outstanding for early acces and cant wait to play when fully released. The combat feels great and works well with the dark atmosphere of the game. But most of the time I have to admit you rely on the RNGesus for quite alot of deaths making some really unique and funny moments. :)

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I don't typically write EA reviews, but DD is an exception. I don't like rogue-like games. I don't like games that are frustrating. I've gottent too old for games like that. I play games for fun. I play games to replax. So I shouldn't like DD. Yet I find this to be simply one of the better games I've played this year. It is exceptionally fun while being frustrating. There's a wonderful mix of tension, frustration and triumph. The theming of the game is exceptional - the voice-overs, the look, the feel all build this wonderful universe of gloom. There's tension around every corner and you feel every decision is meaningful. There's plenty of options to cater to your playstyle. I truly feel that every decision I make in Darkest Dungeon is a crucial one. Very few games feel that way. Thus I find DD to be also a fairly intense game to play. Furthermore, they've done a great job during EA of balancing classes, adding content and ironing out some annoyances. It's nice to see someone use EA the way it was meant - getting community feedback and using it to make the product much better with a clear plan to get to a truly complete release candidate. Props to them for that too.This is a game that will get you screaming at your monitor. You may even break your keyboard. But it's tense, brilliant, fun and I recommend it for every gamer.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game! I have a lot more hours in cause it won't open inside of Steam. Check "troubleshooting" in forum if you're having problems. The difficulty is there ... but not unfair or punishing. Here are some tips:“Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer” – Don’t jump levels.-	Bring enough torches to keep light levels above %75 – Surprise enemies – Use light-based trinkets-	Keep mental track of which enemies have already attacked-	Scouting is good – Torch up before room battles.-	Always pack shovels and enough food to avoid going hungry-	Type “Darkest Dungeon Curio” into google-	Name characters after quirks to be removed and locations they are weak and strong in-	Always correct your character order after battles-	Experiment with push/pull tactics .. some enemies have nothing in certain positions.-	Always bring a Vestal – Healing saves lives-	Develop character’s guild skills so they have positional flexibility – Enemies will scramble you.-	(not all but) The majority of trinkets are garbage  – Drop them and keep better loot-	Accuracy is winning – Enemy dodge increases in later levels-	Criticals are winning - Flip the script on tough battles and reverse stress-	Dodge is winning - Reduce damage and stress taken-	Avoid trinkets that lower accuracy, criticals, and dodge (unless counterbalanced by other trinkets)-	Unequip core trinkets after battles – Give them to the next team going out.-	Always scroll over enemies to see their “stun-bleed-blight” susceptibility before attacking-	Stun is clutch – Stun enemies with the highest speed so their first hit is compromised-	Prioritize enemies that use stress attacks-	Kill weak enemies first so they can’t continue attacking-	Be selective about which quirks to remove -	Throw young recruits in the fire … if they live … Nice! … If they died … mehhh.-	Dismiss characters that are stressed out and saddled with negative quirks.-	A lot of Blight in the Weald – Plague Doctors Battle Medicine helps-	Bleed skills aren’t great in the Ruins – Too many skeletons

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a strange game (but in a good way if you read further and peruse my reasoning).It's a gritty dark fantasy adventure set in an undetermined time. You act as an overseer who recruits motely crews of adventurers to unearth relics (and whatever isn't nailed down) from the ruins of your ancestors' lands. Unfortunately one of your ancestors dealt too far into the occult, unleashing some horror which wears down on the resolve and sanity of your heroes (that's where the Lovecraftian stuff comes into play).Seems fair enough, and enough of a reason to get into it and play it. What makes this game strange is the idea that failure isn't only a possibility, but inevitable. The grim, gritty atmosphere isn't only in the graphics (which are beautiful, inspiring, and decadent at the same time), but in the gameplay and feelings evoked by this game. Expeditions into the ruins of your ancestors will fail, and death/madness is a likely prospect given that your adventurers have both HP and stress to manage throughout the game.Gameplay wise, it plays as a party rogue-like with turn-based combat. There is copious strategy to be discovered and applied as you unearth the ruins and build a competent enough team to assault the 'Darkest Dungeon'. To prepare your hired cohorts, you can find relics and family heirlooms in the various parts of the manor's surrounding lands to help upgrade the hub village you use to rest and arm your hirelings. With these heirlooms, you upgrade the various businesses and buildings: upgrading the blacksmith allows you to better arm your (surviving) heroes. Upgrading the Inn enables your unhinged heroes to restore their sanity by taking their mind off the oppresive atmosphere via gambling, drinking, and of course whoring. Your more pious heroes benefit from the chapel, which allows them the option of prayer or sacrifice to hopefully assist in recovering their resolve. A sanitarium acts as both a mental ward and hospital to cure your hirelings of any debilitating diseases or psychosis. Even outside of battle and dungeon-delving, there's enough strategy in managing your town that any contemplative RPG-Strategy players will be satisfied.Unfortunately, the biggest gripe that I have is the early-stage grind required to build a competent team. Experience is only gained through successful runs through the dungeon, and not at an encounter basis, meaning a failed mission merely leaves you with a bunch of insane heroes and little treasure. That would be fine, but items can only be upgraded if the hireling's level matches the item's strength. And unfortunately, most dungeons increase in diffculty and strength as you complete them (regardless of the heroes you might have in reserve), meaning that one bad run due to a very cruel and unforgiving random number generator can easily wipe out your best and well-armed heroes, leaving you with level 0 hirelings to face the same threats your A-team took on. This ends up adding hours, effectively bashing your head into the wall, and sending heroes through the meat-grinder until the dice ends up rolling in your favor. That idea alone can be very discouraging.Still, if you are a fan of atmosphere and of the belief that it's persistence that wins you the day, then Darkest Dungeon is a worthwhile purchase and a memorable game experience! 4 out of 5.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												The game has a fantastic feel and atmosphere to it. You'll certainly feel like you're part of the darkest dungeon environment. The gameplay is interesting and challening. You never really feel like you've become all powerful. There's always a chance that things could go badly for your squad, even against foes that you've easily beaten previously. On the whole though, the game play is a bit of a slog. Your guys level up, but as they do, they're limited to playing the higher level dungeons, so their relative power remains somewhat constant. This is challenging, but doesn't make your team feel like they're progressing much. Don't fall in love with any of your characters, as there's always a chance they won't make it out of the dungeon alive. On the whole I liked the game. I'm yet to finish it, despite being almost 60 hours in. In fact, I don't even feel close to finishing it. The game has become something of a grind, and I can't see myself finishing. A fun game for a time, but not something I'm rushing back to.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
EDIT PLEASE READ FIRST!!!: I have been playing this game since the FIRST DAY of early access. Many things have changed since then but DD is still a great game. A lot of the reviews you will read on here that give this title a thumbs DOWN are mostly due to the difficulty which revolves around the RNG (Random Number Generator) of the game. While this is true that many things in the game revolve around computer generated "dice rolls" that does not mean in ANY WAY that this game is bad and as such I will NOT be docking points because people walked in here thinking that this game will hold your hand and give you a pat on the back (Pete's sake in the intro Red Hook even says that DD is about making the MOST of a BAD situation). I personally feel that there is nothing wrong with an RNG and that is actually one of the reasons I love D&D which is almost ENTIRELY based off dice rolls. *sigh*...It's all thanks to these MOBA-douches that are all about "My skills as a player should not be dependent on bad rolls HUH HUH" *stomps away disdainfully* Anyway..IF YOU FIND IT TOO HARD AND UNFAIR: Well my first inclination is to say go cry to your mommy you console peasant BUT...there are game play configuration options found in the game menu that you can turn off and on, things like enemies doing only max damage for crits instead of multipliers, turning off battle length penalties and so on. Now that all the crap is out of the way let's begin...DARKEST DUNGEON REVIEW"Ha ha ha! Let those dirty beasts worship the mud now!"Thus are the words of the Ancestor. Your Ancestor.In Darkest Dungeon you play as the Descendant who's Ancestor left a rich and prestigious estate...which has now been completely overrun by tenticle demons that came through a portal conveniently opened by your (now DEAD) Ancestor that sent a letter to you so you could clean up his mess.... GEE! WHAT A GUY!So you go to the manor and the estate, which is in complete shambles, and start rebuilding. As you go as a party of 4 into different dungeons and complete missions you will begin to rebuild that forsaken ground that was entrusted to you. You will recruit new hirelings and I say hirelings because even though Red Hook has said this game is a bit like XCOM it is NOTHING like XCOM. Your hirelings will die. They will die OVER AND OVER again.So let's get down to the *Nacho Libre voice* nhiitty grriiiteyPros:+AWESOME ARTWORK. Beautifully drawn characters which are VERY reminiscent to Mike Mignola's work on Hellboy. I don't think that was a coincendence either.+BRUTAL GAMEPLAY. Like I've been trying to tell you guys a million times: this game was made for masochists. It will punish you SEVERLY for even trying to step foot out of the Estate. But at the same time getting those crits or barely completing that mission with only one survivor makes it so worth.+GREAT SOUNDTRACK. It really is, lot's of drums and deep horns. Each dungeon has a unique theme song. The Warrens' is warlike and orcish sounding while the Weald's is more on the horrific side.+NARRATOR IS 10/10. I mean "EXECUTED WITH IMPUNITY!" doesn't grant an auto-thumb up?Now the Cons-FOOD. Food is a needed thing especially for long trips in a dungeon, manually healing your party and also for countering starving events which pop-up randomly. The thing is even if you feed your heroes manually and then move one space you might still be hit with a starving event. Would be nice to at least have a way to manually avoid that instead of wasting food on healing your team (you can't even feed them a ton of food because it will say they are full) to only be hit by a starving event.-STORY. A bit weak. Almost none at all. I guess the bosses have their own mini plot's but all in all it's not SUPER compelling. That's where the gameplay comes in to pick up the slack.-BRUTAL GAMEPLAY. Funny how this is a con and a pro right? I put it as a con as well because this is not a game for everyone. It's for those sick creatures that like to cut themselves with pencils and other slightly blunt but mostly sharp objects. It is very tough for players that are looking for a fair game as this is NOT a fair game and it most likely will stay unfair. I guess I'm one of those that likes the crazy difficulty. TL;DRFun, dungeon crawler that's based around dice-rolled combat and brutal difficulty which is backed up by great artwork and a stellar narrator. Final Score?: 8/10

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												This is a challenging game, about loss, hopelessness, and the inevitability of death.If you're looking for something about as bleak as Dark Souls, or a team-based dungeon crawling rpg, then this is what you're looking for.Notable features:-Deadly Combat: Characters die, and die quickly. Even a top-tier hero probably has 50-60 hit points, with some enemies getting 90+ damage critical hits.-Tactical Positioning: Where characters are in your team roster determines which skills they can use and which enemies they can target. Pay attention to character special abilities when preparing an expedition.-Turn Timer Combat: Each combatant has a Speed, used to determine when to act in the order. Higher speeds go first more often, though the RNG can make even slow characters go first once in a while.-Inevitable Madness: Stress and insanity are incredibly, insidiously dangerous. When heroes get stressed, they get afflicted and stop being tactical. When they get too stressed they can have a heart attack and die. Stress is a killer, and carries over between expeditions.-Darkness Matters: Lighting and darkness have actual game mechanics that make the use of light into a risk-reward choice. High light gives hero buffs and high dark gives monster buffs, but high dark gives better loot and more frequent hero critical hits.-Downsides to Everything: One of the common loot rewards is a category of items called Trinkets. Trinkets have mystical properties that give a benefit, but almost always have an equal or greater drawback as well. And everything in the game follows this same model. Leveled up heroes will refuse to go to dungeons that are weaker than them, even if their gear and skills are inadequate to the dungeons they pursue. Many beneficial hero skills also have a drawback (personal debuffs, chance of allies bleeding, increase stress for allies, etc.). Loot items take up inventory space that you need for food or other supplies.-Genuine Triumph: Because you have to work for it, your victories are satisfying. Even the bleak and nearly pointless ending cinematic cannot detract from the satisfaction of having actually defeated the Darkest Dungeon.Overall: Lots of fun, lots of frustration, and a very satisfying sense of triumph upon completion. Recommended for patient people not affraid of Lovecraftian horror stories.

												Not your average dungeon crawler, it's hard core in the sense that you can lose your favorite heroes permanently and money/stress management is challenging. However your town still keeps its upgrades so there is progression. The attention to detail on the character interactions, especially when they lose their minds, is really impressive. content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I'm honestly not sure whether I should reccomend this or not. It is extremely well made - the music is exciting, the sound, dialogue, and voice acting is great, and it has an amazing visual style.  It is challenging but actually fairly balanced IMO - once you know a general good structure for a team and the the bad luck that usually crops up in different places then things will become a lot less random. The first few runs will be a gong show while you are figuring things out though. As will the first time in a new area, or with a new team, or after leveling up, or against a boss . . .This is kind of why I am not sure about reccomending it - the struggle is real and constant.  Usually you get 'better' as you play a game - you have new skill, or the game gives you better weapons etc. In DD your team gradually levels up and at a certain point are too 'skilled' to run easier dungeons. Suddenly your 'A Team' absolutely sucks and you are getting out by just the skin of your teeth. On the one hand, this keeps the challenge up - you need to find new stategies and group configurations and there is always that anxiety about entering a dungeon.  Characters have a set suite of skills and can only be leveled up so much and even high level items seem to have some crippling negitive aspects along with the good. On the other hand, while you continue to achieve more difficult and amazing tasks, it is not actually satisfying. I would come to dread my characters leveling up. Most of the time I felt like a stressed out HR manager trying to fill vacancies.This was probably intentional though - the whole game is a bit of a commentary on what 'adventuring' would be like in the real world. Having to go out in the dark  and murder a bunch of horrible monsters would actually suck quite a bit wouldn't it?You know what - I'm going to reccomend this. It is something different and even if I didn't actually 'enjoy' it , it definitely had me thinking about it long after I was done a session.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												You'll see lots of people claiming that this game is far too random and that they have had times when parties of heroes have all been wiped out by crappy RNG. I've seen a few reviews where people have said its 'unfair' and its 'not if your heroes die, but when'. But sadly, that's kind of the point of this game. The game even says that most heroes will dies. People expect this game to be less harsh than it says it is. ive played it in early access and how it is now and it is a great game, you have amazing story, voice acting, immersion and a really dark, atmospheric world in which it is set. The only drawback is apart from the wealth you get from dungeons, there isn't much of a reward for long play time. 9/10 would recommend.

Posted: May 30, 2016
												Game's hard. But that's the point. Game feels like it's full of despair and terror, which translates well into each dungeon dive. Each encounter is difficult and, unless super prepared (and even then), all can be lethal. Bosses are wicked hard, losing characters is a crazy bummer, the new events are insanely difficult. Hard as hell game that you can easily blame on "Bad RNG" if you wanna take the easy route. Go in knowing you'll lose and each little victory tastes that much sweeter. Expect those moments where you have to stop playing because your characters died to something stupid, so you can calm down and grieve the loss of your many Vestals.

Posted: June 9, 2016
												What I've learned so far in the game:  Upgrade the stagecoach. (Number of heroes arriving) Do not be afraid of losing your heroes.  Keep track of your stress meter. Can be a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Get used to fails. They may happen a lot. Buffing your heroes is VERY important. Upgrade more the Blacksmith, Guild and Sanitarium. Keep track of your heroes quriks, diseases and abilities. Don't interact with all curios, unless you know what you're doing.Of course there is more to it, but so far what I've listed is important too keep in mind. The game is difficult, the enemies are merciless (so do somethin to debuff their stats ex: use Man-at-Arms, Jester). Keep your torch lit above 76 and expect unfairness in higher levels. You gotta be well prepared for every dungeon expedition, get food, torches and some items that can cleanse the negative effects of some curios ( A curio is something you come across it and you my decide to investigate.Its kinda like the Dark Souls of dungeon crawlers. It can feel very rewarding after finishing quests.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Make no mistake: this game is not for everyone. It is the type of game that requires patience, more patience and, every so often, the ability to chant mantras like "I will not rage, I will not smash my keyboard..." Pros:Art, SFX, replayabilityCons:RNG - the gods of RNG are easily angeredPicture this: you get a high level party and proceed to faceroll anything that comes your way, all the while listening to the awesome "ancestor" voice saying "OBLITERATED!", "DESTROYED!", "MASTERFULLY EXECUTED!" as you kill, bleed and poison your opponents. After the dungeon is complete, you collect lots of loot and you feel confident. Big mistake.As your ancestor reminds you, "Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer". But you think that this does not apply to you and so you start another dungeon, with the same party. After all they were successful in the previous run...And this is where DD reminds of who is in charge: enemies start handing out critical hits to your heroes as if it was Christmas all over again. And so, your vestal panics which in turn prevents her from doing her job: TO HEAL. The other members of the party get stressed because she is constantly babbling to herself about the horrors she has seen. This leads to more stress piling up and, quicker than you realise, they are all screaming and cursing and hitting themselves till they are nothing more than nervous wrecks left at death's door...And then the blissful silence of death...your heroes that so confidently defeated the evil hordes in the previous dungeon are now resting eternally in the graveyard. You look around and find only young and inexperienced recruits, barely capable of lifting their weapons.How many heroes does it take to appease the RNG gods? Only they know. But if you have the strength to rise from the ashes, you will find the time spent in the Darkest Dungeon rewarding.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												When my adventurers set off, they were sane.So eager.Drawn by the compelling tune of merciless avarice and desires for multitudinous glories, they paced into the dark alcovesof the damp cove by the beach. Some began to cast furtive eyes around. When would they first see action? When would blood first be drawn? Two rooms in, they got their wish.Two slimy fish-men, residue coating their scales and blood on their teeth, one fish-priest, wielding skulls and trinkets looted from adventurers long dead, and in the front, a hulking, tentacled mass, wielding sharpened wheels on clammy tentacles. For as much damage dealt by the warriors, more seemed to be dealt to them, leaving them bleeding and scattered in both mind and body.When the pack of monsters was dealt with, the warriors breathed heavily in relief, yet also shivered in anticipation of waht was to come.As they progressed further, pain and fear eroded their wills, as ancient evils had eroded the pits from which such beasts had emerged. Tentacles lashed out.Fangs gleamed.Torches faded to embers.uncomfortable truths were confronted.T'was the Leper, so easily able to deal damage to others, who broke first, developing an irrational, masochistic tendency to injure himself, refusing aid and healing from the Vestal, the team cleric. His gasps of pain led to further stress in the others, as did his eventual death at the hands of an unholy priest, wielding jagged blades to rend for the Old Gods. The Leper's death eventually broke the Vestal, who had been refused time and again by him, even as he bled out before her. She became abusive, hurling insults at the others, who were faring less and less well, as each new trial chipped at their minds, enabled further by their abusive healer refusing them aid when it was needed.As a result of this, the Highwayman found himself too in an early grave, as he bled out from an unsightly gash inflicted by sharpened blades plucked from shipwrecks by clumsy, fish-like hands.And so there were two.the Plague Doctor, the last (somewhat) sane member of the crew, decided to cut her losses and retreat to the relative safety of the village hamlet. However, the situation caused the Vestal to become so distraught that she collapsed on the spot, dea of a heart attack as the result of unbearable pressure.In the end, only the Plague Doctoe made it out alive, with all the loot picked up by the group and some trinkets salvaged from her colleagues' bodies. She retreated to the village bar, to drink away her sorrows. But what she had seen would forever scar her.As for the losses?No bother.There will always be more cannon fodder to send into the darkest of dungeons.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												“You remember our venerable house... opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination!”Darkest Dungeon is a game that just oozes ambiance out of its many orifices; from the excellent art design to the deeply powerful narration of the Ancestor. The game is difficult, and you can expect to bury many of your heroes before you manage to cleanse the taint of eldritch horrors from your ancestral home (the game tells you as much on the title screen.) On the other hand, outside of the NG+ mode, there’s actually no way to lose the game, either – new recruits, available for free, will show up at your gates every week… and if you don’t have the cash to outfit them with weapons, training, torches, or even food… well, hopefully they’ll be able to make a quick run into one of the low-level missions, kill some cultists, grab some gold and gems, and beat a hasty retreat to refill your coffers… and if not them, perhaps next week’s batch….I think it’s a superbly well executed game. The low and medium level dungeons are forgiving enough that you can make some mistakes or run with suboptimal parties without getting your head handed to you, giving you the experience needed to face the elite dungeons, and eventually even the darkest dungeon itself.I think my only complaint would be that you do end up needing to run a lot of missions to collect the materials needed to upgrade your hamlet and level up your heroes. It never reaches what I’d consider a slog; but I also really, really enjoy both the turn-based combat and the amazing narration that goes along with it."Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer."

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Yes, this game is ridiculously difficult, and yes, much of it is tied to RNG. However, the RNG in Darkest Dungeon reminds me of something similar to XCOM. An attack with 95% chance to hit can still miss and its infuriating when it does. Has that stopped people from loving XCOM? No. So the only cause I can find for all the negative reviews from long time early access players is failure to adapt to the changes that have been made.Darkest Dungeon is made to be punishing, and it's void of guarantees. The design of a game like this is intended to force the player overcome impossible odds on a mission through careful thought in combat, and managing your party members well in town (in this case by properly budgeting treatments, upgrades, provisions, etc.) and if the player can successfully do these things then they will be successful to some degree.Failures come as often as these successes though. Party members will die, and you will be forced to abandon quests in order to save others. But some of the greatest satisfaction comes from salvaging your roster after losing one or two in a dungeon, and then using that roster to clear a dungeon or defeat a boss, then collect the fruits of your labor. The sense of accomplishment is tremendous, and the rewards are worthwhile.So please give this game a shot if you're looking for a punishing challenge with appropriate rewards and satisfying and intricate gameplay.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												TL;DRGreat game early to mid-game, but gets too grindy endgame. Still an 8/10Full ReviewI think I just want to address this first: If you really think that this game is 100% RNG based that can instantly wipe out your entire party in a single dungeon run, I can assure you that is not the case. A lot of the game is based on RNG, but unless you're being really stubborn, a crit hit on you or a few misses in a row won't be the end of you. You're given plenty of options in hero choices, trinkets, and skills to rig the odds best in your favor for a particular mission. But once a mission starts heading south, REMEMBER THAT YOU CAN QUIT THE MISSION AT ANY TIME. I hear a lot of complaints about how BS stress can be, but you always have the option to abandon the mission if too many party members are afflicted, diseased, ect. Pick your battles wisely, and you'll never have a party wipe. I beat the game without one, just check my achievments. The only place where RNG really plays a huge role is with Deaths Door, when a character reaches 0 hp. And thankfully because of that mechanic, it prevents instant one-hit party wipes. Though they are debuffed for the rest of the questNow, onto the main bulk of review.The story: An ancestor of yours accidentally unleashed an eldritch abombination into the world, so it's up to you to fix it.The main bulk of the gameplay revolves around sending heroes out to do various quests to collect gear, gold, and heirlooms, mainly to prepare for the assaults on the Darkest Dungeon. Doing missions levels up their resolve, which allows them to get better gear, better skill upgrades, and do harder missions. If you wanna purchase the better gear/skill upgrades, you need heirlooms from your various missions in order to unlock these. Later on, with a high enough Blacksmith and Guild(Used for skill updgrades), you can even upgrade your stagecoach to bring in heroes with pre-upgraded armors in skills, all the way up to level 4, which helps with the grind a bit. For stress and afflictions,  as your heroes explore, they'll accumulate stress and may develop ununfavorable traits. If stress gets to 100 in a dungeon, they'll either become afflicted negatively which will cause them to act irrationally depending on the affliction, or they have a slight chance of gaining a great buff, which can seriously help out your party. If stress reaches 200, they'll suffer a heart attack, which will either reduce their health to 0, or if they're already at Death's Door, instantly kill them. You can reduce stress in the dungeon by using certain skills, from camping. Out of the dungeon, you can use the Tavern or Chapel. Sometimes the traits can be really bad (E.G, -10 accuracy against a certain enemy type), but for the majority of the time, you don't have to worry way too much about these traits.When it comes to the main dungeon crawling, you take 4 heroes through a variety of missions, from simply explore the area to collect 3 amount of artifacts, to work your way up to the boss. As you start off, your worst opponent will be inexperience. As you continue to play, you eventually learn which team combos work best where, along with the fact that your heroes should have beter gear as you go on. It's a difficult yet fun curve, which takes a while to get over. Once you get over the curve though, that's when you start to notice the repetitiveness of the dungeons. Stronger enemy varients for just about every enemy is just a different name and higher stats, so you don't really see too much variation between enemys in later areas. It's the exact same for the bosses. You have to re-fight each boss 3 times, each one stronger than the last. This really contributes to the feeling late-game that you are pretty much only just grinding since you're seeing the same place and enemies over and over again because you need to level up heroes or need more gold/heirlooms. And trust me, the darkest dungeon is insanely hard, and you need to grind A LOT in order to prepare for it to prime your lv 6 heroes to perfection. Not to mention the "Never Again" penalty that your heroes get when they finish a Darkes Dungeon quest. Any heroes that successfuly assauled the Darkest Dungeon will never return there again, which means you need 16 lv 6 heroes ready to go. Because of this, I seriously don't recommend creating throwaway parties for suicidal gold runs.The Darkest Dungeon, the final area in the game, is true hell. All the enemies deal insane bleed, blight, and stress damage. Not only that, abandoning the mission will take the life of a random hero. On the plus side, there's no obstacles, no traps, and no chance of ambush, and the dungeon isn't randomly generated. The "abandoning takes a random hero" is really the only major flaw of the dungeon. Darkest Dungeon is a game where you NEED to learn from your mistakes, the Darkest Dungeon especially. For learning from your mistakes there, you're guaranteed to grind up at least one new hero. But the satisfaction from beating each darkest dungeon assault is imeasurably satisfying. All the odds were against you, and you still won.SPEAKING OF SATISFACTORY (SPOILER TERRITORY AHEAD)The second greatest flaw of the game has to be the ending. It's a forced bittersweet ending, and I mean FORCED. It's "Well you may have literally killed this god, but you merely delayed the inveitable", coming full circle and ending on "Ruin has come to my family." TL;DR, some dimwad decided to re-awake the monstrosity that lived down there AGAIN despite the (likely) 14 heroes you had who already knew about the terrors of the dungeon. The eldritch abomination was awoken because the Anscestor didn't know what he was getting into at first. WHAT REASON WOULD ANYBODY HAVE TO AWAKEN THE THING AGAIN? Hell, if they wanted to end it on a lovecraftian note, why not end it like how the Rats in the Walls ended, by just flat out destroying the entire estate that sat upon the dungeon? This ending is a forced punch to the gut saying, "Lol I know you suffered a lot but that was pointless". There are a million different ways this could have ended, and Red Hook took the "Blatantly forced edgy" ending.Despite it's shortcomings, the game is still great. The art and sound design is amazing, the dungeon crawling (for a majority of the game) will always keep you on your toes, and the stress mechanic is something pretty original that adds a new layer to the game's dungeon crawling. It's a good 8/10 game if you can tolerate the pain early-game brings

												If you are afraid of difficult games then don't play this game.  This is not your typical turn based RPG where you need to only manage your health.  Stress is a huge factor and you must manage your hereos' mental state as well.I really love the atmosphere as it does a great job capturing the cthulian theme. I truly dread going into the next dungeon fearing that my guys will die or stress out and have a heart attack. The artwork works extremely well with this game as well as the dark voiceover clips that plays randomly when bad or even good things happen. With plenty of classes to choose from and every one of them doing something different, the gameplay never gets old... and it's a turn based combat system! The dungeons are always randomly generated and so each dungeon is much different than the last. Darkest Dungeon is one of the best games I've played in a long time and after 100 hours of playing this game I still can't wait to jump back in.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a strange game (but in a good way if you read further and peruse my reasoning).It's a gritty dark fantasy adventure set in an undetermined time. You act as an overseer who recruits motely crews of adventurers to unearth relics (and whatever isn't nailed down) from the ruins of your ancestors' lands. Unfortunately one of your ancestors dealt too far into the occult, unleashing some horror which wears down on the resolve and sanity of your heroes (that's where the Lovecraftian stuff comes into play).Seems fair enough, and enough of a reason to get into it and play it. What makes this game strange is the idea that failure isn't only a possibility, but inevitable. The grim, gritty atmosphere isn't only in the graphics (which are beautiful, inspiring, and decadent at the same time), but in the gameplay and feelings evoked by this game. Expeditions into the ruins of your ancestors will fail, and death/madness is a likely prospect given that your adventurers have both HP and stress to manage throughout the game.Gameplay wise, it plays as a party rogue-like with turn-based combat. There is copious strategy to be discovered and applied as you unearth the ruins and build a competent enough team to assault the 'Darkest Dungeon'. To prepare your hired cohorts, you can find relics and family heirlooms in the various parts of the manor's surrounding lands to help upgrade the hub village you use to rest and arm your hirelings. With these heirlooms, you upgrade the various businesses and buildings: upgrading the blacksmith allows you to better arm your (surviving) heroes. Upgrading the Inn enables your unhinged heroes to restore their sanity by taking their mind off the oppresive atmosphere via gambling, drinking, and of course whoring. Your more pious heroes benefit from the chapel, which allows them the option of prayer or sacrifice to hopefully assist in recovering their resolve. A sanitarium acts as both a mental ward and hospital to cure your hirelings of any debilitating diseases or psychosis. Even outside of battle and dungeon-delving, there's enough strategy in managing your town that any contemplative RPG-Strategy players will be satisfied.Unfortunately, the biggest gripe that I have is the early-stage grind required to build a competent team. Experience is only gained through successful runs through the dungeon, and not at an encounter basis, meaning a failed mission merely leaves you with a bunch of insane heroes and little treasure. That would be fine, but items can only be upgraded if the hireling's level matches the item's strength. And unfortunately, most dungeons increase in diffculty and strength as you complete them (regardless of the heroes you might have in reserve), meaning that one bad run due to a very cruel and unforgiving random number generator can easily wipe out your best and well-armed heroes, leaving you with level 0 hirelings to face the same threats your A-team took on. This ends up adding hours, effectively bashing your head into the wall, and sending heroes through the meat-grinder until the dice ends up rolling in your favor. That idea alone can be very discouraging.Still, if you are a fan of atmosphere and of the belief that it's persistence that wins you the day, then Darkest Dungeon is a worthwhile purchase and a memorable game experience! 4 out of 5.

Posted: April 15, 2016
												The game has a fantastic feel and atmosphere to it. You'll certainly feel like you're part of the darkest dungeon environment. The gameplay is interesting and challening. You never really feel like you've become all powerful. There's always a chance that things could go badly for your squad, even against foes that you've easily beaten previously. On the whole though, the game play is a bit of a slog. Your guys level up, but as they do, they're limited to playing the higher level dungeons, so their relative power remains somewhat constant. This is challenging, but doesn't make your team feel like they're progressing much. Don't fall in love with any of your characters, as there's always a chance they won't make it out of the dungeon alive. On the whole I liked the game. I'm yet to finish it, despite being almost 60 hours in. In fact, I don't even feel close to finishing it. The game has become something of a grind, and I can't see myself finishing. A fun game for a time, but not something I'm rushing back to.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I don't typically write EA reviews, but DD is an exception. I don't like rogue-like games. I don't like games that are frustrating. I've gottent too old for games like that. I play games for fun. I play games to replax. So I shouldn't like DD. Yet I find this to be simply one of the better games I've played this year. It is exceptionally fun while being frustrating. There's a wonderful mix of tension, frustration and triumph. The theming of the game is exceptional - the voice-overs, the look, the feel all build this wonderful universe of gloom. There's tension around every corner and you feel every decision is meaningful. There's plenty of options to cater to your playstyle. I truly feel that every decision I make in Darkest Dungeon is a crucial one. Very few games feel that way. Thus I find DD to be also a fairly intense game to play. Furthermore, they've done a great job during EA of balancing classes, adding content and ironing out some annoyances. It's nice to see someone use EA the way it was meant - getting community feedback and using it to make the product much better with a clear plan to get to a truly complete release candidate. Props to them for that too.This is a game that will get you screaming at your monitor. You may even break your keyboard. But it's tense, brilliant, fun and I recommend it for every gamer.

Posted: July 21, 2016
												I bought this game during the Summer Sale. I started playing recently and I absolutely fell in love with it. As many mentioned, this game drips with beautiful dark Lovecraftian atmosphere. The gameplay is alot of fun, but might get repetitive. However, in time, you will change the way you play. At first you most likely grow attached to your starting crew. But the further you go, the more this view will get stomped in the ground.You see, heroes die. Even your strong, upgraded powerhouses. If you get the hang of the game, you will realise this game is more about proper management then it is about picking favourites and winning the game with it. By the way, winning this game takes a LONG LONG time. In that regard you might compare this with a game (I know it sounds silly) like Stardew Valley. You build slowely but surely, and get a bit futher step by step.If you play this game for long stretches of time, it might get repetitive and boring, but this a game that is best played a few hours at a time. So the next time you come back you have some new ideas and things you want to try out.It's a great game, but it is a game that changes you over time. Your playstyle will adapt and thats the beauty of it. And be prepared to invest alot of time in it if your set on beating it!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I absolutely cannot recommend this game to anyone. A videogame is meant to be enjoyable and fun, but apparently nobody at Red Hook Studios was informed of ths. Every design decision seems to have been purposefully made to irritate, annoy and take the fun out of playing it. There is absolutely no enjoyment whatsoever to be had in this game, and this comes down to every element of the game being either mostly or entirely outside of your control.  Almost everything in this game is arbitrary. Random dice rolls are quite clearly rigged to favour good results for the enemy and bad results for you, and systems that supposedly work on fixed numbers cheat to produce unfavourable outcomes seemingly on a whim.The money spent to keep party members alive and sane outside of missions is inexpicably subtracted from the same pool from which you need to purchase supplies to keep them alive and sane during missions, and money, supplies and upgrade resources are never numerous enough to allow you to make any real progress except by sheer, blind luck (and don't expect that to ever come at a time when it might genuinely help you). Stress accumulates extremely quickly and can instantly kill your heroes even if you keep their health topped up. Enemy dodge rolls seem insanely slanted as compared to how often your own characters are able to do it. The items required to cure damage-over-time effects are insanely expensive compared to the average income of a mission and the maintenance costs of your characters.The game also crashes randomly with little explanation.Every single one of these issues confront you within the first twenty minutes of the game. You will not complete this game. You will not enjoy a single moment of playing it. Spend your money somewher else. If you have under 120 minutes of play, demand the refund that Steam promises you. This game does not deserve your custom.

												Striking art style, well done animations, good narrator commenting along our journey. Darkest Dungeon is a fun turn-based dungeon crawler that offers an interesting twist on the usual mechanics by adding a stress meter for our heroes. The longer they stay exploring, the worse it gets. content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								An outstanding title from a dedicated dev team.Darkest Dungeon is one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time. The game is unapologetically hard and unforgiving. This game will make you work for victory.Your heroes will face countless perils and inevitably descend into madness. The key is balancing the mental health of your heroes while making enough progress to keep the coin flowing for further ventures.The art style is simply beautiful with fantastic narration and an enthralling soundtrack to match the forever enclosing darkness. While the narrator provides a commentary for your journey, the members of your party will voice comments ranging from celebration of a hard won victory to hurling abuse at the rest of the party for the gross incompetence.If you are looking for a challenging gameplay experience where every move must be calculated and where sometimes, as hard as it maybe to admit, retreat is absolutely necessary for long term success look no further.For the price the dev team are asking, this game is an absolute bargain.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Oh boy, how to properly give this game it's due? Here's the thing: You're going to lose or suffer horrible setbacks. That's pretty non-negotiable. However, the game is seemingly made entirely around that concept and it works. Under ideal circumstances it really feels like you're walking on thin ice and at any given moment it can break. Then, one of your 4-member Dungeon crawling group goes temporarily insane and every action you can possibly take seems to have negative and dire consquences - and it's equal parts crushing, hilarious and entertaining while it happens. Very quickly you will need to let go of any "perfect gameplay" style of gaming here. Even leveling up can bring negative quirks. Every magic item in the  game has a bonus but also a drawback aspect to it. While many games start out easier and get harder as they go along, Darkest Dungeon seems to take the opposite direction, although so far I'd never say it gets "easy", it simply goes from your adventures almost always ending with someone dead or crippled to a situation where now and again you can scrape by. Victories are rare but all the more sweet for the rareness. It's hard not to love this game. Also, while it is a work in progress, much of the foundation appears to be laid. There is plenty of content here for a lot of gaming pleasure.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though I adore this game on several fronts (the art style is amazing and efficient, the atmosphere at the start is great, the turn-based combat is better than most games of this type (but could be more refined)), i still have to give this game a massive thumbs down summed up in one word: Treadmill.This game is a massive treadmill, it almost feels like playing a mobile game. Putting your adventurers into the brothel to recover stress is amusing, leveling up that same brothel to level 10 is NOT fun or enjoyable in ANY way. You have to level up EVERYTHING in this game. The town buildings, the skills, weapons and armor of your adventurers. And all of those upgrades are just small improvements of basic numbers. After the initial phase of the game, which is very enjoyable, these treadmill mechanics kick in, and advancing in the game just feels like a hassle.It saddens me that would these mechanics be stripped out, the game would probably be amazing. The treadmill adds nothing to the gameplay and atmosphere, it undermines these at several fronts. While fighting for the life of your adventures can be tense and fun if you're into this sort of gameplay, losing leveled up characters to RNG is NOT fun. Because this event again demands more farming of you to level up a new character... ugh. No respect for a player's time.To further illustriate my point, let us compare to another roguelike-like game beloved by me and many - FTL: Faster than Light. In FTL the game is structured in 'runs' which last up to an hour at the most. Each of these runs is unique, and nothing is carried over into the next game (except unlocking new ships). This means that the gameplay is intense and it is all about about achieving things within THIS run. Nothing is there to be farmed. There is no grind.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Darkest Dungeons is a roguelike turn based strategy game that draws heavy inspiration from the works of HP Lovecraft (Cthulu, Dagon, the Old Ones, etc). The gameplay, characters, and especially the VOICE ACTING are exceptional. The game has low system requirements and runs very smoothly. Despite this, the graphics are somehow very good and the art style is endearing. DD is the best example of an early release game that did everything right. There have been and there are still some problems with the game that have to do with clunky GUI and inventory management but I've noticed the developers have been constantly making improvements to the game with patches. They've been churning out fixes and even new characters and locations left and right. I get the feeling that the developers truly care about this game. I would wholeheartedly recommend this game. A timeless classic.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												This is recommended with a huge asterisk.Yes, the game is fun. Yes, it's worth the money. But it feels like a pay-to-win game without the cash shop.Any and all unlocks take exorbitant amounts of resources, especially hamlet upgrades and treatments in the sanitarium.Higher difficulty dungeons and bosses are exactly the same as starter ones, but with inflated hp and damage, with higher resistance to all debuffs.Stress is just another health bar, and is usually minor enough to be ignored in all but the most dire instances.Once you've killed off the first round of bosses, there's not much to do. Dungeons are either too low level for your main party to go after, or too long/dangerous for newcomers to rank up safely.The RNG is oppresively stacked against you, with higher level dungeon enemies able to dodge most of your attacks while critting you almost every turn.The Collector is a game-ender. I got him in all but one of my first boss runs, with him wiping my entire party in a few turns.Speaking of, the bosses themselves were♥♥♥♥♥♥easy, especially the cannons in the weald and the flesh in the warrens, giving almost no challenge aside from having over a hundred health and summoning help every turn.
