number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												First things first, when I say that I recommend Darkest Dungeon, I recommend it for people who know what they're getting into. Personally, I love this game so let me start with the best parts that made me fall in love with this game. From the perfect dark, gritty atmosphere of lost hope and despair, to the eldritch abominations that plague the land as your foes, the setting and ambiance is perfect. You get the basis of the (admittedly simple) plot upon startup and that's where you meet your best frenemy that travels with the player's party out of view: the Narrator. As you travel and fight through the world, the Narrator WILL NOT hold your hand, and instead he comments on your escapades as well as failures brought out from your decisions. He perfectly compliments the setting, being the final icing on the cake alongside the subtle music that fits every scenario: The depressing tones in the Hamlet (your home base), the background noise while traveling (which is ominously no music, ironically... only occassional horrified screams of agony), and the battle music which, although it never sticks in my head (as it's really just background noise), I find it perfectly fitting while I'm kicking♥♥♥♥♥and getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me on a silver platter. Now for the combat... It's a roguelike RPG with turn based strategy. With your team of four hardy fighters, you crawl through dungeon after dungeon and wait your turn while fighting another team of four (or three, or two, or just one...) enemies (For those unaware of turn based strategy, just imagine it like a slide on a playground, where everyone in the line gets a turn then restarts when everyone gets their turn). What makes this combat extremely interesting is that correct positioning of your team is key. Certain classes will work best in certain positions due to their attacks only working in certain positions (and said attacks can only work on certain enemy positions as well). With that in mind, you have your classic buffs and debuffs (better attack, slower speed, etc.), as well as status inflictions (stun, bleed, etc.), and even a unique one: Stress. As you go on and fight, your team will get stressed out (because ♥♥♥♥ it man, you don't see this♥♥♥♥♥♥on your everyday 9 to 5 and through the week). Pushing your characters to their limits will either cause them to bend or break under pressure, turning them into either heroes or total♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ respectively. Here is one such example of the game's biggest theme: Risk vs Reward (in my opinion, it is). The risk to either fight or heal, putting chance to a missed sword swing or a lucky bullet crit. Another mechanic of the game is light level, which the darker it gets, the more rewards you can get but the easier it is to become stressed out. Even the items show this, as the best items for one stat will decrease another, such as increasing your armor but lowering your damage, or increasing your stress intake while also increasing other abilities' power. I love the Risk vs Reward aspect to this game as I'm a very cautious player, but games like this and Dark Souls push me to take chances for once.Now, sadly, for the negatives that lie in this game (and hopefully I can express why they don't bother me enough to truly walk away forever). I will admit that the RNG in this game rules over it with an iron fist alongside its brother, RPG grinding. Where others curse these two tyrants and walk away once the two have broken them, I relish in the anarchy. The RNG admittedly does leave incredible amounts of the game (if not every fight) up to chance, but through buffs and items, you can help your chances so you're not entirely up the river without a paddle. The game may be a huge gritty numbers game, but I'd much rather calculate what an item will do for me than an actual math equation (which I don't even calculate them myself, I just pick out items with good stats and jump into the fray). Now, it really is grind heavy... EXTREMELY grind heavy with character permadeath, but it does fit the theme of Risk vs Reward with how much you'll be pushed back from losing a character, wanting the player to play it safe, but the game forces you to take some chances as you won't be strong enough to persevere. With the excessive RNG, you're forced to take chances anyway, you just have to be willing to jump into hell instead of being pushed in.Now, when setbacks happen (and by god they will happen), you just have to persevere. Essentially, this analogy is the game: You are a little boy, this game is your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ older brother, and your bin of legos are your progress. When you're a little boy, all you want to do with legos is to stack them up to a giant tower, but your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ older brother being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wants to knock your tower down. The taller the tower, the more your brother will set you back when he knocks it down. Eventually, there'll come a time when your brother finally knocks down the tower, but what do you do? You may get upset and need some time to cool off, but eventually you brush yourself off, put on your big boy pants, and you build yourself a new ♥♥♥♥ing lego tower. Eventually through hard work, struggle, (chance), and perseverence, you make the best lego tower anyone's ever seen. Then you start it all over again... Much in the same way of Dark Souls: You fight, you die, you keep fighting, you eventually make it, then you start over.My final verdict: If you're prepared to gamble then jump on in. If you're a cautious gamer then this game will break you from being overly cautious. Start up the game and you've already bought your one way ticket to hell, meaning you're going there one way or another, so you may as well enjoy the descent.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												It may not appeal to everyone, but I love this game. Watch some gameplay videos and read some reviews if you're still on the fence.Pros:- The aesthetics, music, narration are all top-notch- The narrator is so good he deserves a second mention. Seriously- The gameplay is turn-based, so you can play strategically and thoughtfully- There's more than one way to "succeed" at the game - there's no single strategy that works better than everything else (but also see below)- The setting and unfolding storyline are great. Very Lovecrafian and GrimdarkCons:- Punishingly difficult. Some may see this as a pro. Be ready to cut-and-run, be ready to dismiss heroes that are damaged beyond repair, be ready to accept failure and death on a regular basis- Some classes/heroes feel noticably less useful than others, though there's not 100% agreement on which heroes- Though there's not one game-winning strategy that works all the time, some enemies and bosses DO require specific tactics to defeat, and if your group isn't ready for them, victory may not be possible. Again, that's part of the game, but this may bother some players.If you know what you're in for, and you're still interested, I'd give this game a shot, for the graphics and music (and narration) alone.

								Not sure where this game is going but it does not feel like an RPG to me. It feels more like an acrade fightin game with a little story. PositivesArt work is awesome.The narration is  well doneThe theme of the game is dark and brooding.The stress and affliction stuff is genius, more games should pull this mechanic.Great light mechnaic, it adds a lot to the gameNegativesThe lack of havng one main character really hampers the story. If you want one of those here is a good one....as for RPG not so much.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												EDIT: After a long and steep learning curve where I really had big trouble with this game, I've decided to change my review to be positive. When you figure out how things work (the game won't explain even half of it!), it gets a lot more manageable and fun. Usually, I always recommend tackling games without a guide. THIS GAME IS AN EXCEPTION! Read all the guides you can possibly find! If you are willing to do so, you will be greatly rewarded with a cool experience.ORIGINAL REVIEWI really like many aspects of the game. The general theme is great, the graphics are really cool, and the narrator's voice is awesome and contributes a lot to the atmosphere. It's dark, relentless and unforgiving.All that sounds really great. The problem is that the amount of randomness in this game is totally out of control. Need some examples?- Will an attack hit? Random.- Becoming poisoned, or start to bleed? Random. - Turn order? Random.- Is the treasure chest a deadly trap? Random. - Will the hero die when he's hit while deadly injured? Random.- Will there be an act of bravery or a mental illness when stress is at max? Random.- Which party member will fall victim to a trap when you walk into it? Random.- Which new characters will be available after a dungeon run? What are their skills and stats? All random.... and worst of all, these random elements absolutely cannot be avoided by the player. The game forces them upon you. There are regular opponents in the game that can  inflict permanent (!) random diseases on your characters with their NORMAL ATTACK (for crying out loud), which cost an awful lot of money to cure. So, literally, if your heroes are unlucky, they WILL die. This is NOT under your control, not even in the slightest. What's more, the game also fails to display any kind of percentages with which an action will succeed, it just happens. Not even turn order is properly displayed when you have to take an action and make a choice which enemy to take down.To summarize, you can be the greatest tactical genius that ever walked this planet earth, but if you are simply not lucky enough with the random numbers, this game will kick your♥♥♥♥♥without a moment of hesitation. This is just bad game design.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												This game is not for everyone and reading through the numerous positive and negative reviews should give an idea if this game is for you.  I would suggest you need to go into this game with the right attitude.  It is not about getting attached to an uber group of four heroes you use to play through the whole game.  I put 20+ heroes in the graveyard on my 1st play through, but I think in a new play through I could likely lose none.  This game has great flexibility in party make up. Choosing the right heroes, with the right quirks and right equipment - for the right area, makes an huge difference.  There are a lot of complaints about the RNG, and I shared some of those when I started playing.  However, once I really learned about the different areas, attacks, heroes skills, etc, I found I rarely faced losing a hero even with back luck with the RNG.  The skill is learning how to mitigate Murphy's law.  If you are going into an area that has a monster that can kill a hero in 1-2 hits, bring a fast hero with stun and then another that can do a damage debuff.  Voila, no problem.  RNG only really hurts you if you are not prepared.  Most fights are won or lost before you embark on your mission.  Also, sometimes you just have to give up and retreat from a quest rather than risk a party on the edge of a heart attack and/or low life.  This game does require an investment in learning the nuances and thinking through every attack, but finishing the final quest, with no loading of prior saves, no cheats, etc. was very satisfying.  Artwork, sound and voice over are excellent fits for the theme.

Posted: May 31, 2016
												If you like a dungeon crawler with a twist for the obscure, a difficulty system that will keep you on your toes without being too extreme and the chance that a bad planning will probably end with your adventurers going back home in a wooden box, it's a wonderful game. Avoid if you're easy to frustrate or if you can't cope with the idea that each time you take your characters out for a stroll they'll probably need one to several runs to recover.Also, great developers. Not so long ago, when this game was in early access, I had a very different idea about it and am very glad to see they have heavily improved the basics. Cons would be that it's kind of easy to find the dungeons repetitive.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Fun Game, I got gifted this during the holidays. It's about a town that is surrounded by all manner of evil creatures. Skeletons, pigmen, bandits, witches, necromancers, and more. You send heroes in, four at a time, to get rid of them. The combat is turn based, like jRPGs, however positioning is important. If your healers are in the melee range, they can't heal well. If your melee is in the very back of your formation, they can't attack well. Besides combat, you also have to manage your heroes when they come back from their questing. Fighting in the dungeon takes a mental toll, and you need to spend money in order to get them back in fighting shape, along with outfitting them with weapons, armor, and training. The art is great, and the narrator is awesome. Just look up "Wayne June Lovecraft" on youtube and you'll see. I recommend this game, but it might be hard to get into. Most of the difficulty is in figuring out the mechanics, as you get more familiar with the game, you'll know what to do to avoid having your heroes die or go crazy.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												If you're considering this game, you need to know three things before you buy: 1. Your party members WILL die. Don't get too attached and salvage what items you can. 2. There is no shame in retreat. In fact, sometimes retreat is the only smart choice. 3. You will rage quit at least once playing this game. Darkest Dungeon has kept me on my toes and breathless for hours on end. This is a game with tons of nuiance and some very interesting game mechanics that push it beyond the regular rpg party side scroller. ITS HARD. I've never played such a challenging game that I couldn't just smash my way through. What brings me back every time however is that challenge. The art and game style are also incredible and well worth checking out.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												I dig this game quite a bit. It starts out looking like a pretty simple concept: get your team, get some gear, go kill some monsters, rinse and repeat. Then you start learning about the other concepts that make it complex. Stress is one; your characters don't just take physical damage. They take stress damage as well. They need a break after a hard dungeon crawl, otherwise they can develop harmful quirks or even die of a heart attack. It's an interesting thing; you end up having to juggle your characters while some are hale and hearty, some are having to pray or gamble their stresses away, and others may be getting treated for leprosy or rabies. You have to be able to pay for all of these treatments, too, so that just means more trips into the dungeons. It's a neat take on the Roguelike style. I've become a fan.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												This game is fantastic.You round up a team of heroes and send them into a dungeon to kill horrors and bring back loot.  However, these aren't godly JRPG superhumans you're sending in, your heroes are fragile both in mind and body.  This is reinforced both through the Mignola-esque art style and through the gameplay.  Even if you are well-prepared and cautious, you are always a handle of unlucky rolls from disaster.  The fact that you can and will lose heroes is mitigated by the fact that fresh recruits are freely available, and the upgrades to your hamlet are permanent once unlocked.The game design ensures that you will feel tense as you explore the dungeon.  Your stocks of food and torches slowly run out, and the dungeon becomes more menacing as the light level dims (even so, these dangers are balanced by greater rewards).  Encounters and traps will whittle away at your health and sanity, and much of the time you will have only limited means to recover.  If things go badly, it is often best to cut your losses and run away.  However, it's all too easy to say 'just a little bit further' and before you know it you've been ambushed and are being cut down.The devs have said that they are considering future balance tweaks, and I trust them to do a good job.  The gameplay is more polished compared to the initial EA release and the difficulty is very-well calibrated.  Combat is tactical due to the positioning mechanics and yet feels visceral given the possibility of huge swings of luck.  I have put hours and hours into this game and it still gets my heart pounding every time.  I'm still not at the titular 'Darkest Dungeon' but I already feel that this has been one of my favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Being new to games as such (roguelikes in general), this game can seem hard and unforgiving. This was especially true when in the Early Access, but after the release, the game seems much more fair. With proper part mangement, strategy, and some luck, you can get through each stage. The risk of losing a hero(s) is what makes the game, to most, uninviting. But honestly, that risk is what makes the game so rewarding: Without that, the game would be much less exciting. Pros:   TONS of classes. Each class feels like it has its own role in a specific party (except for plague doctor :\. Cant seem to find a place for him/her quite yet)  Variation of abilites.  There are 6 different skills that a class has. You can chose up to 4 at a time. Each new recruit comes with only 4, the other 2 you have to unlock (which isnt hard to do). You can swap these skills anytime when you are at the town.Pro/Con   Constant saves.  Can either be a pro or con, depending on how you view it. Basicly, the game constanly saves the game so you can't go back. Once your hero dies, he is dead. I honestly think this makes the game more immersive and adds to the risk to the game. You can get around this, but not as easily as other games.Cons:   Constant crashes when loading into a new area  Annoying, but not really a big deal since the game constaly saves, meaning all you lose is the time that it takes you to get back into the game. I have yet to lose any progress to any crash.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												All the negative reviews are people who can't revise strategies or simply don't pay attention to the huge amount of info this game transparently gives you.Is this game difficult? Yes, but is it unfair? Only if you make it so.This game is all about strategic planning. It clearly lays out your characters strengths and weaknesses, and you must carefully consider how strong a combination of heroes can be against enemies that also have strengths and weaknesses.This is absolutely not a casual, every once in a while game. I generally play this a few hours each day, and it has yet to get old.Beyond the statistical fairness of the game, the art is unique and very emphatic. The narrator is seriously one of the very best sounding (and well written) of any game I've played.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												It may not appeal to everyone, but I love this game. Watch some gameplay videos and read some reviews if you're still on the fence.Pros:- The aesthetics, music, narration are all top-notch- The narrator is so good he deserves a second mention. Seriously- The gameplay is turn-based, so you can play strategically and thoughtfully- There's more than one way to "succeed" at the game - there's no single strategy that works better than everything else (but also see below)- The setting and unfolding storyline are great. Very Lovecrafian and GrimdarkCons:- Punishingly difficult. Some may see this as a pro. Be ready to cut-and-run, be ready to dismiss heroes that are damaged beyond repair, be ready to accept failure and death on a regular basis- Some classes/heroes feel noticably less useful than others, though there's not 100% agreement on which heroes- Though there's not one game-winning strategy that works all the time, some enemies and bosses DO require specific tactics to defeat, and if your group isn't ready for them, victory may not be possible. Again, that's part of the game, but this may bother some players.If you know what you're in for, and you're still interested, I'd give this game a shot, for the graphics and music (and narration) alone.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Not sure where this game is going but it does not feel like an RPG to me. It feels more like an acrade fightin game with a little story. Basicallly do not get attached to any of your characters beasue they will most likely die. PositivesArt work is awesome.The narration is  well doneThe theme of the game is dark and brooding.The stress and affliction stuff is genius, more games should pull this mechanic.Great light mechnaic, it adds a lot to the gameNegativesThe lack of havng one main character really hampers the story. Basically you throw adventurers at dungeons until you are done. Lots and lots of them...The lack of consistency in monsters and dungeons is extreme. It is a crap shoot every time.The lack of a persistant inventory is annoying, not sure what they were going for but all the stuff you buy magially disappears after a dungeon run.The rehab is crazy costly, it seems that they were trying to balane out the large amounts of money I think.All is all it is more of a dungeon fighting arcade game them an RPG. If you want one of those here is a good one....as for RPG not so much.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I played this game like 30 hours to reach the end of the beta version, and another 20 hours after it's fully released.In my opinion, this game is not for everyone. However, if this type of games are your things, you just cannot stop playing. There're 3 reasons that I don't recommend it to everyone.  First, If you don't like cast away your heros like a spent torch, this is not your game.Sometimes you have to send them away because they're useless, or they just meet their fate on the quests, or you even have to recruit heros to farm a bit of golds, and throw them away. It's all about expendable heros clearing their(or future heros') path to the success.Second, the battle system is not for everyone. So it is all about planning your attacks. All the enemies are unique. Most of them are extremely strong or has devastating debuffs.Neutralize them before they kill you and make the most of every turns you get.Third, I must warn you, this game is rather unforgiving and challenging. You can lose all of your legendary heros in a minute. No guaranteed victories. Everything is unexpected, no easy wins. That's what makes this game fun and non-repetitive.If those things sound appealing to you(or you don't mind them), I highly recommend you to buy this game. Defenitely worth the price. 2000 yen... I mean, 15 dollars or so.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												This game will make you hate how much you love it. If you ever were a fan of turn-based-combat RPGs, this one is a must! Just nifty!Pros:- Excellent art, voice acting, story-engine and an original take on classes/party building.- High replay value, dungeons are random generated and no play will be the same. The only constant in this game is the sorrow and despair you'll feel crusading against the darkness.- No saving, what happens happens and the only direction to move in forward. This means that you will have to live with your mistakes, and don't think alt-F4ing or "End Process" will save you from that last encounter, nope, like in real life, when bad things happen you can't just quick-load the last moment you were happy and giddy!Cons:- Not really for the casual gamer, but has potential to turn a casual gamer into a hardcore fan.- No saving, what happens happens and the only direction to move in forward. This means that you will have to live with your mistakes, and don't think alt-F4ing or "End Process" will save you from that last encounter, nope, like in real life, when bad things happen you can't just quick-load the last moment you were happy and giddy!- It's rather small, so it will leave you wanting more (while wanting less despaire and misery). Considering the price and the indie factor, I hesitate to put this as a con rather than a pro

Posted: February 3, 2016
												Not for the faint of heart, or somebody who gets mad easily.You will LOSE people, you will get completely BS rolls.  But if you like a challenge, you'll keep coming back no matter how much the game pisses you off.The game's spin on the whole dungeon crawl experience is a fascinating journey into the mind.  Nobody usually stops to consider the mental fortitude of adventurers except this game.  Consider for a moment the horrors and tribulations an adventurer faces has on a person's mind.  This game does that.  And keeping the sanity of your best people becomes a challenge in and of itself.Graphically - I like the stylized graphics.  The animations are really nothing to write home about, but it's not the game's focus and can be safely ignored.Music - It's solid.  Never got repetive for me.  I especially lke how it changes and becomes more intense the darker it gets.Overall, I give the game a 8/10.  Only let down a bit by a interface that could probably use some refinement and streamlining.  but otherwise it's a good game I don't regret buying and will probably put a lot more time into... even when it makes me scream ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T, THAT ROLL WAS COMPLETE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T!  WTF!?

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												So, the first twenty hours were pretty great. The art is the best thing ever, the writing is good, the combat very thoughtfully created and fun and nailbiting to play through.However, I lost interested and stopped playing after a while. The end objective is never really clarified (presumably, a tentacled Lovecraftian monster awaits in the Darkest Dungeon, the purpose is never really spelled out. You need to close a portal by... getting your guys to a high enough level to handle entering the final dungeon area? There's not even a "gather four keys" subplot.)  The game presumes the existence of repetive grinds is enough to pull you forward, but it's not really. Contrary to what you might think, there's not much RPG elements. You don't come across randomized loot, or make key decisions in how to permanently upgrading a character. What would make me want to grind up to level five or six?The game sells itself as a game where character death is frequent and permanent, but this is kind of misleading. You have an inexhaustable supply of heroes, you can rename them, recolor them, respec them at any time, and when they die, you can take their items off their corpse. So if your favorite Grave Robber dies, nothing happens other than you having to spend three hours leveling another Grave Robber to your current highest level and spending gold to upgrade them. Without limited numbers of heroes, or unique characters, death felt pretty meaningless. Why not just have them recuperate for three campaign turns? Or, maybe better yet, make the campaign itself more rougue-like, and shorter, so you have to make more consequential decisions on who to recruit.In the end, I'm really pumped for Darkest Dungeon 2. This game felt complete, but it felt like the prelude to a much more fun sequal -- it needed more plot, more environments, more hallway variations, some tweaks to the gameplay. And it needs support to make the late game involving, with more rewards with the harder difficulty.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												This game has been getting some bad rap from some people. Said people walked into the game expecting something that the game isn't. So here's a fair review of Darkest Dungeon:1. Yes; the game is a rougelike. It is tough, dark, challenging, and will be punishing at times. Is it an impossibly difficult game? No. But it is difficult. At times it will have you frustrated, but that's the point. The game sets out to make sure you DON'T get too attached to your heroes. They will, in all liklihood, die. And that's what people hate. They hate that they can't just waltz through a game, get a few boo-boos, and then truck through the rest of the fight with no danger. The fights don't work that way. Hero death happens, and it's critical that you avoid it if at all possible obviously. But there are times when you weigh your options and you make the wrong choice. This game won't hold your hand for you. You are the master of your actions: you deal with your consquences.People often complain that their tactics in one dungeon didn't work in another dungeon. That's because each dungeon offers a range of new challanges that must be faced with new tactics. Why would your blight heavy party, who was able to destroy the blight-prone skeletons of the ruins meet the same monotonous victory in the warrens, where the pig men are used to disease and blight? Pick new heroes ffs. Get some curse and bleed up in there. (Pro tip, a party with no tank goes really badly. A party with no capability of healing also goes really badly). This game does what it's supposed to, and it does it rather well. It shows the player that your actions have consequences, and you need to put a decent amount of forethought into your strategies. Don't get too bummed out when a hero dies. It happens. Total party wipes happen. You can avoid those if you know when to retreat. But if it does happen, just move on and assemble a new team and learn from your mistakes, as you do with any other game (dare I say, and life in general).

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												I played two seperate versions of this game for about 15-30 game weeks each.  Recently I decided to buy it because this is probably one of my favorite games I've played in a long time.  The first build I played which was probably dated from around 06/15, was a gruelling experience.  Many parties were wiped.  I was constantly barely hanging on, and everything was quite rough.  But it was intriguiging.  I later on found a more recent build dated from around 2/2015, and started a second playthrough, taking the grueling lessons I learned on my first playthrough by heart.   I started out much stronger this time, but still I made mistakes, and eventually I had a double party wipe combined with bankruptcy.  I set the game down for a bit a few weeks.Finally, I decided to buy the game.  So far Im about 40 weeks into this playthrough with at least one of every class above level 3.  I have no deaths, and have not started a single run without optimized equipment.  At this point I am unsure if the game has been made easier in recent patches (Healing seems much more available).  Though this is not necesarily bad.  There is always that faint line of balance where if I focus the wrong target, everything will go to hell (It's happened).  I also noticed a large number of complaints about the rng.  From what I've experienced, The Rng is much less random than people paint it out to be.  The worst case scenario is usually the norm, and anything other than that is a blessing.  When you play with this consideration in mind, the game becomes much more maneagable and feels much better.  I think the Rng Mirrors the style of the game.  On the outside it's hopeless, but deep underneath it creates  am environment primed in equal measures for hope and hopelessness.Also in terms of art review, It's fantastic.  The diction is beautful, and the writing lends to it so well.  Overall this is very very well done from an artistic standpoint, and can easily be worth about 10 hours of play to experience it on the surface

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I see a lot of people comparing this to Dark Souls, but in truth the only thing the two have in comon is their difficulty. Though this game isn't exactly difficult, unfair would be a better word. When you die in Dark Souls it's entirely your fault, but when you die in Darkest Dungeon chances are pretty good that there's nothing you could have done. I like the concept, I like the premise, I love the art, I like a lot of the gameplay, but I really can't reconcile with how heavily RNG factors in. I've lost characters because they refused to be healed while they were on death's door. That's a special kind of unfairness that you have to be actively searching for in a game to find enjoyable. It's a niche game for a niche audience made up of a combination of masochists and people with unfaltering resolve. It's not a bad game by any means and I've had some great fun with it, but it just doesn't appeal to me. But if you're the kind of person who finds enjoyment in having the odds stacked completely and totally against you then by all means go ahead. If nothing else this game mirrors its story perfectly, I can't play it for more than a few hours without going completely ♥♥♥♥ing mad.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												TL;DR - Die hard Rogue-like fans will probably find it too easy. People looking for a typical dungeon crawl might find it too grindy. It hit a sweet spot for me though, and the aesthetic is great. Def worth a play.----------------There's this card game called Mao. The rules are: you don't get to know the rules. The only person who knows the rules is your worst most annoying friend. If he says the suit you played doesn't match the 70s rock song he was thinking of, your card is wrong and you lose. His sister, who is really cute and who has totally figured out eye-liner, will laugh and in that moment you will realize that she was never going to go to prom with you pretty much no matter what. This part of the analogy isn't super relevant. The point is that Mao has a lot in common with Rogue-like games.When you play a Rogue-like you're at the mercy of a set of unknown rules. And it's not even your awful friend Dave who's making them up. The rules are written by some software developer who didn't even go to your high school and probably didn't even know Dave's sister back then. Maybe they're dating now, whatever, it doesn't matter.There are a couple of ways of looking at this power dynamic. You can feel bullied and cornered, or you can accept that you'll be defeated many, many times and decide to use each defeat to learn little scraps of information that will help you exploit the rules and do a little better next time. I'm no masochist. I mean, I added Dave on facbook to be nice, but I unsubscribed from his feed. If a game tortures me too much, I'm out. There's too much other good stuff out there to play. I do get the appeal of the second approach though. The game doesn't actually kill me in real life. It gives me infinite chances. There's fun to be had in hacking it until it breaks. It all boils down to how much fun I'm having figuring out the rules.Darkest Dungeon has rules and mechanics that are unique and fun to figure out. That's the make-or-break for Rogue-likes I think and that's why this review is marked positive. It can feel like a grind at times - like "OK I get it, I learned this lesson. This party configuration should be shredding this fight but Dave just keeps lying about the rolls he's getting behind that DM screen!" He's not, it's just bad luck. But whatever, Dave is the worst. Anyway, Amber return my calls. I know you're single again.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												This game is built for the old-school gamer. The gamer that grew up before this hand-holding AAA garbage-fest we see today. Press F to pay respects. Darkest Dungeon gives you just enough of a tutorial to get you on your feet, but even then the tutorial itself is difficult. One of my heroes died on the first mission, something that would not happen again until several missions later. I've seen many negative reviews in the "most helpful" section complaining of bad RNG and steep difficulty. The only conclusion I can reach is those reviewers are millenials that need their hand held. If this game were any easier, I would not enjoy it. If this game had player-favored RNG, I would not enjoy it. If this game told me what to do and when to do it, I would not enjoy it. These seem to be the qualities some people desire however. There is a disclaimer before you even start your first save file and every time you load the game thereafter which states that this is an extremely challenging game. Your heroes will die. You will be compelled to abandon some missions (or face a party wipe). You will be forced to make many difficult  choices.  I mainly wanted to write this review in an attempt to dispel the false rumors you see in the "most helpful" section. The great atmosphere, art style, voice acting etc. can all be witnessed via the gameplay trailer. The RNG that people claim to be unfair is actually quite the opposite. The RNG in Darkest Dungeon is actually the most balanced I've seen in a game in a long time. Your players will get crit often, but your crits will land just as well. Your player will get their attacks dodged, but you can dodge just as many enemy attacks. Your players will go from 100%-0% in a single strike, but you can land the same blow. You are not favored in any fight. Neither is the enemy.The problem people have with this game isn't the RNG, but instead the difficulty curve. The game is always hard, but it goes from hard during the level 1 and 3 dungeons, to brutal in level 5 and insane in level 6 dungeons. The massive spikes in difficulty catch the average player off-guard and once a level 5 dungeon is started for the first time with the usual crew and they get demolished, discouragement is had and RNG is blamed when in fact it was their lack of preparation. In level 1 dungeons you can pick any composition you want, and still succeed. You could go in with 4 of the same class, all with no trinkets and still complete the quest. During level 3 quests, you need to mix up your roster a bit and start thinking about good class combos but it's still straightforward and can be tank and spanked. Then comes level 5 dungeons. I have a feeling once most players reach level 5 quests is when they start blaming "RNG" and stop playing out of frustration. The difference in difficulty between a level 3 and a level 5 dungeon is immense. In level 5 dungeons, your party composition is extremely important. You need to have a clear idea of what each class brings to the table along with their strengths and weaknesses. It's no longer a zerg rush where all your attacks land and you can just go full offense. Debuffs need to be applied. Stuns are your friend. Movement skills become necessary. You must camp at the right time. Your trinket selection is  vital.  All of these mechanics aren't new, but they weren't really a factor until now. Once you figure out how to correctly utilize all of the mechanics the game has to offer, level 5+ dungeons become "easy" again.So in conclusion Darkest Dungeon is not the unfair game with imbalanced RNG that the "most helpful" reviews would like you to think it is. It is a beautifully difficult game that has steep learning curves. These nightmarish creatures can be felled! They can be beaten! Confidence surges as the enemy crumbles!TL;DRDarkest Dungeon has fair RNG. It is the most fun you'll have while simultaneously wanting to rip your hair out. Buy it.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												This a great little turn-based RPG. It has the very basic premise of the player taking control of a group of heroes and exploring the corrupted locations (read: dungeons) around the hamlet in which he is based. Success leads to the hamlet being improved, the heores becoming more powerful, and the story slowly unfolding.It is a very hard ironman roguelike, so be prepared for the losses and setbacks. Whilst it is technically impossible to lose, you can be set back by a large amount in one game. There are a lot of threads in the forums about the brutal difficulty level and you just have to accept that things are just out of your control on occaision. That occaision could lead to you losing your favourite hero before you realise, and it is an ironman game, so dead is dead.This game is one of the most successful in setting the right atmosphere. The stylish Cthulhu mythos, brilliant hand drawn artwork and pitch perfect narration all contribute, imparting the right feeling of despair and struggle. It all enhances the game to elevate it from a good game into a great game.Positive:The atmosphere is absolutely fantastic. The narration deserves awards.The game is addictive, well designed, and a joy to play.The simple design hides a depth that later leads to deeper tactics and hero synergies.Good learning curve. Forgiving at the start, but punishing if you do not bring your A-game to the later levels.The achievements are good fun to attempt to gather, and increase the longevity of the game.Negative:The RNG can be brutal, in a stacked game. You have to fight hard and enjoy the little victories.The gameplay can feel repetitive, and the grind, whilst enjoyable, can still be a grind. In recent patches the developers have been working with the community to balance this, and it is pretty much there.A few of the hidden achievements reward spectacular failure, and may even require specific hunting, so really could be considered anti-achievements...Notes:Be warned. This game has a very volatile and vicious community that is split right down the middle. This is due to a disagreement in the community about how the game progressed through development. Just recommending this game has earnt me the enmity of thousands of players.

The art direction is fantastic and the gameplay is really exciting and difficult as you learn more of the mechanics. It takes a LOT of time. The game is difficult and grindy but hey, thats what makes it what it is. I can see how this might get tiresome after leveling multiple parties to 6 to do the Darkest Dungeon levels but as far as difficult games go this is my favorite (it just took me some getting used to not worrying about killing off all my lowbie characters since im used to being protective of any rpg characters im playing as or guiding). This game is incredibly promising and theres a lot of negative reviews based on mechanics that were put into the game on purpose, which should not throw you off if everything else about it peaks your interest.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												There's so much good about this game I'm not sure where to start... But I'll do my best.First of all, the game has fantastic storytelling and narration. The meloncholy voice confessing his sins and warning you about what might be ahead really leaves you in a sense of suspense, and it really keeps that dark, end of the world type of tone in the game, where you otherwise might just think "Oh it's time to skip into the dungeon and loot it again!"Second of all, the game is, for the most part, very fair. People often complain about RNG, but this often causes their defeat because they become too comfortable with smooth runs, and aren't prepared for the worst when it finally happens. While a hero dying is permanent, you'll often be given so many chances to save them. A hero can never been one-shot, in any circumstance. Instead, they enter death's door, where every hit beyond that has a chance to kill them permanently(If you want to understand this mechanic further, please research it online, there's plenty of info.)Thirdly, the art. The art looks fantastic! It really drips with that Lovecraftian feel. The characters all look really unique, and the locations are as eerie as ever.Of course, the game also comes with the unique stress system. While it is the idea that's supposed to keep the game so unique and seperate from others, it actually feels more like a secondary health bar. You try to keep it under control, and it will sometimes require maintenance outside of the dungeon, because your heroes do not instantly go to 0 stress after a mission, while they will fully heal afterwards(odd, eh?)The only negative thing I can say about the game is that it feels like it hangs around a little longer than neccessary. With a lot of skill, you can clear the game in a reletively short time, but the endgame is extremely difficult, and unless you find the information online, will probably consist of some trial-and-error. The problem is, because the permadeath, you'll find yourself having to re-train heroes from step 1 to retry the final dungeon. This can make the length feel a bit inflated for anyone unable to overcome that final hurdle.Overall, I'd say the game is fantastic, though I bought it on sale, I feel it was completely worth $15.PS: I normally despise turn-based games that don't involve 3D movement.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								"There once was a plague doctor named Pancevolt. She proved to be an invaluble member of the team she worked with. Her skill in alchemy was unrivaled, and even the mightiest foes quivered at how she killed her opponents: making the enemy ill, and cutting them down if the other members of the party didn't do it before her. The team was glad to have her with them.But even the best fighters are not invincible.During one fateful expedition, the plague doctor was poisoned to death...a truly ironic fate, indeed. Her team was devestated. A fellow teammate, Dismas, lost all hope. He resorted to drinking, made even worse since he was a known cheat at gambling. The bottle was his only friend until he finally accepted that his friend was gone, and she was never coming back.The party has never been the same since. However, the people she worked for still carries on her legacy. They will finish what they started...for Pancevolt...."You'd probably think the above is a sob story I made up, but this actually happened to me in the game. Expect the same kind of thing to happen to you during your playthrough, as it is pretty much unavoidable given the game's unforgiving nature. Think of it as the Dark Souls of turn-based dungeon crawlers; except all deaths are final. Any sort of small mistake can potentially screw you over; especially when your fighters can actually go insane is they become too stressed, or even straight up have a heart attack if it goes too far beyond that.This game will kick your♥♥♥♥♥ It will not apologize. It will even keep a graveyard with a list of those who have died. I often have to abandon missions because I fear for the lives of those I put in the party.I ♥♥♥♥ing love it for that.If you don't like difficult games, don't bother with this one. For those of you like a challenge, however, you should AT LEAST try this game. I can guarantee you will not regret it, unlike the countless expeditions you will go on where party members will inevitably die trying to reach their objective. If you're a hardcore gamer like myself, or even casual gamers that may want to test their dungeon crawling skills, I cannot recommend this one enough.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Can't stop... playing... this game.One of my first ever experiences delving into a Roguelike game. It was brutal at first, even daunting and futile until you get your♥♥♥♥♥whipped enough to realize it's not just the game being complex and difficult - it's you failing to learn and pay attention to the finer mechanics involved. From the specific text dialog in interactive prompts that give you a hint, to the varying degrees of provisions, management, and enemies you may encounter. Monsters and bosses scale and change with dungeon progression, as do the workings that govern and inhabit each of these places.  If there is ONE game that has done replayability correctly, it's this one. There are so many variables to take into account at every turn of this game that it's never the same, and there is always something new to experience and learn. I will say that there is A LOT of management involved if you are going to play this game 'correctly'. Every aspect of this game has things you may CHOOSE to manage and take into account. You can do the basic necissities, but you're going to feel the burn when you took your Plague Doctor with 4 bad quirks related to the dungeon you just entered, and you didn't have enough money for a satisfying quantity of both torches and shovels. Or completely forgetting that you can change  skills while you camp, and abilities when you're out of combat before a crucial fight. There is much to cover if you want to consistently maximize your effectiveness at every stage; alot but never too much. An important and well struck balance in roguelikes.  This game will test your wits, and challenge your attentiveness with: money, hero, and ability managamenet, limited inventory space, hero stress and health, trinkets, virtues and quirks which effect stats positively and negatively respectively. The list goes on and on. The more you play, the more you learn to manage if you want to stay one small step ahead of the challenges in this game. It's exhilerating. When you do things right and keep up with the learning curve it's a great feeling of triumph and understanding. You take that with you far enough until you foolishly bring two level 1's on a rank 3 dungeon and get your Legend Crusader sent to graveyard because you thought the game got easy all of a sudden. I could go on about this, but instead you should probably just buy and play this game and save me the time. Currently this game in my mind stands as 9.5/10 and this is still early access, with 2 major content areas still to be added along with loads more features, and improvements. The art is great, the narrator is awesome and even though you hear him a lot it really never gets old. There are times in the game I swear the developer put in small hidden scripts that respond to certain optional choices you make.This game is a ravenous evolving beast that wants you dead.

Early Access Review
								So I have had a journey with this game, I bought it from my own curiosity and the reccomendation from a friend and I was looking forward to playing it. The first labtop I tried it on the game crashed from startup and no matter what my friend and I tried it would'nt work so I was at a loss untill I tried a different labtop. This is where it gets interesting the labtop ran the game, hooray, but my joy was short lived as all the background, skill icons, and map were invisible, still usable but not able to be seen, but I continued on anyway playing the game. After putting in over 30 hours unable to see most of the game and being at a severe disadvantage in a already hard game I have one thing to say ... I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS GAME in all its entirety and the only way it could get better for me is if my bug gets fixed or new expansions happen. This game is brilliant and I recommend it to anyone looking for a difficult rogue like game that has a beautiful art style and ask of them to look past any of its early development flaws.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								     For the little time that I've spent on this game, there's always a little part of me that was wishing it was playing something else. Something easier. Something less depressing. Something that didn't get my nymphomaniac hero stuck in a brothel for more than two weeks... and didn't even relieve him of all his stress.     Honestly, this game is hard. Dark Souls hard. It wears on your resolve and eats at your patience like cancer. The reason you come back, though, is cause you know it can be beaten. The stress system develops characters' traits in a way I've never seen before, and you start to weave stories in your head about how and why the character ends up with those traits through the sparsely animated combat scenes. On top of the gorgeous artwork and ominous narration, this game provides a lot of atmospheric pleasure and just the right amount of difficult to keep you coming back for more. 8.9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Dismas was the first to die. His bones shattered like so many dreams upon the club of a Pig man.Next was Raynauld. In his time praying at the Abbey, he had witnessed true horrors, and refused to return. His own mind betrayed him in the bowels of the Weald. Next up was a Leper that went by the name of DuFrask. Dufrask was everything anyone could want in a leader, save for his nasty habit of cheating while Gambling. He was Sturdy, and a seasoned Weald Explorer. In stressful situations, he would bend like the willow but cut deep like the bramble. He lead multiple fools through the depths of the abyssal caverns beneath the estate, many died, but many rose to glory.In my hubris, I told DuFrask that he would be taking a regiment of men to face off against the Wizened Hag who'd taken up residence there. Much like the fools who still came to this town thinking they'd find anything but despair and death, I allowed myself a small portion of Hope. I see now that this was a mistake.DuFrask was accompanied by two other veterans of the caverns; Laci the Jester and Millith, a Vestal, as well as a newer edition to my regiment of explorers, Holland, a Bounty Hunter of few words.To make a long story short; it was a nightmare.Millith was killed almost as soon as we'd stepped foot in the dungeon. Like the fool I was, blinded by my own pride in my best warrior, I pushed on, ignoring the warning Millith had given us with her death, "We are all doomed!" Without healing, Laci was soon to follow the Vestal's example.DuFrask and Holland pushed on into the dungeon, but we never did find the hag. DuFrask was slaughtered by the repeated assault of several corpses, leaving only the Bounty Hunter standing after all was said and done.With no foreseeable chance of victory, I pulled Holland out and we returned to our dreary home above. He cloistered himself soon after that, and I did not hear from him for a week. When he finally returned to me, he was a changed man. This dungeon, it does not simply end when you leave its blackened halls. The darkness, the suffering, the pure malice of it stays with you, haunts you. Your mind is the one dungeon you can never escape.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fantastic game-Very difficult and frustrating. You will fail frequently.-Highly replayable, with varied mission types and enemies-Lot's of different character classes to experiment with-A great sense of accomplishment with each survived mission-Very engaging art and music sets quite a moodThe turn-based combat is a very entertaining balancing act.  Just when you think you've got the enemy on their heels, they throw something new at you.  Getting unlocks is truly rewarding because you have to work hard for them and frequently lose heroes doing so.  Team management requires timing (who rests for how long and where) and attention to resources, as well as a fine awareness of each character's perks and disabilities (which evolve over the course of the game).  The Lovecraftian dungeon exploration theme is wrapped in Mignola-esque, heavily inked art and set to a dark, oppressive soundtrack.  I'm really excited to see where the developers go from here, which is rare for early access.  I can't recommend it enough.

Early Access Review
								This game has not only had a great deal of thought go into preventing you from cheating to save your most beloved hero (no re-load from previous save here 10/10).  It is also a exceptionally challenging turn based dungeon crawler that makes you plan and think ahead as best you can.  There are so many aspects that affect the combat and your heroes.  There is a lot to see and do here.  The developer has also done a great job of making the dungeons feel dark and perilous.  The narrator is brilliant too with a foreboding H.P Lovecraftarian style.  I have a great deal of praise for this game.  If you were a D&D or AD&D player back in the good old days; get this game!  You will love it! 10/10  P.S  Early access and not a single bug, crash or issue in sight.  Plays perfectly every time.

												This game has a lot of potentional and feels like the devs put a lot of time in it, but it suffers from tedious grinding and a lot of RNG. People will tell you that this is the "Dark Souls of dungeon crawlers" but it's simply not. Surely both games are hard and can be comperable in that way but Darkest Dungeon is more of a frustrating experience and it gives very little room to learn something from your mistakes. As mentioned before the game is VERY grindy, things will quickly get a lot more expensive and you'll have to rely on safely grinding money and heirlooms with low level parties to be able to treat and upgrade your stronger heroes. If you check the global achievements stats you can see that only about 1% of the game owners have completed the game.. That alone means that the game is rather messed up.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												The game is novel and kudos to them for coming up with a brand new IP and new game mechanics. That being said I think the game ultimately falls a little flat in how repetetive the grind becomes. There is a lot of nuance and plenty of things you could say about whether the grind is thematic or acceptable or expected or what, but ultimately it is what turned me off of the game. You spend time and effort building up your team only for RNGesus to take it away, and then you are literally looking at hours trying to build a team back up again. Thematic or no, it quickly gets boring and tedious.I don't like the "do you recommend or not" binary choice here. If you don't mind grind then by all means go for it, it's a great game. If grind bothers you then I'd stay stay away.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Few games on my playlist have such debate or "salt" in the forums... then again, just shows how varied the playerbase is for this game.Generally three camps; 1) people love it, 2) a few people loath it, or 3) the neutral switzerland of the bunch.... the silent majority that just actually play the game and stays away from the forums.I try and stick with the third bunch, its a game I jumped into thanks to seeing good streams - a better option of seeing how you'd like a game rather than these "reviews" lolFor me, its a 'little and often' game - I play a few hours pretty often; it does have very frustrating moments, the good, bad and ugly.It runs smooth and is a nice little dungeon crawler that ups the difficult and certainly falls into the resource management, with some grinding for funds, the stress, the food 'clock', and the RNGness, which after playing solidly can get annoying, and for new players just starting, is pretty naff... but once you get a good pace and varied roster of 'heroes' a few hours in, it evens out and you'll be ok :)But for a couple of hours play after a day of work, it works really well. The atmospherics are brilliant, the narration perfect; few other games I have had such atmosphere! Maybe Hand of Fate :PIgnore the salt, check out plays on videos and try it out for yourself; the worst case is you'll just refund it :)

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic in so many ways. What if at some point darkness was unleashed and there wasn't some super powerful ally of goodness and justice to just squash it under foot? This is that game. A game where adventurers go in and almost none return alive. It covers the stresses of dungeon crawling that no other game comes close to. Your adventurers get stressed as things go wrong, gain diseases from rifling through graves, and get cursed when messing with relics and shrines. There's so much more other than "did you bring enough potions". You need to worry about food, affliction cures, does my party compliment each other, do I have enough shovels to go through obstacles quickly, do I have enough torches so I don't lose sanity and hit chance too much. You also have limited carrying capacity and money to buy and carry all the gear and treasure you find. It's alot of fun managing all these different aspects. You also need to choose where to place your heroes/adventurers for your delve into the dungeon. There are four spots in total for both you and the enemy so choose wisely as to who goes where.I bought this game about a week after it was put up on steam and have been reading the patches as they come out as well as tinkering with the things they fix/change. Alot of the reviews I have read currently are about how unnecessary some of the new mechanics are. However, when you start a new game you can choose to turn off corpses and heart attacks (the two main reasons people are upset). Play the game and if you don't like them you can restart and turn off the ones you don't like.Let's talk about the corpse and heart attack features so that you can be informed about them before starting.The corpse mechanic is where after an enemy or hero dies, their corpse will appear in the square where the monster/hero used to stand. This is great because in this game there are abilities that rely on the position of the enemy and yourself. One example is the Plague Doctor class. She has an ability called Plague Grenade that she can only cast from the last two spots and that can hit the enemies last two spots. Another ability is Noxious Blast which can be used from the last three spots and can hit the enemies front two spots. Now here's something important, each class has seven abilities BUT they can only take four of those abilities at a time. You can swap them out in town but not in a dungeon so you want abilities that compliment your party composition and the placement of that particular adventurer. So if you stick the Plague Doctor in the back you want abilities she can use back there. The reason corpses were implemented is that when an enemy (or one of your heroes) died, the positioning of each hero/enemy would shift one spot forward in order to fill their spot. This would cause abilities to no longer be effective as the enemy is no longer where your ability can hit them or your hero is no longer in a position where they can use them. So if an enemy in the front died and all the enemies moved forward a square, the Plague Doctor will be unable to hit one target with her Plague Grenade as there is only one enemy in the last two spots. Another class that benefited from this is the bounty hunter which has a couple abilities that force move the enemies around. This new mechanic of corpses allows those abilities to be used and not just passed over for min/maxing your damge, now you have to strategize a little bit.The other mechanic, Heart Attacks, are an interesting feature because it used to be that your heroes could keep adventuring even after they went insane and lost all hope. This only applied a negative to their stats or ability to act so you could keep pushing onward disregarding an original mechanic, stress. Now however, you need to avoid actions that give stress (not eating, walking around in the dark, removing obstacles without a shovel, having stressed people in your party, etc.) and start using items and skills that relieve stress as well as leaving stressed heroes in town to calm down. If a hero reaches 100 stress they will gain an affliction (debuff) or virtue (buff) as before but now instead of being able to stay stressed indefinitely, once a hero reaches 200 stress they have a heart attack and die. This really solidifies the necessity of proper stress handling. You need to know when to back out before your supplies and heroes can't take the crushing darkness any longer.I really hope this helped clarify some of the complaints you may see and allow you proper insight as to why some of these mechanics were introduced.10/10 recommend to anyone who enjoys a roguelike, dungeon crawl, strategy, or any mix of the three type of game. Be warned though, the game is difficult.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon (a Lovecraft inspired dungeon RPG) is a  turn-based battler with an overarching structure, and one idea that lifts it way above the ordinary. This is stress, the idea that people subjected to the kind of horrors that dungeon explorers go through might crack under the pressure. Each hero has their own stress meter, which is regularly added to by everything from it being too dark to the presence of a killer god, and when a tipping point is reached their mental fortitude is tested. In some cases they’ll respond favorably and inspire their compatriots but, far more often, the mind breaks.The game begins with a foreboding admonition. It’s a game about making the most of a bad situation, you’re told from the outset. Your actions are permanent, therefore the quests you embark upon will often end in failure. “Heroes will die,” it says. “And when they die they stay dead.” That's what is one of the most striking thing, how the rampant and merciless randomness always keeps one off balance, struggling to stay alive. It comes in both the usual accuracy percentages for various attacks and dodges, but also unexpected and unusual places - even the turn order is mixed up by behind-the-scenes dice rolls. So you’re never quite sure, for example, if your Vestal healer will be able to patch up your Crusader tank before the enemy can deal a killing blow, permanently removing that character and all his progress from your roster. By robbing you of the certainty and predictability you usually see in a turn-based tactics game of this nature, Darkest Dungeon creates tense and terrifying battles where you’re never sure what will happen next.Then there are quirks, which can positively or negatively impact a hero’s effectiveness in certain dungeons, or against certain enemies, or cause them to independently perform actions, including stealing any money you see in the case of Kleptomania, and each hero can have up to five positive and five negative traits. Keeping track of them all – your stable can hold up to 25 of them at once – is a big task.Consider Lovecraft. No, consider the anglerfish, that Lovecraftian nightmare of the deep with its sickly glowing lightbulb luring you in before the wretched face becomes visible. The tiny, melted eyes, the cruel underbite, and the thatch, not of hair, but of teeth. This is Darkest Dungeon, even before the fish people turn up and are troublingly untroubled by bleeding. This is a game that's horrid in a way that means that you can't look away, a game of exhaustion and luridness and of terrible things happening in an awful, awful place. In other words, it's just lovely.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Pros: Polish and design.Fantastic artwork that usually makes you forget it's basically paper dolls. Sound design so good, you want to keep hitting things just to hear the results.Narration that's simply delicious. Both the wording and delivery are like red meat that's been cooked rare and is f#$%ing you skillfully, but hatefully, in the ears. I would pay that guy to narrate my bathroom breaks.The content is so creative. Basic themes... a mix of fantasy and Lovecraftian horror... but the execution just oozes flavor and originality. I mean, The Leper is a front-line tank, and he can survive a lot because... he's really been through some sh!t, you know? Every element of the game is like that. A idea that's been developed, polished, tweaked, and polished more.Challenging. Strategic. Unforgiving. Constant choices with real consequences. Do you eat extra food in camp so you're at your best for the boss fight? Or do you skimp and hope to survive, so you can hang around for longer to scavenge afterward? Such great gameplay design. I've been playing this game since it was in Early Access, and it was so good then... they've since made significant updates (corpses, new heroes, new areas, etc.) that added depth without complexity. You know those great game ideas that everyone has that end up being far too complex and unwieldy to be fun? This is the perfect example of a simple game where the designer built up complexity, piece by deliberate piece, adding features because they WORKED instead of just being fun ideas, and in the end the gameplay is both complex and has incredibly good flow.Cons: It's addictive. Is that a con? If you don't stretch yourself and try new things, the game can start to feel repetitive. This can be the player's fault, for playing conservatively, but sometimes the best strategic choice really is to do yet another easy run to the Ruins. Which naturally feels grindy after you've done 20 times already. Though... you can still try new team compositions to keep it interesting. Learning how abilities and heroes work together is a long curve.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Ignore the whiny negative reviews that complain about Early Access. They're a mix of people complaining that the game changed too much, or not enough, and that has no bearing on how good the game is as it exists right now.tldr; it is DAMN GOOD right now.I played it in Early Access, but I was waiting for the full release to really dive in because I knew anything less was not 100% representative of what the final product would play like. A lot of other Early Access players seem to be struggling with that concept.So, what makes it good, DAMN GOOD, FANTASTIC even? The answer is simple:You are rewarded for paying attention to detail. In my first serious attempt at playing this game I made it to my 28th dungeon run without a single person dying, and only 10 out of a possible 112 ever suffered mental breaks during dungeons. A lot of those mental breaks, and my single death, could have been avoided if I were a better player with a little more experience and a little less willingness to try to kill a super special (optional) boss monster the first time I ran into one.Why did my teams survive so frequently? I paid attention to what classes were good at and formed teams that complimented each others strengths and weaknesses. I made sure they all had the correct skills assigned, and upgraded to their highest possible ranks before entering dungeons. I did the same with their Blacksmith upgrades and always gave them the best Trinkets I could, since the game has a handy "unequip all trinkets" button that makes giving each expedition your strongest Trinkets a trivial task. I did visit the wiki to figure out which Curios were in each area, and what "key" items were used to get the best results from interactions, but this is something anyone can figure out and memorize just by playing the game. No, more than any amount of wiki information, making good decisions based on paying close attention to detail is what saved *almost* all of my people (RIP that Jester).Anyways the videos will show you what kind of game it is, which is a turn based RPG that deals with the stress of being an adventurer. It handles the topic of mental health far better thant any video game about killing mutant pigs I've ever seen, as well. Your heroes don't have a "sanity" meter and they never "go insane". They have a Stress meter and they become Fearful, Abusive, Irrational, etc... but also possibly HEROIC.The theme is eldtrich horror, which is all about Lovecraftian tentacle monsters, ultimately. The game doesn't give up all the goods up front, though, and you'll run into a number of nastier / more unnerving baddies the further you get.The art is beautiful, and its direction is consistent throughout the game. The UI is very easy to work with. The sounds and especially the music and the Narrator's voice acting are top notch and do a lot to immerse you.11/10

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Beware before you buy this game Darkest Dungeon. Now do not misunderstand I love this game, but this is not for the faint of heart. This game is made to screw you over, and put you in the most terrible of situations, it all depends on how you prepare for it. Half this game is about planning, what to bring for the mission. Beware at naming your characters friends and family, as you’ll get attached and they will sometimes die. I mean heck I do it and I felt like a horrible person if I had to dismiss them or they were gruesomely killed. As I rewrite this I felt I wrote it unfairly. So getting further into the game, I will admit this is one game. There can be some improvements to the items and the cost of some upgrades.  It’s a brilliant game and just be careful. This is a gold standard to early access games, an exemplar, of the formula working. I love this game, even if it is a abusive relationship. odd I know but heck I love hard games. Positives+ Innovative gameplay, each class puts different talents on the table. Want a finesse fencing fighter, that can dodge blows and critical like mad; but is also flexible? Get a Grave Robber. Want a character who can both tank and heal? Grab a Crusader. Etc+ Art is exquisite, it fits the lovecraftian dark theme of hopelessness of it all. It has some inspiration from X-com meets dark souls. It has a dark graphic novel esthetic. + Sound design is great. It really has the disparity of it all. + Battle is refined, its form following function with every piece and detail, there is a huge amount of strategy, and you are forced to try out new classes, strategize. It’s satisfying. Be prepared to think on the fly.+ It has a high risk high reward game play, the further you are on the edge, the higher the intensity. You get this adrenaline rush when you succeed and get the epic loot at the end   + That announcer, I swear when he says: Confidence surges as the enemy crumbles. Makes me just bloodthirsty when you crit. +It fits the dungeon theme right, they are terrifying, full of risks, and they are the dark secrets of the world. Those whom dare to explore them they will find great relics and wonders, but also the world’s greatest horrors. A dungeon is not a place to get free riches, they are a test of your perseverance and will. Negatives -    This Game is not fair, it will put you in the most horrible situations that are unwinnable-    A lot of your attacks is a roll of the dice, same as the enemies so they can one hit kill you. Combat can be just risky at times. -    Have no emotional attachments to your team, it will only lead up to disappointment -    Be prepared to restart the game a lot….A lot. Salt will be common here-    Later weeks will become impossibly hard I got to week 70 and everyone died. No money and I am screwed.-    Dodging is a farce, as there will be moves that cannot dodge even with high dodge-    The enemies will always get initiative before you, and will always go first and sometimes they will cheat and hit you twice even if you have more speed. Yes I looked my perks and none of them were slow draw. -    There will be plenty of B.S parts where even common enemies will one hit kill you, no deaths door where you have a chance to save them, nope, they die-    Money and treasures are fickle, at times you will get almost nothing at times for going through a dungeon where surviving is your treasure, along with your team to be mentally intact.-    Bosses have instant one hit kill team wipes, they cannot be interrupted. Bypasses all armor and causes max stress.-    Even if you come prepared, you will still get your butt handed to you -    Stress is B.S at times where having a great virtue when maxed out stress and getting a good virtue is rare. There are times where a hero will refuse to be healed, as negative perks when max stressed will always happen. He is about to die and just gives up, the team then gets maxed out stress and one of them gets a heart attack. -    Murphy’s Law, the game. What Can go wrong will go horribly wrong. -    Enemies level up with you to rookie to veteran and they will always have better stats then you, I know a challenge to one thing but I feel that this game spikes up from hey let’s start you easy, to punching you in the stomach and shoving your face in the mud telling you: Know your place human. This game is Bipolar like that

Posted: April 30, 2016
												I can honestly say that this game is a lot of fun... at first at least. The real downfall for me is that your heroes plateau too soon. I won't say the game is too hard, I'll just say that there is too much variability in each expedition. The random factors in this game can make it so that the exact same team, same strategies, etc. can win easily or fail miserably in the hardest dungeons. By the time I got to the Darkest Dungeon, I realized that I'd reached the point of diminishing returns for entertainment value. I managed to collect all the trophies (from high tier bosses), but I didn't finish the Darkest Dungeon — and I won't finish the Darkest Dungeon, because once you get to the Darkest Dungeon it's just not fun anymore. (Sorry not sorry.)I complained a lot here, but I'll say that the game really stands out as something different. Heroes in this game are paper plates for the banquet, and you can't get attached to any of them, because I guarantee you any hero you use frequently will fall victim to a catastrophic critical at some point. If you like challenging games, look no further. I would recommend you look at some Darkest Dungeon rage videos on YouTube before you start playing this, because this is not for the ill-tempered.Long story short: Prepare to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												I am not a big fan of harsh games. Dark Souls, for instance, is nor my cup of tea. And I must confess that I was initially discouraged by some of the reviews, which pointed out that the game was difficult, unforgiving, and severely luck based. Despite that, I decided to give it a try, and so far I must say it is well worth it. It is a hard game, that is for sure. Your characters are always affected by some debuffs and afflictions, and it doesn't get any easier as you progress. I don't think there ir an error with the probabily calculations of attacks in the games. The fact is: the challenges are really hard. Sometimes uneven. It is hard to see a good and developed character die, but so far i haven't faced any situation where the death couldn't be understood by the battle situation. And it is wrong to say it is luck based. Of course, there is a chance aspect, as in any other game, and in real life as well. But there are several strategy element in the way you build your party for a quest, which is affected not only by their skill, but theri equipment, and even their positioning within the party. Having said that. I still think they could either tone down a little the difficulty, or at least tone up the rewards you get by completing quests.But it a good choice for ppl interested in a squad strategy game with some rpg elements.

								An extremely difficult and very challenging game, but I jcan't help but keep coming back for more. It's challenge adds to it's amazingly gloomy and dark atmosphere (which is furthered even more by the phenomnal narrator), which really sets the tone for the entire game.
