Definitely recommend this to anyone who likes turn based RPGs, and wants a good challenge, with a great atmospheric setting.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
Pros:- Beautiful game. The art style, music and creepy narrator all add to a gripping and enjoyable experience- Lots of depth between the different character classes, enemy types, itemization and dungeons- Extremely satisfying to finally crush everything in the game when you're experienced enough to know howCons:- Way too much grind. People say the game takes 80 hours to finish and that's about right. At 20 hours you'll have mastered the basics, 40 seen almost everything there is to see, 60 you'll have mastered the game in it's entirety and you'll spend the last 20 getting enough characters to run the final dungeon several times. This could have easily been cut in half with some simple changes to how you gain gold and experience and the game would have benefited from it- Too much reliance on RNG for me. When you run into situations where you start a battle, all enemies take thier turn first, focus on your weakest guy, crit him for all his life and he dies before you get a turn it's kind of an issue.- Minor issues with certain mechanics like some a town building taking trinkets from you when others dont, making it much less useful. Some confusion between the both fixed number and percentage based stat system, sometimes it one, sometimes it's the other but either way isn't straightforward with the way they actually work.Rating: 4.5/5I'm giving Darkest Dungeon a near perfect rating because for a game from a small indie company this has been one of the better games I've played in a long time. Both the setting and learning curve give off a very Dark Souls or Bloodbourne vibe and that's very hard to achieve. First the game will build you up with some victories, then it'll punish you and kill your hard earned characters, then you'll learn what you did wrong and when you finally get that 'aha' moment of gameplay it's the best feeling in the world, very similar to how you play Dark Souls the first time. By the end of the game I was plowing through every enemy with any party combination and it was a great feeling to see how far I'd come from being scared to enter each room of an easy beginner dungeon.There's several things to learn in the game and almost all of it comes from trial and error. First there's a second type of health bar for each character called stress. Take too much stress damage and they start to go insane, ignoring your orders or giving up their turn completely. Take much more stress on top of that and they have a heart attack with a change to straight up die. Managing the balance between hp and stress is the first challenge. Then there's the different classes and their skills, how those classes interact with each other, itemization and how those work to boost your abilities, the dungeons themselves with the layouts and encounters they provide, enemy types and how they work together and then strategy on what you need to prioritize in order to not die horribly.DD isn't without it's issues however and the grind is probably one of the biggest for me. I could hardly believe people when they said the game takes around 80 hours to learn and complete. How can a game with not a lot of content take that long? Well several things hold you back and grinding for gold and experience is one. Every time you lose a high level character on a long run because you were inexperienced, greedy, stupid or RNG decided to screw you it can take 5-10 hours to level up and grind the gold for 1-4 new characters to get back to max level... Without the beautiful artwork, great music and creepy narrator I probably wouldn't have been able to see the game through to the end but those aspects pull the game up significantly. I'm a huge fan of the art direction and and the animations are always a joy to watch even after so many hours of playing. Overall Darkest Dungeon is an experience I think many people will be turned off from at first but is absolutely worth toughing out to the end. Much like Dark Souls (I know the comparison keeps coming up) it's a game that you need to dive head first into and endure the frustration to really begin to enjoy. Without a lot of word of mouth and 'trust me trust me you'll learn it' from friends I fear many people won't give this game a chance but I'll be that person now. Trust me, get your♥♥♥♥♥in the dungeon and don't come out until every malformed, slobbering, chittering monster is annihilated!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Now that I'm just short of 40 hours played and taking on long champion runs, I wanted to give my own review. Note that I played the early access versions for less than an hour each time, mostly because I would immediately find a class, stack it, and blow through every encounter using the same ability over and over. That was indescribably boring.This version *appears* to not have any obvious single-class stacks in it, and corpses have taken care of a lot of the issues with overefficient AoE skills. So now that I felt like there was a game to play, I dove into it headfirst!Mechanically, the difficulty level follows a vague u-shape with a long tail. At the start, it feels hard. You gain a few upgrades, and it feels easy. Then you hit the next tier of dungeon, Veteran level, and the upgrades and trinkets feel woefully underpowered or too expensive to upgrade The risk-reward seems to favor the game, and I can see why it'd become discouraging if you are forced out of your comfort zone around the same time that the game can nearly instakill a character. This I suspect is the cause of most of the negative reviews, and it's a well-deserved criticism. There is a middle point where the hill is rather steep and you could lose 20+ hours of invested characters on a bad dice roll.However, do a little thinking. In the apprentice dungeons, you could simply win by sheer damage and tankiness. You would outlast and destroy the enemy. In the veteran dungeons, the enemy begins to outpace you. So you must change up your style.First, pick up some mitigation to go with your damage. Debuffs and stuns are critical for holding down the front line while you clear the backline. Find a character who is flexible across a shuffle and make sure to have at least a backup plan on your skill upgrades so that you don't spend two turns moving everyone back. Get a debuff to remove protection or pick up some heavy blight and bleed. Get camping skills to clean up stress, even just before you get back to town.And finally, maybe most important, stop going on short and medium missions. They pay you far less money than long missions and they are not significantly easier.Selecting the right camping skills allows you to refresh your party every time you use some firewood. This means that on a long mission, you're guaranteed two to three times as much fighting in the field, two to three times as much field treasure, and the size of the mission is not three times bigger. Long missions also have guaranteed secret rooms, so find ways to buff your scouting and bring a few keys.Want to clear bad quirks? Guess what, long high-level missions are more likely to have the curios that combine with provisions in order to kill negative quirks.To put it another way, if a long mission pays you another 2.5k for winning, that's like finding another trapezohedron just for playing on that mission that week. And if you have to abandon, you've spent a lot more time playing and will be leaving with far more goodies in your pocket.Finally, 1.5k gold is worth less than 6 deeds in the early game. Stop ditching heirlooms for gold. Take longer missions, make up your gold with the quest rewards, and pick up all the heirlooms you can find until your buildings are fully upgraded. Every building upgrade is more money in your pocket in future weeks.Once you start setting up combos in your trinkets, combos in your party, building in flexibility and playing to the innate efficiency of longer missions, you'll start to crush your way out of the difficulty hump mid-game. Not to say that it becomes easy. You'll still face the risk of RNG death. But at least you'll always have the resources to recover and push onward towards bigger challenges yet.Thus, having come to terms with what Darkest Dungeon is like, I get why some people were unhappy with the random unfairness, but I feel it's all perfectly conquerable. My guess is that it'll take me another 20 hours minimum to approach beating the game the first time, and that I'll be far more efficient with my time on the second run.If you have a mind for this kind of thing, Darkest Dungeon will be a ton of fun. It's tense, you have to gamble a lot, and you'll probably have some serious setbacks to overcome.On the flipside, it will take a ton of time to finish, most people won't even reach a veteran mission (let alone a champion mission), and a failure could be very frustrating, making the recovery feel like a grind instead of a game. If you want something to sit down and play casually, this might not be your cup of tea.Last caveat. If you're EXTREMELY good at this kind of game, DD will certainly have cracks in the design, and you'll abuse them and suck the fun out of your experience. I haven't found one yet, but I'm sure they're out there. For this rare class of player, there are more technical, in-depth games.All that said, yes, it's a great game, I'm having a blast, and I recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												It feels good to have a game to really challenge you but at the same time have so many possible choices that you're not limited to a meta. There is a lot of trial and error to it, but it's a lot of good fun once you start to figure out how to finally rip all of the skeletons and Eldritch horrors apart instead of the other way around.The art style and overall mood of the game is fantastic too if you're into that Tim Burtinesque spooky vibe. Even made by the same folks (Klei) who put Don't Starve together, and that one was also well worth the hours spent until my character was slain.If you're an RPG fan, love a good challenge, and want to crawl some dungeons. Pick this up. Lots of cool bosses to try, tons of class combinations and skills to fine tune your party, and the narrator has a morbid, tongue-in-cheek way of pulling you into the world.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Overall I enjoyed and recommend this game.  In my opinion its later levels are too dominated by randomness and grinding, and with the stakes as high as they are (permanent loss of characters and items that took immense time investment to get that far), that randomness starts to feel very cheap and oppressive.  That turns into tedious play, and the game stops being as fun in the end.There are ways to play that help to mitigate the RNG threat, but you'll never be free from bad rolls of the dice totally hosing your progress.  This is the disadvantage of a game like this -- the main (and most tempting) tool for upping the difficulty is easily overused.  I suspect this is a game I will never finish, simply because I cannot dedicate the time to it, and because tedium isn't fun.  I've been playing champion dungeons for about 10+ hours now, and I'm kinda tired of it.  Further, I'm told the final dungeon has even more tricks to artificially lengthen the game and force you to grind even more.  I'm just not up for that.  :(Don't get me wrong... The game can be grindy or infuriating at times, but overall it's been a fantastic experience.  That's why it gets a thumbs-up from me.  The experience falls apart in later levels and I'm disappointed by that, but I've had enough fun with the game that I cannot justify down-voting it just because of a poor end game.  The theme and mechanics treated me *very* well through most of the game, and it delivers fantastically before the RNG and grindy issues start to really hurt.Unless you're a completionist who would feel very uncomfortable walking away from the game before the end, then I greatly recommend this game.  Up until the end stages, it's hard in a fair and reasonable way, and you feel very smart when you figure out ways to mitigate the threats and have mostly successful runs.  The severe penalty of failure only sweetens success.  There are ways to make forward progress in the late game, but they're too slow for me and I've moved on to other games; please see other reviews' coverage of that content.Pros:-Fantastic Theme and Presentation.  This kept me coming back even when I was frustrated.-Very Interesting and Fun Mechanics.  Again, I kept coming back because the design is compelling, and I wanted to try out new ideas and strategies (which you can do easily in early levels).-I sank lots of hours into this game and don't regret themCons:-Steep Learning Curve.  Game does very little to teach you, and expects you to learn by doing.  This is pretty harsh given the sharp penalties of failure, though you can always recover (early game is pretty easy to bounce back).  But it can be difficult to learn the system without getting your rear handed to you an awful lot until it's discouraging.  I recommend checking the guides & wiki from time to time, if not often.  (and some guides are very out of date, so be careful)-Late game is dominated by grinding and randomness, and it's difficult & tedious to minimize those issues.  You're stuck playing a certain "correct" way, and it quickly becomes tiresome and unrewarding.-I'll probably never finish this game, and at this point I'm okay with that.  With my time so limited, I have to know when to call it quits.Overall: Good.  I recommend you pick it up.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I started playing Darkest Dungeon without knowing how it was balanced and designed on release.A few reviews for this game relate to the changes that have been made over time and the state it now is in.There seem to be many complaints about the fun factor having changed and the game beeing unfair and frustrating. Well I had now a good 30 hours of fun with the game. So far it demanded a lot from me in terms of:1. Ressource Management2. Party Setup3. Battle tactics4. My own greed and will to finish a run1. Ressource ManagementMoney is short and at best I accumulated 20000 Gold. I had to get inventive with my party setup and made sure I healed as much stress as even possible with the jester, houndmaster, crusader or via camp before leaving the quest. I had to pass on healing quirks which were either not relevant to be healed (like ranged malus on a pure melee character) or not that grave. 2. Party SetupBefor every run I spend about 5 to 10 minutes deciding which item i take along and which characters will do the job. Taking to account which enemies I will encounter and what my battle tactics will be for this run. There are tons of nice combinations and some that are just not a good option :D 3. Battle tacticsGoes hand in hand with the Setup. Once you are in battle and your party is for example not equiped with a stress healer like the hound master or jester you put hard focus on any enemy that inflicts pure stress damage. 4. My own greedIs key...Letting low level characters die in a dungeon is not a big deal and pushin forward is only rewarding. But well trained and equipped characters.. when all vanquished.. is just the worst.Summa summarum:The game is super fun. Good atmosphere. Graphics do their job and fit the game and the narrator is just epic. At some point I wished for even more variation in the narration just because you heard it all at some point but nevertheless genius.I recommend this game to:- Indie and Fantasy-RPG genre game fans- Round-based, dungeon crawling and Build-up simulation gametype fans- People with a taste for uncommon audio and visual settingAfter all everyone will make his/her own experience with the game and this is just a very very small view into how I experienced the game.

Early Access Review
								I feel it calling to me as I write this.  Once, I was as you are now.  Pondering the purchase of this game.  I saw the screenshots.  I read the reviews.  I thought I knew what I was getting myself into.  This hubris would be my undoing.  I believed myself above the other gamers who had gone before me, that this game had chewed and spat out raving mad.  Seconds become minutes becomes hours become days.  Still this game won't let me be.  One more mission.  One more attempt to carve order out of chaos.  It is always one more something.  I wish I could warn you away.  If you could see my bloodshot eyes, my pale countenance...maybe that would be enough to convince you to pass this game by.  But hah, you have my same arrogance, don't you?  You believe that you can conquer this game that has conquered me.  You've been warned.  Always remember that you were given that, at least.  When you've been driven to my neighborhood of crazy, I will be glad to give you the tour.  We are always looking new faces here...

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												The atmosphere and art style is great. The gameplay is also fun. It's not a bad game. The problem is I'm 13 hours in and I've had enough because I know what to expect from the game. I found out online that you can't just use one party in the Darkest Dungeon. Once a party has cleared one level they'll refuse to ever go back. This means that you have to level up multiple parties to the highest levels. That's completely killed any desire I have to play the game. That's grinding for grinding sake. To me that's absolutely disrespecting my time as a player. I'm more than happy for the game to brutalise my party and kill of my favourite character unfairly,, I love the fact the heroes are disposable pawns, I can even tolerate how bad luck can destory a party. That's fun. But no game like this will ever endear me by arbitrarily deciding I can't use my party 'just because'. I'll happily lose a party I've built but I'm far from impressed the game just decides I can't use them. It's not challenging, it's not fun and it's designed to make me take longer to complete the game; screw that, especially in a game where bad luck can wipe out a party.If the idea of levelling up 3-4 parties doesn't bother you then I reccomend it. What I have played was a lot of fun but finding out the game just makes a party useless in such an arbitary fashion leading me to have to grind more has just killed any desire I have to play it. To me it's a deal breaker.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												This is more of a review of my general impressions. I'll leave all the details for guides or other reviewers. I was on the fence about this game for a long time, and finally decided to take a risk... it paid off! I really enjoy it! 10 hrs of gameplay as I write this, and one or two characters are level 3.Dungeons that remind me of adventuring when I played Dungeons & Dragons. Grim and difficult, and you usually left with a handful of hitpoints, but bags of treasure.A game that has economy of gold that isn't too difficult to manage for a penny-pincher, but an economy of Stress that makes you second guess if you should send some of your heroes back into the fight so quickly.The recruit aspect of the game feels a bit like XCOM, or Ogre Battle. I think building your teams is half the fun in games like this, and it's not too complicated.Leveling them feels a bit like Final Fantasy Tactics, actually. Rotating who gets to fight, and who doesn't, to build them all over time. But the combat works more like a classic RPG turn-based game.I've been waiting for a game that had this style of combat, but didn't look like it was made with RPG Maker.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												I won't go in details what Darkest dungeon is - if you are on this page, you already know about it. So:Do you like being punished? Do you like suffering? Soon you will either will love it like half of your heroes or you will go mad like the other half. Darkest Dungeon to me feels the same like the old times when I played World of Warcraft with my casual guild:1) You prepare for a hard dungeon/raid2) You think you are ready3) You storm it!Just to find our you were not prepared - you haven't bought enough food or torches, or bandages, you did not play out the best of your squad, you mis-clicked as you were already pretty frustrated with overwhelming (bad) outcome of battle or the RNG just hates you.Darkest dungeon is the turn-based Demon/Dark souls for the tactics lovers, who prefer thinking over reflexes but equally enjoy being spanked and shown how misarable things could get. It is risk vs. reward and it is a damn guilty plesure.So - what could you expect? - Suffering, losing your upgraded heroes who were just finishing the quest? Yes! But add to that amazing graphic style, witty narrator, 'Lovecraftian' feel of evil and tons of fun.Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 33 of 63 people (52%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I cannot recommend this game to you unless you meet a very small criteria of type of people.The other negative reviews hammer home the points. Certain classes are just better and the changes made over time with this game have not made it so those classes are stronger, at best, the strong classes became weaker or were changed in ways to make them weaker. When I first bought this game, I would take random parties for no light dungeon runs in order to make some quick cash for my main party to be able to afford some upgrades or be able to afford to prepare for a dungeon after buying a very good trinket. I came back to the game just today and have played for a few hours. I attempted what I did before with a little mix and match. It did not go well and not in an RNG sort of way. The party was just not effective and I abandoned the quest and them pretty quickly. Thus I was able to get back to my good party who was getting through dungeons with only minor problems and the occasional amount of stress reaching a moderate level where I would need to go to an off team to deal with the stress. The problem here is that it creates an absolute issue with regards to the classes. There are classes that are good and there are classes that are not. If you take the wrong classes, the game is hard. If you take the right classes, the game is not hard. Now I will say that the art, sound, and music are all top notch. They have been from the beginning. The story is Lovecraftian Horror, so think depressing. If you don't like the idea of a cosmic horror that is going to win no matter what and we are just delaying the inevitable. Do not play this game.Personally for me, I used to have fun experimenting with different parties and seeing whether they could scrape by while doing something that no sane real adventurers would do. That's not possible anymore and the design decisions all led here. I once told myself I wouldn't buy early access games anymore and this game reinforces that decision. Until I see the final product, I do not plan on buying most games.TL:DR This game might be for you if you like a game where there is one way to win and you like Lovecraftian Horror with a touch of RNG.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I've been playing this game not too long since the early access came out and have loved every minute of it. Building your town, your team, your collection is all so rewarding and you start to care about the characters you bring in. Losing one hurts and you'll sit there, shaking your head, upset that one of your best has just fallen, but then you get angry, take your next group, and rip the dungeon apart in an attempt to exact revenge. The stress mechanic is great, it keeps you on your toes to watch out for the well being of your team in fear that their mental stability will cost the team a critical move, or end up dying from a heart attack! Each dungeon has its own style and tricks, with certain enemies only appearing there. Including the enemies, each dungeon has a unique boss, each with their own arsenal of attacks and hidden tricks.Dark, creepy, with an art style that is amazing and a soundtrack that will cause goosebumps, this is something to get if you like a challenge. There is the option to turn off some of the aspects that make the game whole (if you find things too challenging), but I ask that you don't. Red Hook has provided an amazing game and it should be played the way they intended it to.

												This game is really fun to play, even when you are learning and absorbing the mechanics. It's challenging, but fair, as once you figure out the classes and their associated mechanics, you can learn how to deal with the challenge better. The art style is beautful, and the narrator's voice is fantastic. The game creates a gloomy yet awesome atmosphere, and never stops being fun. I always find myself thinking, "...just one more dungeon and then I'm done..."Due to the randomness, the depth and variety of classes, and the depth and variety of the RPG mechanics this game has massive replay value. This is worth your money. The developers of this game should get your money so they keep improving this game and making more.If you don't like challenging games, or play AAA titles on the easiest difficulty setting just for the story, or feel this compulsive need to click on everything then I do not recommend this game for you. However, it is not as hard and tedious as some people like to say.However, you should try it and make up your own mind.

								There's hard and there's frustrating.  Darkest Dungeon gives the illusion of difficulty while actually being frustrating and rigged.  The concept for the game is top notch.  A Cthulhu-madness-Dungeon-And-Dragons crossover!  The execution; however, will leave you wanting a refund of both your money and time.  There are three enormous issues that the gameplay can not overcome.  First, corpses.  Google it.  Incredibly poor game design.  Second, the weakness of each character's will makes their death a sigh of relief.  When your Brothel-diving-table-cheating-irrational-rabid Grave Robber finally kicks the bucket you're going to cheer... a lot.  Don't waste your hard earned money on a title that you want to hate to love but end up just hating.

dungeon setting is really cool and the misfit murder hobo heroes are fun,it really does have a ton of character.Sadly this game suffers from the strong vision of its creators, they wanna make a game true to the Cthullu mythosand that means, everybody is gonna go insane and die and well they kinda nailed it.A lot is said about the pro's and con's of RNG in games and in something like XCOM it's not so bad because you can stack things in your favor with strategy and careful play, DD doesn't really let you do thatall the planning in the world wont stop your whole team getting wiped out in single turn.and before I am told I suck and my opinion is dismissed, this did not happen to me for a fair whilemy graveyard was empty (though corpses and heart attacks went of right away, ♥♥♥♥ corpses are dumb) (even surviving an encounter with the Hag boss and finding that my team composition was totally unable to harm her, which felt like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to me, I should be able to use the combinations I enjoy) right up until today when I first entered the cove I sent my strongest team on the apprentice lvl 0 mission, the first fight was a lil rough but nothing too bad, but the second fight, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥the second fightI quickly suffered my first casualty and things are looking real bad, then an enemy exploded and put my whole team at deaths door facing enemies with 100% damage buffs,I ran and thats when I realised I did not have any bloody moneyand the meager progress I had made (I never felt like I was making much progress while playing, despite building what I thought were some strong heroes) seemed pretty much goneI think this game needs a difficulty selectan easy mode where you can actually feel like you are making progress and doing well.A normal mode which can be their original vision, untainted.And finally a super hard nightmare mode for all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who always say every game is too easy and they 100% it on the hardest difficulty in one day because its so pathetically easy (I don't know why these people even play games, they never seem to enjoy them)Also I will say that the art was actually kind of a let down, the opening intro is so freaking amazing but honestly most of the enviroments and the enemies are pretty lame, mushroom people, pig people, skeletons, fish people and just plain old people, a few designs aside they are mostly kinda dull and not very scary at all, I had expected more to be honest.TL:DR I wanted to like this game but I never actually had any fun, even while winning.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
tl;dr -> My main character got stressed out and nearly had a heart attack, so I put him in the tavern to relieve some stress. Now he's a chronic gambler and refuses to leave. 11/10 realistic vice simulator.Normally, I have a rule not to review early access titles until they have been officially released as a finished product, but I decided to make an exception for Darkest Dungeon (DD) because of the great feedback the game (and developers) have received. I received a review copy and was extremely interested to try DD because I love dungeon crawling and rogue-likes, and the title had already received massive acclaim for being true to both genres.The aesthetics are fantastic - the amount of detail in the character models and environment is very high. Each character's skills are flashy and cool to see. The sound effects and music are great at maintaining a dark, intense vibe - enhancing the rogue-like atmosphere and reminding you that you can die (forever!) at any moment. The story is unfinished, but what currently exists is fairly basic - you must travel through different dungeons, eventually reaching the main one. Many have tried, many more have failed. You will also fail. Many times.Controls are easy to learn and the tutorial helps explain every mechanic in the game. The learning curve is moderate to extreme depending on your experience with rogue-likes and turn-based strategy. The developers have done an exemplary job of communicating with the gaming community, going as far as adding an option to remove a newer feature - corpses (killing enemies would leave behind a corpse that had to first be destroyed before the lineup of enemies moves forward - many people found this annoying) and heart attacks (your characters could instantly die if their stress reached high levels). The tutorial is good at getting you ready for the madness that is the Darkest Dungeon. There are a lot of mechanics to keep up with (in particular, player stress), but there are always tooltips for everything, be it while you are inside or outside of combat. Furthermore, new elements - usually reflected by new buildings being available in your main camp - are introduced slowly, so you have time to get used to things before a new feature is added. The most challenging parts of DD will be managing your party stress and maintaining a balanced party structure (ex: you don't want to go into battle with 4 healers lacking any offensive abilities).Gameplay consists of you traversing through a dungeon, exploring rooms and the passageways between them. You must complete a main mission - like exploring 90% of the rooms or completing 90% of the room battles - before you can receive a reward and leave the dungeon. If you retreat early, your party will accumulate significant stress. Stress can be disastrous, as it will sometimes cause heart attacks (if the feature is turned on) and can cause people to panic (granting either a buff/debuff for the duration of the dungeon).Combat is intense and can be very, very challenging. Replayability is high because you can construct your 4-member party from a large pool of characters, randomized whenever you return to the main hub. You can build a roster, which is highly advised because you need to alternate between healing/recovering stress party members - this takes a game day (or longer) - and using them in battle. Perks and disabilities can become extremely annoying, as these are also randomized, and debilitating conditions (ex: kleptomania will cause a character to sometimes open items and keep them - preventing the items from going into your inventory) can only be removed if you spend a considerable amount of gold.During battle, you will take turns attacking your opponent, healing/buffing your allies, or using items. One of my favorite characters can transform into a werewolf, but it will cause stress to the other party members. If a party member reaches 0, they are downed and can be revived by others, however, if they are continually attacked, they will permanently die.Overall, the gameplay is rapid, unforgiving, and a lot of fun. I must admit, for an early access project, there is a lot of content to enjoy even if you were to buy DD as is (with no future updates). If you are a lover of rogue-likes, dungeon crawling, and turn-based strategy, then you must try this game.Highly recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue ReviewsMy Website[theroguereviews.com]

Early Access Review
								This game is awesome, IF- you like the art style- you like a grindy playstyle- you like atmospheric games (which it is, although the story itself is a bit lacking imho)- you can tolerate losing your favourite characters to really bad luck- you really do need to be able to take a punch now and then. The game is the most unforgiving one of this kind I've ever played. (My personal coping strategy is to not play the game for too long in one run, because it sometimes feels VERY unfair if you lose 2 or 3 of your better/more liked characters in one run.)The game is working fine for me, and I guess I'm gonna be sinking a lot more hours into it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok simply put this is a great game.Ignore all the reviews complaining about the devs "ruining" the game. The whole point of this game is supposed to be that you aren't getting through it without a lot of setbacks. Characters die and go insane and that is supposed to happen. The devs are super great about this game, changing things that the community really hates.  The reason you see all the bad reviews  is because people don't like change. The devs made the game harder and forced people to do different things and people got mad and said the game was awful now because it is harder....But thats the point of the game! The theme of the game isn't  sometimes everyonce  and awhile something bad happens in your merry adventure. Its that madness and death surrounds you at all times but there is still hope. This game is fun and I'm currently waiting to play more till more content is released in the full release because i don't want to spoil the game. Honestly if you plan well and play smart this isn't some insane game that makes you curse the RNG gods like some obviously salty people seem to proclaim.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								For an Early Access game, Darkest Dungeon is incredibly well polished. It has an excellent introduction and narration and is very atmospheric. Some of the UI could use improvements, and it has the potential to turn into a grind fest, but over all I am very impressed.The basic premise is that you are traveling to reclaim your family manner which is overrun by monsters after your relative opened a gate to hell. As you travel through the randomly generated maps you need to manage your party's health, sanity, light and equipment.As your party succumbs to the darkness they may develop various quirks which means you may not even be able to trust your own team. You will die. You will die A LOT. Its OK, there are always more adventurer’s waiting.Mechanically the game is simple, walk from room to room dealing with traps, looting objects, and fighting. Combat is turn based and you have a handful of actions to chose from. These actions depend on where you are located in the party line as well as where your opponents are making it fairly dynamic. Also, you can retreat at any time, but it comes with a price - stress. Too much stress can make your character’s unplayable until they take time and money to recover in town.I look forward to seeing what comes next, especially if they maintain this level of quality.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Everything in this games oozes originality. And that says a lot for a turn based RPG. A lot of element of a lot of different style is in there. I'd describe the games has. A horror survival rogue-like turn based management RPG. And all those element are already well made even in early access. Just keep in mind that. You WILL lose some heroes. Even a lot if you're not cautious. You are not gonna be able to exit victorious in all your dungeon attemps. Sometimes you will have to flee after the first battle. But if you manage your heroes well you will eventually find that the game is getting easier. There's updates every other week or so. And the devs are really listening to the community. Fixes and content are added at a fair pace and the game is definetly playable even if two stages are still under construction.Be aware... Every decision you take is final. No loading no backtracking. If you keep fighting with you favorite hero under   1/4 of is life or over 3/4 of is sanity.. You might lose him/her. If you go unprepared in dungeons you might not make it to the first room. And if you think this game is easy you're gonna cry your mom and probably go back to candy crush with a severe depression. But do i recommend it ? HELL YEAH more than any game on steam right now.9/10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well played bit (>20 hours) this out of curiosity back in February at friends place and liked it, with 1-2 healers the starting level heroes were doable.Waited for a sale or release after that, now saw it at -25% and took it, saw that they added new classes, cool. Went in for a spin and also found out that there's heart attack at the end 2nd stress bar and it's not chance based like Death's Door. Not cool. Like really, at least make it chance based so you can gamble on it and try to finish the combat/mission or bail it.With 1-2 healers the dungeons were doable with starter chars, with the limited rng in the types of new recruits but with the heart attack chance, what I quickly tested, they will force me to fail a mission more than I can finish them at the ratio of 1:4 if I want to keep even half the chars alive from a mission.Not really funny with the limited pool of recruits. No really interest in updating their skills or gears if I can be sure they can't even last 2nd dungeon if they go in with even little stress leftover. Early Access is early and this was and is the one game I'm actually rooting for but as things stand now, very, very rocky rng start for each play is a big thing for now. Here's to the hope they really try to balance the heart attack mechanic and make it even gamblingly viable to do a dungeon without 2nd healer.OR reduce the stress incurred by aoe damage since +5 or something like that 'Stress Recovery' from single target skill from single char means nothing when you incur 5-20 stress every round and aoe/crits make it just that much more worse. Healer's barely keep up with the damage and now you except the chars to keep up with the stress mitigation WHILE also thinning the enemy numbers at the same time? Pfft.Stress is something you shouldn't be able to wipe clean 24/7 but it should at least be manageable and something you could gamble little on it, instead of nuh nah nope bruh, you ded, mission failed 5+ times in row.TL;DR Recommend but those on the fence, DON'T go for early access, wait for release and hope they balance this one out.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												This game. This game is wonderous. It embraces its Lovecraftian heritage while also being a phenomnally crafted game. The art direction is bleak, yet it has a beauty to it. Yet that same bleakness also leads to some truly demented monster designs, designs that echo the sort of unspeakable horrors that Lovecraft spoke of. The light and stress mechanics weave together in a truly phenomanal fashion. This game, more then any other RPG I know, makes risks and rewards so damn satisfying. To give one of the best examples in the game, take the Shambler fights. Shamblers are rare, very monsterous enemies that can be summoned at Shambler Alters that you may encounter on your journey. If you place a torch on the Altar, the Shambler will appear. You enter pich-black conditions (monsters hit harder, cause more stress, but also player crits are more common) and your party will always be suprised, which throws the EXTREMLY important party order into a shuffle. These factors, combined with the Shambler's attacks, mean that you can be in a very dangerous position. But the payout for killing a Shambler is well worth the risk, as killing a Shambler gets you an Ancestral Trinket, easily the most powerful trinkets in the game. Thus do risk and reward entertwine to provide riches, or disaster, on every outing into the dungeons.The enemies are vicous, the dungeons are vast and filled with peril and glory. The bosses bring challenge to those worthy enough to face them, and both legendary glory and unspeakable evil await. So....will you heed the call... of the Darkest Dungeon?

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Do you know Murphy? Well this is his game. If something can go wrong, it eventually will. The question is are you prepared enough to handle that eventuality?Darkest Dungeon is a game that follows the HP Lovecraft theme and it has the writing, voice acting and art style to match it perfectly. You will have to work with the abilities (and disabilities) of the heroes you recruit in order to build a strong enough army of adventureres to conquer the Darkest Dungeon.A lot people will say that the game has too much RNG, but the truth is the game has a lot of tactical and practical decision-making that is required for you to safely bring your band of heroes through each dungeon with minimal casualties and stress. This is not a game where you were meant to win by default just because youu have higher stats. If you want to win, you're going to have to put some thought into your actions and decisions and that might include retreating and abandoning a dungeon run before you lose your most powerful party.I can't relate to those who have a hard time with the game. I did my homework and haven't had a single death in my first 135 weeks of play and I've been having fun making calculated risks to see what I could get away with without sacrificing any heroes. As of writing this I'm preparing my teams to go into the final dungeon. For better or for worse, I know I'm going to have a lot of fun throwing my legendary heroes into the maw of this final challenge.Get the game... and see you in Hell.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game will probably be fun for you for the first 40 or so hours, but after that, it just gets very repetitive.   Effective strategies that clever players devise for success are ultimately nerfed in the patches.  To me, the pleasure of a game is figuring out strategies to overcome challenging situations, rather than relying on luck from a random number generator.  Even with the nerfs to your characters and the power boosts to the enemies, the game is still manageable and is not nearly as difficult as you might be lead to believe based on the reviews of other gamers on here.  However, the game gets boring because of the lack of customization for the characters.  There aren't any special armors or weapons to find.  You simply have generic upgrades, so when going on your quests/missions, there isn't really anything too exciting that you will ever find.  It just the the same old gold, and items that help you unlock generic upgrades.  There are "trinkets," but these are nothing to write home about, and are also generic.  You will get multiple copies of the same useless trinkets.   The bosses can be cool, but it seems like the developers got lazy.  Rather than making new bosses, they just re-used the old bosses, but made them tougher.  So you have to fight necromancer level 1, level 2, and level 3.  This just adds to the lack of excitement.  I guess I get a certain level of satisfaction successfully going through this game while having only minimal causalties when I read how so many others are frustrated and can't seem to figure how to achieve consistent success.  However, this minor joy is not enough to keep me coming back for more.In summary, the game a lot more content (far more than it will ever have) in order for this game to be noteworthy.  Will you enjoy the game for the first 40 hours or so?  Probably.  Then you will realize that you are tired of going through the same process over and over again without any hope of a unique reward.  I am hopeful that someone out there will create a mod which makes the game a lot better.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I started playing DD on this last patch and I for one like the game. I cannot recommend it unfortunately. Echoing many of the other reviews that have been written recently, DD has a myriad of wonderful features, including excellent voice acting and mechanical rpg enhancements, the concept of stress, the artwork, and the music all serve to make Darkest Dungeon a joy to play to a point. That point is reached fairly quickly in the game due to the compounding effects of stress and the costs to combat stress and improve your crew. None of the provisions like torches and food you purchase for a given expedition that you don't use are lost upon return. Oversupply yourself and you lose a significant amount of coin. Underprovision yourself and you risk failing the expedition and really getting behind on your coffers. With the high costs of stress reduction and improvement opportunities, and expedition costs, I am starting to see a challenge in making any progress to the higher levels in this game. Recruiting newer characters that are too weak to explore your only choice of dungeons and being unable to use your higher level characters much due to the effects of stress or the many negative quirks they aquire that cost too much to remove means you end up playing only the very beginning portions of a given dungeon and make barely any progress.Bottom line, a really great game ruined by too high of a challenge level. You will find yourself getting frustrated playing it now so I would wait until another patch comes through that addresses the difficulty issues.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								On a positive note, I love the concept of this game, I like the art, the rogue-like elements, and in large part the execution is fantastic. It hooks you in with the progression of the town and your heroes and I genuinely felt excitement and nervousness at attempting a quest because you never know whats going to happen!Now on the more neutral side of things, but ultimately the downfall of the game, is the difficulty, which is ridiculously hard... and believe me when I say I enjoy really hard games.It took me about 2 dead heroes and 4 failed attempts at runs before I even finished my first run at the first basic quest. While I personally didn't mind this, I don't think this is a good way to bring new players into the game and it is going to turn a lot of people away very quickly.Despite the tough learning curve I began to piece together how things worked, I began developing my town and upgrading and recruiting a variety of heroes to put strategic compositions together to take town tough quests.It felt good.I was absolutely loving it... then, I attempted the Wisened Hag quest for the first time... with obviously no idea of what she did or what I needed to prepare for. Fortunately, everything was going swimmingly. I breezed my way through the dungeon and headed into the boss room on full health with practically no stress... Perfect!At which point, the boss randomly captured and reordered my units, with basically no way to stop it because they were all permanently moved into the one position they could not attack. If I tried to move one into the position it needed to be in, she just moved it back. So I completely helplessly lost my 4 best heroes at once, with no way to retreat or counter what was happening...Frustrating... to say the least.Don't get me wrong, I understand you're going to lose heroes, it's part of the game. And, as bad as it was, that wasn't the real issue.The zero option and severity of that fight just felt hollow. I could have done nothing about what happened because I had no idea what I was in for, I just clicked that button to enter the room and lost everything.But the really aggravating and ultimately insurmountable problem was that I now had nothing. No money, and therefore zero way to buy provisions for another quest; or de-stress heroes; or upgrade heroes; or in fact actually attempt to get back into the game at all.That was it: 9-10 hours of gameplay down the toilet.So lesson learnt, I suppose? All I need to do now is make sure I keep a buffer of gold in case things go bad right?Sure, but  do I want to start over and build my town up from scratch?Nope, do I heck. I'm done. I had a great time with it, but it just ended all my motivation to keep playing right there and then and I can't bring myself to spend the time starting over, only to hit the next boss I haven't seen before and I get set back another 10 hours.I'm confused why they thought this was sensible game design and what outcome something like this would have with anyone other than just feeling like you've been duped into wasting your time.So just like the heroes in the game, my resolve was tested:Did I become Focused? Stalwart? Courageous?No.At best, they might hope that someone becomes Masochistic and starts over. But, frankly, it just left me feeling Hopeless.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I can't reccomend this game as it stands in early access, though the artwork and vibe are brilliant and the core idea is solid, the only way I can see to progress in this game is to recurit newbies every mission, grind them to dust in a level 1 dungeon, barely surviving - dismiss them because you can't afford to deal with their problems and repeat.This means I've never had heroes get past level 2 and in fact I sent a fairly optimised group of level 2 heroes against a level 1 boss mission and they all virtually got one shot by falling rocks.There's hard and then there's just dumb. Am I supposed to grind level 1 non-boss missions untill none exist any more (it happens!) or is it now impossible for me to make any progress in this game? Why do enemies leave corpses in the way when they die and my guys just turn to dust and leave no corpse?If you make a game hard you need to make your losses feel non-arbitrary and like there's something you can try differently to overcome the challange and at the moment the only option I see is a boring as hell grind fest on characters than never level just so I can amass resources with no end in sight.I really hope release rebalances some fun back into the difficulty. Too much grind for too little progress, making every loss an excercise in random frustration, not exciting challenge.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
Darkest DungeonDeveloped and Published by: Red Hook StudiosReleased: January 2016+ Bone chilling occult setting with...+ Great looking hand drawn art direction,+ music that fits perfectly and...+ an incredible performance by the game's narrator.+ Challenging roguelite dungeon crawls full of death and horrors+ Developers hellbent on making DD the best game possible for everyone+ Unforgiving RNG which will lead to numerous adventurer's deaths- In the normal campaign, no true failure state- Developers hellbent on making DD the best game possible for everyone- Unforgiving RNG which will lead to numerous adventurer's deathsDarkest Dungeon is beautiful game that needs to be experienced, perhaps except by  those who can not deal with unfair RNG occationally killing your characters.Darkest Dungeon is also a study in why we as gamers can't have, and do not deserve nice things.  It has been fascinating to follow the developers' journey through Early Access tweaking their game, attempting to make everyone happy, and of course always ending up enraging crowds in the community no matter which direction they take.  Surely something games developers have learned from, for the future.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Not worth picking up in it's current state.  It doesn't allow you to learn how to manage anything before it just dumps on you,  who thinks that's fun?Difficult games are fine, and often enjoyable.  The dark souls series is a good example.  For the most part they reward you for making an effort and trying to learn.  This game does not, it gives you two fights that you're supposed to win and then dumps you in the rest of the game with all the things you could use to improve locked until you let yourself get♥♥♥♥♥♥on.  It makes me very sad that the game isn't actually fun because the art is awesome and the atmosphere is pretty danmed cool.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Pretty cool game, but it's one of those games where they have probably spend countless nights balancing the random. A "roguelike" in only the sense that it's randomly generated and replayable with severe consequences. It just goes too far into the severe consequences it gets rediculous. It's like it's set on a hardcore mode that only a few would enjoy. It's got a tone, that just oozes smugness, telling you in the start "Don't worry, we made this game to be no fun at all, because..."Take provisions as an example. Apparently these spoil instantly as they enter a ruin, and cannot possibly be used afterwards, they loose all value and probably get thrown away even though at the end of the journey they eat into your carrying capactiy on what you can bring back. So you are constantly in need of balance for how much you might get out of a quest, how much stuff you might need to pass a dungeon, and how much you might find? Add to this the fact that dungeons "level up" for no reason, and you're running out of capable warriors, it's like your playing a game over and over again, just increasing the difficulty level but not really getting anywhere.Another awkward balance to keep things "tense" is healing, you may have healers, but they can't heal out of battle. So instead of figuring out a system to balance having too much healing ability, the game designers chose to make an arbitrary descision on not being able to do something outside of lethal situations. This lack of strategy just leaves me bummed. This also makes it that there are tons of helaing abilties, and you just need to balance multiple party builds with enough healing, but not too much. Oh the fun. Lastly the need for 4 people in your party is just contrary to how the game begins with 2 characters. So even if you'd be okay with your 3 fresh and sane adventurers, to maybe just take a half way excursion into the dungeon, you NEED to take gibbering jim who really should really be spending time in the asylum instead. I mean it just wouldn't be fun if the game couldn't force its stress mechanic onto you every step of the way, would it? The characters in this world are also by far the most fragile examples of humanity. Someone says something bad more then once, steals all valuable loot, refuses to help, and then DIES!? Well oh no, why don't you all just slip on into eternal hopelessness. This is a game that was obviously designed by people who think getting "triggered" is as serious as social science wants you to belive. I suppose the real answer was to just let gibbering jim go, not get him help and maybe then the game would let me just play with 3 characters- ah who am I kidding, probably would have shown a kill screen and ended it all if I was that sick.I havn't really gotten too far into this game, and my above examples probably makes that clear. Its just one of those games where you need a community forum to go read over, to learn the basic concepts, ammounts and progression just to have fun. Although this is apparently what "ruined" the original game (before the hound and whatnot update)  because there was a strategy which could be applied, to far too great an effect. This broken game from the past apparently got all glowing reviews, and now tha game is just completely different, but some people are happy about it I guess? There is no amateur mode. The game also does such a poor job at teaching you anything I have the feeling the game creators just thought Deamons Souls was the greatest game in the world because who knows what the heck that game wanted, was really more of a community puzzle then a game. Those outside of the community aspects just had to try and fail countless times. However that game got one thing right which this didn't, you failed a lot but this was the "normal" state of things and it kept going. In this game you fail a lot and you just start over and over again, doing that same tedious fight, see the same tired cut scenes, progress the same 3 missions before you get everything in the game... Ugh. This games "normal state" is to fail, and get nowhere and start over again, so if that sounds like fun by all means, sign up to the closest darkest dungeon community forum, load up a ton of reading and pull an all nighter. Its got charm, it's got variety, it's just too much "raw" for my taste.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't write many reviews but I really feel I need to warn people off this game. Look, I like a challenge as much as the next gamer but this game is just ridiculous. Here is the first thing. You actually might lose one of your starting characters in the tutorial. Let that sink in. You can lose a character in the tutorial (which, by the way, you cannot skip). I’ve never played a game so unbalanced. As you read further review or look in the forums, you’ll see many saying “These people are whiners, it’s not that hard.” I don’t know what game these people are talking about but it’s not this one. After several attempts at playing, it’s mostly an exercise in frustration. Your enemies will rarely miss you but you’ll miss them often. They will get several critical hits, you’ll get very few. The vast majority of “treasure” you find will be trapped and your party will only get wounded and stressed with nothing to show for it. When your characters become stressed to the breaking point (this will happen often) they’ll come down with some sort of affliction. This will slow the game quite a bit because every turn the afflicted characters must say something about it. I could go into a lot more but I just wanted to shoot this review off before I uninstall the game. This might be a good game sometime in the future but I regret having bought it at this point.

								First off i love the art style and play of this game. The narrator was also a BIG plus and  the game play was nice BUT now here comes the negatives..... When you are allowed to die in the tutorial i call that bad game planning. This game is so frustrating and irritating that i don't ever plan to play it again unless they fix some game mechanics..... one of them being the fact that your characters miss way more  (4 to 5 times more than the enemy) and that the enemy gets more turns than you and that all your meat shields (yes meat shields because that is all they are so don't get attached to any single one because he/she will be taking a one way trip very very soon on the corpse disposal wagon) have negative traits to start with and the negative traits just keep coming even the rare positive traits are not that good.I was really hoping this game would be a refreshing change but instead i find it  to not even be worth my time or the money i spent on buying it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								A brutally realistic dungeon crawl with comic book-quality artwork of a medieval Gothic style. Your heroes have quirks (both good and bad) and they can get stressed out, diseased, or worse when things go badly in the dungeon. Treatments and enhancement are available in town, but you really have to manage your financial and human resources: protect/enhance your star players and use other recruits as fodder. It's one hell of a hard game and worth the trouble... if you are a bit masochistic and tolerant of long-term planning and rewards.   In other words,  it is a great game for Dad's with very little time to play.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Too much RNG, and not enough skill based combat. Yeah, I get it, turn based RPGs do have an element of RNG to them, but mechanically this game is just bad. Enemies out hit you and out stress you. I don't mind that there isn't a good way to heal out of battle, as it makes the game feel more like a test of endurance, but it's not uncommon that I will just get to an easy fight and drag it out for an hour just to heal, because all in combat heals restor a pathetic amount of HP. Also the Vestel feels like a necessary class due to having by FAR the strongest heals. In my opinion, having any class feel necessary is just BAD. This game really needs something of a way to heal out of combat. Add to that the fact that when you get a character to level 3 they refuse to do low level quests (apparently all the heroes in this game are just jackasses) Ugh... Lets just say this game has more going against it than for it at the moment. Anyways, I really do want to see where this game goes in the future, but it's gonna be several patches before I look into it again.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I do not recomend this game mostly because its not much of a game, you dont really manage your heros that much, every building has a very linear upgrade system, actually everuthing is very very linear, and the battles are just super boring, the vast majority of battles consist of you wait and watching the enemy attacking you, again and again, and then you can use 1 or 2 of your party members before the enemy party gets another full cycle, and you have no input during their attacks, no precise quick times to either maybe give slightly reduced dmg or possible dodges. No you just wait and wait watching the enemy attack while your party members freak out and skip their turns because they dont like scurry monsters. I would think a Crusading Knight or a Murderous Highwayman wouldnt be affraid of little slug things or skeltons.How ever beautful and interesting it is i just dont find it a fun game. Its more like a sim of watching fail adventurers suck at DnD.UPDATE- Spent over 3 more hours, had lots of fun building a strong team of a healer, 2 gunmen and a crusader, fought through 3-4 dungeons using good tactics and won each battle, had a few close calls but i was ok, made it to the first boss and it ruined the game.The Wizened Hag, first turn she put my knight into a boiling pot instantly, the pot damages the hero inside every turn, not round, after each unit move, and she gets a turn after every pot breaks and after each of your turns, she spams area attacks that never miss, and 9/10 my attacks missed, also causes over 20-30 stress per attack, when a hero is not in the pot it is indestrucible and makes melee attacks vs her blocked.She killed one of my guys after haver 4 attacks in a row against me, i quit the fight finally after 3 failed attempts and i quit the game period, until they nerf the AI in many ways and make the fighting fair i cannot recommend this game, it is annoying, unfair, and overall very boring once you get spammed by enemies.Update: Nothing much has changed in the last week, still gameplay that is completely random and unfair, you still spend 80% of the game watching the enemy attack you and spam area attacks, still needs loads of balance work and refinement of the gameplay.Add- 8/15/2015New updates, same errors, just fought the wizened hag again, fight went well got her down to 20 health out of 66 with 2 highway men, 1 arbelest and 1 hellion when she dumped the hellion out of the pot at deathsdoor then istantly put 1 highwayman into the pot THEN Seasoned the hellion and instantly killed her,  then spew the highwayman out to deaths door, then took the other highwayman into the pot, THEN i got to attack, but none of the 2 could hit her, expect the highwaymans tracking shot for 3 dmg, then she AoE attacked and killed those 2 and i lost just like that. In summary the game has such amazing art, sound and setting but it suffers from boring and repetitive fighting, horrible RNG , unfair inbalances, and tedious and time wasting animations and dialauges that interupt the flow of the game and literally prevent player actions. I do not recomend this game to anyone until it gets a major gameplay overhaul.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a Lovecraftian fan, this game is pure excellence. It's unbridled focus on Necromancy, Cosmic Horrors, Weird Fiction Tropes and recently on an Innsmouth-centric revolt allows an atmosphere of insidious dread to prevail through such terrible game mechanics. Yes, I said it. Reveling in the diverse rogue gallery of lore-centric enemies is awesome. You'll feel like you got lost inbetween Algernon Blackwood and Lovecraft while crawling through catacombs as Wayne June proclaims your inevitable failure, and the masked Leper leading your party suddenly cracks. But I feel a unique, separate kind of dread when all four of my level 5's miss the basic skeletals and get wrecked. Or when Cup of Annoyance is cast 37 times in a row by their back line without giving me a turn, stressing my entire party to Hell itself. DD's combat engine is dicerolls from D&D, home brewed, without much semblance of balance.Darkest Dungeon is a sidescrolling click-n-crawl much like Grimrock, with a tiered party of 4 classes taking different depth charts. Positioning is important, as archers can't shoot from the front, and your crusader can't swing from the back. Following? You crawl down hallways, which are littered with procedurally generated loot, into rooms, filled usually with bad guys. That's all it is, besides for a feature creep styled town where heirlooms acquired can upgrade it to provide cheaper upgrades. No town events, invasions, 1-day missions, or anything resembling variation. Objectives range from scouting all the rooms, killing all the bad guys, or collecting 3 pieces of unique loot. All 3's results do not effect your party any differently, leading me to realize DD is a monotonous descent into the uniquely terrifiyng realm of boredom, and boredom that punishes you for being alive.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Since my unpolished rushed review was actually getting some attention i've decided to go and write a proper review this game deserves so those who did'nt find it useful can maybe change their mind a bit n so enough of that off to the review:The game is from my expiriences one of the best dungeon crawling rogue likes i've played in quite sometime. This game in my short time I had with it had me wanting to come back for more. The game is quite creative with it's combat system in the way that after so many times your party comes close to death their mind is tested in which their mind will either snap or they will be heroic and reward your roster with buffs; or if their mind snaps it will cause some debuff to that character such as paranoia or selfishness. That system alone had this game sticking as unique in my mind. As for the rest i'm just going to do a quick Pros/Cons list.Pros:1-Creative Combat System2-Unique Art Style3-Great Environments and Ambience4-Good Voice acting5-Creative foes and Quests.6-Great Balance Combat and Exploration.7-Adds in Realistic Hunger elements to the ChaosCons:1- Game is buggy and tends to crash but fixes can be found, i personally had a glitch where it'd freeze at the hamlet screen n i'd have to wait for it to load and not respond then begin responding.2- hard for players new to rpgs or dont have previous expirience3- some deciscions you make due to the Randomness screw you over in ways you cant manage no matter what ^.^Verdict:9/10 - Amazing game but due to the bugs I had to lower it a notch however for an Early Access game it is superbly done and I would recommend this game to any of my friends. This is a great game and deserves the support.

Early Access Review
								I wish I could recommend this game. The core concept is solid and the story and atomosphere is great. But the implementation is deeply flawed.The developers clearly wanted to create a challenging game but their idea of "challenging" was simply to add a bunch of random bad things that can happen. These things can't be planned for or mitigated and occur with incredible frequency.Combat itself is actually pretty good and is another reason I wish I could recommend it. But here again the strategy of the game is short circuited by the extremely random nature of things.To sum up where this game went wrong they confused randomness with challenging and tainted a decent core system.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I want to say it's an amazing game but there are too many frustrating problems with it. - Everything and I mean EVERYTHING will increase the stress of your heroes. Wich mean that unless you are really lucky or spend alot of time using underpowered stress healing you will need to send your hero to a stress relieving activity wich cost aroud 1k gold..... for each hero..... when you probably made 5-6k gold in the same mission...... not including the gold you spent for the provisions...... so if you are lucky you might have 1k profit in your pockets.- Too much RNG. You can miss many many times in a row if the RNG gods are not on your side and when the enemy has a crit streak ? Oopsie you just lost that one hero you spent a couple of missions to level up. Oh and while I'm at it.- Leveling. Once one of your hero reach lvl 3 hes too good for low level missions so hes completly unusable unless you have a full team of lvl 3 heroes. Yeah that suck- Oh and you know when I talked about paying for stress relieving being too expensive ? On top of stress you have to pay 1k to cure your hero from a crippling negative trait or disease wich fall from the sky like rain. And you didnt have gold to cure that negative trait ? Oopsie now you have to pay 5k gold to cure it since its now a lasting one.I just love so many things about this game. The atmosphere is beautiful. The classes are so awesome and the combat is very interesting. I just wish that RNG wasnt such a big part of it because it makes good team composition loose their efficiency. That hero deal more damage to marked monsters ? Lets hope you dont have to spend 3 turns trying to mark it. Cool you marked it.... Oh nvm it changed position so now my hero cant hit it anymore.Frustrating and completly discouraging to new players who want to enjoy the game. They could keep the RNG I wouldnt mind but the gold cost are stupid high. You just end up having to pay for so much crap that you cant even buy upgrades.Thank god it doesnt cost anything to recruit new heroes. I guess I should just keep recruiting without leveling or getting back their sanity and send them in missions hoping the RNG gods are good to me.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								In it's first release, I found the game fun to play with a distinct level of challenge and a stress system that was intensely punishing but sometimes offered up a moment's respite as your party became less and less effective as their stress increased.I took a break from the game, and about two weeks later, I came back and tried a new Campaign.  I lost half my party in the "approaching the town" tutorial mini-dungeon and from there lost at least half my party (if not wiping entirely) on every dungeon run I took there after.  At every stress threshold I could rest assured that my party members would get "Hopeless" or "Selfless" as a break, which happens about a little over 80% of the time.I'm all for punishing rogue-like mechanics, but it seems to be unnecessarily punishing when my party of 90+% are hitting in the 40to50% range before their stress penalties, and in the 10% after the stress penalties.  How do you even play a game like that?

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall one of the best games I've ever played for anyone that is a fan of roguelike mechanics or turn-based strategy. Pros:* Excellent aesthetic, from the art style to the overall theming and the voice acting. The writing is generally very good also. * Good variety of mostly useful classes. * Fairly easy to grasp combat system, but with a lot of depth. Cons:* A lot of the trinkets (items) are situational, but many are just downright useless. This has been really improved on over the course of Early Access so I have faith this will continue to improve. * Can be grindy at times. With only four dungeon environments it can get a little repetative, but the challenge of just about every run really helps make that less of an issue. * Some of the classes are clearly less useful than the others. Most classes can be useful to some degree, but there are some that are clearly better. This too has been improved over the course of Early Access.As a final disclaimer, I don't believe the game is nearly as difficult as some people make it out to be. You are punished for mistakes, but as long as you have some experience with strategy games and are willing to learn from your mistakes you will eventually get the hang of it. The constant threat of being punished for your mistakes makes the game still really fun and challenging even when you have become very competent with it - a slip-up will punish an experienced player just as much as a novice.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												This game is punishing. You blow through characters like cleenex and combat/sanity mechanics are just unpleasant. You just barely survived that fight? Well you're going to walk into literally invisible traps. Nothing you can do to avoid it. Oh, you have a good order for your characters? Well screw you! You get "surprised" and they change order for no reason. It will take you like 4 turns getting them repositioned during which you will be hammered by enemies. Just walking along minding your own business? Well people in your party just starts accumulating "stress" for no reason. Also, you can't use the healing abilities of your characters out of combat (for some inexplicable reason) and your one healing item - food - is basically garbage. Overall, this game is fine, but not really worth the money. It just isn't fun to play. The mood is great and the art is nice, but the deck is SO stacked against the player that you end up killing A LOT of your sprites which ruins any sense of accomplishment for the RPG mechanic. Why care about any of my characters if they have the life expectancy of mayflies?

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												You will lead the most PUSSIFIED band of adventurers ever. Every single round of battle, they are taking huge amoubts of stress, which when it his a certain point... like 4-5 rounds, they develop a rather nasty quirk--LIKE BEING TERRIFIED OF THEIR OWN SHADOW and getting massive debuffs as a result.Oh, and do you like games where the mobs get more turns than you? Then you are going to LOVE this game. I have actually suprised a group of mobs and I get off a single attack by one of my adventurers, and then all 4 of the mobs get their turns before the next 2 members of my party get their turns, and then 3 of them followed by 2 of me.... and you et the idea. Even though I am trying, in vain, to level my toons before facing higher level dungeons, it is a losing proposition. Your character will pick up 2 -3 diseases PER character per dungeon run. It takes a week and massive amounts of gold to cure EACH disease, so that a successful dengoen run against low level mobs leaves you owing 3-5 times as much gold as you gathered. Oh, and did you bring supplies you didn't need for the run? They are gone. At the end of the dungeon run they go *POOF*. You must purchase new supples EVERY single dungeon run, and they are EXPENSIVE. Purchase too many and you lose gold. Purchase too few and you must retreat from the dungeon--and thus lose gold.Also,you will not be able to reach the back mobs except for ranged attacks. So you take down the front two mobs, and...... AND YOU STILL CANNOT HIT THE BACK TWO MOB WITH YOUR MELEE CHARACTERS BECAUSE THE CORPSES OF THE FIRST TWO MOBS ARE BLOCKING THE ABILITY OF YOUR MELEE CHARACTERS TO GET TO THE BACK TWO MOBS! You must then waste valuable turns in destroying the corpses so you can reach the back two mobs!!!You can tell this game was deigned by someone who didn't understand that games are supposed to be FUN! Adventurers GATHER and ACCUMULATE loot -- theyare not supposed to become POORER each and every round!I'd like to give this game 2 thumbs down, but only 1 is permitted.
