number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												TLDR: Great look and feel, but RNG goes beyond risk/reward and resource management and can just screw you anyway. Seems to be building towards a long and unfulfilling/frustrating grind.The game feels great when it seems like everything is calculated risk and resource management. If you get a disease or negative quirk from an object instead of treasure, that is fine because you know the risk and have the opportunity to abstain. If you have a character go insane from stress in combat, you likely didn't bring people capable of healing stress or brought someone you should have left in town for a round. A defeat from pressing on when you're low on supplies is also a learning experience. Essentially, you need to take steps so that even if something goes wrong it isn't game over.Unfortunately the variance is just too high. Maybe ~11 weeks (11 dungeon expeditions) into the game, my party of 60-75% health, low stress characters encountered a boss that was not marked on the already scouted map and was magnitudes more powerful than anything else in the dungeon. The party wiped with one enemy minion left.The problem with this is even if you take fewer risks, have an excess of resources, and the game indicates what is supposed to be in the next hall or room, you can still lose everything in a single random twist. That crosses the border from punishing to unfair.And if this is happening so early into the game, I'm expecting there to be a lot more situations like this one.Given that there is an achievement for finishing within 99 weeks, and the tremendous costs of upgrading anything beyond the first level in the town, I'm going to assume that this game won't be worth the time, effort, and frustration to complete.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I realize this is early access, but I would not recommend this game at this time.  There is a fun game in there; the concepts are brilliant but the frustration is huge.  The spread in outcomes of the various RNG rolls results in unavoidable failure spirals where things will be going along brilliantly and then suddenly all of your heros are fully stressed, you are out of money, and no easy quests are available to attempt a recovery.  The overall balance seems extremely poor; some dungeons you will receive 50% the number of enemies, and they will all be of an easy type and other dugeons will have twice as many enemies and each fight will decimate your party.  Add in the unavoidable RNG (you can be unlucky with what hero types are available, giving you an unfeasable party configuration leading to certain failure) and this game is just not worth the price of admission.  I hope they refine it, because I feel like this could be a really good game.  One last thing; many people are saying the root problem is that you have to learn the game.  Some of my favorite games are the Souls games which are difficult, but once your endure and learn the mechanics you become powerful.  This is not that scenario; the Souls games are tough but fair.  This game's reliance on RNG outcomes yields and experience which just is not fair.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												It was my favorite game of 2015 and it wasn't even technically out yet.It's a hard game, but screwing up won't typically make you lose, it will just push your progress back. It's an RNG heavy game so if dying due to bad luck makes you rage, you shouldn't go anywhere near this game. The positioning based turn based combat is innovative but does get repetitive after a while, however with 14 classes in the game and only 4 slots to put them in, and considering some classes can be built multiple ways (Combat Vestial vs Support Verstial), it's going to take quite a while to run out of combinations to expierment with. Enemy variety isn't amazing but it's good enough.By far the biggest draw is the style of the game. The Narrator is a gem, the art is fantastic, despite how dark the lovecraftian setting is, I never get tired of looking at this game.I can't even comment on the community controversy, when I got this game when it released in early access I trusted the Devs to bring it to a solid completed state, I didn't care when they added corpses because it was their vision, I didn't care when they added the option to remove corpses because it's their vision. And I believed in their vision.What I'm saying is, this game is not made for everyone, however I recommend it becausse if you are the kind of person this game is made for, it is a must buy, even at full price.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												The game's random nature is absolutely disgusting and unfair to the player.It feels precisely like the "random" nature of "free"-to-play games that beat you into dust if you don't pay. Except you just did. It will still beat you mercilessly because... it's a dark and gloomy experience? Nah, it's a Russian Roulette-type "game". Framed against you to boot. A roulette where winning is awarded by not having your party howled into madness by two ghouls in a dungeon, thus effectively removing them from the game, just because the dungeon randomized this way.Roulette is not a game, it's a scam. So is Darkest Dungeon most of the time.The game would have been glorious if not for the unbalanced randomness. At least add a mode where there's three times less crits! Crits that totally negate a nicely executed effective strategy just because the stars decided to ♥♥♥♥ you up.A game is to be understood and solved. You can't solve randomness, you can only use it to scam fools for money and make horrible game design.Some compare it to Dark Souls, yet Dark Souls doesn't punish failure, it encourages you to try more by saving your things and skills intact and giving a second chance to claim your souls. Here you can totally expect enemies to inflict critical strikes several times in a row just because ♥♥♥♥ you, thus getting you into a horrible death spiral of semi-permanently maimed top characters and suicide missions.It's not a game. It's a scam that doesn't even profit the creaters properly. A very nice game completely ruined by anti-tactical randomness. It's the Darkest Roulette.

number of helpful: 17 of 32 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												Seeing how many nevative reviews it gets, feel obligated to write one myself. So, if you get here not knowing what the game is - it's turn-based RPG, where 4 heroes (15 classes available) struggling through dungeons (5 types, 4 difficulties), slowly improving their abilities (each class has 8 but only 4 can be active in 1 battle, and learning costs) and armor (also costs a lot), plus getting some diseases, stress, negative quirks (more often) and positive quirks (less often), which you need to pay gold to remove or improve. You also collect gold and building materials to upgrade your town for it to be at least a little bit more cozy.. and less expensive. It's pretty dark. And hard. Most important part is that if your hero dies, he/she dies forever. And if whole party dies, not only that, you lose all items, including equipped ones, and those are pretty rare and expensive. As you can see, there are countless people who experienced exactly that. And they blame game for it. Ofc they should blame themselves, instead. Because when you lose 1-2 people in a fight, it's obvious that you should run, or at least try to. Or if you have 5% of health on 2 characters. Or no food or torches and 2 stressed heroes of 150/200 (200/200 hero dies). If game is too hard for you, you can actually lower difficulty a bit (altho i wouldn't advice that), then if you feel overwhelmed, maybe you should go and hire more heroes of low lvl (you can have up to 28 heroes at one time) and go on easier missions, which will give you some money to upgrade armor and skills for stronger heroes. Actually you can do a lot more stuff (change abilities, use consumables), but let me assure you, that if you played for 10-20h and lost everything instantly - it's your fault. Even if you played for 80h and instantly lost everything, it's your fault as well. RNG is always there, but if you're fully equipped and you know synergies - you totally can complete everything game throws at you. Excuse me for that rant there, it's just i see too much whining in reviews >.>Now to pros:-Great atmosphere (music, narrator's voice, art style, depressive medieval themes).-Actually hard and challenging gameplay.-It's one of those games where you can spend equal time on a mission and preparing for a mission, thinking who's the best for it and taking right items - makes you think. -Victories feel satisfying.-Game is actually very well balanced, no useless skills, and they don't look like some chars are only playable together, in fact you can create lots of different parties. Altho on higher difficulties only some will be good.-There are many interesting little things that add up, improving gameplay, like how the way you relieve stress on character sometimes can matter on the next battle, or how stressed heroes act inside the dungeon - they actually almost feel alive.And to cons:-As victories are satisfying, defeats are crushing. Literally. If you actually lose a party, you will sit in your chair with emptiness inside for a while. And maybe you'll need some long break from the game. Even losing one special person can be harsh. It's actually a good thing too, if you ask me, since it'll teach you life lessons, not like almost every other game, which lets you be child forever. But it would be odd to see in pros.-Balance or no balance, RNG sometimes can be weird, for example it still eludes me how turns are counted, when my character is obviously faster than the enemy, yet he can't have first turn. -Description of skills is usually helpful, but the problem is, you also have to know enemies to be prepared. And even tho you can see half of their stats, which are hp, armor and dodge, you can't really see their attack damage, negative effect chances or accuracy. Which are or wiki site anyways, so it's silly, that it's not in the game itself. Especially considering how hard the game is already.Alright, so in the end - if you like harsh, unforgiving, dark as the void itself experience - welcome home (such as it is). But be ready for doom, it's coming. And don't be shy to use some guides. If you don't like such things - please, stay away. For your own good.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												When I first started playing this game, I was absolutely transfixed and couldn't put it down. The art style, tight combat system, and dark atmosphere was fantastic. Being able to experiment with various trinkets and hero compositions as well as lighting levels in the procedurally generated dungeons was a real treat.Unfortunately, once I got to the champion level dungeons that all fell apart. Heroes with the best equipment and rare trinkets were being brought down to 0 HP from one non-critical hit from the larger random enemies players will encounter. No matter how many buffs or debuffs I applied, no matter how many different party configurations I attempted, it was all in vain. I kept losing my best heroes. The worst part is, since gold is such a precious commodity, the fortune I used to equip them was also constantly lost.I have researched this game by looking up threads, wiki articles to learn more about abilities and afflictions (since those numbers and effects are hidden in-game) and many hours figuring out what worked and didn't. Then the game just stopped being rewarding for giving it hard-earned time and just began punishing me, over and over.I went into this understanding that death was part of the experience, but once you're near the end, the experience becomes so unforgiving, tedious, and malicious, it was practically begging me to exit the game.Sure, other people have beaten it. You might too, if you study this game like you're prepping for an SAT or dissertation. You will have to read guides, articles, watch YouTube videos, and spend just as much time watching the game as you do playing it. There is no room for experimentation in the end-game, you either think exactly the way the developer envisioned something being beaten, or you get to restart.There is no freedom or flexibility in this game's design. If you decide to buy it, good luck. I've long since given up on this product. It has sucked up too much of my time and left a bad impression in its wake.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Sorry but no,I tried to like this game. I really tried. A friend of mine recommended the game and the style and scenario sounded awesome. And it really is a good game and one day I might try it again.Bought it during mid-week sale and started playing; 4 days later on Saturday morning I was fed up with it. Most of the time you are just hoping that nothing “too” bad might happen. And most of the time things happen, which you cannot influence. A hard game is nice, but starting the game right now is just unfair. Even more experienced players might disagree, my friend also did.Following I like to point out why I do stand by my opinion:1. The difference between virtue und afflictions is just too much; if one reaches virtue everything is fine. If on the other side reaches one affliction like irrational the changes of "success" in the expedition are very low to no existing any more. One affliction will cause another one (best were three irrational people during one fight) and heardattacks are just waiting.2. Getting rid of stress is too hard. The enemy crits you: 10 stress for the target and some stress for the person next to him. You crit, maybe 3 or 5 stress relief. That's ok, but if you are a Vestal or a Plague Doctor who heals, the crits are rare. And lasts due to DOT's like blight or bleed do not grand stress relief. So no stress relief for you Plague Doctor. The worst is having a hero with a stress level of 40-50 in your town. Sending him into the tavern or the abbey costs a lot of gold (compared to your loot, I will get to that) and it might have a "nice" perk, like losing additional resources or him just leaving for a while. On the other side there might also be a disease (I love the plagues) or some negative character quirks which you was gifted during your last journey and might need treatment. I had one Level 3 hero which was then to proud to join my expeditions any more, due to all abovementioned I was not able to bring any other heroes up to his level and continue.3. The loot is just not enough for the current costs. I equipped not too much food, torches etc. but still I was barely able to loot enough to cover the costs of the expedition and heal from afflictions, sicknesses or negative character quirks. Not even speaking of healing a permanent negative character quirk or locking in positive one. That was much out of reach.All the mentioned things were not part of the game before. From what I read they became mostly part of the game during the last bigger patches and its unfortunate I just started playing; but I seems that many players who just started faced the same troubles. More experienced players seem to disagree. In my opinion they tend to disagree mostly due to affect that their mentions are already maxed out, the higher costs did not hit them that hard. Their heroes are already high level and are able to face the fears; just coping with them became harder. So more experienced are happy with these new dangers. But starting right now with them is just too much burden. RNG just crashes your endeavors from try to try. And to try dark runs without any equipment to gain a small amount of loot and get rid of the poor "victims" is no opinion for me; that is just stupid grinding! Furthermore it does not help the heroes you try to prepare for higher level dungeons and they might get die anyway due to RNG.So in conclusion I cannot recommend the game right now. Even with the option to disable heart attacks or corpses (which I think is not the worst of ideas due the importance of the hero and the enemy position for some attacks) I will recommend it. I wanted a challenging game, not one I can only start in “easy” mode.Maybe one day I will give it one new try!

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												At the end of a 3.5 hour session i've resolved that this game isn't for me anymore. That 22 initial hours of the game came from the initial early access release and damn was it a fun, mildly rng based experience. With full release I came back with the idea to play and have fun with my hard rogue-like. Well boy was I wrong in assuming I'd have anything resembling "fun." The big issue is that if your game is going to be nothing but dice rolls and hoping for a good start based on the rng then you need a lot of opportunities for good rng. Which there really isn't, it's you getting crit, getting stressed (both in game and out) and then when rng finally goes your way and you get that lucky crit, or that solid fight it isn't satisfying or gratifying, it feels owed. Like "finally the game is balancing out a little." And when your players can't feel good about having a good thing happen it's a problem.If you're like me it just comes down to the idea that if the game doesn't make me feel good, if it gives me a completely uneven ratio of stress:fun, and if the game isn't rewarding or gratifying to play then it just isn't worth playing. It's the worst type of game that you want to like but in the end is just so frustrating and annoying to try and deal with you just can't. If I could refund this title I would, I'm sorry Red Hook, you had a great idea, but you executed your gameplay and theology of it like blizzard executes hearthstone, the difference being in hearthstone the rng will always balance out, in darkest dungeon it just piles on and piles on until someday you get the luck streak you need jsut to be able to play the f***ing game. Who knows maybe someday I'll try it again and that luck streak will allow me to get past level 3 heroes.

number of helpful: 20 of 38 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												As a lot of the other reviews state, the visual aesthetic, sound design, and narration are all amazing.  Hero design, enemy design, level design and progression are all excellent as well.  Where this game falls off is its midgame pacing and the somewhat flawed combat system.  I actually don't mind the RNG-based combat too much, although anyone that says this makes the game difficult is kidding themselves.  The problem is once you reach champion level dungeons, crit rates seem to make a huge jump and there are some battles where you get crit 3 or 4 times in a row and there's nothing you can do.  I wouldn't even have a problem with this  but for some odd reason you can't see the enemies crit multiplier even though you can see pretty much everything else.  Randomness is fine and even allows for skillful gameplay and strategy, but ONLY when you allow the players to play around probabilities.  Enemy crit rate is the biggest factor in making the randomness in this game feel unfun in my opinion, you can't do anything to reduce it or prevent it, and the game doesn't even tell you which enemies have high crit rates or moves with high crit rates so you can focus them.  It just seems like a baffling design choice especially since crits are so important due to the way they interact with stress.Another negative is that while losing heroes in the early game makes for very tense gameplay and atmosphere, losing a high level hero in  the mid-game due to the aforementioned multiple crits in a row makes you lose motivation to keep playing.  Not because the game is too hard, but because grinding a party back up to level takes too long and becomes unfun (once you clear the bosses in an area doing the dungeons becomes pretty stale), some people might say that this adds to the atmosphere and immersion of the game, but it just feels like bad design.  A lot of this stems from the midgame pacing issues that are supposedly going to be fixed with DLC, but it's just something to be aware of.  Another minor complaint I have is that it's too easy to make money spam hiring Antiquarians to trinket scrounge and just dismissing them when they build up too much stress, there should be a system in place to prevent abuse of dismissing too many heroes or abandoning too many dungeons. Also wish there was a little more boss variety instead of just a stronger version of the previous level's boss, or more random miniboss encounters like the Shambler/Collector, both of these things would help with midgame pacing immensely in my opinion.TL;DR: Midgame-endgame pacing and combat RNG are issues with the gameOverall the game is still very good, got a super enjoyable 25ish hours out of it, but after that it started feeling a bit too slow/grindy for my taste.  8.5/10

number of helpful: 21 of 40 people (53%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've tried to play this game with the advise given on the opening screen. I'm aware that the game is designed to involve constant meat-grinding of the characters. That is not an issue I cannot overcome. There is a lot that, with enough polish, would make for an amazing game. Even meat-grinders have their place.So what went wrong? You know that feeling where you're telling Windows to do something but Windows is ignoring you to do something else? This game has something even worse. In this game, that frustration is an intentional feature. As you play the characters you're controlling go insane, and they have a chance of ignoring your input to perform other, deliberately inconvenient, actions. The game's designers believe they are trying to model mental illnesses, but instead all that's happening is they refuse to do what's in their own best interests.Reviewing a game like this is particularly gut-wrenching because the developers had a really good game. The earlier sections, where the characters are still usable, have definite promise. There is a lot of nuance and a lot of interesting stuff in those sections, but the developers lost sight of what appeals to the fans of strategy games. If they had simply placed limits that were somehow understandable so that the player could work around them in-the-moment then cope with the baggage later on, the game could have been amazing. Unfortunately, what starts out as an engrossing every-move-matters strategy game quickly degenerates into something unpredictable. No more strategy. When your planning doesn't matter anymore there's just a typical par-for-the-course "you have to have a healer" click-fest.Hit points are all that matters in this game. Heal people. Damage people. Heal yourself more than they damage you. You can't account for the nuance anymore, so who cares about all of the flavor and the details. The game is just going to have disorganized shizophrenia anyway.

Instead, you are treated to a game where RNG is king and your decisions are only as good as your ability to get lucky enough that they actually take effect.Mechanically, the game is a complete mess. content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game seems to play on losing quests, which is fun for 2 or 3 quests, but not 8 in a row. Constantly the hero's get "stressed" and decide to skip their turns which again could be a fun mechanic however I've watched an entire battle unfold with no possible interaction as all my heros kept skipping their turns. Often you will get to the last part and get slaughtered simply because your hero(s) got stressed and just stand there taking a thrashing. Not fun and not realistic in the slightest part. The game does have potential and could be fun but right now it's just no fun unless you like replaying the same 4 quests and watching yourself get thrashed with no possible way to stop it except quitting the game all together. I hope to see the mechanics fleshed out and made more "fun". Right now the smaller battles feel like they go on too long.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've tried to play this game with the advise given on the opening screen. I'm aware that the game is designed to involve constant meat-grinding of the characters. That is not an issue I cannot overcome. There is a lot that, with enough polish, would make for an amazing game. Even meat-grinders have their place.So what went wrong? You know that feeling where you're telling Windows to do something but Windows is ignoring you to do something else? This game has something even worse. In this game, that frustration is an intentional feature. As you play the characters you're controlling go insane, and they have a chance of ignoring your input to perform other, deliberately inconvenient, actions. The game's designers believe they are trying to model mental illnesses, but instead all that's happening is they refuse to do what's in their own best interests.Reviewing a game like this is particularly gut-wrenching because the developers had a really good game. The earlier sections, where the characters are still usable, have definite promise. There is a lot of nuance and a lot of interesting stuff in those sections, but the developers lost sight of what appeals to the fans of strategy games. If they had simply placed limits that were somehow understandable so that the player could work around them in-the-moment then cope with the baggage later on, the game could have been amazing. Unfortunately, what starts out as an engrossing every-move-matters strategy game quickly degenerates into something unpredictable. No more strategy. When your planning doesn't matter anymore there's just a typical par-for-the-course "you have to have a healer" click-fest.Hit points are all that matters in this game. Heal people. Damage people. Heal yourself more than they damage you. You can't account for the nuance anymore, so who cares about all of the flavor and the details. The game is just going to have disorganized shizophrenia anyway.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This gets a huge mehhhhhh from me. The art style is amazing and the combat is fun and strategetic.. buuut my gripes with the game outweigh the fun I had which made me stop playing a number of times. Mainly to do with the stress. I liked the idea of your heroes getting stressed and without treatment going insane or getting some other affliction (like Rogue Legacy  a bit) but it doesn't really work. The problem is that your heroes all seem to have an intense fear of slightly dark places and major heart disease that means they can only go through one room before they're ready to pack it in forever and die.   The games already difficult enough without constantly having to leave half way through dungeons because everyones cutting their wrists and screaming at each other. It wouldn't be so bad if to progress the game didn't ask you to complete 90% of rooms, which I only ever managed to do two or three times after I ignored my heroes ♥♥♥♥♥ing and let a couple of them die.    I liked the idea in writing. But I found myself constantly having to spend all my money to treat the stress levels, meaning I wasn't progressing at all because I had no money left to buy resources or upgrades. It just wasn't fun anymore because I felt like I was playing a dumbed down version of the sims.    Also you'll hear the RNG system mentioned in almost every negative review, and I agree with that. Sometimes your screwed over for the sake of being screwed over and theres nothing you can do to stop it. It's luck. An example are chests which can be trapped and curse you, piles of rubbish which you have to dig to get past (without a shovel they hurt you) and of course the combat which can be really easy or reallly difficult depending on what the game decides.(thank you for reading my review, don't leave a nasty comment otherwise my stress will go from 0 to 200 and I'll go insane :D)

number of helpful: 23 of 44 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												If i could give this game something between a thumbs up and a thumbs down i would.It has great use of art style, narration, dungeon crawling, and the lovecraftian theme. The dark world you need to traverse affects your heroes on an emotinal and mental level. It really helps you feel the impact of the insane situation you find yourself in, watching your party slowly lose their minds from the horror they face.Every battle and dungeon expedition is narrated by excellent voice acting, and going into dungeons forces you to think about what supplies to bring and what to throw away for space. Sometimes bandages are more valuable than gold.I have a great deal of respect for what this game tries to doHowever...Many pivotal moments in this game come down to a throw of the dice. No matter how hard you preapre, no matter how well thought out your stratagy, everything can fall apart at a instant. A poorly timed miss, a weak heal, or a well placed crit can spell out death for the party youve spent a long time preparing, and there is nothing you can do about it. Hours of progress can be wiped in an instant.This unfortunately can and will lead to large amounts of grinding, whether for money or levels, through the same dungeons youve been to time and time again. Progress in this game is slow, painfully so, and the final darkest dungeon requires many heroes to be max level. Fully upgraded max level heroes that can die at a moments notice.I imagine the devolpers of this game wanted the player to feel as stressed as the party they are playing as, because every fight is a challenge, and the fear of losing it all will put you on edge, but when you lose a full team (or even a half team) of level 6 heroes, it can be depressing to the point of game quitting especially near the end game. Its like putting 50 hours into a big game youre trying to 100% only to have your file deleted.This game absolutely has its merits and you can tell the developer put much time into it. However, the heavy focus on RNG and the repetative grind hold this game back from being something truly special.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												Sorry but I cannot recommend this game. One of the cardinal rules of video games, in my opinion is that you don't put the player in a situation where they have to restart the game in order to proceed, losing all progress. You might react to this by saying, "Well you just hate rogue-likes. You're supposed to die! That's the point!"I don't hate rogue-likes. I loved Rogue Legacy, for example. The problem with this game is that you can get quite far, and simply be unable to proceed, losing all of the work you've done to level your party, etc. This is just unacceptable, in my view. If this doesn't bother you, and you want a very difficult challenge, and a steep learning curve, and damn the consequences, then this game might be for you. It does have very interesting and unique mechanics. It's not horrible. It's just not for me.

content:

Early Access Review
								I guess this might be fun, if you enjoy losing constantly to a naive RNG. The game badly needs tuning, it's frustrating and feels like you can never gain traction unless you luck into it, which isn't much fun.edit: I've played enough at this point that I think I get what's going on: the game is over-tuned to defeat power gaming strategies, which leads to an un-fun experience for players who just want to jump in and play and aren't intentionally trying to crack the game in half. I really think a difficulty level option would fix this nicely; hell, lock steam achievements to the higher (classic) difficulty if you like but don't make the game so punishing for new or casual players that it doesn't catch on. That would really be a shame, the game is great fun at times.I still can't recommend the game to "the average gamer" at this point but if you enjoy classic roguelikes and can deal with the RNG deciding to randomly kill you at times the game is tons of fun, if a little rough around the edges.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Pros:  The art is good, the sound is good.Cons:  Bugs (only some of which have been patched), shallow gameplay that pushes brute force grinding.Imagine a game, I have a number between 1 and 100.  We keep playing until you get it right."Oh", you say, "well once I know the solution the game is easy".But then I say "well after you guess it right, I just change the number and we go again"Then I say the guessing game is "hard", "offers replayability", and other superlatives.  Well, Darkest Dungeon is like that pretty much.  Yes, there is some depth to Darkest Dungeon, yes it certainly has its good points, but the gameplay design just seems clumsy.  There are considerable assets in the game, and it's certainly a different experience in terms of looks and sound to a lot of games out there, but on the whole, I have to say it comes up short.I cannot recommend this game at this time.  If mods are released that address numerous gameplay issues, and bugs fixed, sure, it would be a great game.   The developers do continue to patch the game, and modding tools have been announced to be in planning, so there may be hope yet.I will update this review if changes are made sufficient to my considering the game to offer good value.Though this is a negative review, if you like the looks of the game and really don't care how it plays, by all means, go for it.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												Like many others have said, Darkest Dungeon has fantastic visuals, with a unique art style, satisfying animations, and excellent voice acting. The game does indeed require skill, but the lack of a recommendation comes from the simple fact that many of Darkest Dungeon's mechanics rely too heavily on luck and RNG.  I like a difficult game as much as the next gamer, but when hours of progress are reset because of unfortunate map structure or heavy fear build up (to name just a couple of many mechanics largely based on luck), you are delving into the dangerous waters of bad game design. I want so badly to like this game, as there are many redeeming qualities, but the cons outweigh the pros.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Disclaimer: I'm a relatively casual gamer. I don't like to invest loads of time into a game if I can help it, so bear that in mind with my review, which I'll keep pretty short.There's a lot about this game, visually and conceptually, that is amazing. The art is fantastic, the voice acting and music and overall sound design are loveable, character designs are nice, etc. There's a lot that, on the surface, makes this game seem like it's cream of the crop material. The turn based ascept is nice, and the concept of sanity and stress are good elements in this game. The story isn't all that bad either, and I like the idea of having adventurers going out to collect resources in order to improve a town over time.That said, it's unforgiving. A lot of suffering in this game isn't a result of player mishaps like in other brutal games like Dark Souls or Bloodborne. Rather, combat is mostly RNG in terms of who is and isn't being beaten up on, and the sanity mechanics are demanding in management. It's frustrating for someone who doesn't want to invest a lot of time into a game, because getting a feeling of accomplishment in this game is difficult. More often that not, you'll be losing heroes left and right due to circumstances out of your control, which left me feeling like this game's an exercise in futility.For anyone who's looking for a game to casually enjoy or feel a sense of accomplishment, I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 5
												The overall package of Darkest Dungeon is very polished. Great visual design, audio, the whole thing.But in attempts to promote their game as 'hardest of the hardcore', the devs basically skew the stats against the player in calculations.When at 60+ Dodge I dodge nothing, there is something clearly ♥♥♥♥ed up with the RNG numbers. I have seen mobs with far lower Dodge dance around my guys' blows. This includes an undead bloated corpse.I'm sorry, but no. If you want your stat-based super-tough hardcore game, you bloody well make those numbers on my statscreen mean something.Give me percentages, PROPER percentages, don't hide it behind arbitrary numbers. SHOW me the chance to hit instead of seperating Dodge and Miss chance. How exactly am I to know you are fair if you deliberately obscure numbers?Heck if enemies do have an Attack rating that fights against Dodge, then SHOW it along with their Dodge and Speed ratings that the game currently DOES show! Let it be consistent! Let it be truly fair!Maybe that new update with the new mode would help.But they should come out and say it, that 'mode' is an actual proper balance patch.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Challenging, atmospheric and generally well made. Or it used to be. But at some point during Early Access "difficult" got replaced with "RNG punishment" and "grind". So after a while it just becomes tedious. Which is unfortunate.  If they toned down the grind I would recommend this game fully. But as it stands I would say: this game is best enjoyed playing for a bit and then ignoring for a long time and then jumping back in. That should make the repetitive nature easier to handle. But that really is working around a flaw in the game by not playing the game. Which is inherently wrong. Don't get me wrong, the game is fun to play for shrot periods of time, and like the I said the atmosphere, sound and art syle are brilliant. The mechanics are even neat in concept. So basically is a game that's more tedious than hard worth the current price for you?

Posted: February 17, 2016
												Graphics, sound effects and settings are great.Unfortunately, it's just very very very very grindy. You have to run the same 4 dungeons over and over and over. Going into a dungeon has a large cash cost, both for supplies and for curing whatever ailments and stress you leave with, and often the reward is simply just marginally smaller. Moreover, when your heroes level up, they can no longer go in the early level dungeons. But they are still too weak for the high level dungeons - you need to spend a huge amount of gold to simply make them read. So your starting heroes become useless after gaining a few levels, until you have grinded enough gold with a new party to equip them. And there's a LOT of grinding to do that, trust me. If this game had microtransactions it would have been called ridiculous and described as something you had to spend money on because the grind was insufferable otherwise. As it is, there's just a lot of grind.I really looked forward to this game, but having to run low level parties over and over to sequeeze out a tiny bit of gold in order to get my higher level guys ready has just killed my enjoyment of it. I really want to like it, but after playing an hour at a time I just can't stomach it any more, because of all the tedious micromanagement just to squeeze out a tiny bit more gold.

number of helpful: 32 of 62 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Darkest Dungeon is a glorified slot machine disguised with a bloody, wild, dark-fantasy theme. Everything is RNG dependant, as well as being designed to work against you. Your healers barely heal even with trinkets and buffs, your sluggers often miss regardless of traits and buffs, and taking on the actual, literal 'Darkest Dungeon' portion of the game is simply an exercise in sadomasochism. Many are quick to defend the 'difficulty' of this game because of the current trend in video games (difficult games, ala Dark Souls, Binding of Isaac, etc.), however, the simple fact is that Darkest Dungeon isn't as tough as it is dependant on sheer luck. Crits, dodges, empty rooms and hallways, the discovery of treasure and trinkets that aren't totally useless and the like. Player skill is much less important than simply scoring a critical hit on a cultist with your Crusader or Leper.Until you struggle through the game and become rich, many of the upgrades to both buildings and equipment are simply too expensive to afford. The hero roster is pitifully small despite how easy it is for them to die, training heroes to their max level takes too long given how tiny said roster is and how quickly they can be killed, trinkets are often as needlessly debilitating as they are helpful, heroes become too stressed too easily (especially in the final dungeon).The game simply isn't fun to play...but at the same time, the gambling nature of DD makes it addicting. After 100+ hours I've come to realize that I've only been playing this game for those sporadic moments of utter joy that follow criting a tough enemy party three to four times in a row. Those times are wonderful, but they're also far and few between. More often than not, the enemy will be punishing YOU relentlessly, not the other way around.In summation: buy this game if you like to gamble. It's good for that. The art is fun to look at for a while as well and the narrator is a nice touch...at first. After completing your 20th quest, though, his repeated quips become reminiscent of nails on a chalkboard. The mechanics, however - the actual meat of the game, are rather unenjoyable.

number of helpful: 42 of 82 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Let's start with the good. The authors absolutely nailed the Lovecraftian theme as far as the art, music, writing and voice acting goes. Which makes it doubly painful to realize Darkest Dungeon just doesn't work as a game, and furthermore, the gameplay mechanics clash with the theme.There are many problems with Darkest Dungeon, but the fundamental issue, the deal breaker, is that there are no adverse consequences for playing it super, ultra, 100% tediously safe (other than the mounting boredom and sense of lacking purpose, that is). Roguelikes in general always have one (or preferably several) mechanic to exert mounting pressure on the player. It could be the rebel fleet pursuing you. It could be your diminishing food stocks and the approaching winter. It could be an invincible ghost that spawns if you take too long to reach the exit. There is no such mechanic in Darkest Dungeon. You are perfectly comfortable where you are at all times; no schedule, no encroaching darkness, no enemies at the gates... no loss condition. You can abandon a mission not going your way at any time, with no consequences.And this absolutely murders any drama or excitement the game could have otherwise provided. Gone is the incentive to improvise and try all sorts of mad gambles to try and cheat death. Gone are all the memorable tales and memories. What's left is a tedious grind towards an inevitable conclusion.Now that the main issue is out of the way, let's explore a few of the game's peripheral failings:* The battle engine is prone to abuse. Healing moves are infinite and free to use, meaning if you're really bored and morally bankrupt, you could keep one last enemy perma-locked with stuns while you fully heal your entire party (both HP and stress) every battle. It comes to a point where just using healing techniques feels like cheating, because the game offers no hard rules on what "legitimate" use of them would be.* The game is chock full of tiny, inconsequential, boring bonuses/penalties. +5% chance to crit. -1 speed. +15% damage if Saturn is in conjunction with Venus. +5% evasion against your mom. You're expected to care and optimize this stuff that hardly makes a difference.* It's a bit ironic that a Lovecraftian game that sells itself - with very compelling imagery, might I add - on the psychological ravages of combat, is in fact so lenient and restrained. If you are expecting characters to slowly and permanently unravel, to become damaged basketcases progressively incapable of functioning, you're going to be disappointed. The penalties accrued by psychological damage are tiny and inconsequential, and furthermore, characters can accumulate a maximum of 5 of them. You can safely ignore this aspect of the game entirely, if you so wish.* It's remarkably hard for a (player) character to die in this game. As long as they have at least 1 HP left, they can take a nuke to the head and survive. At 0 hp, each hit has a 1 in 3 chance of killing them (for good, which means you have to grind for hours to replace them). Heal 1 hp, and they can take another nuke. This is bad on multiple levels. On one hand it makes the majority of the game an absolute (and pointless) breeze and encourages complacency. On the other hand, when death does occur, instead of doing something of consequence, something that could affect whether you win or lose, the game merely wastes your time.TL;DR: The game looks and sounds terrific, but the gameplay loop is a pointless, repetitive and extremely long grind with no loss condition, no drama, no excitement, and with an exploitable battle engine full of questionable design choices.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I haven't touched this "abandon all hope" game in a while, but I was excited to see some new characters added to the roster and some interesting changes when I came back to the nightmare. But then I noticed something huge that couldn't be ignored: The enemy got some new debuff attacks. Not one or two. ALL of them. The stress damage and the crit rate was also alarming. The first five dungeons I tried angered me so much because I always lost at least one party member (the thrid one was a TPK). It was the sixth that I got a lucky break and convinced me to stick it out. So, out of six dungeon crawls, only one went the way I wanted it to? I don't like those odds.After seeing that I'm not the only one griping about the ramped up difficulty, I'm starting to lose hope. Rogue-Lite games are a growing favourite of mine, such as The Darkest Dungeon, FTL: Faster Than Light, and other Indie Rogue-Lites, but there's a delicate line between challenging and punishing. I don't know if the next patch will fix anything, but I don't want to lose hope in this game.For now, I can't recommend getting this game, as much as that saddens me to say so.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Roguelikes or Rogues or whatever the term is have a certain appeal.  That "I like to be punished and die a lot."But I personally also like to progress.  And this game is too unforgiving too often.  I spent hours training groups to take on the "Darkest Dungeon" the difficult ones, and in seconds they were obliterated.  That isn't fun to me, that's just telling me my time spent was time wasted.I set the game down for a long time, came back, played through a dungeon...  I watched the stress of my party climb, I watched them one by one freak out, not one of them becoming valorous.  Then they started dying.  Then I remembered why I stopped playing it.I got 40 hours out of it, but after a few other experiences similar to this (FTL comes to mind), I think I'm done with the "punishing" / "rogue like" genre.  My recommendation is to avoid the frustration.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												The game is interesting enough, atmosphere and art are well done, the stress mechanism is very immersive.On the other hand, the permanent death mechanism attracted me, but eventually I found it anti-fun. When you lose four guys at level 3 (max level is 6), you are kind of screwed, but well you just hire four other guys and you keep the game rolling.However, when your four-man party gets wiped in the final dungeon, after a dozen or so of hours just to level and equip these guys, all that's left for you is to grind more hours. And then get wiped again, and... You get the idea.I play hardcore Diablo 3 (and played hardcore Diablo 2 before that), so grinding and restarting is not something I am opposed to. But Darkest Dungeon is not a grinding game, what is fun in this game is making progress towards an end goal (while in the Diablo series, trashing monsters and finding loot is what's fun). When your entire game is reset, it just feels like you've lost your time.For the record, this is one of the very few Steam games I own that I quit without finishing (too lazy to check, but in fact it may be the only one). Some would say I am just not good enough, I would say that it is not rewarding enough.

								I've been craving a good RPG for quite some time now and after finally playing Darkest Dungeon I can say I found that game. What makes this game fun is its unquie stress system that can affect your heroes for better or worse. Finding out how to micromange their stress, treat their conditions, and manage provisions is all part of this games test. Finding good loot and landing those ever lucky crits brings thrill and excitiment, making you want to go back once again into the dungeons for more punishment. The game oozes with atmosphere with its unquie artwork and character design, narratoring voice, and dark atmosphere set in a lovecraftain era. Darkest Dungeon is one of the most polished early access games I've had the pleasure of playing. If you really like rpgs with a rogue like element in it; I highly recommend this game. Darkest Dungeon can only hope to improve from now on.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Darkest Dungeon blew all my expectations away. Here is a quick summary to why I love playing it:+ This game oozes theme and style. The aesthetic look and music really matches the gothic dungeon crawler nature.+ Gameplay mechanics that fit with the game's theme. Relating to the point above, but this game has great smaller mechanics that fit very well together like the stress system of seeing the horrors of the night. The torch mechanic, allowing you to burn up your torches to make things easier or let them burn down for a tougher challenge but greater rewards is great. But what if you run out of torches? Well then you are definitely in for a tough time.+ Varied characters and classes. Loads of variety here in both combat and camping skills that create charaters with purpose.+ Loads of content for an early access release. This is what early access should be: I've played 4 hours and I've only defeated the first boss out of nine. There is three areas to explore with two more on the way (I presume for the full release). I've only seen one bug, which was incorrect text and it wasn't gamebreaking at all, and has already been patched.+ Lots of player choice. This game is tough, everything goes wrong, but is still a lot of choice available to the player as they explore.This game is exactly my type of game: A game where there is tough choices (like XCOM), short rougelike missions (like Rouge Legacy/Binding of Issac), but have lasting effects and purpose over a longer campaign (like XCOM and Rouge Legacy again).One point to note:- This is not a negative, but there is a lot of random generation involved for if you hit or miss, if you do 4 or 7 damage, etc. Some players may not enjoy that aspect, I love it as it creates unique experience and amusing moments when my occultist healer does more bleeding damage than he healed.From the start you can see that this game has a lot of love and polish put into it. Every day over the past week, I have always been excited to return to Darkest Dungeon. Highly recommended by me, I'll keep updating the review if something comes up, and when it is fully released.If you wish to see dungeon gameplay, here is an episode part way through my Darkest Dungeon series that starts with dungeon crawling:

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
THIS REVIEW IS OUTDATED BY SEVERAL MONTHS, TAKE ALL THAT IS SAID HERE WITH A GRAIN OF SALTDarkest Dungeon is an unforgiving dungeon dive into Hell that taunts you as you lose control of the very minds of your troops.The incessant hatred this game spews my way has caused me to reset my save three times already, where now I've finally hit a luck streak. However, that's just it:  Lady Luck must smile upon you for success. Skill carries great weight, but this game is a dice game with invisible dice; nothing is guaranteed, all is up to chance.However, this does not stop the fun from being apparent. The sense of accomplishment from completeing a dungeon, from slaying a foe, from defeating a boss... it adds up. Slowly, your forces become stronger, your choices become more wisely made, and you begin to master that which once ailed you.PROS:Tactical, rewarding RPG combatSupreme focus on gameplay over flashinessEasy to learn, difficult to masterA variety of class choicesPlenty of varied loot to findGrinding that doesn't feel like grindingRetreat is supported and holds little against the player...CONS:...except that your forces gain stress quickly while doing soDifficulty can be disuadingStress can seem unbalanced at timesReliance on chance hurts immersionGameplay8/10Story7/10Sound10/10Graphics10/10Overall9/10I would heavily recommend this game to any hardcore gamer, but I'd hesitate for someone new to the RPG genre. With punishing difficulty that rewards tactical thinking and good luck, this game branches out to be one of the most unique RPGs I've played in multiple areas.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I followed DD since early kickstarter reveals, and hoh boy. As a forward, I absolutely LOVE difficulty in gaming. I have way too many hours logged onto DotA 2, Dark Souls 1 & 2, XCOM, etc. because I look for that punishment in my gaming. That being said, Darkest Dungeon lived up EXACTLY to the absurdly high standard its hype set for me. I was glued to my computer for hours and hours, praying that the hag's cleave wouldn't snuff out my party at death's door, hoping to land that fateful crit or stun, and damn if I haven't lost a lot of dudes. But I knew exactly what I was getting in to (thanks to the folks at Red Hook being very open throughout development) and damn if I didn't get exactly what I wanted.Now, of course the game isn't perfect. There are a few typos, a couple issues, and ♥♥♥♥ Lockjaw. The divine wrath of RNGsus can, at times, be absolutely heartbreaking. But is that a bad thing? In this case, no. The game marketed itself on its punishing, brutal style. On its hopelessness, and on its faint glimmers of heroism. And they are all very, very real.And that's to say nothing of any of DD's qualities other than its fantastic gameplay; I'm not sure if anyone has had an issue with the art style, or the narration, but they're both spot on for the game's atmosphere. The chilling voice of the narrator can praise your heroes for crits and kills, or comdemn them for their failures and disappointments. One issue that was more annoying than invasive was that if a cleave attack (Breakthru, Grapeshot, etc) crits, especially if the crit kills, the narrator states his lines on cue, over and over per crit/kill long after the moment had passed, and sometimes after combat had ended. But more of that ghastly voice filling the halls? Not too bad an issue at all.All this said, and the game's just released on early access. JUST RELEASED. Early access has, as a concept, been plagued by the lack of developer care (abandoned titles, quick cash outs, AAA devs using it as an excuse, you name it) but this title is very clearly polished, and cherished by its creators. The folks at Red Hook took a lot of time, and a lot of effort, into making a product that would be adored by their followers, and by those just finding out about the title. And it really shows. I'm looking forward to everything they add, the heroic and the tragic, and I'd recommend this wonderful buy to anyone who loves difficulty, darkness, and tragedy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I havent played alot yet, but beleive me I INTEND to. I tend to ramble, an bounce around so ill leave the summary at the top.TL:DR: This game is fantastic in the most grim, DIRE way imaginable.Story: If your interested in Lovecraftian stories, tales of hopeless all-consuming darkness, then you've found the right game. The setup is pretty simple, and i havent really played far enough to see if it evolves any further in the grand canon. HOWEVER, there is undeniably a facinating story to be found in the moment to moment gameplay. Examples: (In maybe my 2nd or 3rd quest one party member developed the "masochistic" trait. Later on, she is mortally wounded in a fight, when this happens you have a chance to heal them, but the next time they take damage theyre done. Before my healer gets a turn to bring her back around she cries "I welcome the hangmans noose!" and killed herself. im not even exaggeratting.) (Then there was the timei had completed the quest, but could see on the map another section to explore, we werent to bad off, and it was just one section so what could go wrong? 1 teammate died, the rest went insane and had to spend the next week drinking, praying, and fornicating respectivley. I FELT like such a greedy fool, the game didnt have to tell me in a cutscene. Combat: Turn based RPGs arent my forte, so its hard for me to coment on this part. I tend to get frustrated when i miss, or sustain a critical hit as it feels like i couldnt have really dont anything about it. Ill give this game a pass on that solely because it fits really well with the aesthetic and tone. That being said, no huge insta-gib moves that ive seen so its not particularly offensive, but still the randomness is strong. Enemeis are distinct and varied, your character classes are fun and interesting. Game doesnt hide information from you, tells you your chance, how much dmg the hit might do, all the enemies resistances, its rlly nice. OH one key difference, POSITIONING! All moves have a required position in the party line up, and a required position for the enemy to be in (Denoted by a series of yellow and red dots respectivley). which makes assembling your party all the more interesting.Systems: The sanity meter doesnt really feel as impactfull as id hoped, but some people may prefer that. Improving your town requires special recources, which is nice. Most stuff however is bought with gold, character improvements, recouperation, and most importantly supplies. supplies that vary from essential food and torches, to cure type items, and multiple "key" type items. There is visible depth even from the begining, and alot of hard choices on what to level and how to spend your resources.Aesthetic: 11/10 the art is what initially grabbed me on the project, finally seeing more I must say it continues to impress. The systems also strengthen the tone of general madness, like with the second story example. Finally, and most importantly...THAT NARRATOR! Wayde June absolutley kills it with his performance, and all the lines are perfect. Every line had me smiling the widest cheshire cat grin, its just so satisfying.Seriously? still reading this miniature essay? what else do I need to say, games great. Just pick it up if anything i said sounded remotely interesting.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been craving a good RPG for quite some time now and after finally playing Darkest Dungeon I can say I found that game. What makes this game fun is its unquie stress system that can affect your heroes for better or worse. Finding out how to micromange their stress, treat their conditions, and manage provisions is all part of this games test. Finding good loot and landing those ever lucky crits brings thrill and excitiment, making you want to go back once again into the dungeons for more punishment. The game oozes with atmosphere with its unquie artwork and character design, narratoring voice, and dark atmosphere set in a lovecraftain era. Darkest Dungeon is one of the most polished early access games I've had the pleasure of playing. If you really like rpgs with a rogue like element in it; I highly recommend this game. Darkest Dungeon can only hope to improve from now on.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love this game. So far it's the best one I've played in 2015, and I can't wait to see what they add.Unlike many other early access games, this one feels complete at its foundation. Core gameplay is very much there, and more importantly it's fun. It seems like anything they add now will just be extra content and balance passes, the latter of which could admittedly throw things into disarray.This game is punishing, and sometimes it can seem unfairly so. But a bad roll of the dice usually serves to compound existing problems and flaws in strategy rather than turning an absolute win into an absolute failure. Bad luck can definitely ruin your day, but preparedness is key and the game's system for this feels innovative if a bit samey after a while.If you're on the fence about this one, just get it. You won't be disappointed, and even months out from final release you'll have a great game to play.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall a very good game, there are dozens of different classes, you can upgrade skills and make builds, the game has an ver important tactical aspect to it, if you rush in like a no-brainer, you won't get anywhere, all in all it's really good, the only downside I can think of, is that this game needs some tweaking on some aspects, especially when it touches the enemies, while your characters rarely ever dodges or crits, your enemies seem to dodge/crit dozen of times per battle, I've had a streak of 3 turns of nothing but dodges, another streak of 2 turns of crits, the healing is somewhat weak right now, at least in lower ranks, you cross your fingers to heal 4, only to have your enemy swing for 5 and get you bleeding.The difficult is high, people who quit easy should avoid this game, it reminds me a lot of This War Of Mine, as to how it takes in account an interesting factor: the psychological aspect of your heroes, I've had a compulsive crusader, who opened everything, not even caring if it was rigged or not.The game is a 10/10 for gameplay and story, right now the only downside I can think of is the overpoweredness of dodge and crit in your enemies' hands :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far, I am extremely impressed by this game. The artstyle and atmosphere is grittty yet gorgeous. The combat system is standard for most turn-based strategy RPGs, but it's visceral enough to make every turn tense. Upgrading your town and adventurers is done smooth with enough depth to give you plenty of choices for your party structure. Overall, the game has just about everything a good rogue-like RPG would need.But it doesn't stop there. The sanity and stress mechanics are what make the game different from anything else. Not only does it make the game more difficult, but it will completely change how you play the game from any other. There is a lot more micro-management along with trial-and-error when your adventurers start taking turns for the worst.I can only imagine just how much more they could add to this game considering it's still in Early Access. At it's current state, it's definitely a must-buy for anyone who likes dark fantasy RPGs.

Early Access Review
								Well on it's way to being one of the rare Early Access success stories in my estimation. Fairly well polished already and the content that is in the game is steadily engaging despite being limited. There are a few minor annoyances in the game that can grate the nerves in a mild sense and a few possible class balance issues, but those seem to be the only downsides to the game thus far.I get the impression that most folks who seem put off by this game were not ready for the Roguelike elements of the game and seemed to be expecting a cake walk in a tea park, despite the warning the developers have put in before the title screen and the Lovecraftian setting. Just keep in mind that you will not succeed with every mission, regardless of how well you may think you have prepared, and that you will get ♥♥♥♥ed in the♥♥♥♥♥(hard) now and again. Once you learn to just roll with the punches you should find a lot here to love.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								This 2d side scrolling roguelike with a dark souls vibe is the first game this year to really excite me. Take a party of 4 adventurers from a pool of randomized characters, each with randomized traits and quirks, to clear out an ancient estate for its former family. Be prepared to have your characters die left and right due to your mistakes but the ones that survive will have earned their veterancy by surviving a trial by fire. After each dungeon, you'll return to a town that you can improve the way you like to give your adventurers the best edge possible. Plus you can send your party to gamble or pray so they don't lose their marbles. Essentially, if you like aesthetic of dark souls and the gameplay of roguelikes then buy this game. Right now. Also, even though this is early access, it in no way feels like early access. (i.e. no jenky combat or unavailable buildings etc)

content:

Early Access Review
THIS REVIEW IS OUTDATED BY SEVERAL MONTHS, TAKE ALL THAT IS SAID HERE WITH A GRAIN OF SALTDarkest Dungeon is an unforgiving dungeon dive into Hell that taunts you as you lose control of the very minds of your troops.The incessant hatred this game spews my way has caused me to reset my save three times already, where now I've finally hit a luck streak. However, that's just it:  Lady Luck must smile upon you for success. Skill carries great weight, but this game is a dice game with invisible dice; nothing is guaranteed, all is up to chance.However, this does not stop the fun from being apparent. The sense of accomplishment from completeing a dungeon, from slaying a foe, from defeating a boss... it adds up. Slowly, your forces become stronger, your choices become more wisely made, and you begin to master that which once ailed you.PROS:Tactical, rewarding RPG combatSupreme focus on gameplay over flashinessEasy to learn, difficult to masterA variety of class choicesPlenty of varied loot to findGrinding that doesn't feel like grindingRetreat is supported and holds little against the player...CONS:...except that your forces gain stress quickly while doing soDifficulty can be disuadingStress can seem unbalanced at timesReliance on chance hurts immersionGameplay8/10Story7/10Sound10/10Graphics10/10Overall9/10I would heavily recommend this game to any hardcore gamer, but I'd hesitate for someone new to the RPG genre. With punishing difficulty that rewards tactical thinking and good luck, this game branches out to be one of the most unique RPGs I've played in multiple areas.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Why the darkest dungeon is worth the early access.Normally I go against any early access game simply because they are never finished and lack content to begin with, I've only logged several hours into this game but I've already fallen in love with it. The game offers a grim and difficult setting as you take your party through these dark and dreadful dungeons that instill a lack of hope into you. The game is ungodly hard as you have to manage your characters and manage them well, bring the right party members that compliment your characters, the position of them matters, bringing the proper amount of food or torches with you and the small inventory makes you decide "is this item worth it?"The game briefly gets easier as you level your characters but only to get stomped by a harder enemy. You have to decide wether to go on or to abandon the dungeon and suffer the consequences of abandoning your quest. I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes turn based dungeon crawlers with a difficulty similar to games like dark souls. It provides a challenge and rewards you for sticking it out until the end, though its early access the amount of content is pretty good and I can't wait for more to come.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								A horrifying suffering simulator in which you send a team of heroes into a variety of terrible places in search of loot and the destruction of evil.  Your heroes will die.  If they are lucky.  If they are unlucky, they will go insane, and drag everyone else into insanity in a terrible death spiral that will ultimately kill your entire party.  The incredibly dark and oppressive atmosphere and wonderful art help turn what could be a mediore experience into an amazing one, despite the crushing loses you will take early on.On the other hand it's a lot of fun once you get the system down.  The initial difficulty curve is steep, and you are always at risk of losing people.  But there is a method to the madness, and with some time and upgrades, you recieve the satisfaction of having a team of incredibly flawed badasses storm into the dungeon and lay waste to evil, bringing out mountains of loot to shower upon your other characters to give them a fighting chance.Game is in early access at this point but feels very solid and well put together.  Well worth the buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Darkest Dungeon blew all my expectations away. Here is a quick summary to why I love playing it:+ This game oozes theme and style. The aesthetic look and music really matches the gothic dungeon crawler nature.+ Gameplay mechanics that fit with the game's theme. Relating to the point above, but this game has great smaller mechanics that fit very well together like the stress system of seeing the horrors of the night. The torch mechanic, allowing you to burn up your torches to make things easier or let them burn down for a tougher challenge but greater rewards is great. But what if you run out of torches? Well then you are definitely in for a tough time.+ Varied characters and classes. Loads of variety here in both combat and camping skills that create charaters with purpose.+ Loads of content for an early access release. This is what early access should be: I've played 4 hours and I've only defeated the first boss out of nine. There is three areas to explore with two more on the way (I presume for the full release). I've only seen one bug, which was incorrect text and it wasn't gamebreaking at all, and has already been patched.+ Lots of player choice. This game is tough, everything goes wrong, but is still a lot of choice available to the player as they explore.This game is exactly my type of game: A game where there is tough choices (like XCOM), short rougelike missions (like Rouge Legacy/Binding of Issac), but have lasting effects and purpose over a longer campaign (like XCOM and Rouge Legacy again).One point to note:- This is not a negative, but there is a lot of random generation involved for if you hit or miss, if you do 4 or 7 damage, etc. Some players may not enjoy that aspect, I love it as it creates unique experience and amusing moments when my occultist healer does more bleeding damage than he healed.From the start you can see that this game has a lot of love and polish put into it. Every day over the past week, I have always been excited to return to Darkest Dungeon. Highly recommended by me, I'll keep updating the review if something comes up, and when it is fully released.If you wish to see dungeon gameplay, here is an episode part way through my Darkest Dungeon series that starts with dungeon crawling:

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has all the best features of old turn-style RPG systems, as well as a couple new ones.  It's frustratingly enjoyable (odd combo) to deal with your character's stress levels to keep them from going insane.  The dark atmosphere is spectacular, and the animation, though simple, is amazing.At the very start of the game I nearly lost a Crusader to madness due to skeletons and cultists, only to have him die after de-stressing him a couple journies later.  I ended up having money problems as my people became permanently stressed.  I could do better, so I restart.After restarting the second time, I realize that not all adventurers are built for the dark horrors of my family's manor, so as their stress level gets higher I excuse them from service.  With gold in their hand and jibbering on their tongue, they wander from my hamlet speaking of beasts and demons, but I'm sure the rest of the world will sort them out.Now I have a problem, however.  My coffers are over-flowing with gold saved by not spending a cent on weak-minded adventurers, but now I have inexperienced adventurers with no knowledge of what's to come.10/10, would pull my hair out again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												+: Darkest Dungeon is a roguelike funded by Kickstarter, based on the idea of a more gothic "emo" style roguelike RPG. The heroes are not your bright and super courageous characters off to save the day, these heroes suffer from many mental, emotional, and personality problems. Everything is bleak in Darkest Dungeon, and the heroes aren't very heroic. I love this.+: The narrator is AMAZING. Almost as good as the Bastion narrator.+: The art style is also amazing, and some of the best hand drawn art in a video game I have ever seen.+: The music is ALSO AMAZING, and one of my favorite soundtracks.+: There's a lot of cool mechanics to the game, like light/torch. Light/Dark affects the different character classes and items and skills differently, and some rooms/items are only earnable in one mode. As it gets darker both players and monsters are easier to surprise and have higher crit chances.+: The battle system is one of the most unique turn based battle systems I've seen. It's a very interesting take on it - positioning is very key and plays a huge role in what abilities you can use and on who. Of course, there is a ton of abilities that can change your or your enemies positioning, so a smart player can actually deny enemies from using their good abilities by moving them into a bad spot.+: One of my top games of 2015, go buy this game, seriously.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is a solid 8/10.Read on if you want more detail from a player that has cleared what is available!The only real problem with the game is that it is not finished - as expected with an early access title.Its turn base combat is addicting and much like a 'Final Fantasy' of old or the newer 'Bravely Default', 'Child of Light' etc.The magic however is in the music and narration. The stern and chilling narrator sets the atmosphere and bits of pieces of information of your settlement are revealed as you progress in difficulty and reinforce your camp. The delivery is much like a Dark Souls game in that it’s dank and gritty with plenty of atmosphere with a story present if you choose to read and listen. The art is fantastic and the animations are great, two minor gripes were being unable to auto arrange/organise my trinkets and some form of accomplishment screen for my hour sink/completion.It took me 4 save files to steady a team into the harder dungeons and I managed to keep that team alive until completion (lvl 6 heroes and all 3 bosses of each zone available defeated) in 58 weeks (In-game time system).I recommend you buy this game if you want a throwback to a turn based combat system that is both unique (stress mechanic) and pleasantly familiar.Eagerly awaiting the descent into the actual Darkest Dungeon!Vas

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Great fun, but a ton of options need to be added in order to make it playable. The granular nature of the character's traits is amazing - few games have such depth to the afflictions that your heroes can have. The combat is straightforward and tactically driven in a rewarding way.Having said that, the game is unplayable unless you've got it running on mute in a window while you read online or otherwise occupy yourself while the characters bicker amongst themselves with their meaningless random flavor text. If your characters become stressed (and they will), you'll go from a dungeon crawl to a dungeon full-stop while the game sorts out all the various interactions between them.I certainly don't mind the game's difficulty (you will fail and that's part of it) but the gameplay needs to sped up by an order of magnitude. I can't imagine playing to Week 20 at this pace.Edit: I came back after updates and it's even less balanced and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG death will punish you for no reason. It's not hard so much as it's insultingly random and doesn't care that you're grinding again because RNGesus hates you. Can't recommend this turd anymore.
